Including on some Rete extensions like accumulators.#2016-06-1303:02mikerodI've read most, if not all, of the Jess wiki docs accessible via this link.#2016-06-1303:02devni keep tinkering with the idea (yet another project that is on hold due to the amount of time i have) of a datomic-driven rules engine#2016-06-1303:03mikerodYeah, that has seemed like an interesting idea to me before as well#2016-06-1303:03devnreified transactions a la Tim Ewald (sagas) here: http://www.datomic.com/videos.html#2016-06-1303:03mikerodI haven't done much with Datomic other than listen to a bunch about it and read up on it. I've liked a lot of the ideas etc there and hope to work with it at some point#2016-06-1303:04mikerodI don't think I've watched these ones yet. I will. Looks like a good set of videos#2016-06-1303:04devni know that there have been at least two rules engines built on datomic which are not open source (sad face)#2016-06-1303:04devnone of them, as i understand it, had all the fixins (truth maintenance, etc.)#2016-06-1303:04mikerodOh, also on Rete. I follow Drools stuff a fair amount too. Drools has pushed the bar with optimizations and has a lot of good extensions and documentation as well.#2016-06-1303:05mikerodOh. Unfortunate neither is open source then#2016-06-1303:05devnyeah, though it just makes my curiosity a bit more intense#2016-06-1303:06devnquery in datomic is basically the LHS.#2016-06-1303:07devnthe datomic thing is most interesting to me i think because most rules engines (as far as i understand it) do not address temporal concerns#2016-06-1303:08devnthis is partly why durability is interesting to me: "show me what would have happened as of a point in time", or "show me what it would look like if the rule base contained this rule, without committing it"#2016-06-1303:08mikeroddevn: yeah, temporal concerns can be a wrench#2016-06-1303:08mikerodin things*#2016-06-1303:08mikerodI think Drools has tried to work with temporal concerns some#2016-06-1303:08mikerodI haven't read up on it much at this point#2016-06-1303:08mikerod"events" i think they ccall it#2016-06-1303:09devninteresting, googles#2016-06-1303:09devnso, i've only read a couple of sentences while skimming the docs, but very interesting#2016-06-1303:09mikerodhttp://docs.jboss.org/drools/release/6.4.0.Final/drools-docs/html_single/#DroolsComplexEventProcessingChapter#2016-06-1303:09devn
"Complex Event Processing, or CEP, is primarily an event processing concept that deals with the task of processing multiple events with the goal of identifying the meaningful events within the event cloud. CEP employs techniques such as detection of complex patterns of many events, event correlation and abstraction, event hierarchies, and relationships between events such as causality, membership, and timing, and event-driven processes."
#2016-06-1303:10mikerodyeah, that may be the sort of thought you're thinking about#2016-06-1303:10mikerodI know Ryan has said a little on the topic of dealing with temporal "events" as well, but I'm not sure how much its been thought out yet#2016-06-1303:11mikerodClara durability of session state (working memory) is going to be important to the work I'm doing right now, so that should keep progressing. We haven't needed anything more complex as of yet.#2016-06-1303:11mikerodTo us, we've just thought of retracted facts if things change in the future#2016-06-1303:11mikerodand inserted a new fact if there was a "change"#2016-06-1303:12mikerodI'm sure this can be limiting if you have more complex use-cases#2016-06-1303:12devnwe deal with a lot of sparse data, and so a fair amount of work is done to validate concepts, those concepts are then turned into facts. i'd sort of like to extend rules to the problem of validation and creation of concepts#2016-06-1303:13mikerodinteresting#2016-06-1303:13devnwe of course build up concepts inside the engine, too#2016-06-1303:14devnbut there's a sort of ETL-like process that varies a lot. i imagine a sort of rule-based ETL#2016-06-1303:14mikerodsounds doable#2016-06-1303:15devnyeah, certainly, just haven't had the stomach for it, because i think there's tooling i'd want to build to manage this process and have decent visibility into it#2016-06-1303:16mikerodwell if you come up with good tooling ideas that'd help on the Clara end, I'm sure we'd all be happy to hear about them#2016-06-1303:17devnI mean, I'm as much interested in providing ideas as I am hearing about them.#2016-06-1303:17mikerodhaha#2016-06-1303:17mikerodyeah, visibility is something we should strive for#2016-06-1303:18mikerodour current push this release round is probably going to center on performance and then this durability thing#2016-06-1303:18devnAs I said, I don't feel like I have a good enough handle on internals to say: "here's a great idea!" because I worry that the performance overhead will be insane, or that i'll be unable to capture some key piece of information necessary to the idea without reworking some significant piece of Clara#2016-06-1303:18mikerodbut thinking more on what can be done for visualization, "explainability", etc should stay imoprtant#2016-06-1303:19devnthe leverage#2016-06-1303:20devnit's extremely important for us to say: "We recommend these actions based on the following information related to the patient, provider, etc."#2016-06-1303:20mikerodmostly just keeping tracing sort of information in data structures that can be hooked on by whatever tooling#2016-06-1303:20devnwith a sort of decision tree that people with a clinical background can use to validate those recommendations#2016-06-1303:20mikeroddevn: yeah, we've had similar sort of use-cases with rules#2016-06-1303:20mikerodso far, what we've mostly done - which has been sufficient - was to just show the support "chain"#2016-06-1303:21mikerodwe either manually write rules to do so, or we built some automatic helpers around insert's#2016-06-1303:21mikerod(defrule my-rule [?s <- SomeFact] => (insert! (map->AnotherFact {:something blah :support [?s]})))#2016-06-1303:22devnI committed some code as part of an early spike on clara which added a :contributing-factors {} k/v in the RHS#2016-06-1303:22devnha! so i'm not crazy!#2016-06-1303:22mikerodyes, we have implemented some ideas around this. not in Clara directly, just in our own projects#2016-06-1303:22devni've been looking at that sideways and thinking: hmmm, this feels weird to me#2016-06-1303:22devnparticularly because over the course of the "chain", things can get a little sticky#2016-06-1303:22mikerodwe've defined protocols or something as well that can sort of walk the "contributing facts" chain#2016-06-1303:23devnyou might need to merge multiple :contributing-factors across the results of queries in order to get the real picture#2016-06-1303:23mikerodyeah#2016-06-1303:23devnand then you have to wrestle with order#2016-06-1303:23mikerodvisualizing it int he end can get interesting#2016-06-1303:23devnor overwhelming ðŸ˜„#2016-06-1303:23mikerodyeah#2016-06-1303:23mikerodwe've sort of just "flattened" the chain up to certain points where there is a meaningful user-defined name#2016-06-1303:23devnor at least, the visualizations ive come up with are like: oh god, no nurse is ever going to look at this#2016-06-1303:24mikerodso it's sort of hierarchical, but flattened out just to where we have some sort of meaningful name to show end-users#2016-06-1303:24devn@mikerod: yeah, i think i was close, but the user-defined name is important#2016-06-1303:24devnInternalRecordThatExposesImplementationDetails {?x 1, ...} => no bueno#2016-06-1303:25mikerodyeah, definitely don't want that#2016-06-1303:25devnthe bindings which wind up being worth a damn, again due to sparse data, can be troublesome also#2016-06-1303:25mikerodyep#2016-06-1303:25devnyou don't want to expose bindings which didn't matter at a particular conceptual level#2016-06-1303:25devnbut then, they turn out to be valuable in some future rule#2016-06-1303:25mikerodyeah, so it is hard to automate and just assume "all bindings"#2016-06-1303:26mikerodyou could mark fact types in some way or another htat are "internal details" vs meaningful though#2016-06-1303:27mikerod(defrule [?f <- ImplDetailThing] [?f2 <- Meaningful] => (insert! (map->Fact {:val something :support [?f ?f2]})))#2016-06-1303:27devnI'm now generating records (using eval, don't hate me) that pull from a big old map of domain concepts => data definitions#2016-06-1303:27mikerodso just like automate attaching all bindings as support#2016-06-1303:27mikerodbut then when walking the chain later, dropping out stuff in the chain/tree that isn't useful#2016-06-1303:27devn@mikerod: ah, that's a good idea.#2016-06-1303:27devnhaven't played with a specific fact type#2016-06-1303:27devn(for capturing the meaningful bits)#2016-06-1303:28mikerodyeah, could think of a protocol like ISupported (depending on how you like to name things)#2016-06-1303:28devni wonder: any ideas on a query that pulls "ordered" Meaningful facts?#2016-06-1303:28mikerodyeah, not sure on ordered, unless you had somehting to order by#2016-06-1303:28mikerodgenerating records with eval sounds fun ðŸ˜›#2016-06-1303:28devnright, but i mean, i am willing to throw some of my pride away#2016-06-1303:29mikerodit may make sense if you are syaing you are trying to make data types dynamically driven off of config#2016-06-1303:29devnso an atom per session that increments using the RHS of rules could work, maybe#2016-06-1303:29mikerodyeah, maybe something like a counter#2016-06-1303:29mikerodjust be aware the the rules engine has some liberties it can take as far as when it fires rules#2016-06-1303:30mikerodrules may fire in different orders due to non-determinism (we'd like to minimize), optimizations, etc#2016-06-1303:30devnyeah, i desperately avoid order where i can#2016-06-1303:30mikerodjust never get too reliant on rule order unless you have logical rule order that with eventually be consistent due to truth maintanence#2016-06-1303:31devni'd rather not ever pay the cost of needing to think about that#2016-06-1303:31mikerodand :salience when desperate#2016-06-1303:31mikerodyeah, it is complexity#2016-06-1303:31mikerodand ruins the declarative nature of the rules#2016-06-1303:31mikerodand eventually becomes brittle when you get many rules involved etc#2016-06-1303:31mikerodwe certainly often see rules with logical dependencies between each other though#2016-06-1303:32mikerod(defrule rule-1 [MyFact] => (insert! (->AnotherFact ))) (defrule rule-2 [:not [AnotherFact]] => (insert! (->AlternativeFact)))` etc#2016-06-1303:32mikerodbut I think that is obvous usages#2016-06-1303:32devnyes, that's really what we deal with, but i do worry a bit that if that's not the case in the future, we're going to be sad pandas#2016-06-1303:32devn99% of our stuff is a DAG#2016-06-1303:33mikerodyep#2016-06-1303:33devnerr let's go with 90%#2016-06-1303:33devnðŸ˜‰#2016-06-1303:33mikerodhah#2016-06-1303:33mikerodwell, I'm logging off for the night though.#2016-06-1303:33devnyeah, same here#2016-06-1303:33mikerodgood talking with you. When I was first getting familiar with the internals of Clara I found it useful, and still do if Iâ€™m unsure of what some rule will look like in the network, to just create a session from that rule and look at the rulebase generated. That is, something like (-> (mk-session [rule-in-question] :cache false) .rulebase :alpha-roots) and just poke around the rules network generated.#2016-06-1322:00wparkerIâ€™ve found that if Iâ€™m not dealing with the compiler, it is very possible to just deal with the rules network and forget where it came from. The memory is even more isolated in some ways in that it mostly is just a composite data structure, albeit one very much tailored to the needs of the engine.#2016-06-1322:02wparkerThe reason I put the :alpha-roots in the call above is that facts inserted start there and propagate downward to the children of those alpha-roots#2016-07-0707:57raymcdermottanyone using the durability feature? want to try it out on heroku with redis as a backend, wondering if there are any experience reports out there#2016-07-0707:58raymcdermottalso @ryanbrush I note that the durability feature is experimental#2016-07-0707:59raymcdermottwhat is your thinking about what extra work needs doing there to conclude the experiment?#2016-07-0717:08wparker@raymcdermott: The current durability implementation has some significant problems that are described at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/198 . Please feel free to ask questions here or there if anything is unclear. @mikerod is working on a more robust durability implementation that will be targeted at speed of rule execution after deserialization; Iâ€™ll let him speak to the current state of that. Do you mind elaborating a bit on your use-case for durability? For less taxing use cases performance-wise just re-executing the rules from your serialized facts might well be a good approach.#2016-07-0717:54mikerodraymcdermott: Iâ€™d definitely say to suspect the durability of Clara to get a full overhaul. What is there right now hasnâ€™t really been maintained and probably will fail or produce incorrect results for modern-day Clara sessions.#2016-07-0717:54mikerodIâ€™d definitely recommend reading through https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/198 and Iâ€™d really like to know if these goals align with what youâ€™d want out of it#2016-07-0717:54mikerod(ass Will said above)#2016-07-0717:54mikerodas* ðŸ˜›#2016-07-0719:55raymcdermottk thanks - will take a look and give some feedback#2016-07-0720:05raymcdermottSerialising facts using transit out to REDIS would be enough in my case. I can imagine that vast rulesets would benefits but its not the case for my first set of use cases.#2016-07-0720:07raymcdermottI want to make a simple way to check a web user's disposition based on a small number of rules#2016-07-0720:08raymcdermottwith Heroku any dyno should be able to answer any query and obtaining the facts from the back-end should be kept to a minimum, hence REDIS#2016-07-0720:12raymcdermottwas also thinking that I could keep the data in a memoized set since Iâ€™m not talking about a huge number of user sessions and I can limit the size of the set with the help of core.memoize#2016-07-0720:12raymcdermottso itâ€™s good to understand where the work is happening ðŸ™‚#2016-07-0722:31wparkerYeah, if youâ€™re OK with just running everything again to retrieve your state performance-wise that would probably be easiest. Youâ€™d want to just use your top-level input of course or account for the use of generated facts in your rules of course; inserting logically generated facts by Clara back into a session that then generates facts not in the original session is a problem with the current durability implementation as Mike mentions in that issue. Regarding the number of user sessions, just in case you donâ€™t know, Clara sessions are immutable so you can just have a single base session without user-session-specific facts that you then add things into.#2016-07-0806:49raymcdermottTo play that back my understanding is that I create an empty session (as in (def empty-session (mk-session))) and insert facts on a per customer basis and fire the rules per customer - I hope thatâ€™s what you mean. If not, I would like to understand more!#2016-07-0806:51raymcdermottthe issue seems to revolve around cases where side effects or where establishing truth is expensive in complex sessions but I donâ€™t have that issue - my case is very much operating like a pure function where Clara is simply used to improve expressivity#2016-07-0807:12raymcdermottdumb question - are the facts from previous sessions GCd? If not, must I retract them? It would be simpler to take the hit on running mksession every time and TBH I have not profiled that so maybe itâ€™s also not such a biggie!#2016-07-0814:18wparker@raymcdermott: Clara sessions are intended to be data structures that obey Clojure idioms, that is, they are value-based and immutable. When you insert a fact into a session, a new session is returned that is independent of the previous session. So, for example, if you create an empty session and insert a fact into it, the original empty session still exists and can be reused. I created a quick demo of this at https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/c6be14cb249d55b6d2e3ff42500a9334#2016-07-0814:20wparkerThe â€œcom/clear-session-cache!â€ clears a cache of created sessions that Clara automatically creates unless it is explicitly turned off. The sessions without facts are cached by Clara on the set of rules, queries, and session options to save compilation time. However, this cache should never contain sessions with facts. The relevant code for that cache is at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.11.1/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L1530#2016-07-0814:21wparkerClara should only maintain references to facts through sessions. Once all sessions containing a given fact are GCâ€™able then that fact itself should be GCâ€™able as far as Clara is concerned.#2016-07-0814:23wparkerTo clarify too, Clara doesnâ€™t copy the facts between sessions that contain them; if you have a session that contains FactA and then you insert FactB in it youâ€™ll have two sessions that both contain a reference to the same FactA object. Clara expects that facts wonâ€™t be mutated after insertion.#2016-07-0818:05raymcdermottthanks - I appreciate the effort put into your answer#2016-07-0818:05raymcdermottitâ€™s also nice to see answers from two people that are not @ryanbrush ðŸ˜‰#2016-07-0818:06raymcdermottseriously, I'm a fan and itâ€™s good to see the community growing#2016-07-0917:19devnAnyone going to strangeloop this year?#2016-07-1423:20devnAnyone have thoughts on clojure.spec and clara? Also, I was wondering: If I I decided to move to using :fact-type-fn on plain old maps to determine type, would it be possible to automatically bind the syms the same way they're bound for Java beans and Clojure Records?#2016-07-1423:24devnMainly, I'm interested in preserving provenance of the data that is being used to create the records. Given what's showing up in alpha10: user> #:person{:age 42, :name "Fred"} => {:person/age 42 :person/age "Fred"}, and the fact that destructuring is going to work with namespaced keys, I wondered what y'all would think about automatically binding from namespaced keys in maps.#2016-07-1814:06wparkerRegarding using the fact-type-fn, the automatic field lookup is determined by the type; see https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.11.1/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L152 So right now the auto field access will just be by the record or bean properties. I could conceivably see this is an extension point if there were use-cases for it. However, I donâ€™t see any reason why you canâ€™t use hash bindings for other types. So, for example, something like#2016-07-1814:06wparker[FactClass (= ?fieldA (.someNonBeanAccessorMethod this))]#2016-07-1814:06wparker@devn:#2016-07-1815:10mattdarlingI'm actually interested in achieving something similar, is there any kind of field access aside from "auto field access"?#2016-07-1817:35wparker@mattdarling: The fact itself is bound to â€œthisâ€ in the constraints on the RHS (right-hand side) so you can do arbitrary things with it there. So#2016-07-1817:35wparker(defrule some-rule#2016-07-1817:35wparker[FactClass (= ?fieldA (some-arbitrary-operation this))]#2016-07-1817:36wparker=> ;; whatever RHS#2016-07-1817:36wparkerNote: I meant constraints on the LHS above, not RHS ðŸ˜›#2016-07-1817:36wparkerso left-hand-side#2016-07-1817:36wparkerSo the lack of automatic field access shouldnâ€™t prevent you from doing anything functionality, it is purely a bit of syntax sugar#2016-07-1817:36wparker*functionally#2016-07-1817:42wparkerThat said, no, I donâ€™t believe anything other than records or beans is supported for that syntax sugar now. I donâ€™t think it would be terribly difficult to change the compiler to make that an extension point, perhaps making clara.rules.compiler/get-fields a multifunction (http://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/defmulti) if someone was interested in doing so and Ryan agreed (I havenâ€™t thought deeply on the issue though, it is possible there would be a complication Iâ€™m not seeing immediately).#2016-07-1818:17mattdarlingGot it working as I wanted with "this", thank you! I thought that was just example syntax, not an existing feature#2016-07-1818:47wparkerAh no, the â€œthisâ€ binding and field bindings for Clojure records and JavaBeans exist already and have for some time; they arenâ€™t an experimental feature or anything like that#2016-07-1818:55mattdarlingI had used the bindings for Clojure records initially, but wanted to introduce a bit of polymorphism, so I switched to maps with a key to indicate their type + made that the fact-type-fn#2016-07-2211:17mikerodmattdarling in case you like the â€œsyntax sugarâ€ of it you can also use destructuring in rule conditions the same way youâ€™d use it in the arglist of a fn#2016-07-2211:18mikerod[:my-type-thing [{:keys [x y z]}] (< x 10) (= ?y y)]#2016-07-2211:18mikerodso that just destructures the map as normal in clj and then you have â€œdirect accessâ€ to â€œfieldsâ€ x y z#2016-07-2211:18mikeroditâ€™s just syntax sugar though really. performs the same as destructuring#2016-08-0906:07ramkumarkbHi, I am new to Clara and trying it in one the projects. Has anyone tried to use Clara with Hazelcast as its working memory? In general, any tips on the WorkingMemory management for an enterprise app with many domain objects (50 types, each about 100k objects) would be really helpful.#2016-08-0906:08ramkumarkbBtw, I hope this is the right forum to ask Clara related questions.#2016-08-0908:09wparker@ramkumarkb: This is indeed the correct place to ask questions about Clara. ðŸ™‚ Weâ€™ve used Clara in some heavy-hitting scenarios, although perhaps not quite as many as 5 million total objects, at least intentionally. In general, my instinct is that bad scenarios would probably be a combination of both the number of facts, the rules, and the data scenarios, rather than just the number of facts though. Thatâ€™s generally what weâ€™ve seen, except in some cases where weâ€™ve had bad rules create a number of facts that was a problem for the heap. Iâ€™m not sure what you mean by using Hazelcast as the memory - are you implementing your own memory as a replacement for the Clara defaults, considering using it in combination with the persistence stuff @mikerod is working on with https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/198, or something else? Iâ€™m not an expert on Hazelcast, this is the first time Iâ€™ve heard of it. It would certainly be interesting to me to hear about other perf-intensive use-cases.#2016-08-1802:01flavioHello, I'm new to Clara and Clojure and stumbled upon a case, which is expected behaviour but I am not sure what to do with it, so maybe you can enlighten me: I have a rule with an or condition on two boolean member variables of a Java object passed into the Clojure namespace. The rule is if either of the booleans is true, then fire. Now I have a case where both variables are true and it seems that the same rule fires twice, which seems expected behaviour. I do not understand how to proceed as I do not need it to fire twice... Thanks for any input.#2016-08-1803:34ramkumarkb@wparker: Thank you for the reply and suggestions. Will get back after we run some tests and see if we indeed have trouble fitting into a single JVM. #2016-08-1908:12wparker@flavio : So the or is on two different conditions on the same fact? It sounds like this need not fire twice. Or conditions in the constraints on a single fact condition donâ€™t produce multiple firings, that is only for :or conditions that are actually part of the Rete network. I think of something like [:or B C] as firing for all elements of the union of B and C, to put it differently, whereas conditions like [B (or pred1 pred2)] are still one set that just calls clojure.core/or to determine what facts of type B should be members of that set. A concrete example might help; https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/booleans.clj#L41 will fire once per matching Order, while https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/booleans.clj#L19 will fire once per matching NewCustomer or ValuedCustomer. If you have a single fact that youâ€™re trying to test it sounds like you want something more like new-or-valued-customer-basic-coupons in that examples page; the :or condition functionality is really just shorthand for writing multiple rules in a single defrule in the code. Does this help? It is a bit confusing because weâ€™re using the same word â€œorâ€ to mean fundamentally different things.#2016-08-1908:14wparkerAlso, you may have seen http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/booleans, but if you havenâ€™t that could be helpful. The key point though is that that only addresses booleans created like https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/booleans.clj#L19 ; the way to distinguish the cases visibly is what is a clojure keyword (:or :and) versus a normal Clojure function call like (orâ€¦ or (and...#2016-08-2112:40flavio@wparker: thanks for your explanation. It is as you say: [:or B C ] is firing as an union, whereas what I am looking for is [B (or pred1 pred2)]#2016-08-2213:26ramji013Hi All, I have posted my query in different group instead Clara. Anyone in the group please help to look into this. regarding 2nd question, we have found the answer. response type of queryString() from QueryResult is Object type, that can be typecasted to respective object. https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/clojurescript/p1471836222005217#2016-08-2215:20ryanbrushHi @ramji013, if you're having a specific issue the best way to troubleshoot is to post a minimal runnable example that shows the problem you're having, possibly as a gist or issue on github. def'd variables should be visible from within rules; we do it frequently. If you're doing something in ClojureScript I'm less sure, since I haven't used that in earnest.#2016-08-2215:21ryanbrushAs for getting to nested fields, you can use Clojure's destructuring to get to the top-level field (or fact itself), and then access nested fields just using Clojure expressions as part of the rule left-hand side. Some details on restructuring are here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/#2016-08-2215:27ryanbrushAn announcement: Clara 0.12.0 has been released! There have been a bunch of performance enhancements from @wparker and @mikerod, and a handful of bug fixes as well. Details are in the change log: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0120#2016-08-2915:38ramji013Hi All, I am new to Clara rules. One of my usecase I supposed to iterate list of object and perform validations in clojure. Anyone could you please suggest an approach, how it can be done? #2016-08-3008:49wparker@ramji013 : It seems like something like (filter valid-object? object) if you just want the collection of invalid objects or something like (when (some invalid-object? objects) (throw code-to-create-exception-here)) if you want to fail on an invalid object would work if you have a simple predicate. From your comment Iâ€™m not sure why Clara would be helpful. Perhaps there is some other complication to your use-case though.#2016-08-3113:17mikerodramji013 without a little more context, it is hard to assist much, as wparker pointed out. I will also add that if you have large collections of objects though, it is often better to insert them all into the Clara session separately or â€œextractâ€ them in a rule and perform the inserts in the RHS (right-hand side) of the rule. From there you can assert the validity of objects in a object-at-a-time sort of pattern matching. This can be helpful if you wish to then perform joins to/assertions with types of objects in the sessionâ€™s working memory with these objects that you have decided were â€œvalid".#2016-09-0307:59flaviohello all, I am experimenting with accumulators and face following problem where I would need your expertise. I have following rule: (def oldest-person (acc/max :age :returns-fact true)) (defrule get-oldest-person [?senile-person <- oldest-person :from [Person (= ?name name)]] => (println (str "The oldest person is aged " (.getAge ?senile-person) ". The person's name is " ?name)) ) The Person fact is a java bean. The accumulator doesn't seem to do anything with the :age variable, as the output is not accumulated: The oldest person is aged 50. The person's name is Person 3 The oldest person is aged 150. The person's name is Person 4 The oldest person is aged 200. The person's name is Person 1 The oldest person is aged 100. The person's name is Person 2 I suspect I am not passing the right variable binding to the accumulator, but I am not sure what to change. (.getAge) instead of :age throws an exception when compiling. Thanks for any pointers.#2016-09-0400:54wparker@flavio Do you mean that you were trying to do something like (def oldest-person (acc/max (.getAge) :returns-fact true)) ? (.getAge) isnâ€™t a valid Clojure expression; an interop form needs a target to invoke on. http://clojure.org/reference/java_interop might be helpful if youâ€™re unfamiliar. Introducing the ?name binding in the accumulator will cause you to accumulate once per name, which doesnâ€™t seem like what you would want in this example case. As chance would have it, I have a PR open to clara-site that discusses the subject. https://github.com/rbrush/clara-site/pull/8#2016-09-0400:57wparkerThat grouping behavior isnâ€™t new to 0.12, but there were some bugs around it before that were fixed in 0.12#2016-09-0415:30flavio@wparker , thanks for the updated documentation on the accumulators. This explains the constraint part of the accumulator. I have now successfully run following example: (defrule get-old-person-count [?old-person-count <- (acc/count) :from [Person]] => (println (str "The number of elderly persons is " ?old-person-count)) ) Which returns the number of Person facts as expected. However, I am still struggling with accumulators expecting a field to work with: (defrule get-old-person-max-age [?oldest-age <- (acc/max :age ) :from [Person]] => (println (str "The oldest person is aged: " ?oldest-age)) ) Above rule throws a null pointer exception as it doesn't know what :age is. My question is how can I pass a field name to an accumulator where the field name comes from a Java Bean. I went through the Interop documentation multiple times but I can't seem to get it right. Thanks#2016-09-0508:38wparkerIâ€™d surmise that youâ€™re doing numeric comparisons on nil, though I canâ€™t be sure without a stack trace. You probably need something like (def oldest-person (acc/max #(.getAge %) :returns-fact true)). In your original you use :age as a function, but when you look a keyword up on something that is not a Clojure map you just get nil. You can refer to fields by name in Clara rules and queries due to some special handling by Claraâ€™s compiler, but that isnâ€™t the case when you define accumulators, which are really just maps of keywords to Clojure functions if you take a look at what the value of oldest-person ends up being in a REPL.#2016-09-0508:38wparker@flavio#2016-09-0508:56flavio@wparker: thanks a lot for the response, this was the syntax I was looking for. I couldn't find it on the Java interop page. #2016-09-0714:12mikerodflavio is you want to avoid reflection, youâ€™ll have to type-hint the .getAge call too#2016-09-0714:13mikerodSame as any other Clojure expression and Java interop#2016-09-0812:31flavio@mikerod, is it generally good practise to type-hint for perfomance reasons? Are you guys recommending it? or, why should I not do it?#2016-09-0820:59wparkerI suggest reading https://kotka.de/blog/2012/06/Did_you_know_IX.html . A very short explanation is that the JVM can compile something like (.someMethod x) to run faster if the type of x is known at compile time. In absolute terms, though, even without type hints the calls are still fast. In our codebase we make a point of avoiding reflection since 1. We work at a very large scale that makes such bottlenecks matter. 2. It is easier to avoid reflection entirely than to have to release our code again when it turns out there is a major perf problem. What you should do depends on your use-case and the attendant tradeoffs; some people donâ€™t (and shouldnâ€™t for their use-cases) care about reflection#2016-09-1415:57mikerod@flavio yeah, I would say that reflection does have a significant performance penalty, but all of what Will had to say about it is probably the standard advice there.#2016-09-1415:58mikerodAlso, see the official Clojure stance http://clojure.org/reference/java_interop#typehints which I believe is written by Rich himself#2016-09-1415:59mikerodIn our applications, we donâ€™t want to risk/spend the performance penalty though, so we aggressively eliminate reflection warnings. The Clara compiler does give some effort in ensuring type hints are automatically added where the Clara compiler can effectively infer the types. However, that only goes so far.#2016-09-1706:36flavioThanks for the advice. Will definitely try to avoid reflection. #2016-09-1914:53ramkumarkbHello, I am trying to use Clara in a project and was wondering if there is any way to insert facts both from Java & Clojure, before firing the rules. The idea is that one could transition from Java for existing facts but use Clojure for inserting new facts, before firing all the rules (which is in Clara DSL). I was trying to read the docs here : http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/java/ But could not find any example where facts are inserted both from Java & Clojure. Any pointers would be immensely helpful. Thank you!#2016-09-1919:35devnThoughts on generating a graph based on rule firings?#2016-09-2009:03wparker@ramkumarkb : If you mean that the facts are Java objects, I donâ€™t see any barrier to that; JavaBeans are a very normal Clara fact. If you mean working in Clojure with a Java session of the sort in the docs you linked, you can interact with it via Clojureâ€™s Java interop; see https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_java.clj#L42 for an example#2016-09-2016:05wparker@devn I think https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/inspect.clj#L67 has the info youâ€™d need for truth maintenance governed facts anyway, clara-tools builds on this https://github.com/rbrush/clara-tools/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/impl/facts.clj#2016-09-2016:06wparkerMy understanding is that this ultimately works because Clara stores logical insertions in the activation-memory#2016-09-2016:07wparkerIâ€™m curious - do you have a particular sort of case in mind?#2016-09-2016:08wparkerThe graphs in clara-tools seem to work OK, though when I last poked around at them there seemed to be some oddities around accumulators, but I havenâ€™t looked at it much yet#2016-09-2016:08devn@wparker Our rules are pretty DAG-y, and continue to grow in number#2016-09-2016:09devnfor the sake of development, understanding the flow, it'd be nice to output the rules as a graph for a particular run#2016-09-2016:09wparkerAh, so more of a static thing than as a web app like clara-tools perhaps#2016-09-2016:09devnI want to show someone who works directly with a customer the decision tree#2016-09-2016:10devnthough, as time goes on, a more interactive tool could be nice, to simulate what might happen if a rule were added to do X#2016-09-2016:11wparkeryeah, something like a static doc visualization to hand someone could be useful#2016-09-2320:08devnI'm havin' a lot of thoughts...#2016-09-2320:08devn@wparker you specifically said in the above "the info you'd need for truth maintenance governed facts"#2016-09-2320:09devnit got me wondering about some of our logic. there are places in our rules where im thinking unconditional insertion would improve our ability to reason about the rules#2016-09-2320:09devnit's kind of a place to hang your hat: "You can always rely on me being there. Nothing can undo this."#2016-09-2320:10devnIt strikes me a bit like the convention of using do--- on functions which have side effects#2016-09-2320:11devnin the same way, im thinking about unconditional insertion to mark the territory of where branching will never happen, or ought to be expected not to happen#2016-09-2710:45wparker@devn the reason for truth maintenance governed facts to have more information available is that when facts are inserted using truth maintenance, the memory stores information to the effective of â€œthis fact was inserted from this rule based on X other factsâ€. The code in the memory is at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.12.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/memory.cljc#L685 This is only called if truth maintenance is used; if you use unconditional insertions it wonâ€™t be. You can see the conditional on that at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.12.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L228 It is a little confusing because the ProductionNode will add â€œactivationsâ€ in any case, but Clara batches insertions from them in the activation-memory as a sort of queue, then pops them off when you call fire-rules https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.12.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1483 As far as the reasoning behind this, truth maintenance does have some performance cost. If you do want to keep track of unconditional assertions, I suspect a way to do it with listeners could be found.#2016-09-2710:52wparkerAs far as simplicity, Iâ€™d suggest keeping in mind that rules can fire based on intermediate state in the rules engine that wonâ€™t be reflected in the final state after the fire-rules loop finishes, and unconditional insertions can thus reflect such intermediate state. In our case, we have a mostly stark dividing line between â€œtypes of facts that can be inserted from outside the sessionâ€ and â€œfacts that can be created by rulesâ€; our unconditional insertions tend to be from rules whose LHS looks for things of the former types. Thinking through how the intermediate state of the rules engine will play out can get pretty tricky and may be non-guaranteed behavior depending on the use case. There are certainly many legitimate use cases for unconditional insertions though.#2016-10-1813:00tbrookeI started playing with the protege IDE associated with Rete4frames https://github.com/rururu/rete4frames and wondered about using protege with Clara -I am not sure how it is integrated but it might be a nice way to build up an ontology for use in a Clara rules system#2016-10-1915:40ryanbrush@tbrooke I haven't used Protege, so it's not obvious to me how this would plug in. Clara's core Rete implementation could be invoked by external tools that generate rules. Most of our usage of Clara is based around rules working with arbitrary Clojure records rather than specialized templates or RDF-style tuples, so we typically use a more conventional development environment.#2016-10-1915:42ryanbrushThat said, a template-style approach could certainly use Clara's rete implementation. To illustrate this, rules could be generated from an external structure like how I describe here: http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/ So some front end tool could produce the rule structure that is then converted to Clara rules using a pattern similar to that post.#2016-10-2302:27alex-dixonAnyone made a clara app with reagent yet? ðŸ˜„#2016-10-2508:18wparkerThe (experimental) clara-tools project uses Reagent https://github.com/rbrush/clara-tools, but it is focused on displaying the logic from a JVM rules session, not using rules in cljs to drive an application. Iâ€™d be curious too if there is any such usage.#2016-10-2803:12ramkumarkb@wparker: Hi William, With reference to your discussion thread on conditional activation: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/clara-rules/conditional$20activation%7Csort:relevance/clara-rules/w_Iq7zom2bU/OFcbeFZlCwAJ We have a similar requirement when we want to fire rule-3, when either rule-1 or rule-2 does not fire for a fact of TypeA We find that the [:not [Logicamarker ]] approach is not working as it appears that RETE engine fires the rule bcos before the rule-1 or rule-2 creates the LogicalMarker, rule-3 LHS seems to be satisfied. Any tips would be really helpful. (defrecord LogicalMarker [marker prop1 prop2] (defrule rule-1 [?a <- TypeA (= ?prop1 prop1) (= ?prop2 prop2)] [?x <- TypeX] => (insert! (map->LogicalMarker {:marker "1" :prop1 ?prop1 :prop2 ?prop2})) (defrule rule-2 [?a <- TypeA (= ?prop1 prop1) (= ?prop2 prop2)] [?y <- TypeY] => (insert! (map->LogicalMarker {:marker "2" :prop1 ?prop1 :prop2 ?prop2})) (defrule rule-3 [?a <- TypeA (= ?prop1 prop1) (= ?prop2 prop2)] [:not [LogicalMarker (= ?prop1 :prop1) (= ?prop2 :prop2)]] => (println "Conditional Rule executed successfully!")#2016-10-2818:59ryanbrushHey @ramkumarkb, I posted a response on the Google Group thread. Hopefully that helps.#2016-11-1114:47ryanbrushHey everyone, a quick announcement regarding Clara: we've been using it heavily in production at Cerner for some time, so we're making it official an open source project sponsored by Cerner.#2016-11-1114:48ryanbrushYou can see the announcement here: http://engineering.cerner.com/blog/clara-rules-joins-cerner-open-source/#2016-11-1114:49ryanbrushThis is a good thing for Clara. It reflects its importance to our production systems, and shows this project will be maintained far into the future. Otherwise, not much else will change from the users' perspective; it's the same code in a new location, with all future releases in the com.cerner group on Clojars.#2016-11-1622:21surreal.analysisI think Iâ€™m missing something with accumulators - Iâ€™d like to have some sort of collection of reasons that something failed#2016-11-1622:21surreal.analysisOriginally I thought the best way to do that would be to have rules for each mode of failure#2016-11-1622:21surreal.analysisAnd those rules would add a fact with a reason#2016-11-1622:22surreal.analysisTest code here: 
(defrecord DomainObject [name1 name2])
(defrecord Invalid [reason])

(defrule name1-not-test
  [DomainObject (not= name1 "test")]
  =>
  (insert! (->Invalid "test")))

(defrule name2-is-test
  [DomainObject (= name2 "test")]
  =>
  (insert! (->Invalid "name2 test")))

(defrule collect-invalids
  [?reasons <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid]]
  =>
  (prn "Invalid for: " (map :reason ?reasons)))
#2016-11-1622:22surreal.analysisWhen run with: 
(-> (mk-session 'clara-playground.core)
                           (insert (->DomainObject "nottest" "test"))
                           (fire-rules))
#2016-11-1622:22surreal.analysisThe output is 
"Invalid for: " ()
"Invalid for: " ("test" "name2 test")
#2016-11-1622:22surreal.analysisAfter reading more on the accumulator side, I added a restriction#2016-11-1622:22surreal.analysisAnd rewrote collect-invalids as 
(defrule collect-invalids
  [?reasons <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid (= ?reason reason)]]
  =>
  (prn "Invalid for: " (map :reason ?reasons)))
#2016-11-1622:23surreal.analysisBut that output is 
"Invalid for: " ("test")
"Invalid for: " ("name2 test")
#2016-11-1622:23surreal.analysisAny suggestions on what Iâ€™m missing?#2016-11-1622:24surreal.analysisIf itâ€™s unclear, I want collect-invalids to fire a single time, with all the reasons#2016-11-1622:29surreal.analysisOr is this something thatâ€™s better left to queries?#2016-11-1709:31wparker@surreal.analysis I think this is expected behavior. The contract from Clara is that the state after all rules finish firing will be consistent with the rules, but the steps Clara takes to get there inside fire-rules are undefined except if you provide salience. Your print statements are reflecting intermediate state in the rules engine that is eliminated before fire-rules returns. So in your first example, collect-invalids fired with no Invalid facts because none had been created yet; once Invalid facts were created it fired with them. If collect-invalids had inserted other fact(s) the facts inserted by the firing with no Invalid facts yet would be removed before fire-rules returned to the caller. For something like this Iâ€™d suggest using queries or inserting another fact using insert! since these will be adjusted by the truth maintenance system when Invalid facts are added to the session.#2016-11-1709:32wparkerSo something like (defquery invalid-query â€œquery for Invalidâ€ [Invalid (= reason ?reason)])#2016-11-1709:32wparkerOr (defrecord CollectedInvalid [all-invalid-reasons])#2016-11-1709:33wparker(defrule get-all-invalid [?invalids <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid]] => ;; for exame#2016-11-1709:33wparker``#2016-11-1709:33wparker(defrule get-all-invalid [?invalids <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid]] =>#2016-11-1709:34wparker=> ;; do something here that doesnâ€™t depend on intermediate state#2016-11-1709:34wparkerIgnore "(defrule get-all-invalid [?invalids <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid]] => ;; for exame [9:33] ``â€ please, I was trying to set up a code block but apparently donâ€™t know how to do so in Slack ðŸ˜›#2016-11-1709:35wparkerWhen you did#2016-11-1709:35wparker(defrule collect-invalids [?reasons <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid (= ?reason reason)]] => (prn "Invalid for: " (map :reason ?reasons)))#2016-11-1709:37wparkerYou donâ€™t fire when there are no Invalid facts since ?reason is not bound elsewhere (this is the behavior as of 0.12.0 at least, we fixed some bugs around accumulators that release). However, the effect of adding the ?reason binding in the accumulator condition is that you collect all Invalid facts for each reason and fire once per distinct reason.#2016-11-1709:38wparkerSo something like (defrule get-windspeeds-at-location [?wind <- (acc/all) :from [WindSpeed (= ?location location)]] => ;; do something )#2016-11-1709:39wparkergiven four windspeeds, where two come from LocationA and two come from LocationB, would fire twice, once with ?wind bound to the WindSpeed from LocationA and once with ?wind bound to the WindSpeed facts from LocationB#2016-11-1709:41wparkerHopefully this clears things up, please ask if it doesnâ€™t and if anyone has thoughts on things at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/ that could be cleared up to reduce confusion Iâ€™d be interested#2016-11-2321:41devnQuery on queries: Iâ€™d like to find all the facts in the session of type MyFact, where myfact looks like this: #MyFact{:stuff #{{:a 1} {:b #AnotherFact{:c true}}}#2016-11-2321:42devnIâ€™d only like to find MyFact where #AnotherFact{:c true}#2016-11-2322:20devnItâ€™s unclear to me how parameterization of queries works. I have an arg :?foo to the query which is a keyword, but it does not correspond to a field on the fact.#2016-11-2322:30ryanbrushQuery parameters just check for equality on a bound variable. So to query on a value in a nested structure, you'll need to bind that value itself to a variable. You can do this by just having an expression on the left-hand side that gets the nested field, e.g. (= ?foo (some-expr-to-get-a-value this).#2016-11-2322:37devn@ryanbrush ok that makes sense, but what if I need the parameter as an argument to the expr that retrieves a value?#2016-11-2322:37devn(= ?foo (get-in [:a ?foo :b] some-declared-field-on-the-toplevel-record))#2016-11-2322:38devnwhere ?foo is the parameter (defquery myquery [:?foo] â€¦)#2016-11-2322:41ryanbrushYeah, queries only do equality checks on bound variables. You could either bind all combinations of the nested path if it's small enough, or have your query return more than you need and filter it out afterwards, or consider other ways to model the data. Not sure what would work best for your model.#2016-11-2322:43devn@ryanbrush ok, thatâ€™s kind of where i guessed we were heading. though i dont totally grok the binding of all combinations of the nested path.#2016-11-2322:46devnthe use case is that thereâ€™s a blob of :contributing-facts that gets populated by a big collection of prior rules firing, and i want to write a query that finds all of the facts where the thing that contributed is :x. short of writing a ton of queries, or generating them dynamically, iâ€™m not sure that changing the model will help much. this is the typical â€œletâ€™s have one place where we can dump a grab bag of metadataâ€#2016-11-2322:57ryanbrushYeah, I suspect having a function that scans query results, or finding another way to bind your additional criteria, would be your best bet.#2016-11-2322:58devn@ryanbrush thanks for the help#2016-11-2322:58ryanbrushSure thing!#2016-11-2500:39nlessaHi, is there any way to set an observable to a clara session to get any new insertion/rectraction fo facts? (I am wondering if it would be possible to use a clara session as a source of a stream of facts).#2016-11-2511:58wparker@nlessa Clara only returns new sessions in response to external calls to insert, retract, fire-rules etc. so if youâ€™re looking to listen for changes in response to those actions Iâ€™d suggest just querying the session after those calls. It is also possible to add arbitrary listeners to a session - you can see the protocol at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/listener.cljc and an example that simply records all operations listened upon at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.clj - but keep in mind that listeners often take you into internal implementation details that could change. Also Clara sessions are immutable, in keeping with typical Clojure data structure semantics. Inserting/retracting facts and firing rules returns a new session with the relevant operation applied but leaves the original unchanged. It might be possible to give a better answer if we had a better idea what youâ€™re trying to accomplish.#2016-11-2920:05nlessaHi @wparker, thanks for your explanation. What I had thought was to try to treat a session as a source of streaming data. As soon as a new fact is inserted/retracted another job would examine it and take another necessary actions. I see that I can easily obtain a similar effect composing the insert! with sending the fact to a Kafka cluster (for example) but not sure how to deal with the retracts that happens automatically in a clara session.#2016-11-3013:41wparkerI think comparing the result of queries, which will reflect the state of the session before and after you fire rules, is what youâ€™re looking for. So if you have something like#2016-11-3013:42wparker(defrule lousy-weather-rule [?c <- Cold] => (insert! (->LousyWeather)))#2016-11-3013:42wparker(defquery lousy-weather-query â€œâ€ [] [LousyWeather])#2016-11-3013:42wparkerThen (def empty-session (mk-session [lousy-weather-rule lousy-weather-query]))#2016-11-3013:43wparker(query empty-session lousy-weather-query) will return nothing#2016-11-3013:43wparkerHowever, (def not-empty-session (-> empty-session (insert (->Cold)) fire-rules))#2016-11-3013:43wparker(query not-empty-session lousy-weather-query) would find a LousyWeather fact#2016-11-3013:44wparkerYou could query both before and after inserting/retracting + firing rules afterward and see what changed, then dispatch on that#2016-11-3013:48wparkerOne perhaps non-obvious part of this is when you query the session, youâ€™re not actually performing much work since Clara basically computes the results for queries after fire-rules. When you run a query youâ€™re really basically retrieving the results already computed with a little data manipulation to get just the bindings you use in your query. You can see that implementation at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.13.0-RC4/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1605#2016-11-3013:50wparkerBasically a query and a rule look the same to the rules engine mostly when you look at determine what facts match, a rule just does more things (i.e. it is activated and can insert more facts) once you find matches#2016-11-3013:54wparkerYou can think of it as large trees of the different node types in engine.cljc where ProductionNode corresponds to rules, QueryNode corresponds to queries, facts are given to the root nodes of these trees and passed down to the leaf nodes, which are ProductionNodes and QueryNodes#2016-11-3013:57wparkerJust comparing the results before and after for the queries would work, albeit somewhat inefficiently since youâ€™d be performing work even when nothing at all changed. I think there are ways Clara could return changes in queries more efficiently than that if you were interested in contributing an enhancement like that though.#2016-11-3013:57wparker@nlessa#2016-11-3014:30nlessaThank you very much @wparker. Based in your answer I will try some approaches and let you know what I got.#2016-12-0312:18svenhusterI'm looking to build an appointment scheduling system and am contemplating if clara would be useful in this context. I've got multiple constraints around field engineer work schedules, travel time matrices for a currently small number of locations we have, expected duration etc. I need to gather a number of appointment options that fulfill the constraint to the select one through user input. Is this at a high-level a suitable problem to approach with clara?#2016-12-0521:51devn@svenhuster we do some scheduling logic, but not the actual creation of events. My advice would be to spike on it and see where you get. Pick a nontrivial subset of your logic, and see whether it gives you what youâ€™re looking for#2016-12-0521:51devn@mikerod Thanks again for the talk, and for the chat afterwards. It was awfully cathartic to talk to folks with similar problems in healthcare, and the rules engine space in particular.#2016-12-0522:06mikerodsvenhuster I agree with devn that one of the best things you can do is try to reason about your problem through some examples actually trying to use Clara rules and a rule-driven approach#2016-12-0522:06mikerodsee if it is naturally working or if you are hitting major barriers#2016-12-0522:07mikerodI often thing that http://www.jessrules.com/guidelines.shtml#2016-12-0522:08mikerodJess (an older rules engine written in Java, with a Lisp-like DSL) has some reasonable guidelines#2016-12-0522:08mikerodI think we could do better to get some guidelines on this up on Clara rules#2016-12-0522:08mikerodHowever, the most powerful Iâ€™d say is to try demoâ€™ing out solving one of your problems (even if simplified) by using rules and see if it can make any sense.#2016-12-0522:09mikeroddevn It was good to talk with you. It was nice to hear your perspective and things youâ€™ve been working through.#2016-12-0602:08devn@mikerod william byrd is a friend of mine#2016-12-0602:09devnwhat if Barliman (his code synthesis project) could synthesize rules#2016-12-0602:10devniâ€™ve found thereâ€™s a sort of typical â€œwell i know i need to join X and Y on field :q"#2016-12-0602:10devnâ€œand i expect a Z to be inserted"#2016-12-0602:12devnthis is a kind of partial description of both arity and return value#2016-12-0602:12devnyou may have a function cool? in the same namespace#2016-12-0602:15devnhe showed an example of: provided a definition of reduce-right, you can define concat#2016-12-0602:15devnimagine a smallish rulebase in a namespace under test#2016-12-0602:18devniâ€™m talking a bit of gibberish i suppose, but will was talking about synthesizing the â€œlast 10%â€ of your program#2016-12-0602:18devni wonder if generating the â€œlast ruleâ€ in a smallish rulebase would be an interesting place to try that out#2016-12-0602:28jonsmockFor me, the writing the rules is the "easy part" but knowing if my rules cover what I think they do is the hard part#2016-12-0602:29jonsmock(I'm saying this as someone who is completely entranced by Barliman. I love that stuff, and I cloned the repo for the flight home)#2016-12-0602:30jonsmockBut at least at work (we use clara-rules), I want tooling around the rules I have#2016-12-0602:30jonsmockCould just be me, not trying to dismiss what you're saying#2016-12-0602:31jonsmocki.e. here's a ns of rules, did I cover all cases#2016-12-0602:31jonsmockOr our actual situation: here's a ns of rules, is it possible more than one can fire?#2016-12-0602:32jonsmockAgain might be unique to the way I use clara-rules, but I have a hierarchy that looks like:#2016-12-0602:32jonsmockbasic fact rules -> intermediate level deduction rules -> final action rules#2016-12-0602:33jonsmockAnd I want just one final action rule to fire (this doesn't actually do a side effect. Something else uses the output of the rule engine to take an action)#2016-12-0602:34jonsmockBut yeah, Barliman looks sick. I seriously eat that stuff up#2016-12-0607:43svenhuster@devn @mikerod thanks a lot.
