We basically have 3 tiers ... oh I guess I said this above#2016-12-0615:47jonsmockbasic fact rules -> intermediate level deduction rules -> final action rules#2016-12-0615:47jonsmockthe basic fact rules are basically digging out important stuff from giant maps from other systems#2016-12-0615:47jonsmockSo I probably could write generators after that level#2016-12-0615:47jonsmockAnd property test the intermediate and action rules together#2016-12-0615:48devnwe built a library that builds facts, and their variants (intermediate facts) using a bit of macro sugar#2016-12-0615:48devnso thatâ€™s your step 1#2016-12-0615:49devn
(deffact FooFact
  â€œBlah blah"
  (alias foo-fact

  (field some_id :spec string? :doc â€œblah blahâ€)

  (variant InterestingFooFact
    (field additional_field :spec number? :doc â€œâ€¦â€)))
#2016-12-0615:50jonsmockOh neat#2016-12-0615:50devnerr sorry, i guess thatâ€™s not your step 1, but itâ€™s kind of interesting#2016-12-0615:50jonsmockYeah that's really neat#2016-12-0615:50jonsmockIt would be cool to put more relational info int hat#2016-12-0615:50devnthen we can use it to validate our facts conform#2016-12-0615:50devnyeah absolutely#2016-12-0615:51jonsmockFor us, it's all about what the insurance has paid, etc#2016-12-0615:51devnwe also introduced a trace_id on all fact types, which is carried around, so you can track the lineage of a fact a bit easier#2016-12-0615:51jonsmockSo I'm thinking like (deffact TotalCharges ...) and having other facts declaratively say that they are less than TotalCharges#2016-12-0615:52devnand, we have a :contributing_factors field on many (not all) facts, which captures interesting â€œwhyâ€ information#2016-12-0615:52jonsmockAh cool#2016-12-0615:52devnbut some assembly required#2016-12-0615:52devn@jonsmock yeah, this fact library was a first pass#2016-12-0615:52devnthereâ€™s more that could be done there for sure#2016-12-0615:54devn@jonsmock we also have (optional-field â€¦), and a way of specifying an explanation for each fact, so if you call (explain the-fact), itâ€™ll give you the view youâ€™re looking for#2016-12-0615:55devnto date we havenâ€™t actually used explain, which is just a function of the history of this project#2016-12-0615:55devnwe should have done it earlier, but there were bigger fish to fry#2016-12-0615:55devnnow weâ€™re overdue for adding better explanations#2016-12-0615:56devnâ€œwhy did we make an InterestingRecommendation?â€ => â€œPatient is over 50 and has a recent encounter (< 45 days) where X happenedâ€¦"#2016-12-0615:57devnSpeaking more on the topic of tooling#2016-12-0615:58devnWe built a graph you can traverse by clicking from nodes to rules and such, but textual explanation seems to be more fundamentally valuable#2016-12-0615:59devnRyanâ€™s clara.tools project is on the right-ish track, but the sheer volume of information for a graph of any decent size can quickly turn into wading in a swamp of facts which arenâ€™t all that interesting#2016-12-0616:00devnitâ€™s not an easy problem. views need to be tailored to your domain, and to your audience#2016-12-0616:00devnbut perhaps thereâ€™s some meta way of specifying views that could be shared#2016-12-0616:43jonsmock@mikerod That was a solid talk#2016-12-0618:30mikerod@jonsmock thanks!#2016-12-2012:47fabraoHello all#2017-01-1413:33skurohi *#2017-01-1413:34skuroIâ€™m just exploring clara these days, and I had a question#2017-01-1413:34skuroin my model, some of the facts have a timestamp property, which can be used to let facts expire when they become too old#2017-01-1413:37skuroso far I have this in my little experiment: 
(defrecord Fact [timestamp ...])

(defn too-old [t]
  (< max-age (- (now) t)))

(defrule ignore-old-facts
  [?fact <- Fact (too-old timestamp)]
  =>
  (retract! ?fact))
#2017-01-1413:39skurois it the right strategy? I guess facts wonâ€™t be re-evaluated over time in a given session, so if I go for this I would have to recreate it periodically#2017-01-1413:39skurobut maybe Iâ€™m not understanding clara yet ðŸ™‚#2017-01-1615:01wparker@skuro Youâ€™re correct that facts wonâ€™t be re-evaluated in this case. My suggestion would be to write something like#2017-01-1615:02wparker(defrule ignore-old-facts [TimeFact (= ?time time)] [?fact <- Fact (too-old timestamp ?time)] => (retract! ?fact))#2017-01-1615:03wparkerIf you retract an old TimeFact and then insert with a newer TimeFact this will force re-evaluation of the join#2017-01-1615:05wparkerThereâ€™s been some discussion on the mailing list of providing support for this sort of use case (events that expire with reference to them in Clara removed) but at this time there isnâ€™t anything in Clara to directly support it.#2017-01-1616:06skurook, thanks#2017-01-1617:03wparkeryouâ€™re welcome#2017-01-1914:00dm3do I understand correctly that a rule like the one in https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/sensors.clj#L48: 
(defrule get-current-temperature
  "Get the current temperature at a location by simply looking at the newest reading."
  [?current-temp <- newest-temp :from [TemperatureReading (= ?location location)]]
  =>
  (insert! (->CurrentTemperature (:value ?current-temp) ?location)))
will accumulate CurrentTemperature facts, never retracting them?#2017-01-1916:52dm3seems the above is retracted on every new TemperatureReading. Is my intuition right in this case - the retraction happens because when the new TemperatureReading (t+1) arrives, the condition under which the previous CurrentTemperature became true (t+0) is now false?#2017-01-1917:36wparker@dm3 that is correct#2017-01-1917:37wparkerWhen the conditions that caused a logical fact insertion to occur Clara will adjust the session to reflect the new status of those conditions#2017-01-1917:37wparkerLogical insertions are those done with insert!#2017-01-1917:38wparkerIf you used insert-unconditional! youâ€™d end up with multiple CurrentTemperature facts potentially depending on your rules firing pattern#2017-01-1917:39wparkerBut as long as you stay away from uncondition insertions and manual fact retractions inside rules you can just think of the rules as pure logical relationships that â€œif as session has these things in it it will also have these other things in it"#2017-01-1917:39wparkerâ€œa sessionâ€ not â€œas session"#2017-01-1917:42wparkerAfter you call fire-rules at least, i.e. (-> your-session (insert your-facts-here) ;;no-contract-about-status-now fire-rules ;; now-there-is-a-contract-about-the-status)#2017-01-1917:42wparkerAlso note that youâ€™ll group on the location of the TemperatureReading in the above#2017-01-1917:43wparkerSo if you have TemperatureReading facts with different locations you can have a CurrentTemperature fact for each distinct location#2017-01-1917:43wparkerDoes that make sense?#2017-01-1917:48dm3yeah#2017-01-1917:48dm3running into some other issues now#2017-01-1917:50dm3what if I have facts that change with time and do an insert CurrentTimestamp -> fire-rules -> retract CurrentTimestamp periodically? Are there any obvious issues I'll run into?#2017-01-1918:44wparker@dm3 As long as you use truth maintenance Clara will resolve all transitive impacts on rules#2017-01-1918:45wparkeri.e. if you insert Fact1 which causes RuleA to insert fact2, and fact2 causes ruleB to insert fact3#2017-01-1918:45wparkera retraction of fact1 will cause fact3 to be removed from the session if appropriate based on the rules#2017-01-1918:47wparkerRegarding â€œfacts that change with timeâ€:#2017-01-1918:47wparkerClara assumes that facts are immutable#2017-01-1918:48wparkerIf you do something like (insert JavaBeanFact) fire-rules (.setSomeFieldUsedInRules JavaBeanFact newValue)#2017-01-1918:48wparkerthe behavior will be undefined#2017-01-1918:49wparkerif you want to change fields youâ€™ll need to retract the fact and then insert a new one with the modifications you want#2017-01-1918:50wparkerActually Iâ€™d consider mutation of facts after insertion to result in undefined behavior in general, apart from whether the field is used#2017-01-1918:51wparkerMutating fields after insertion used in rules would definitely cause problems with the current implementation, would need to think about mutations not impacting rule bindings but either way the behavior isnâ€™t guaranteed and I wouldnâ€™t advise doing it#2017-01-1918:52dm3thx#2017-01-1918:52dm3I wasn't considering mutations#2017-01-1918:52wparker:+1:#2017-01-1918:53dm3I'm thinking of batching the input stream of events and reducing the batch with (fn [sess batch] (-> (insert sess timestamp) (insert-all batch) (fire-rules) (retract timestamp)))#2017-01-1918:54wparkeryeah obviously the existence of problems depends on the specific use-case but I donâ€™t see problems in general with inserting and then retracting a timestamp fact that would have downstream impact through various rules#2017-01-1918:55wparkertruth maintenance will sort out all the impacts to downstream rules#2017-01-1918:56wparkeralso remember Clara sessions are immutable#2017-01-1918:56wparkerso you could do something like this as well#2017-01-1918:56wparker(def session-with-facts-no-timestamp)#2017-01-1918:57wparker(def time1-session (-> session-with-facts-no-timestamp (insert time1) fire-rules))#2017-01-1918:57wparker(def time2-session (-> session-with-facts-no-timestamp (insert time2) fire-rules))#2017-01-1919:21dm3I'm now trying to do the following: 
(ns rulebot.test
  (:require [clara.rules :as clara]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]
            [clara.tools.tracing :as tt]))

(defrecord Value [value instant])
(defrecord Step [step instant])
(defrecord CurrentValue [value])
(defrecord CurrentStep [step])
(defrecord CurrentTimestamp [instant])

(clara/defrule current-value
  [?e <- (acc/max :instant :returns-fact true) :from [Value]]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->CurrentValue (:value ?e))))

(clara/defrule current-step
  [?e <- (acc/max :instant :returns-fact true) :from [Step]]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->CurrentStep (:step ?e))))

(clara/defrule step
  [CurrentValue (= ?value value)]
  [CurrentStep (= ?prev-step step)
               (= ?curr-step (int (/ ?value 10)))]
  [CurrentTimestamp (= ?instant instant)]
  [:test (> ?curr-step ?prev-step)]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->Step ?curr-step ?instant)))

(defn go []
  (let [session (-> (clara/mk-session 'rulebot.test)
                    (tt/with-tracing))]
    (-> session
        (clara/insert (->CurrentTimestamp 0))
        (clara/insert (->Value 1 0))
        (clara/insert (->Step 0 0))
        (clara/fire-rules)
        (clara/retract (->CurrentTimestamp 0))

        (clara/insert (->CurrentTimestamp 1))
        (clara/insert (->Value 11 1))
        (clara/fire-rules)
        (tt/get-trace))))
which fails on the step rule because ?prev-step gets bound to an {:ns-name .., :lhs ..., :rhs ...} map for some reason...#2017-01-1919:31dm3@wparker can you see anything obviously wrong with that?#2017-01-1920:40wparker{:ns-name .., :lhs ..., :rhs â€¦} is what the internal representation of a rule looks like; its the map structure that defrule stores in a var#2017-01-1920:41wparkerI donâ€™t have time to look into it in detail at the moment but Iâ€™d guess that the â€œstepâ€ field is being resolved to the â€œstepâ€ var instead#2017-01-1920:41wparkerIf you type â€œstepâ€ in a REPL in that namespace you should see the same value#2017-01-1920:43wparkerIâ€™d say this edge case merits a GitHub issue to determine what to do with it but for the moment I think you can resolve this by naming your rule something that isnâ€™t the name of one of your fact fields#2017-01-1920:43wparker@dm3#2017-01-1921:17dm3you're right. Once that's fixed, the example goes into infinite loop#2017-01-1921:17dm3so your help will still be appreciated! ðŸ™‚#2017-01-1922:49wparkerI see youâ€™re inserting Step in one of your rules that looks for facts that are inserted due to Step#2017-01-1922:50wparkerAt first glance Iâ€™d say youâ€™re likely doing something where youâ€™re inserting a Step that then causes itself to be retracted and entering an infinite loop that way#2017-01-1922:50wparkerIâ€™d need to take a closer look at it to work out exactly what#2017-01-1922:52dm3hmm#2017-01-1922:53dm3the step rule does insert a new Step, which should then retract the old CurrentStep and insert a new one, unless I'm misunderstanding something#2017-01-1922:56dm3however, after the step rule runs, the current-step rule is still executed with the previous Step fact#2017-01-1923:00dm3it's probably the truth maintenance screwing with me - Step (t0) is inserted outside the rules, Step (t1) is inserted by the next-step rule with CurrentStep (t0). After Step (t1) triggers current-step to retract the CurrentStep (t0), the Step (t1) also gets retracted which again triggers next-step with CurrentStep (t0)#2017-01-1923:02dm3what should I do in order to accumulate the Step facts (more like events in this case) instead of having the above happening?#2017-01-1923:13wparkerto be honest Iâ€™m not sure what sort of logic youâ€™re trying to represent with the recursion there so an alternative isnâ€™t obvious to me#2017-01-1923:34dm3I'm trying to capture increases in Value as Steps. There's a stream of Values coming in, which I batch and fire with a new CurrentTimestamp every N ms. Some of the batches might trigger a new Step, which I've imagined would appear as a new fact in the session. I guess the culprit of my troubles is the recursive relation between the CurrentStep and Step.#2017-01-1923:37dm3tried reformulating the next-step rule as follows (becuase the CurrentStep is just the MAX of all steps): 
(clara/defrule next-step
  [CurrentValue (= ?value value)]
  [?s <- (acc/max :step :returns-fact true) :from [Step (= ?prev-step step)]]
  [CurrentTimestamp (= ?instant instant)]
  [:test (> (int (/ ?value 10)) ?prev-step)]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->Step (int (/ ?value 10)) ?instant)))
#2017-01-1923:38dm3the above works, except I couldn't figure out how to bind the ?curr-step = (int (/ ?value 10)) inside the condition#2017-01-2010:14dm3seems I need something like a merged RETE/ECA engine (e.g. as described http://ceur-ws.org/Vol-412/paper3.pdf) as I first need to distill events into state#2017-01-2017:28wparkerThanks for the link, now Iâ€™m curious and will have to read that paper ðŸ™‚#2017-01-2201:13wparkerFYI @dm3 I logged an issue for the issue you were having with the field symbol resolving to the rule var discussed here above. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/259#2017-01-2209:58dm3thx#2017-01-2616:36mike_ananevhi, there! Question about types. Does it necessary to use defrecord in order to declare fact? Can I use ordinary clojure maps to derive a fact and validate them by clojre.spec?#2017-01-2617:39wparker@mike1452 Clara will use the fact-type-fn to determine what type a fact is for matching against conditions. The docs/examples can probably be improved in this regard but it is alluded to in the generated API docs at http://www.clara-rules.org/apidocs/0.13.0-RC4/clojure/clara.rules.html#var-mk-session#2017-01-2617:40wparkerDefrecord is just convenient for some peopleâ€™s use-cases because it creates a type to match against out of the box#2017-01-2617:40wparkerwhen you use clojureâ€™s type function as the fact-type-fn (which is the default)#2017-01-2617:46wparkeralso because it allows you to use field names in a rule condition directly i.e.#2017-01-2617:46wparker(defrecord Cold [temperature])#2017-01-2617:46wparker(< temperature 0)#2017-01-2617:46wparkerrather than (< (:temperature this) 0))#2017-01-2618:24mike_ananev@wparker thanks! awesome rule engine!#2017-01-2618:56wparker@mike1452 this has come up several times. Ideally weâ€™d have an explanation of the option at http://clara-rules.org at some point when someone gets time to write one but in the meantime I added a quick example at https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/fact_type_options.clj#2017-01-2619:17mike_ananev@wparker cool! thanx!#2017-01-2619:18mike_ananev@wparker btw, is it possible to use Clara rules with Apache Flink? We are building online anti-fraud system and evaluating several engines.#2017-01-2620:23wparkerClara currently always runs in a single JVM, although it can be used in a distributed environment if it itself isnâ€™t distributed, and we actually do so. Claraâ€™s architecture would likely facilitate an enhancement to distribute it and if someone were interested in driving that it could be discussed.#2017-01-3119:57apbleonardLooking for options for debugging rules. Would have saved some time discovering typos etc today if I could have switched on debug logging evaluating every condition of a given rule say. Or even had "explain-non-activations". Any tips?#2017-01-3121:49apbleonardOk. So it looks like inspect would have helped me. Will also try tracing tomorrow...#2017-01-3121:54wparkerInspect might be more helpful if youâ€™re looking at ordinary sorts of errors like a bad rule etc. Tracing can be useful too but definitely gets into implementation details#2017-01-3121:55wparkerIf it concerns exceptions running against the branch that is out and in progress for https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/255 could be helpful too#2017-01-3123:39apbleonardThanks :) Was more about straightforward debugging. Just getting started with Clara! #2017-01-3123:45apbleonardAlso - looking at source of load-rules in clara/rules.cljc you can just supply a list of symbols resolving to individual rules, not just namespaces - is that correct? Would love an example of this. Flexibility around how rules are assembled would be great.#2017-01-3123:59wparkerI think a call to mk-session like the one at https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/fact_type_options.clj#L20 is what youâ€™re talking about, ignoring the :fact-type-fn and :ancestors-fn options#2017-02-0115:16mikerod@apbleonard Think of it as clara.rules/mk-session accepts any number of â€œrule sourcesâ€. This can be anything that implements the clara.rules.compiler/IRuleSource protocol or just a collection of rule/query structures.#2017-02-0115:17mikerodClojureâ€™s Symbol implements the clara.rules.compiler/IRuleSource protocol. The function to implement is clara.rules.compiler/load-rules which must return a collection of rule/query structures.#2017-02-0115:18mikerodHowever, Will had a good example if all you want to do is something simple like pass rules in#2017-02-0115:18mikerod
(defrule one-rule <etc>)
(defrule another-rule <etc>)
(defquery some-query <etc>)

;;;; Make session
(mk-session [one-rule another-rule some-query])
#2017-02-0115:19mikerodyou can also mix and match. Symbol implements IRuleSource by expecting the symbol to resolve to a namespace name. It scans the whole namespace and finds all rules/queries in vars of that namespace.#2017-02-0115:20mikerod(mk-session [one-rule another-rule some-query] 'some.ns.with.rules)#2017-02-0115:23mikerod@mike1452 Will mentioned that records allow you to refer to record fields directly in the rule. For non-records, you can use destructuring though. Just so you kmow 
(defrule my-rule [:my-type-thing [{:keys [x y]}] (= x â€œhelloâ€)] 
<etc>)
#2017-02-0115:23mikerodThere should probably be documented examples of that sort of destructuring.#2017-02-0115:27mike_ananevthanks#2017-02-0222:00apbleonard@wparker @mikerod Thanks so much - that's exactly the examples I was looking for. Assembling rules dynamically will help us handle our mostly similar (but slightly different) rule-sets for different products. Btw destructuring maps also good to know, as records are not often used in our Clojure codebase.#2017-02-0222:02mikerodItâ€™s probably good to be aware that if you can order rules in a meaningful order of precedence, Clara will attempt to use that as a heuristic during conflict resolution (picking which rule to fire first, when multiple are eligible).#2017-02-0222:03mikerodSo if you have rules or sets of rules that naturally depend on other rules/sets of rules, you want to put the dependents after the dependencies. This may not matter to you and may not be worth worrying about until you have a concrete performance concern.#2017-02-0222:06apbleonardWe have relatively low numbers of rules (no more than 100s depending on how granular we make them), but enough for Clara to really help sort out the complexity. ðŸ™‚ #2017-02-0222:06mikerodIf I had rules like: 
(defrule a [(acc/all) :from [A]] => (insert! (->B)))
(defrule b [(acc/all) :from [B]] => (insert! (->C)))
(defrule c [(acc/all) :from [C]] => (insert! (->D)))
All three rules would be â€œeligibleâ€ to be fired immediately, since the acc/all accumulator is always considered â€œtrueâ€. It will just fire with an empty collection if it has no matches, yet. If I mk-session like 
(mk-session [c b a])
This would cause Clara to choose to fire the rules in the opposite order that you would want. The Truth Maintenance System will be sure that your rules logically are correct after firing the rules, however, it will waste cycles firing rules too soon and having to retract and re-fire them later as their dependencies in their LHS change. So you want mk-session like 
(mk-session [a b c])
#2017-02-0222:07mikerod@apbleonard Yeah, it likely isnâ€™t something to concern yourself with now. Iâ€™m just brining it to your attention since when you start to consider generating rules, etc, it may be something to consider later on if performance becomes and sort of concern.#2017-02-0921:36gamecubateHello. Clojurescript doesnâ€™t seem to be supported at this time. Bummer. Was just what I needed for a project at work.#2017-02-0922:37wparker@gamecubate ClojureScript is definitely intended to be supported, although it isnâ€™t used as much as the Clojure version as far as I can tell and not at all at Cerner.#2017-02-0922:37wparkerThose donâ€™t look like fatal warnings to me, did you run into further problems?#2017-02-1003:50gamecubate@wparker I didnâ€™t want to spend too much time digging into this. So, Iâ€™ve switched over to core.logic but I have to say progress is glacial (this said less than 2 hours after the switch). Claraâ€™s eloquent DSL I miss already.#2017-02-1015:20wparkerTo elaborate a bit, those are basically linter warnings that seem related to the rebinding, in a particular namespace, of core Clojure library definitions to new values. You can look at the source in both cases for whatever version of ClojureScript and Plumatic Schema youâ€™re using to see those redefinitions happening. Whether that is good style in any particular case is a matter of opinion, but I donâ€™t think the linter warnings are actually errors. Obviously your choice to use Clara in any project or not, but nothing I see here makes me think there is a bug with Claraâ€™s ClojureScript support. That said, Claraâ€™s ClojureScript certainly isnâ€™t as hardened as the JVM version and bug reports are welcome.#2017-02-1015:21wparkerAgainst master: https://github.com/plumatic/schema/blob/master/src/cljx/schema/core.cljx#L402 and https://github.com/clojure/clojurescript/blob/master/src/main/cljs/clojure/reflect.cljs#L33#2017-02-1016:04gamecubate@wparker End of day when I wrote this. I wasnâ€™t thinking. Of course they were warnings! I gave up there and then instead of doing what I normally do (which is to ignore warnings) and proceed. Will resume Clara tests. Thanks for the nudge. ðŸ™‚#2017-02-1016:49gamecubateMacrosâ€¦ Checking Clara docs, I see mk-session is a macro indeed. I need to probably add a 
(:require-macros [???])
directive. Will try...#2017-02-1016:51ryanbrush@gamecubate I'd check out the ClojureScript examples, like the one at https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojurescript/clara/examples/shopping.cljs.#2017-02-1016:52ryanbrushNote that mk-session doesn't exist and isn't support in ClojureScript, since it dynamically compiles rules. You'll need to use defsession (which compiles them upfront), as seen in that example. In fact, starting with that example, running it, and experimenting with changes to it is probably a pretty good way to get started with the ClojureScript flow.#2017-02-1016:53gamecubate@ryanbrush Thanks. Going through the example now.#2017-02-1016:55ryanbrush@gamecubate Sure thing! If you find problems, please log bugs or let us know. Just to warn you, we've used only the Clojure version in production and therefore haven't deeply optimized the CLJS flow so you might run into more issues there. But bug reports, and especially help tuning or optimizing the CLJS flow against real workloads, would be welcome.#2017-02-1016:55ryanbrush@gamecubate I think we're also behind on the version of ClojureScript we've tested against, so validating against newer versions is welcome as well.#2017-02-1016:56gamecubate@ryanbrush :+1:#2017-02-1017:00gamecubate@ryanbrush Would you recommend I run my code against 0.13.0-RC4 (as per README.md) or, per your example, 0.13.0-RC7?#2017-02-1017:01ryanbrush@gamecubate Probably doesn't matter for your needs, but the readme is just out of date. 0.13.0-RC7 will be good. (We're overdue in just releasing 0.13.0 itself, so expect that in a release soon.)#2017-02-1017:01gamecubategot it#2017-02-1017:05gamecubateWow. This is one great example.#2017-02-1017:06gamecubateJust need to replace dommy with (my chosen) Reagent code.#2017-02-1017:12ryanbrushYeah, we probably should update the example to use a more modern approach. ðŸ™‚#2017-02-1017:18gamecubateIt works nicely, though.#2017-02-1017:18gamecubate

successful. Am plugging in reactive (test) UI right now.#2017-02-1017:19gamecubateMy first instinct (as with all Reagent app data) would be to wrap the session in a (reagent) atom, but defsession being a macro and all, not sure this is even feasible, nor desirable, nor useful.#2017-02-1018:13gamecubateDone. Works nicely. Will now try and compile with advanced-optimizations.#2017-02-1018:16gamecubateWorks!#2017-02-1018:17gamecubateClara it is, then. ðŸ™‚#2017-02-1018:56ryanbrush@gamecubate Glad it works! Note that defsession will create the initial, empty session as a static var, but that can be referenced and manipulated like any other Clojure data structure. I haven't thought a ton of good design patterns with Reagent...but just thinking of the session as any other complex, immutable structure is probably a good start.#2017-02-1018:57ryanbrush@gamecubate if you do come up with good patterns for using this with Reagent and are interested in sharing examples of doing so, we could look at including them in the examples project (possibly replacing the dommy example that exists today).#2017-02-1019:03gamecubateSo far still exploring. What I have done thus far is for my event handlers (someone enters data in a field and clicks on add button -> triggers handler) to insert new session data: 
(-> my-session (insert (->Customer â€œAlexâ€)) (fire-rules))
. Now am trying to figure out what to do for my reagent components to show the changes. Normally, without Clara, the event handler would simply update the atom that my components are watching. But now, with Clara, inserted data is held in the session and I need to find a way for my components to track that instead.#2017-02-1019:13gamecubateNow, with rules, the handler changes to:#2017-02-1019:14gamecubateMy customer-list component should change as well, and thatâ€™s where I am not sure how to proceed to get session data I need.#2017-02-1019:21ryanbrushNot a Reagent expert, but I think it should be possible to keep a Clara session in a Reagent atom, and swap it out every time you update facts or fire rules.#2017-02-1019:21gamecubateHow do I access records of a certain type, say ClientRepresentative?#2017-02-1019:22gamecubate
(def session-db (reagent/atom my-session))
#2017-02-1019:22gamecubateNot sure.#2017-02-1019:22ryanbrushAll access goes through queries. http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/queries/#2017-02-1019:26gamecubateHow does one write a query that retrieves all records of a certain type? Something like 
(defquery get-clients â€œâ€ [] [???])
#2017-02-1019:27gamecubatewith that type defined as 
(defrecord Client [name])
.#2017-02-1019:29gamecubateI might need an example for using accumulators/all. That looks like the one I need.#2017-02-1019:35gamecubateOh I see. might be

#2017-02-1020:49gamecubateGot it. Just need to set a rule that updates the (reagent atom) db whenever a new session insert takes place.#2017-02-1021:14gamecubateSo, this works. I am not sure however that this should be added to examples because it only serves to demonstrate that using Clara and Reagent together requires (in my solution at least) an extra level of indirection (view -> event handler -> clara insert -> reagent atom db update -> view â€¦). The business logic that Clara offers a DSL for is too simple in this case. Iâ€™ll try and think of something more convoluted before submitting said example.#2017-02-1021:51ryanbrushCool, glad it's working. No rush in adding something to the examples...it's just nice to see a pattern that works with Reagent.#2017-02-1021:53ryanbrushOne thing to note: the session itself is immutable, so you'll probably want to keep it in atom itself and swap out when you make changes. The rules you have above will work because they are just appending state, but you're actually resetting back to an old session state every time.#2017-02-1022:03ryanbrushThere are probably other interesting variations on this. For instance, we could have reactions that fire on a swap of an atom containing the session, and those reactions would query the session and update other state. This could be a little closer to the purely "reactive" ideals of Reagent, rather than having rules that actively update state.#2017-02-1022:08gamecubateI see. Changes needed then; will think about it to see where and how. Thanks! Gotta go pick up kid @ daycare (immutable task for me :). Cheers.#2017-02-1218:42mike_ananevHi! Can Clara detect a rule collisions? If rule C contradicts to rule A ?#2017-02-1220:59apbleonardFairly new to Clara but ... it probably depends slightly what you mean. If you have a rules like "if A then B = 1" and "if A then B = 2", then when you query the session for values of B (assuming A is true) you'll find two values in the lazy sequence returned by the query function.#2017-02-1221:01apbleonardIf you have rules like "if A then B" and "if B then retract A" ... well, I haven't got that far yet!#2017-02-1222:17mike_ananev@apbleonard yeah, first variant with two answers is correct, i think. second variant is not, cause "if A then B" will insert fact B, but if retract A then B will be retracted automatically. my question about contradiction was about case if some big organization issues new policy about smth, i want to check that rules in new policy are not contradict to older policies. so i want to find collisions before new policy is issued.#2017-02-1321:22mikerod@mike1452 @apbleonard the 2nd variant could actually cause an infinite loop since Claraâ€™s insert! will do some automatic truth-maintenance which can hang indefinitely if you have a â€œlogical loop"#2017-02-1321:24mikerodHowever, the 1st variant sounds to be more of what you were asking. You have to deal with duplicated inserts yourself. You could have rules all insert some fact like B there, then have some â€œfinalâ€/â€outcome" rule(s) or query(s) that use an accumulator that you can make decide which facts are the most relevant or correct when you get into a situation of â€œcontradictions"#2017-02-1321:27mikerodHowever, I think you were also wanting the engine to tell you about these rules so you could remove them perhaps? That would be something youâ€™d probably have to workout yourself. Sounds domain-specific.#2017-02-1321:27mikerodIt isnâ€™t really clear what a â€œcontradictingâ€ rule means from the rules engineâ€™s perspective. With the exception of logical contradictions, but those also arenâ€™t even clear in the engine right now since the RHS can insert basically anthing#2017-02-1321:28mikerodand the LHS can test constraints that arenâ€™t simple to statically analyze.#2017-02-1416:30wparker@mike1452 @apbleonard If you use manual retractions in the RHS you become responsible for ensuring that the rule execution order works out so that you get your desired results. It is basically the same idea as with logical vs unconditional insertions discussed at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ This can be done with salience and/or strategic structuring of your rules, but in my experience adds significant complication and room for error#2017-02-1416:31wparkerMy suggestion would be to use accumulators or negation conditions as Mike alluded to above. If you have a priority order of different logical states it wouldnâ€™t be too hard to get the state with the highest priority in an accumulator and use that state in a rule RHS. Alternatively, you can write rules like#2017-02-1416:34wparker(defrule negation-rule-1 [?a <- A (some-predicate-here)] [:not [B (other-predicate-here)]] => (insert something))#2017-02-1416:37wparkermanual RHS retractions can be useful for getting things out of memory or for performance, in general wouldnâ€™t be my first resort though#2017-02-1416:47mike_ananev@wparker thanks for suggestions! btw, what is most biggest rules database you've ever seen in production memory that Clara worked with? 10,100, 500?#2017-02-1416:47wparkerdo you mean the number of rules?#2017-02-1416:47mike_ananevyeah#2017-02-1416:55wparkerI think we have some rulesets with at least 10K rules now, canâ€™t say exactly off the top of my head since we autogenerate a lot of rules with some internal framework code#2017-02-1416:58wparkerthereâ€™s a reason weâ€™ve spent a lot of effort optimizing performance ðŸ˜›#2017-02-1418:04mike_ananevwow, cool!#2017-02-1419:19apbleonard@mike1452 FWIW I have exactly the same challenges. We handle complex government policies introduced atop of older policies, and half the battle is understanding pathways through the logic, and the total space of inputs and the variety of resulting outputs. I'd love to implement the rules trivially enough to give fast feedback to policy makers on what their new policy just did to the complexity of the problem. I feel like clojure's core.logic should be able to help with this...? If that makes sense, anyone know of people using core.logic with Clara?#2017-02-1420:49ryanbrush@apbleonard I'm a fan of core.logic, but am unaware of anyone using it tightly with Clara. I think core.logic works great for problems that can be described as a set of constraints, and core.logic will search that constraint space for a solution. Clara is more centered around encoding business rules or domain expertise. It's not always obvious which tool is best for a given job, so I always think it's a good idea to experiment with both in your problem space before choosing a direction.#2017-02-1421:10wparkerClara-rules 0.13.0 is released. - The replacement of the previous durability API with a more robust and performant one. This is discussed at issue 198. Note that this is experimental and is subject to further change; that said we're successfully using it in production at Cerner. - Improvements in error reporting in rule and query conditions, discussed at issue 255. Thanks to Carlos Phillips for this one. - Various performance improvements and bug fixes discussed on the changelog.#2017-02-1421:11wparkerI meant to say â€œhighlights includeâ€ before my bullets.. I fail at Slack formatting ðŸ˜›#2017-02-1421:11wparkerAnyway, basically a cross-post from https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/Q2p7l-Vmcr0#2017-02-1621:52jarrodctaylorCould anyone be so kind as to help me understand how variable definition works? This is the most concise example I have to illustrate my confusion. 
(require '[clara.rules :as rule])

(rule/defrule wat
  [1 (= ?a "a")]
  [1 (= ?b "b")
   (nil? (println ?a))    ;; => "a"
   (nil? (println ?b))    ;; => "b"
   (nil? (println ?a ?b)) ;; => "a nil"
   ] => nil)

(-> (rule/mk-session [wat] :fact-type-fn (constantly 1))
    (rule/insert 1)
    (rule/fire-rules))
#2017-02-1621:53jarrodctaylorWhy does ?b disappear when printed together with ?a?#2017-02-1622:41wparkerI wouldnâ€™t expect that to happen, but I can see the behavior you describe when I drop your example in a REPL#2017-02-1622:44wparkerIt is a weird case in that youâ€™d normally expect the bindings to come off the actual fact in some way, but it still seems like incorrect behavior at first glance, probably merits a GitHub issue#2017-02-1622:45wparker@jarrodctaylor#2017-02-1622:52jarrodctaylorI was experiencing the behavior with a more traditional rule in my application. This above was as too the point of an example to demonstrate it as possible. I will open a issue on GitHub. #2017-02-1622:52zyloxi know ive had issues when i try to refer to a binding in the same condition (might be the wrong term) where it was bound.#2017-02-1622:53zyloxbut if i used the raw field version it worked fine#2017-02-1623:10wparkerI suspect that the reason adding ?a causes ?b to be different is that if you have ?a in the constraint it will become a join with the previous fact, and if it is absent it is a condition on a single fact#2017-02-1623:10wparkerThose are different paths in the compiler so one could have a bug the other doesn't#2017-02-1623:11wparkerDoing a quick test like#2017-02-1623:11wparker
` (rule/defrule wat
  [1 (= ?a "a")]
  [1 (= ?b "b")
   (and (nil? (println ?a))
         (nil? (println ?b))) 
   ] => nil)
`#2017-02-1623:11wparkermakes b be nil as well#2017-02-1623:12wparkerwith ?a and ?b in the same constraint#2017-02-1623:12wparker@zylox : a â€œconditionâ€ contains constraints, that is you can have a condition like [FactType constraint1 constraint2]#2017-02-2603:21mikerodhttps://leanpub.com/readevalprintlove004/read I don't recall if this was shared in this channel yet. It is an interesting read on rules engines by Fogus. I particularly like the simplified implementation of a (naive and simplistic) rules system. The "fruit fly" system. Hah. It does shed some light on some ideas at a high level. There is a little mention of Clara in the end "credits" too. So there is that. ðŸ˜œ #2017-03-0210:57newresI have a question about using guards on rules in Clara. I am aiming to create rules that can never insert a fact that already exist. The guard statement works fine if I am manually inserting the fact that the guard stops, but if the rule itself is creating this statement the guard does not stop the rule from triggering again and I get an infinite loop.#2017-03-0216:05zyloxya thats a tricky one ive dealt with too. i'm not sure what the solution is either.#2017-03-0216:19newreswith a naive implementation of rules where each rule is checked separately I can see this not being an issue as after each insertion the guard would be checked and with the new fact that guard would be passed. Could this be a bug in the implementation, where somehow not the full condition of the rule is checked for it to fire again?#2017-03-0216:34zyloxmaybe i didnt understand what you meant by gaurds, but if a rule inserts something that that same rule looks at, its pretty much always going to cause another firing#2017-03-0216:34zyloxis my understanding#2017-03-0217:16newresI think i figured out the roof of the problem#2017-03-0217:16newresI compeltely glanced over the fact that clara does truth maintenance#2017-03-0217:18newresthis means if the result of the rule puts in the guard of the rule the fact loses support gets retracted and the rule fires again#2017-03-0217:18wparkerSounds correct, looking through https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/truth_maintenance.clj and http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ might be helpful ðŸ™‚#2017-03-0217:18zyloxtruestory#2017-03-0217:19newresI feel very dense about this#2017-03-0217:20wparkerYou can use unconditional insertions that wonâ€™t use truth maintenance if necessary. In our use cases we strongly prefer truth maintenance and find that it makes the code simpler to reason about, but obviously use-cases differ#2017-03-0217:20newresi was staring at this like a whole evening thinking what the problem could be, whoops.#2017-03-0217:20wparkerIt is a common point of confusion ðŸ™‚#2017-03-0217:21newresIt kind of solves pretty much every problem I had with clara though, so that is a relief#2017-03-0217:22zyloxso you are saying you were stuck in an infinite loop about the infinite loop and the truth about truth maintenence resolved it#2017-03-0217:24newresyeah basically using a guard with truth maintenance, where the result of the rule (or another) triggers the guard can start an infinite loop#2017-03-0217:24newresespecially in the case where it is just a single rule that triggers the guard#2017-03-0217:25zylox(i was just making a light hearted joke about how your proccess of realizing how it was working was similar to a rules network) though your understanding sounds correct to me#2017-03-0217:25newresah LOL#2017-03-0217:25newreswell like I said I feel dense today#2017-03-0219:52nrayapatihttp://www.metasimple.org/2017/02/28/clarifying-rules-engines.html#2017-03-0219:54nrayapatiOverview of the talk @mikerod gave at the Clojure/conj 2016 conference.#2017-03-0220:31mikerodOh yes. Still cleaning up that site some. Going to change the theme since it sucks on mobile. However the content is there. #2017-03-0220:33zyloxnope this is permanent now#2017-03-0220:33zyloxweve seen everything#2017-03-0221:41ryanbrush@mikerod Okay, I'll resist the urge to tweet about it until you have the finishing touches in place. ðŸ˜„#2017-03-0221:42mikerodHaha. Thanks. I'll fix it within a day or so. Out of town so I'm a bit slow. #2017-03-0320:00mikerod@ryanbrush FYI I changed the visual theme to something that is reasonable on mobile and desktop. So I'd consider the Clara blog good to go at this point. #2017-03-0320:17ryanbrush@mikerod Looks great, and nice post!#2017-03-0320:40mikerodThanks!#2017-03-2216:54wparkerVersion 0.14.0 of clara-rules is released. I posted at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/UscQQgDtN-Y with a description of the changes relative to 0.13.0 (the previous version).#2017-04-1222:50souenzzoHi. How to make an "or" in "match" part of rule. Example: 
;; There is 2 types: groups and items
;; Example:
;; :group [1 false 2]
;; :group [1 false 3]
;; :item [2 true]
;; :item [3 false]
;; :group [4 true 5]
;; :item [5 false]
;; Group '1' contains items '2' and '3'
;; Group '4' contains item '5'
;; My `select` query shoud find [[4][1]]
;; because they are groups and they are selected
;; or contains a selected item
(defrule selected-groups
         ;; Or this
         [:group [[id selected _]] (= ?id group) (= selected true)]

         ;; Or this
         [:group [[id _ item-id]] (= ?id id) (= item-id ?item-id)]
         [:item [[item-id selected]] (= ?item-id item-id) (= selected true)]
         =>
         (insert! ^{:type :select} [?id]))
(sorry for big example) (yes, I know how to do it with 2 rules.) (I dont care with duplicate entries)#2017-04-1322:29wparker@souenzzo Would something like [:or [:group â€¦] [:and {:group ..] [:item]] meet your needs? There are some docs at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/booleans#2017-04-2001:28devn@wparker thanks for session->fact-graph#2017-04-2001:28devni'm pretty excited about that change#2017-04-2014:19zyloxsame#2017-04-2015:19alex-dixonHaven't made time to try it yet ðŸ˜•#2017-04-2015:39mac@devn I musty be missing something, which commit contains 
session->fact-graph
?#2017-04-2016:22wparker@mac it isnâ€™t in master yet. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/283#2017-04-2016:23mac@wparker Ah, got it. Thanks.#2017-04-2016:26wparkerglad to hear it could be useful for others as well. Iâ€™d be interested to hear about experiences with it or any tools, visualizations, etc. anyone comes up with and wants to share#2017-04-2016:28wparkerfor the use-case I had in mind Iâ€™ll probably be looking at ways to show particular parts of the graph since the session is so large that showing the entire graph would be an information overload#2017-04-2119:55devn@wparker we built something hackish to build graphviz, and for the entire session the graph was way too big to be useful#2017-04-2119:56devnthen there was an attempt at using cytoscape.js to make it traversable#2017-04-2119:56devnso you could see a few nodes away from YOU ARE HERE#2017-04-2119:57devnwhat i found myself wanting was a way to define views over the graph, like, i may not care about all the edges and nodes between Node A and Node B, so I'd like to define a view that shows me Node A -> Node B without all of the intermediate steps#2017-04-2120:00devnI imagine having something like: (def views {:everything [FactA FactB ...], :simple [FactA FactC FactF]})#2017-04-2120:01devn:simple automatically collapses nodes and edges along the path of A->C->F#2017-04-2120:02devn@wparker another thing that I think would be nice would be to generate a static graph#2017-04-2120:03devnof all the facts in the project, regardless of whether they are ever used#2017-04-2120:04devnbut maybe your PR achieves this?#2017-04-2120:05devnwhat we built relied on the data returned from inspect, which IIRC required us to fire-rules#2017-04-2120:06devnim interested in building the graph of all the relationships, not just the relationships that survive after running the rules#2017-04-2120:07wparkerThe graph would include all logical insertions regardless of whether they were used for anything, but unconditional/external insertions wouldnâ€™t be if they werenâ€™t used for anything#2017-04-2120:08wparkerSince Clara allows them to be garbage-collected if they arenâ€™t used#2017-04-2120:10wparkerMy general line of thinking here was to build a graph, and then#2017-04-2120:10wparkerprovide functions to retrieve particular subsets of the graph, potentially modify it, etc.#2017-04-2120:11wparkerand then look at how to display those views. Basically have a data-oriented approach to the problem that different views could layer on top of#2017-04-2120:11zyloxyou can always reduce the data in a graph, thats the wonder of them#2017-04-2120:12wparkerIn particular, in our case weâ€™d probably want to combine fact graphs with some other indicators that our specific to our internal frameworks#2017-04-2120:12wparkerso Iâ€™m looking for composability#2017-04-2120:13wparkerIâ€™m not clear on what :simple would be - do you mean that if you had A -> B -> C youâ€™d have a direct edge of A -> C?#2017-04-2120:15wparkerAlso, @devn Iâ€™d be curious about why cytoscape.js versus any other graph visualization options you tried or considered - the visualization layer isnâ€™t something I know much about yet#2017-04-2121:06devn@wparker I did not directly participate in the decision to use cytoscape, but as I recall it was chosen partly for performance, and partly because it made the traversal of subgraphs relatively easy.#2017-04-2121:06devn@wparker RE: direct edge on A->C, yes, that was what I was thinking#2017-04-2121:07devnor perhaps you have A->[summary collection of intermediate nodes]->C#2017-04-2121:08devnbasically anything to make it easy to skip the display of 382910 nodes and edges that don't actually tell you much that you care to know about getting from A to C#2017-04-2121:09devni think it's often the case that the fact that you got to C suggests everything you'd need to understand about B#2017-04-2121:14devnfor instance, there is a big fan out and fan in between A and C, like A->[B1, B2, B3, B4, B5, BN]->C If C is a specific fact like: MoreThanThreeBs, then who really cares what those Bs were? all I really care about is that by virtue of A, I have the possibility of many Bs, and all I care to know is if I get to state C from A#2017-04-2121:21devnWe have a lot of scenarios where we need to look at hundreds of thousands of facts on our way to a state, but in the end all we really care about is that given a Lab, we determine whether it is normal or abnormal according to a massive set of facts, and then produce an AbnormalLabResult or NormalLabResult. Labl->AbnormalLab/NormalLab is how I'd prefer to view it in a UI rather than render the 500k+ nodes and corresponding edges in between#2017-04-2121:24devnbeing able to express something like: "Provided #{A}, render direct edges to #{C, D} through nodes of type #{B}" would be nice#2017-04-2121:27devnStop me if what I'm saying doesn't make any sense#2017-04-2121:29devnI suppose I imagine that for any collection of rules and facts, there are layers to the view. Similarly, I don't care which specific constraints in that rule were met, unless I do.#2017-04-2121:30wparkerI can see where that would be useful for some rules patterns, yes. that I don't think would be totally out of bounds for clara.tools.*#2017-04-2121:31wparkerAh, I see#2017-04-2121:31wparkerBy the way, I think having transformation functions in the fact-graph
