be really nice to not leave that as an exercise for the reader, and instead have a couple of basic built-in tools for specifying what you want to look at#2017-04-2121:32wparkeror other namespace as appropriate as you say â€œclara.tools.*â€#2017-04-2121:33devnLike, a function which dumps graphviz, even if there is no dependency within clara to actually render it, seems like it might be useful#2017-04-2121:34devnand then adding on to that: Dumps graphviz where you specify the starting node (the type of fact), and how many hops should be rendered#2017-04-2121:35devnor: Dumps graphviz, and lets you set the color for nodes based on their fact type#2017-04-2121:35devnetc.#2017-04-2121:35wparkerFor that, Iâ€™m thinking youâ€™d do something like (-> original-graph remove-intermediate-steps render-to-graphviz)#2017-04-2121:36devnsure, yeah#2017-04-2121:38devnIt would be interesting to generate some anonymized graphs for all of our projects just to get a sense for what transformation functions would be generally useful#2017-04-2121:40devnI know there are Reasonsâ„¢ to not include the transformation kitchen sink or unnecessary deps, but I feel like a simple toolkit for rules engine graph generation would be super helpful to have, maybe even as part of core#2017-04-2121:41devnas opposed to an external lib#2017-04-2121:52wparkerYeah, there is often a tradeoff of not tying things together too much versus not providing enough functionality especially if you get into needing other libraries as dependencies. Adding generic data transforms doesnâ€™t seem like it adds too much burden though since it is very easily ignorable if you donâ€™t need them#2017-04-2121:55wparkerIâ€™m guessing the types of transforms needed will depend heavily on the domain. For example, in our case, I think a lot of it would revolve around taking a given fact and showing everything either upstream or downstream from that fact, and potentially â€œbacktrackingâ€ a bit from some joins on that path, but not the rest of the rules session#2017-04-2121:57wparkerIf you have a fact A that flows through rules B->C->D->E->F and you donâ€™t get the expected F it would be nice to be able to easily see where it â€œstoppedâ€#2017-04-2121:57wparkeror in the case of accumulation how it interacted with other facts in that chain#2017-04-2122:03wparkerThe first step is to make the full data set available for manipulation though#2017-04-2122:03wparkerYou could get most of it from inspect already but not when you go through accumulators#2017-04-2122:03wparkerwhich we use a lot of#2017-04-2808:36puzzlerHow does the performance of Clara queries compare to something like Datascript?#2017-05-0115:33ennCan anyone suggest how I might instrument my rules to figure out which one is throwing an NPE? The NPE is during > during an accumulatorâ€™s reduction which makes me assume itâ€™s the max accumulator, which I use in only a handful of rules. Iâ€™d like to narrow down which specifically is throwing the exception, but Iâ€™m not sure how Iâ€™d go about putting logging in the LHS of a rule. (The RHS is too late as the accumulators are used only in LHSs.)#2017-05-0116:13zyloxdo you have an example stack trace?#2017-05-0116:17ennyes:#2017-05-0116:19enn@zylox http://paste.lisp.org/display/345606#2017-05-0116:47zyloxya i got nothing unfortunately. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.clj might be of some help#2017-05-0117:28wparker@enn unfortunately errors during accumulation arenâ€™t handled as well as errors in non-accumulator conditions; https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/265 is logged to improve that (non-accumulator conditions were improved in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/255 )#2017-05-0117:29wparkerIn the meantime your best option is probably to wrap the accumulator in question in a way that indicates what rules youâ€™re in when it throw an exception#2017-05-0117:30wparkerClara accumulators are just maps containing functions, and the accumulator can be modified by adding a new value onto one of the keys#2017-05-0117:31wparkerYour stacktrace tells me youâ€™re throwing in the reduce-fn#2017-05-0117:33wparkerSo you could do something like (defn ->wrapped-reduce-fn [original-reduce-fn rule-name] (fn [& args] (try (apply original-reduce-fn args) (catch Exception e (throw (ex-info (str â€œThrew exception in accumulation in â€ rule-name) {} e))))#2017-05-0117:34wparkerand (defrule [?result-binding <- (update (acc/min :field) :reduce-fn ->wrapped-reduce-fn rule-name) â€¦#2017-05-0117:35wparkeractually to work with the update youâ€™d need to reverse the args order of ->wrapped-reduce-fn, but that is the basic idea#2017-05-0117:37wparkerThe problem with tracing is that when you throw an exception and exit the rules firing loop youâ€™ll lose the transient listener that has the info you want#2017-05-0117:37wparkerWhen a RHS exception is thrown we call to-persistent on the listeners but that wonâ€™t happen in an exception during accumulation https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1787#2017-05-0117:38wparkerYou could write your own listener that had global side effects or some such to get around that if you wanted though#2017-05-0117:41wparkerThere are some docs on what the different accum function fields do at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/, you can also look at the structures created at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/accumulators.cljc#2017-05-0117:50ennThank you, the wrapping idea makes sense#2017-05-0117:52ennthough a little clunky as we are not specifying the reduce-fn directly (itâ€™s created via acc/max and comparison-based)#2017-05-0118:03wparkerYeah, it is clunky, but hopefully if you have just a handful of rules and a particular exception it wonâ€™t be too bad. Obviously not as nice as having built-in error handling i.e. issue 265 but hopefully solves your immediate need#2017-05-1819:42wparkerClara-rules 0.15.0 is released and available on Clojars. Highlights include a variety of improvements to session inspection, including functionality to create a graph data structure of facts to facts they caused to be logically inserted, and a fix to a memory leak that caused the memory to retain references to bindings from retracted facts in some cases.#2017-05-1819:43zyloxðŸŽŠ#2017-05-1819:46wparkerThe changelog has further details on the changes: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#2017-05-1819:58ryanbrushAwesome, Will!#2017-05-2304:04devn@wparker thank you for all of your work.#2017-05-2304:05devnYou've made my job easier.#2017-05-2410:32nkabrichcan anyone recommend a good tool/library to visualize the output of clara.tools.fact-graph/session->fact-graph?#2017-05-2412:47skurorhizome?#2017-05-2412:48skurohttps://github.com/ztellman/rhizome#2017-05-2609:18puzzlerCan someone point me to documentation about how to construct clara rules dynamically?#2017-05-2611:02nkabrichAFAIK defrule just generates a data structure so you can either build that by hand dynamically or check out clara.rules.dsl/parse-rule#2017-05-2614:13wparker@puzzler There are a number of examples of dynamic rule creation in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj You can also just build the rule data structures yourself if that is more convenient for your use-case; see the schema at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/schema.clj#L62#2017-05-2614:16wparkerYouâ€™ll need to fully qualify reference in your LHS (left-hand side) code if you use that approach, although in the RHS code it will evaluated in the ns you give if you give one as noted in the comment on the schema; that would be good to do in the LHS too, it just hasnâ€™t been implemented yet#2017-05-2614:40ryanbrushThere is also an example of generating rules from an external DSL on this blog post. Towards the bottom you'll see the Clojure data structure that defines the rules themselves. http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/#2017-05-2614:41ryanbrushBut often just writing defrule for your rules, then looking at the data structure it creates can give you a good idea of what you need, as @nkabrich suggests.#2017-05-2718:55newresoh wow I was just about to ask about dynamic rule creation#2017-05-2718:57newresThe issue I have would be that the list of conditions in the lhs (and some part of the rhs) would be based on the elements of a list that is bound with a condition#2017-05-2718:58newresThe problem is I can not seem to express it right with defrule nor the underlying code datastructure#2017-05-2719:03newresI might be stepping too much over what the rete network does so it might be slow, but if nothing else there should be a way to look into the underying knowledge base for a set of checks the very least based on which I could bind a variable on the right hand side#2017-05-2719:04newresbut this seems like internal stuff to clara the very least#2017-05-2719:29newreswas thinking maybe having a test expression that uses a functon and perhaps some internal way of peering into the current knowledge base, based on which it would return variables#2017-05-2719:43ryanbrush@newres I'm not sure I entirely follow your use case, but it seems possible in principle with some of the rule generation patterns described above. However, I'm not sure I'd suggest that approach if you can avoid it. It might be better to, for example, put the needed data in some structure on the left-hand side, and bind the entire structure to a variable...and then de-structure that variable on the right-hand side to get the nested structure out.#2017-05-2719:52newres@ryanbrush The problem I would have in binding everything and move it to the right hand side is that in the current implementation I need to use the conclusion in the guard.#2017-05-2719:56newres@ryanbrush is there a way on the lhs to reach into the current knowledge base with an expression, without resorting to unification and bindings? Basically with regular programming with some datastructure as a knowledge base the problem is pretty easily solvable, I would not mind skipping any optimizations clara provides just in a few cases.#2017-05-2720:00newres@ryanbrush to describe the problem I have a bit better, suppose I have bound a list to the variable ?L. Based on this list I need to check x number of conditions where x is the length of that list and the conditions vary based the the list elements.#2017-05-2720:07ryanbrushThe left hand side can only see the fact it is analyzing, and previously bound variables. Unfortunately there isn't a way to dynamically peek into the memory more than that...and there isn't a way to really make that visible that will be stable, either, since the order of evaluation of each rule constraint isn't defined, and we use a mutable structure underneath that can change at any time.#2017-05-2720:08ryanbrushGenerating rules ahead of creating the session can be done, but it's not clear whether that helps much. The visibility of the LHS to the fact its evaluating and previous, explicitly bound variables in earlier constraints on the LHS is a pretty firmly build in.#2017-05-2720:09ryanbrushBut you can still bind a list or other structure in one LHS constraint, and then analyze it in a subsequent LHS constraint, if that helps.#2017-05-2720:09ryanbrush...which includes test guards#2017-05-2720:14newresThe problem there is I do not know how I would express the fact that for all elements in that list I need a new slightly different constrained. For example suppose I have in the list 3 variables ?p1, ?p2, ?p3 I would need 3 conditions that check like [T (= ?a s) (= ?p1 p) (= b o)] [T (= ?b s) (= ?p2 p) (= c o)] [T (= ?c s) (= ?p3 p) (= d o)]#2017-05-2720:16newresI can probably generate or write up such rules for the length of x manually if writing it for arbitary lengths is not possible#2017-05-2720:17ryanbrushAnother simpler option (which may or may not work for your needs) is to use an accumulator to match a list of all items of type T, and then analyze that list in your guard.#2017-05-2720:18ryanbrushThe accumulator might not bind anything but the result, so it just passes a list down, and you can call an arbitrarily sophisticated function in the guard to sort it out. Some documentation here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/#2017-05-2720:22newresso I could get all the values of T where the middle variable is a member of the list (In my implementation nearly everything is T, so I need to narrow some things down), than have test as a guard that pretty much checks what the conditions would do in a normal case#2017-05-2720:22ryanbrushYeah, that should work.#2017-05-2720:23ryanbrushIt's probably not the most idiomatic way to structure rules, but we've done things like this as well.#2017-05-2720:24ryanbrushIf you really want to get fancy you can write your own accumulator...but just grabbing everything (or just using simple filters if that works) can get you there.#2017-05-2720:26newresis there a simple way to say that i want [T (= ?b s) (= ?pl p) (= c o)] where ?pl is a member of a list l#2017-05-2720:26ryanbrushYeah, you can pass ?pl to any function on the LHS after it is declared, including checks for inclusion in a list.#2017-05-2720:27newresaha yes that would work, not sure about the efficiency but right now getting it working would be a good step#2017-05-2720:28newresThanks for the help! i am probably pushing clara in some really weird and unexpected ways but the docs really help#2017-05-2720:29ryanbrushCool. Glad I could help and good luck with your system!#2017-05-2720:29newresand the board and the slack, thanks !#2017-05-2914:44nkabrichWhy is this rule creating an infinite loop? I'm trying to insert a "default fact" if no other rule has yet inserted that fact. Or is there a better pattern for this? 
(defrule infinite-loop
  [:not [SomeFact]]
  =>
  (rules/insert! (map->SomeFact {:a 1})))
Also if I add {:salience -1} to this rule, it seems to hang in the LHS? I'm not exactly sure but in any case when I set the salience a (println "looping") in the RHS fails to print and thread hangs.#2017-05-2914:48souenzzonot sure but, i think you can: first accumulate some fact, if it's equal zero, then insert the default.#2017-05-2915:20alex-dixon@ryanbrush Would it be ok to add a Clara channel here? https://discord.gg/v9QMy9D#2017-05-2915:23nkabrich@souenzzo hmm thanks, but I'm still running into an infinite loop using an accumulator and :test to insert a default#2017-05-2915:31alex-dixon@nkabrich Are you using (acc/count)?#2017-05-2915:33alex-dixon
[?nfacts <- (acc/count) :from SomeFact]
[:test (= 0 ?nfacts)]
#2017-05-2915:33alex-dixon?#2017-05-2915:34nkabrich@alex-dixon nope, ill give that a whirl#2017-05-2915:36ryanbrushIf an insert on the RHS causes the LHS to become false, the insert is retracted since it is no longer supported...causing the LHS to become true again and an infinite loop occurs.#2017-05-2915:37ryanbrushThe key is for the RHS insert to not match the LHS. Like check in the LHS for not a default value that the RHS could insert, so it doesn't retract the RHS inserted fact.#2017-05-2915:38ryanbrushYou can also use insert-unconditional to avoid this truth maintenance loop outright, but that can cause other headaches that depend on the order of facts inserted.#2017-05-2915:38nkabrichahh, makes total sense thanks for the explanation.#2017-05-2915:39ryanbrushSure thing. It's probably the biggest pitfall of rules engines like this....but can be overcome with some care#2017-05-2915:41ryanbrush@alex-dixon I'm not familiar with that service. Let me take a look at it later today#2017-05-2915:45alex-dixon@ryanbrush Thanks. Thereâ€™s some discussion within the community to converting from Slack to it. Seems like weâ€™re in a trial period right now. I know from the JS community that Slackâ€™s message limit is a problem and Discord is generally looked to as the solution (they keep unlimited message history) https://github.com/reactjs/redux for example is a popular JS library that has moved to Discord#2017-05-3015:02ryanbrushAs for the Discord conversation, if the bulk of the Clojure community goes over there then we should go along. That said, I feel like I already have too many collaboration tools I use...so I'll probably only be active on the forums where most of Clojure is. I have no objections if users want to create a Clara channel there...I just won't promise to frequent all of these.#2017-06-0813:35jfntnIâ€™m not familiar with clara but Iâ€™ve been wondering if it could be used to model a HFSM/Statechart by defining a hierarchy of rules?#2017-06-0813:42jfntnI.e. in any given state, only a subset of the engines rules are loaded, and generally youâ€™d want children states to activate their parentâ€™s rules#2017-06-0813:44jfntnThe OOP like mechanics can easily be achieved with a custom hierarchy in clojure, but Iâ€™m wondering if scoping rules to their respective state in clara would involve instantiating different rulesets, or dynamically mutating a global rules registry#2017-06-0913:35fabraoWell @jfntn , I used to classify I kind of link status to avoid chains of ifs, but my experience is that it was more complex than I thougth, so I changed to datascript to be more clear and simple#2017-06-0913:36fabraohere is an example what I did 
(defn limite [chave]
  (read-string (chave (:referencia (:config sistema)))))

(defrecord IcmpLocalizacao [nome-link localidade jitter latencia perda])
(defrecord Problema [mensagem nome-link localidade])

(defrule ligacao-fragmentada
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :fragmentada ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule telefonia-degradada
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> jitter (limite :jitter)) (> latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :degradada ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule perda-qualidade
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> jitter (limite :jitter)) (<= latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :qualidade ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule atraso-telefonia
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (<= jitter (limite :jitter)) (> latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :atraso ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule sem-comunicacao
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (= jitter -1) (= latencia -1) (= perda -1)]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :comunicacao_locais ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defquery problemas-comunicacao []
          [Problema (= ?mensagem mensagem) (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade)])

(defn gerar-fatos [fatos]
  (let [regras (atom #{})]
    (doseq [fato fatos]
    (let [link (first (first fato))
          valor (second (first fato))
          localidade (:localidade valor)
          icmp (:icmp valor)
          jitter (:jitter icmp)
          perda (:perda icmp)
          latencia (:latencia icmp)]
    (swap! regras conj (->IcmpLocalizacao link localidade jitter latencia perda))))
    @regras))

(defn compilar-regras [fatos]
  (into #{}
        (-> (mk-session 'correlacao.item.regraslink)
            (insert-all (gerar-fatos fatos))
            (fire-rules)
            (query problemas-comunicacao))))
#2017-06-0913:38fabraoin datascript 
(defn- classificar-elemento [conn tipo op-jitter op-perda op-latencia jitter perda latencia]
  (let [resultado (d/q '[:find ?localidade ?link
                         :in $ ?op-jitter ?op-perda ?op-latencia ?ref-jitter ?ref-perda ?ref-latencia
                         :where 
                         [?e :link ?link]
                         [?e :localidade ?localidade]
                         [?e :jitter ?jitter]
                         [?e :perda ?perda]
                         [?e :latencia ?latencia]
                         [(?op-jitter ?jitter ?ref-jitter)]
                         [(?op-perda ?perda ?ref-perda)]
                         [(?op-latencia ?latencia ?ref-latencia)]
                         ]
                       conn op-jitter op-perda op-latencia jitter perda latencia)]
    (if (= #{} resultado)
      []
      (resultado->set resultado tipo)
      )))
#2017-06-0913:39fabrao(classificar-elemento @conn :fragmentada nevermind > nevermind jitter perda latencia)#2017-06-0913:43fabraoI see that datascript was more flexible, but you can use any other ways to define rules for your job, like in https://github.com/threatgrid/naga or even clojure.logic#2017-06-0917:59mikerod@jfntn I guess I donâ€™t fully grasp your problem statement#2017-06-0918:00mikerodHowever, Clara has certainly been used in a way that creates logical â€œgroupsâ€ and/or â€œhierarchiesâ€ of rules#2017-06-0918:00mikerodYou can have intermediary facts inserted that act as â€œblockersâ€ for some rules, or have some rules not be able to be satisfied until certain facts are present#2017-06-0918:01mikerodHowever, this isnâ€™t done by â€œturning offâ€ rules or by excluding rules from the rulebase/session created, instead it is done purely through logical relationships the rules express#2017-06-0918:02mikerodAlso, the â€œtypeâ€ dispatch function used by Clara rules LHS conditions is pluggable. So you could do things with ad hoc hierarchies of Clojure#2017-06-0918:02mikerodhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2017-06-0918:03mikerodhas some details on the custom â€œfact typeâ€ fn (and similarly the associated â€œancestorsâ€ fn#2017-06-0918:03mikerodI may be speaking way too vague to help answer your question though#2017-06-0918:03jfntnOk interesting, I guess I was wondering if it was valid to consider an approach where the app dynamically loads/unoads a different session depending on some external state machine#2017-06-0918:04mikerodI think @fabrao may have had some interesting points above too. There is a chance that forward-chaining rules arenâ€™t the best approach to certain sorts of problems#2017-06-0918:05mikerodI would say it is not a good situation to have when your rules end up being of the form: A -> B; B -> C; C -> D; D -> E - when that chain starts to get really long and only one linear flow of logic#2017-06-0918:06mikerod@jfntn well consider one of the compelling strengths of a Rete-based forward chaining rules impl like Clara - it stores a bunch of state to avoid re-calculation of join and non-joining constraints done in previous states of the system#2017-06-0918:06mikerodif you flip from session to session, they will not share any of this state with one another. there is a chance that that is suitable for your needs. Iâ€™m just calling it out.#2017-06-0918:08mikerodAlso, the time to create a session is typically non-trivial if you have a fair number of rules involved. So often the pattern is to keep the sessions in memory. There will be limitations to how many rule sessions you can store in memory at a time. The size of them is mostly dependent on the number or rules and conditions involved#2017-06-0918:08fabraohttps://github.com/hraberg/mimir#2017-06-0918:09jfntnSo I guess I was assuming you could somehow keep the facts but change the rules, not sure if that makes sense in practice#2017-06-0918:09jfntnhttp://blog.cognitect.com/blog/2017/5/22/restate-your-ui-using-state-machines-to-simplify-user-interface-development#2017-06-0918:10mikerod@jfntn you could query the facts produced from a fire-rules execution of a session#2017-06-0918:10jfntnThis article includes this definition for an fsm:#2017-06-0918:10mikerodand you could insert those facts into any other sessoin that uses them#2017-06-0918:10jfntn
(def fsm {'Start          {:init             'Ready}
          'Ready          {:missing-password 'Password-Error
                           :missing-email    'Email-Error
                           :submit           'Submitting}
          'Password-Error {:change-password  'Ready}
          'Email-Error    {:change-email     'Ready}
          'Submitting     {:receive-success  'Success}})
#2017-06-0918:10mikerodI believe I just read this a few days ago#2017-06-0918:10mikerodI hadnâ€™t really thought much about it though.#2017-06-0918:11jfntnI was imagining something like rules as transitions instead of keywords, and a sort of recursive definition where the Symbols on the right-hand side could be whole FSMs#2017-06-0918:11mikerodHave you found that it is difficult to express the FSM sort of logic just using 1 session?#2017-06-0918:13jfntnWouldnâ€™t you have to encode the transitions across many rules though? Maybe I just want something that will define a valid session from recursing over this tree#2017-06-0918:14mikerodIt isnâ€™t immediately clear to me how it would look#2017-06-0918:15mikerodPerhaps this article is enough to go off to make a toy example in Clara with 1 session#2017-06-0918:15mikerodBut it may not be sophisticated enough to show anything useful - I donâ€™t know#2017-06-0918:16mikerodIâ€™m just trying to find the simplest solution the the problem and Iâ€™d hope there would be a nice mapping of the idea to a single session. Just to avoid the details of bouncing around between them#2017-06-0918:16mikerodYou could certainly have a map of â€œsession name keyâ€ -> session#2017-06-0918:16mikerodand have RHSâ€™s produce a fact that says what is the â€œnext sessionâ€ to evaluate#2017-06-0918:17mikerodOr to flip that and just have the RHS produce a fact that your outer FSM uses to transition to the next step - I think that is what you said above#2017-06-0918:18fabraoit seems like workflow engine#2017-06-0918:20mikerodFunny#2017-06-0918:20mikerodJBoss had jBPM I think#2017-06-0918:20mikerodwhich basically (I believe) is a FSM sort of system that triggers Drools rules at certain stages#2017-06-0918:20mikerod(among other things)#2017-06-0918:21mikerodSo I guess the idea came up there as well. Iâ€™m still just curious about whether or not a single session canâ€™t express an FSM in the sense of the web app article though#2017-06-0918:32jfntnSeems like it should be possible, but the article is only trying to represent a single FSM, and to extend that definition to a Statechart you have to imagine that each state on the right is not final but can have recursive fsm definitions.#2017-06-0918:32jfntnYouâ€™d be able to chart the whole app with something along those lines:#2017-06-0918:32jfntn
(def app-statechart
  {'Visitor
   {:login
    {'LoginForm
     {'Start          {:init 'Ready}
      'Ready          {:missing-password 'Password-Error
                       :missing-email    'Email-Error
                       :submit           'Submitting}
      'Password-Error {:change-password 'Ready}
      'Email-Error    {:change-email 'Ready}
      'Submitting     {:receive-success 'Success}}}
    :signup {... }}
   'User  {...}
   'Admin {...}})
#2017-06-0918:40jfntnThe key distinction is that for a given node in the tree, valid transitions at that state are the union of its and its parentsâ€™ transitions (or rules in our case), so rules that are not in this set are illegal#2017-06-0918:51mikerodinteresting#2017-06-0919:16fabraoDont you think clara is too complex for that?#2017-06-0919:19fabraotake a look here https://github.com/vvvvalvalval/datalog-rules#2017-06-0919:20fabraoyou can define many ruleset and apply it in your context, so you can dynamic it for your needs#2017-06-0920:19mikerodThere is no engine there, but Iâ€™m assuming you put it on top of something like datascript#2017-06-0920:19mikerodand I think you end up in a backwards-chaining situation there#2017-06-0920:20mikerodwhich may be find and fit the need. I think it just comes down to what you want out of it.#2017-06-0920:20mikerodalso, you have to consider any performance concerns you may have, clj/cljs support (I think datalog-rules would be fine in either), etc#2017-06-0922:07jfntnNo I think conceptually we do want forward chaining and all the caching goodness from clara, just trying to wrap my head around what type of application-level integration we could have#2017-06-1000:17mikegai@jfntn modeling a statechart should be no problem within a single session -- you just need to gate each rule controlling exit/enter with a "gating condition" that matches the current state.#2017-06-1000:18mikegaiThe state chart syntax you supplied could be operated over and expanded to a set of rules, each of which begins with matching the state from which those entry/exits apply#2017-06-1000:48mikegaiMaybe something like this (in tuple / #precept syntax instead of default Clara): 
(def-tuple-rule ready-exit-missing-password
  [[:app :state :login]]
  [[:login :state :ready]]
  [[_ :missing-email]]
  =>
  (insert-unconditional! [[:login :state :password-error]]))
#2017-06-1000:49mikegaia macro would expand the concise statechart syntax to rules like that.#2017-06-1000:50mikegaiand then of course you could define/derive :missing-email elsewhere#2017-06-1000:50mikegai@jfntn do I have what you're thinking right?#2017-06-2610:19mishagreetings! Is using clara for sessions as small as single UI form â€“ an overkill in context of mobile applications (e.g. React Native apps, where performance is more expensive than on desktop websites or backend)?#2017-06-2614:37mikerod@misha It could be. Even if not for performance, it may just be too complex of a tool for the job. What sort of reasons were you thinking that it may be helpful for a single form?#2017-06-2614:37mikerodI guess I wouldnâ€™t think a form would have enough complex control flow#2017-06-2614:50mishaby form I mean registration/billing/etc. form (just to clarify)#2017-06-2614:51mishaforms can get pretty complex, with all the fetching, autosuggesting, autocompleting, validation, etc.#2017-06-2614:55mishabut what I am really after, is a way to manage lots of state, it can be as complex, as entire application state: think many dependent and independent widgets on the same screen, or even many screens, but with routing implemented with rules too, instead of having it as a standalone thing with its own tools and approaches.#2017-06-2615:23mikerod@misha yeah, that sounds interesting. I donâ€™t know on the performance concerns. Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™ve heard of someone using Clara on mobile applications to have anything to go off of.#2017-06-2615:24mikerodAlso, precept seems to be using Clara in a somewhat similar way as you describe. However, Iâ€™m not sure it is handling routing.#2017-06-2615:24mikerodhttps://github.com/CoNarrative/precept#2017-06-2615:25mikerodThe space/time complexity of Clara is going to be reliant on the number of rules, complexity of the join conditions within the rules, and the size of facts in working memory.#2017-06-2615:25mikerodSo you can get a pretty large range of performance characteristics depending on your use-case#2017-06-2615:26mikerodThe tendency of the rules network is to favor time over space. e.g. intermediate match state is saved to avoid recomputing values later. So a space vs time tradeoff.#2017-06-2615:26mikerodIf your working memory state isnâ€™t prohibitively large though, the space may still be reasonable#2017-06-2615:26mishaI am yet to read into precept, but guys do not hesitate to call it framework, so I am being "careful" there :)#2017-06-2615:29mishaas far as mobile apps performance concerns go, I am worried about cpu speed at the moment, since I was forced to move datascript to a separate RN thread because of pull calls speed on a somewhat large db.#2017-06-2615:31mishaBut I am looking at rule based systemsâ„¢ from an application state management pov, which might be only few hundred kvs at most, I think#2017-06-2617:08zyloxEDIT: i need to read better#2017-06-2621:31mikerod@misha well if cpu is your worry than at least Clara favors that over space usage#2017-06-2621:32mikerodItâ€™d be cool if you could try it out and report back with how it performs in this mobile case#2017-06-2621:32mikerodNothing stands out to me as being too prohibitive#2017-06-2621:55misha@mikerod first, I need to start thinking in terms of rules, but as soon as will have something to show â€“ I'll let you know.#2017-06-2622:00mikerodsounds fun!#2017-06-2622:01mishaopieop#2017-06-2717:11devnhowdy folks -- so, i have a base session which contains a bunch of configuration facts and what-not#2017-06-2717:12devnwhen the application receives a payload, we push those facts into the session and fire rules#2017-06-2717:13devnbut, if we have 10 concurrent requests ðŸ˜¬#2017-06-2717:13devnwe had been doing these serially via a queue, but design is a-changin' a bit#2017-06-2901:17cflemingHi everyone - I develop Cursive, and Iâ€™ve been chatting to @zylox about the possibility of adding support for the Clara macros to Cursive.#2017-06-2901:17cflemingSince Cursive indexes source, it needs some support to understand macro forms - Iâ€™m planning to open an API for that, but thatâ€™s way off since itâ€™s a large project.#2017-06-2901:18cflemingOne thing Iâ€™m interested in is being able to add support using grammars migrated from specs for macros, since I expect there will be more of them in the future.#2017-06-2901:19cflemingHas anyone investigated or thought about creating specs for the Clara macro forms? That would be a big help in adding support for them to Cursive.#2017-06-2901:19cflemingAs well as selfishly meaning that I can actually try to migrate some macro specs to Cursive - I havenâ€™t seen any in the wild yet.#2017-06-2901:20cflemingSince the macro forms also seem quite complex, it seems like having specs for them would also be generally useful to developers using Clara.#2017-06-2902:11ryanbrush@cfleming Hey, cool idea. I haven't really used specs for macros yet, but I think it would be straightforward to do so for Clara's macros. The structure is pretty well defined (the defrule and defquery macros already have a schema defining their return values) and has been stable for some time.#2017-06-2902:12cfleming@ryanbrush Nice. So is there actually a grammar for the macros themselves anywhere? I see some railroad docs, but they seem incomplete.#2017-06-2902:12cflemingThe schema I guess is for the returned data, right? Not the actual macros?#2017-06-2902:13ryanbrushWe had written quite a bit of error handling code for malformed defrule macros to make it easier to debug, but we don't have a formal grammer besides the (incomplete) EBNF we used for the railroad docs.)#2017-06-2902:13ryanbrushRight, the schema is for the returned data.#2017-06-2902:13ryanbrushI agree this could be helpful for rule authors.#2017-06-2902:14cflemingAre there examples of Clara rules in any OSS projects? I donâ€™t work with it myself so Iâ€™m not sure how a lot of the tricky cases (destructuring etc) work.#2017-06-2902:16ryanbrushSort of. The precent project (https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept) uses Clara, but is more of a wrapper so isn't the most common usage.#2017-06-2902:17ryanbrushThe best place for examples is probably the clara-examples project itself: https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/tree/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples#2017-06-2902:18cflemingThanks, Iâ€™ll take a look at those.#2017-06-2909:45flipmokidHi, I'd like to use Clara in my app which uses Component. I'm currently scratching my head on how I can create a rule that when matched writes to a channel supplied by Component when the application starts. Would anyone be able to give me guidance on how I might do it?#2017-06-2916:00flipmokidOkay silly me, I'm adding the required components as facts and I can pull them out as needed in the rule for use in the right hand side.#2017-06-2916:09zyloxi thought as much but i didnt know enough about Component to say anything haha#2017-06-2921:40devn@cfleming FWIW, I have a cursive license, we have 100s of hand-written rules, and would be happy to be a guinea pig#2017-06-2921:42devni could also share sanitized rules#2017-06-3010:10flipmokidHopefully a quick one, I'm using clara with :fact-type-fn (fn [[e a _]] a). I'm inserting a bunch of facts e.g. 
(rules/insert-all session [[1 :event/eventTypeId 1]
                                          [1 :state/timeElapsed 19]
                                          [2 :event/eventTypeId 1]
                                          [2 :state/timeElapsed 23]])
to match with an example rule of 
(def football-over-20-mins-rule
  (clara-dsl/parse-rule
   [[:event/eventTypeId [[e a v]] (= 1 v) (= ?e e)]
    [:state/timeElapsed [[e a v]] (> v 20) (= ?time v) (= ?e e)]]
   (println "Event " ?e " has gone over 20 mins with " ?time)))
At some point I want to retract all facts for a given 'e', as the event might have finished and I want to keep my facts lean. What is the best way of collecting all facts for matching 'e' so that I can retract them all?#2017-06-3012:42ryanbrush@flipmokid Your best bet is probably to write a query (via defquery) to get all facts for a given e, and then use retract to remove them. There isn't a retract-all (yet), but since it's a multi-arity function you can call it arbitrarily like (apply retract session [my-facts])#2017-06-3012:46flipmokidSorry, it's probably my bad understanding of rules but for my [e a v] fact type how would I get all e's out. As far as I understand the first part of a rule is the type (which is a) and so I'm not sure how I would specify how to pull all entities of a particular number. I'm currently inserting a fact [e :event/retract true] and then trying to find these [:event/retract [[e a v]] (= v true) (= ?e e)] but not sure how to get all matching facts that have the same e#2017-06-3012:58flipmokidI guess I just need someone to help me understand how to write a rule/query that can pull the e's (it's having to write the type at the start that is throwing me). I'm not sure if I can check for the :event/retract fact and then have an accumulator to get all e's for it#2017-06-3013:08ryanbrushI think I see the sticking point here. You'll probably want to match a query on a special "parent" type of all (you can use clojure.core/derive to declare a parent type, which Clara will honor if it's done before the session is created.) Then the query can have a predicate to match on whatever subset you want.#2017-06-3013:09ryanbrush...or I suppose you could just have your fact match on java.lang.Object (assuming your running the Clojure rather than the ClojureScript version) and have your predicate check that.#2017-06-3013:31flipmokidI'm not sure derive will be of much help. For a fact [e a v] e will always be a number (the id of the sporting event) which is not known in advance, a will be the attribute and v can be anything e.g. [1 :state/timeElapsed 19] So do you think if I wanted to stick with my tuple-shaped facts it would be difficult to extract all es of the same value if my fact-type-fn is (fn [[e a v]] a)? Out of interest do you know how Precept handles retractions of its tupled shaped facts?#2017-06-3013:36ryanbrushIf you know the values of a ahead of time then it derive could work, but might be painful to derive all of that. But a defquery approach might work like:#2017-06-3013:37ryanbrush`(defquery [:e-to-remove] [Object [my-tuple] (= ?e-to-remove (first my-tuple))])#2017-06-3013:37ryanbrushHaven't actually tried that, but it's an idea to try with. I'm not familiar with how Precept handles this sort of thing.#2017-06-3013:38flipmokidThat looks interesting, let me give it a go#2017-06-3013:41ryanbrushSounds good. There are some steps I left out...you'll want to return the full tuples from the query, for instance, so they can be retracted.#2017-06-3013:58flipmokidActually, I'm not sure the Object part will match as I'm not using the type function (please let me know if I'm being stupid though, I often am!) (defquery [:e-to-remove] [Object [my-tuple] (= ?e-to-remove (first my-tuple))])#2017-06-3014:10ryanbrushAh, of course. You'll need a custom ancestors function to complement the custom type function. There is an example here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2017-06-3014:10ryanbrushSo your custom ancestor could just return :all-facts if you wanted to match everything. ðŸ˜‰#2017-06-3014:11ryanbrush(:all-facts is just an arbitrary keyword here that could be returned by the ancestors function.)#2017-06-3014:48flipmokidAh okay. I'll try that. Thanks for your help so far, I really appreciate it#2017-06-3015:22flipmokidBrilliant that worked! 
(def retractions-rule
  (clara-dsl/parse-rule
   [[:event/retract [[e a v]] (= v true) (= e ?e)]
    [?elems <- (acc/all) :from [::all [[e _ _]] (= e ?e)]]]
   (println "RETRACTION MATCHED " ?elems)))
Many thanks for your help#2017-06-3015:33ryanbrushNice!#2017-07-0213:06ryanbrushJust released clara-rules 0.15.1! Details in the change log: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0151#2017-07-0613:37souenzzoCan I write a rule that check if there is some other rule that match facts of type x#2017-07-0613:37souenzzo?#2017-07-0614:01zyloxunless you fed rules into the session as facts, not that i know of#2017-07-0614:01zyloxif you had the rules stored somewhere your right hand side could execute some sort of static introspection i guess#2017-07-0800:53dragoncubeWithing REPL are newly defined rules are picking up? It will only look in the current namespace, though, unless you are explicitly passing namespaces.#2017-07-0806:34dragoncube@ryanbrush so I need to call mk-session again? if so, is there any way to transfer facts from one session to another? or maybe fire-rules would be enough?#2017-07-0814:55ryanbrushYou'll need to pass in your facts into the new session again. Clara won't do this automatically, but I usually reload the facts or keep them in a list.#2017-07-0821:03dragoncubeI see, so I need to write small wrapper for insert-fact, retract-fact which would store facts in separate collection. A very simple example 
(defquery get-promotions
  "Query to find promotions for the purchase."
  [:?type]
  [?promotion <- Promotion (= ?type type)])
#2017-07-1317:35nickowsy
(query session get-promotions :?type :lunch)
#2017-07-1317:35nickowsythat example is from the docs. Are you trying to do something more complicated?#2017-07-1317:36fmjreyyeah I saw that example, and now looking at this: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/cbecbdf916625a46ee93e7c84ed411aab3f1dbc1/src/test/clojure/clara/test_java.clj#L51#2017-07-1317:37fmjreythis is a java based example, which looks like it uses strings as map keys, will try that now#2017-07-1319:07fmjreyI think I found the issue, I use query variables in some nested part of the expression, as the long error message says.#2017-07-1319:09fmjreyBasically this does not work: 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?type :?name :?data]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor [?type ?name ?data])])
#2017-07-1319:09fmjreyBut this does: 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?d]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor ?d)])
#2017-07-1319:10fmjreyThanks @nickowsy for trying ðŸ™‚#2017-07-1319:13nickowsy:+1:#2017-07-1321:53wparker@fmjrey the params have to be in the query conditions 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?type :?name :?data]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor [?type ?name ?data])])
is trying to use bindings in the Feature condition without creating them#2017-07-1321:53wparkerthe use in the params doesnâ€™t create them, that is for indexing into the query results later#2017-07-1321:55wparkerBasically the query params wonâ€™t make an otherwise-invalid query valid, they just control how youâ€™ll view the data later when using the query results#2017-07-1321:57wparkerSo in the â€œpromotion typeâ€ example in the doc, youâ€™ll provide a type to query for, and youâ€™ll only get results back of that type; without the param youâ€™d get back other types as well#2017-07-1321:57wparkerThis is the key line of code: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1960#2017-07-1323:40dadairIs there a way to react to retractions? I'm using facts to generate tree manipulation functions (i.e., if FactA, AddChildToSomeTree), and want to be able to remove that tree node if the Fact is retracted#2017-07-1400:50dadairSorry I should add that these are automatic retractions of derived/sourced facts#2017-07-1414:54wparker@dadair it sounds like youâ€™re describing truth maintenance so perhaps that will meet your needs http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/#2017-07-1719:31wparkerclara-rules 0.15.2 is released and on Clojars. This was a fix release for a bug in the distinct accumulator.#2017-07-2016:10mishagreetings! What can I read on combining event sourcing with rule engines? Or about any rules<-> (finite) state machines transitions.#2017-07-2422:55wparker@misha you might try the Google Groups mailing list as well, I know some people have considered using Clara for event processing before. Regarding finite state machines, keep in mind that Clara supports arbitrary code, notably in the RHS (consequences) of rules, so the ability to introspect is limited if your application doesnâ€™t add further restrictions.#2017-07-2508:16misha@wparker thanks, will check it out. to have a real life value, FSMs need to support arbitrary code (i/o) execution as part (or as a consequence) of the state's transitions as well, so that comes down to a design decisions in both cases. In the exercise app I am (re)writing now - html5 video/audio tags are basically i/o, as far as the rest of the buttons in UI are concerned, despite those tags being their own FSMs.#2017-07-2621:27wparker@U051HUZLD I was thinking of mainly what types the rules could insert; given an arbitrary set of rules one canâ€™t infer which other rules a given rule could trigger. It is possible to add metadata of some kind specifying this or to parse it if you restrict the RHS code you write to something you can reliably parse. This seemed possibly relevant if you were trying to translate rules to a FSM, specifically w.r.t. the allowed state transitions.#2017-07-2516:08iku000888Is it possible to use protocol methods in the left hand side of rules?#2017-07-2516:09iku000888I have a vague feeling it would violate clara's design but cannot articulate why ðŸ™‚#2017-07-2516:12ryanbrushYes, the LHS supports arbitrary Clojure expressions, including protocol methods.#2017-07-2516:20iku000888Would you be kind to give an example?#2017-07-2516:21iku000888Having trouble wrapping my head around how to refer to the instance showing up in the LHS#2017-07-2516:22iku000888
(defprotocol IFoo
  (test-foo [this]))

(defrule is-foo
  [IFoo (test-foo ?not sure how to express?)]
  =>...)
#2017-07-2516:23iku000888@ryanbrush Thanks for the help in advance ðŸ™‚#2017-07-2516:24ryanbrush@iku000888 Ahh, I thought you meant calling protocol-based methods on the LHS. The type the rules matches needs to be an actual type, either a Java type or a Clojure type via deftype.#2017-07-2516:25ryanbrush(The one exception is customized "types" discussed here, but this probably isn't applicable to your discussion: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/)#2017-07-2516:26ryanbrushOne correction: I meant clojure.core/derive rather than deftype above.#2017-07-2516:26iku000888I think I understand#2017-07-2516:27iku000888Just thought at first glance I could reify a bunch of stuff and passing it through rules would be a usecase#2017-07-2516:28iku000888Thanks for clarifying! Much appreciate your time.#2017-07-2516:28iku000888ðŸ™‡#2017-07-2516:33iku000888
(defprotocol IFoo
  (test-foo [this]))

(deftype Foo []
  IFoo
  (test-foo [this] true))

(defrule is-foo
  [Foo (test-foo ?not sure how to express?)]
  => (println "is a foo"))
#2017-07-2516:33iku000888Wait, so if it is an actual type I can invoke protocol methods?#2017-07-2621:39wparkerHeads up about something potentially tricky: If youâ€™re on the JVM when you create a protocol, behind the scenes Clojure creates a corresponding Java interface of the same name. An interface is a type that you can write rules against, but it might not do what you expect. Only types that Clojure knows satisfy the protocol at the time of their creation will implement the interface. For example:#2017-07-2621:40wparker
` user=> (defprotocol MyProtocol (proto-method [_]))
MyProtocol
user=> (defrecord MyRecord1 [] MyProtocol (proto-method [_] "Hello World"))
user.MyRecord1
user=> (defrecord MyRecord2 [])
user.MyRecord2
user=> (extend-type MyRecord2 MyProtocol (proto-method [_] "Hi World"))
nil
user=> (proto-method (->MyRecord1))
"Hello World"
user=> (proto-method (->MyRecord2))
"Hi World"
user=> (instance? user.MyProtocol (->MyRecord1))
true
user=> (instance? user.MyProtocol (->MyRecord2))
false
`#2017-07-2621:42wparkerIn another ns you could potentially import the interface rather than the protocol depending on how you set up your ns header i.e. import vs require on it#2017-07-2621:43wparker@iku000888#2017-07-2702:07iku000888@wparker thanks! Did not know about that.#2017-07-2516:33iku000888@ryanbrush#2017-07-2516:35ryanbrushYes, if Foo is a type, you should be able to invoke the test-foo protocol method on it like you show.#2017-07-2516:35iku000888(defrule is-foo [Foo (test-foo this)] => (println "is a foo"))#2017-07-2516:36iku000888Works!#2017-07-2516:37iku000888Thanks again and sorry for the noob noise ðŸ™‡#2017-07-2516:37ryanbrushSure thing! I'm glad it works for you.#2017-07-2516:38ryanbrushJust be aware you might have to reload your rules if you redefine the types in a REPL, since the type will change when you do that. ðŸ˜‰#2017-07-2516:38iku000888:+1:#2017-07-2517:07iku000888@ryanbrush blogged about my first glance of clara-rules (for people in Japan) and thanked you there. Hope that is okay.#2017-07-2517:07iku000888http://qiita.com/iku000888/items/72525cd34cd3c0b44b31#2017-07-2518:14ryanbrush@iku000888 Nice! Thanks for blogging about our little project. ðŸ˜‰#2017-07-2616:51iku000888The first impression motivated me to learn more abt clara-rules and thus another blogpost with a personally cooked up example http://qiita.com/iku000888/items/17ad5f7fa2f0da069997#_reference-37f1c943ec03175da6b6#2017-07-2721:07iku000888Man one can write so many blogs out of clara-rules! (This one shows it can be used for cross entity join logic) http://qiita.com/iku000888/items/7bb53bd3af51ea2e9e68#2017-07-2721:09iku000888I am about to start this project with a gigantic hari-bally specification and feel like clara-rules is a great match. Going to explore more!#2017-07-2818:50nickowsyhi, I'm new to clara and I'm having a bit of trouble understanding clara's durability. I'm serialize the data, storing the rule base separately. When I restore everything, insert new facts, and fire-rules...my rules are not running again. Rules fire great if I use the original session. i.e. not the one that was restored. I have been looking at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_durability.clj and my broken test is at https://github.com/nfox2004/clara-durability/blob/master/test/clara_durability_help/core_test.clj. Any suggestions would be awesome! thanks#2017-07-2819:38wparker@nickowsy from a quick glance over your test I see your original session has a custom :fact-type-fn. Youâ€™ll need to supply the same :fact-type-fn that the original function had when deserializing the rulebase. See the 2-argument version of deserialize-rulebase: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/durability.clj#L653#2017-07-2819:38wparkerSo something like (deserialize-rulebase session-serializer {:fact-type-fn your-fact-type-function})#2017-07-2819:41wparkerThe reason it is that way is that arbitrary Clojure function objects arenâ€™t serializable, so you have to either impose some kind of restriction on the functions used that gives you serializability or require the user to handle it; we went with the latter#2017-07-2820:11nickowsy@wparker thanks a ton! makes total sense ðŸ™‚#2017-07-2823:01dadairNot sure if this question goes against the design of fact-based systems, but is there a way to "update" a fact? That is, say we insert ->Fact x, and then we insert ->Fact y, is it possible to only get a single Fact with updated value y in a query?#2017-07-2823:05dadairconcrete example: 
(-> (handle test-file test-action) (r/query fields-for :?formRef "/forms/aae-form"))
=>
({:?formRef "/forms/aae-form",
  :?fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
  :?field #{#justice.rules.forms.FormField{:formRef "/forms/aae-form",
                                           :fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
                                           :descriptor {:type "VALUE",
                                                        :valueType "STRING",
                                                        :value "foo",
                                                        :constraints {:minLength 1, :required true}}}
            #justice.rules.forms.FormField{:formRef "/forms/aae-form",
                                           :fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
                                           :descriptor {:type "VALUE",
                                                        :valueType "STRING",
                                                        :value "",
                                                        :constraints {:minLength 1, :required true}}}}})
I'd like the query to return all FormField's with unique :fieldRef; so in the above example if I update the :descriptor :value from "" to "foo", I only want the single fact returned#2017-07-2916:09zyloxGenerational data is kind of tricky. I think you could do what you want though (assuming im understanding) if, externally, you have some way to track "newest", having some sort of version field (whether this is datetime or incremented or whatever). Then, in the rules network, have an accumulator for the "newest" value of that field, and insert ->NewestFact and then depend on that instead. Logical retractions should take care of the rest. @dadair#2017-07-2916:11zyloxi just realized you probably meant internal insertions not external.#2017-07-2916:14zyloxif its internal (so inserting on the rhs), thats trickier because in my experience execution order dependent rules get you in trouble real quick, and without that i'm not sure how you would know what fact is "newer". If your goal is actually whatever fact has the most fields populated, you could still do a check on that in the accumulator, or probably better with rules with checks on the fields you care about.#2017-08-0500:24mrchanceHi! Is it possible to cause side effects when a fact gets retracted by the truth maintenance mechanism? I am building something that builds a network of core.async pipes and am thinking about establishing and severing connections based on Clara facts.#2017-08-0522:28mikerod@mrchance could you just make a :not style â€œnegation ruleâ€ to logically handle the condition you are going for?#2017-08-0522:29mikerodWhatever you are wanting to monitor for being logically retracted via truth maintenance. It seems you should be able to make an explicit rule looking for that situation#2017-08-0522:35mikerodHowever, this side-effect of severing connections would certainly have to be resilient to any issues of being executed multiple times on the RHS. donâ€™t rely on it only being â€œcalled onceâ€#2017-08-0600:34mrchance@mikerod hm, ok. Idempotency shouldn't be an issue, good hint though. Gonna try that, although I am not 100% clear on how you mean that. In my use case, there would be rules that produce a [Linked a b] fact which would call something like core.async/pipe on a and b, only it returns something that can be called or closed when the respective Linked fact goes away in order to sever the connection again. How would I address that using :not rules?#2017-08-0600:37mrchanceClara is awesome btw. ! Played with it a bit more in the meantime#2017-08-0600:42mikerod@mrchance an alternative that comes to mind is to hook into Claraâ€™s listeners to try to watch for the particular retraction you are interested in. However, Iâ€™d probably say it is best if that isnâ€™t necessary.#2017-08-0600:42mikerodI hate to suggest things like insert-unconditional! but I see an approach with that at leastâ€¦#2017-08-0600:43mikerodIâ€™d like to think of something better though#2017-08-0600:43mrchanceYeah, I saw the ns in the docs and thought about that#2017-08-0600:43mikeroddemo:#2017-08-0600:45mikerod
(defrule makes-chan
  [?a <- A]
  [?b <- B]
  =>
  (let [chan (somehow-make it)]
    ;; Not sure what you do with `chan` here
    (r/insert! (->LogicalThing ?a ?b))
    (r/insert-unconditional! (->OpenedChan chan))))

(defrule closes-chan
  [:not [LogicalThing]]
  [?oc <- OpenedChan (= ?chan chan)]
  =>
  (r/retract! ?oc)
  (close-the ?chan))
#2017-08-0600:46mikerodI think it just gets sort of dirty when you are managing your own unconditional facts and retracts - typically a pattern to avoid#2017-08-0600:47mikerodnot sure how prevalent this would be for you though in terms of managing it. also, not positive my solution is really a solution to the issue at all#2017-08-0600:47mrchanceOk, I can see what you're getting at, but I agree it looks suboptimal#2017-08-0600:47mikerodClara has a listener protocol you can attach onto#2017-08-0600:47mikerodand I believe you can find the relevant retract events there#2017-08-0600:47mikerodnot sure there have been docs posted up on that#2017-08-0600:48mrchanceNot many, from what I browsed yet ðŸ˜‰#2017-08-0600:48mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/listener.cljc#2017-08-0600:49mikerodThe ITransientEventListener#2017-08-0600:50mikerodeven when looking at this though, I think it is perhaps opaque which retraction youâ€™d want to listen to#2017-08-0600:50mrchanceHm, maybe. I'll give it a try#2017-08-0600:50mikerodI believe (retract-facts! [listener facts]) & (retract-facts-logical! [listener node token facts]) would have the info#2017-08-0600:51mikerodretract-facts! I believe is retracts from the RHS and retract-facts-logical! is retracts from truth maintenance#2017-08-0600:51mikerodother â€œretractâ€ things I believe are more internal node-to-node activity#2017-08-0600:51mrchanceAh, ok#2017-08-0600:52mrchanceThanks! I'll test it #2017-08-0600:53mikerod(mk-session rules :listeners [my-listener-impl])#2017-08-0600:53mrchanceI think there is some big potential here, like a completely reactive description of stateful systems, something that's always awful when it moves past what e.g. component can handle #2017-08-0600:53mrchanceThat's simple enough ðŸ˜‰ #2017-08-0600:54mikerodyeah, it isnâ€™t actually documented on mk-session, not sure why. I donâ€™t think those nsâ€™s are really called â€œexperimentalâ€ around this at this point#2017-08-0600:56mikerodthe only thing Iâ€™m concerned about is if you do not impl all the functions of the protocol#2017-08-0600:56mikerodI canâ€™t remember if you have to â€œpadâ€ those with a no-op in some way#2017-08-0600:56mrchanceTypical case of documentation not growing as fast as its software#2017-08-0600:56mrchanceShouldn't be a problem, it's a one time thing so some boilerplate is no issue#2017-08-0600:57mikerodthere is the clara.rules.listener/default-listener though#2017-08-0600:57mikerodyou could just delegate everything else through that#2017-08-0600:57mikerodbut itâ€™s just a no-op#2017-08-0600:57mikerodyeah, idk. That could be done with some wrappers in your code around the session along the lines of â€œQuery the session, store the results, insert/retract facts, fire the rules, then query again and diff the resultsâ€. It could be done as a Clara listener too by tracking on the listening calls in QueryNode: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.15.2/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L430#2017-08-0605:22wparkerIt is functionality that I think would be useful for Clara itself to provide at some point, a listener to do that would probably get into Claraâ€™s internal impl details somewhat e.g. â€œis this node a QueryNode?â€ logic. Wouldnâ€™t matter if it was part of Clara and tested there though.#2017-08-0613:10mrchance@wparker True, that's another way to look at it. This might work too. Your answer also makes me wonder if Datascript would be the better choice for this usecase though, since there you get the transaction logs anyway#2017-08-0714:03wparkerI havenâ€™t had occasion to use DataScript, but it also seems like something that could be useful for a use-case like what you describe @mrchance . I suspect much depends on what the simplest way to model the logic you have in mind is and what performance characteristics youâ€™re looking for.#2017-08-0717:20mrchanceYes, it all depends on the details. From the FactUi readme it looks like they took a bit from both worlds as well#2017-08-0702:00mikerod https://github.com/arachne-framework/factui Looks like more fun with rules (and Clara)#2017-08-1310:20olivergeorgeI'm interested in how Clara (or rule engines more generally) would work in an environment where a relational database is used as the repository of all information.#2017-08-1310:20olivergeorgeI'm only learning about this stuff so I could be missing something obvious.#2017-08-1310:22olivergeorgePerhaps the key is not letting anyone directly write to the database which would bypassing the rule engine causing it to get out of sync with reality.#2017-08-1310:23olivergeorgeA simple "typical architecture" might answer my question.#2017-08-1319:51hagmonkCan anyone explain why the following case doesn't do what I expect?#2017-08-1319:52hagmonk
(let [matched    (dsl/parse-rule
                   [[:eav
                     (= ?attribute (:attribute this))
                     (= ?attribute_value (:attribute_value this))
                     (= ?id (:id this))]]
                   (insert! {:type ?attribute :id ?id :value ?attribute_value}))

      unscreened (dsl/parse-rule
                   [[:state
                     (= (:value this) 2)
                     (= ?id (:id this))]
                    [:milestone
                     (= (:value this) -1)
                     (= ?id (:id this))]]
                   (insert! {:type :unscreened :id ?id}))

      type-query (dsl/parse-query [] [[?unscreened <- :unscreened]])

      session    (mk-session [matched unscreened type-query] :fact-type-fn :type :cache false)]
  (time (-> session
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :state :attribute_value 2 :id 33695360})
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :milestone :attribute_value -1 :id 33695360})
            fire-rules
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :milestone :attribute_value 123456 :id 33695360})
            fire-rules
            (query type-query))))
#2017-08-1319:52hagmonkI insert two facts which cause a third fact of type :unscreened to be inserted#2017-08-1319:53hagmonkI then fire the rules, and insert another fact which should negate the earlier fact#2017-08-1319:53hagmonkInstead, when I query the session for :unscreened, I see that fact still present#2017-08-1415:18curtis.shaffer@olivergeorge authorization on the database is something that can be done; certain databases (Oracle is the one that comes to mind) support triggers which you could use to detect changes#2017-08-1415:22curtis.shaffer@hagmonk as far as I can tell, all three of those facts will still be in the session; the 3rd fact insertion does not negate the 2nd fact insertion. the :id field makes me think that you want it to be an update, which is not what is done#2017-08-1415:38zylox@hagmonk What Curtis said. You could use an accumlator to grab the highest valued :milestone fact. or if you are looking for all non negative, you could add a :not constraint. Depends on what you are looking for.#2017-08-1417:50wparker@olivergeorge it might help if you can clarify your question. From Claraâ€™s point of view, it doesnâ€™t matter what the ultimate source of the data it processes is. Note though that if rules do things that depend on ordering you have to be careful since Clara can fire and then retract a rule; the contract when using truth maintenance is that the state of the rules engine works out before fire-rules returns. But if you, say, performed operations on a database in a rule RHS youâ€™d have to be careful about controlling rule ordering with salience etc. Our workflows typically involve something retrieving data, providing the data to Clara, firing the rules, querying the resulting session, and then saving the query results - does that help?#2017-08-1504:38olivergeorgeYes thanks. That makes sense. #2017-08-1513:44souenzzoI can/I should run a query inside a rule? (query the "self")#2017-08-1515:03mikerod@souenzzo it isnâ€™t clear to me what you are trying to do#2017-08-1515:03mikerodCurrently you canâ€™t run a query directly from within a rule#2017-08-1515:03mikerodbut itâ€™d probably be good to have some sort of example of what you are trying to accomplish or thinking about#2017-08-1515:06souenzzoI was trying to run a query on "right side" of a defrule. But I already find another solution.#2017-08-1720:07ennCan an accumulator accumulate across more than one fact type (joined on some field)? All of the examples show only a single fact type in the :from clause.#2017-08-1722:20wparker@enn Strictly speaking no, but with a custom ancestors fn you can create a new type that is the parent of multiple types for whatever fact types youâ€™re working with#2017-08-1722:21wparkerSame goes for other condition types as well#2017-08-1722:21wparkere.g. if you have FactTypeA and FactTypeB, you can make FactTypeC a parent of both#2017-08-1722:22wparkerthen [?facts <- (acc/all) :from [FactTypeC (â€¦)]] would accumulate on both FactTypeA and FactTypeC#2017-08-1722:22wparkersee http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/ for more info#2017-08-1722:45ennInteresting.#2017-08-1722:45ennI hadnâ€™t thought of that approach.#2017-08-1722:47wparkerEdit: â€œwould accumulate on both FactTypeA and FactTypeBâ€#2017-08-1804:51iku000888Has anyone tried using clara-rules via a self hosted cljs compiler?#2017-08-1804:52iku000888I run into errors like this#2017-08-1804:52iku000888
