#2017-08-1804:53iku000888I was testing out calvin and have a pretty tiny repro, if there is interest.#2017-08-1805:11iku000888https://github.com/iku000888/tiny-samples/tree/master/node-and-cljs#2017-08-1815:28wparker@iku000888 supporting self-hosted ClojureScript in Clara isnâ€™t something weâ€™ve looked at to my knowledge, and I would anticipate that changes would need to be made to support it. If anyone has gotten that to work it would be interesting to know though. From the looks of your errors Schema has some problems with self-hosted ClojureScript as well, so there might need to be changes there as well for self-hosted CLJS Clara to work. Feel free to log an issue to Clara and anyone who wants to look at what that would take is welcome to do so. It would be nice to have, it just hasnâ€™t been a priority. I canof how Schema would approach any problems with self-hosted ClojureScript in their codebase,#2017-08-1815:29wparkerI canâ€™t speak to how Schema would approach any problems with self-hosted ClojureScript in their codebase, and I donâ€™t know if there have been any previous discussions on the subject, but in my observation theyâ€™ve been pretty open to PRs, issues, etc. in the past#2017-08-1815:30iku000888@wparker thanks for the feedback!#2017-08-1815:31iku000888Will log an issue on the clara repo and schema (after checking they have an issue on self host)#2017-08-1815:32iku000888Would be super cool if self host support lands though, just saying ðŸ™‚#2017-08-1815:42iku000888https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/337#2017-08-1815:42iku000888@wparker Is there is anything else I can provide?#2017-08-1815:49wparkerthat works thanks @iku000888#2017-08-1815:49iku000888Thanks again!#2017-08-1815:52wparkerThere would need to be some changes to Clara as well for this, not just Schema. A quick one that jumps out is that clara.rules.compiler is a clj file and has a java.beans.PropertyDescriptor import#2017-08-1815:52wparkerhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L1#2017-08-1815:52wparkerThatâ€™s the compiler from rules/queries to an executable structure#2017-08-1820:52mikerod@enn Iâ€™ll add on more possibility to this: > Can an accumulator accumulate across more than one fact type (joined on some field)? All of the examples show only a single fact type in the :from clause. You can also â€œwrapâ€ multiple types of facts in a common fact type and accumulate instead on that.#2017-08-1820:52mikerodwithout a need of actually creating a real ancestor, hierarchical change#2017-08-1820:55mikerod
(defrecord CommonWrap [wrapped])

(r/defrule wrap-fact-a
[?a <- FactA]
=>
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?a)))

(r/defrule wrap-fact-b
[?b <- FactB]
=>
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?b)))


(r/defrule accum-them
[?acc <- my-accumulator :from [CommonWrap]]
<etc>
=>
<rhs>)
#2017-08-1820:56mikerodthe accumulator could just access the original, field â€œxâ€, like (-> w :wrapped :x)#2017-08-1820:56mikerodor you could make it have the same fields as the original even with 
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?a))
#2017-08-1820:58mikerod> There would need to be some changes to Clara as well for this, not just Schema. Yeah, I think clara.rules.compiler would probably require the most work on self-hosting#2017-08-1820:58mikerod(aside from schema breaking clara anyways)#2017-08-1820:59mikerodunless there is a way to just not use the schema on the self-host side#2017-08-1820:59mikerodI think technically, the schema are just used for testing and documentation purposes#2017-08-1820:59mikerodbut wouldnâ€™t be too trivial I donâ€™t think still#2017-08-1820:59mikerodAlso, the â€œdurabilityâ€ feature of Clara would likely have trouble#2017-08-1821:00mikerodbut may not be needed anyways and probably could just be skipped for that sort of build#2017-08-2120:37souenzzoHow to test [:test (is-it-possible? ?foo ?bar)]??#2017-08-2216:11wparkerI donâ€™t understand your question - could you clarify?#2017-08-2218:43souenzzoI find out that (= ?foo ?bar) isn't a function. For now I'm using [?res <- (my-fn? ?foo ?bar)] [:test (= ?res true)]#2017-08-2219:51souenzzoI'm having trouble with: lein test - pass all my tests *on repl* - I can test multiple times and get ok, but when I reload the rules namespace, all rules behavior change (my test fail) How to debug?#2017-08-2313:38ryanbrush@souenzzo There are a couple pitfalls on the that can happen. One is that the rule session is being cached, so you're re-running previous rules. This can be turned off by passing :cache false to mk-session as described at http://www.clara-rules.org/apidocs/0.15.2/clojure/clara.rules.html#var-mk-session#2017-08-2313:39ryanbrushThe other pitfall that can happen is if you're reloading your fact types, the reloaded types may be a different class than what Clara was compiled against, so the facts won't match.#2017-08-2313:39ryanbrushThis can also be addressed by not caching the rules session as described above, or by placing the fact types in a namespace that isn't reloaded in your REPL.#2017-08-2313:40ryanbrushOf course, this only applies if you're using the Java or Clojure type system for your facts (which is the default) rather than using a custom fact type.#2017-08-2314:12souenzzoAlready tryied with :cache false, :cache true...#2017-08-2314:12souenzzoI will try to move defrecord to another ns#2017-08-2314:29souenzzoOh. I noticed that my problems started when I started importing records in different namespaces. (still moving to test if records in a "standalone" ns will solve)#2017-08-2314:46souenzzofixed. @ryanbrush clara docs should contains this info.#2017-08-2319:25mikerod@souenzzo Just to add to this conversation: This does sound like something that may be a good idea to point out in some sort of Clara docs, especially concerning development time. However, records getting redefined I think is often at odds with a dynamic repl reloading workflow. I donâ€™t think Clara is the only place affected.#2017-08-2319:27mikerodNot to suggest to use this lib or not, just to point out Iâ€™ve seen the same concern addressed before https://github.com/ztellman/potemkin/blob/0.4.4/src/potemkin/types.clj#L326#2017-08-2319:28mikerodAt one point Plumatic (formerly prismatic) Schema actually defaulted to using potemkins defrecord+ to avoid recreated classes with the same name, that have no impl change, in a new dynamic classloader during (probably repl) reloads#2017-08-2319:29mikerod(still exists in schema now, but as an â€œoptionalâ€ dependency https://github.com/plumatic/schema/blob/schema-1.1.6/src/clj/schema/potemkin.clj)#2017-08-2319:30mikerodIâ€™m just pointing this out because in the past I used this â€œnon reloadingâ€ style of defrecord to avoid weird issues with a record class getting reloading, with references still around to the old version of the class#2017-08-2319:30mikerodyou can get away with moving record definitions into some namespace you are careful to not :reload though#2017-08-2319:31mikerodas long as you donâ€™t want to do something like :reload-all#2017-08-2319:32souenzzoThere is a document about repl development https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Using-Clara-from-the-REPL just add a mention/reference/tip about "be warning on reload types/records across namespaces".#2017-08-2319:33mikerodnice#2017-08-2320:28dadairIs it possible to specify multiple namespaces for mk-session? I have rules organized across a couple namespaces (to guarantee zero collaboration between two distinct rule sets that use common facts), and want to share common queries in a shared namespace. I've tried both (mk-session 'ns.one 'ns.shared) and (mk-session ['ns.one 'ns.shared]) and get a query invalid or not in rule base error for the shared queries#2017-08-2321:24wparkerExample of such usage: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L1144#2017-08-2320:32souenzzo(mk-session 'full-ns.name 'full-ns.name2) works for me#2017-08-2320:38dadairseams to be working now ðŸ˜• shrug#2017-08-2320:38dadairmust have had some weird REPL state#2017-08-2507:54iku000888Not sure how I can express this, but is there a way to express a left-join type of a rule?#2017-08-2513:44mikerod@iku000888 Iâ€™m thinking youâ€™d probably write 2 rules in that case#2017-08-2513:44mikerodor do some of the joining on the RHS - which I often hesitate to think is a good idea#2017-08-2513:45mikerod
(r/defrule joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))

(r/defrule nil-joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:not [B (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))
#2017-08-2513:45mikerodis that the â€œleft joinâ€ sort of thing?#2017-08-2513:46mikerodA always produce a C, just sometimes there is no B to go with an A#2017-08-2513:46mikerodC can hold whatever info you wanted out of the join#2017-08-2800:26iku000888@mikerod Thanks! I was struggling because for this specific problem coming up it was not clear how to create facts that are [:not [B (= ?id id)]]#2017-08-2800:27iku000888(I would only have facts that are [B (= ?id id)])#2017-08-2800:28iku000888But over the weekend I thought of retracting A's that do have a matching B#2017-08-2800:28iku000888Seems it should do the job#2017-08-2800:28iku000888ðŸ™‚#2017-08-2917:20dadairI have a shared entry point into a rule session where a namespace associated with specific rules/queries can be applied: 
(defn run-rules
  "Runs a rule session given a rule namespace, a root state tree node, and a performed action."
  [ns root action]
  (let [session (-> (r/mk-session 'justice.rules.shared ns)
                    (r/insert (->Tree (walk/prewalk tree/augment-if-node root))
                              (->Action action))
                    (r/fire-rules))]
  ...
However, I get a No namespace exception when I pass a namespace in eg. (run-rules 'justice.rules.x ..). I've "fixed" the issue by adding (require ns) inside run-rules, but is there a better way to accomplish this? I could for example just require the namespaces in the ns declaration, or I could have a whitelist of namespaces to require, but I'd like to keep adding new namespaces to be as simple as creating a new namespace and passing it in to the generic shared entrypoint.#2017-08-2919:21mikerod> Thanks! I was struggling because for this specific problem coming up it was not clear how to create facts that are [:not [B (= ?id id)]] @iku000888 sorry for long delay, just saw your response. Iâ€™m not sure what you mean to create a fact to match a negation (ie condition with a :not). The negation condition is used in conjuction with the [A (= ?id id)] in my example. This together forms a â€œjoinâ€ sort of query for all A that do not have a matching B. So back to that example, repeating for clarity: 
(r/defrule joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))

(r/defrule nil-joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:not [B (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))
The rule names may not be the best, but sticking with them: * The rule joins is for the typical â€œinner joinâ€ matches - it matches A with Bs they go with * The rule nil-joins is for the â€œouter leftâ€ part of the join - it keeps the A results that do not have any actual join with a B This may not be the specific issue you had, but that was my interpretation of your â€œleft-joinâ€ type of rule question. Given that you have something with retraction working, Iâ€™m thinking this is a different problem you are wanting to solve.#2017-08-2919:22mikerod@dadair Clojure or ClojureScript?#2017-08-2919:25mikerodEither way though, r/mk-session doesnâ€™t attempt to require namespace for you.#2017-08-2919:25mikerodIâ€™m not positive that would be a great idea either. Best practice in clj would be to be sure to appropriately declare the namespace you want to have compiled - most preferably in the ns header :requires#2017-08-2919:26mikerodYou could get away with a dynamic require call in your run-rules though. Iâ€™ve had use-cases doing that before to load rules from arbitrary namespaces#2017-08-2919:26mikerodI donâ€™t think there is a â€œbetter way to accomplish itâ€ though in terms of what Clara currently offers.#2017-08-2919:26mikerodIt expects things to already be compiled#2017-08-2919:40dadair@mikerod thanks, this would be regular clojure. I've moved away from dynamic require, as it was adding unnecessary compilation overhead (in terms of performance). I'm still using a ns-whitelist var though rather than using the (ns .. (:require ..)) form as I've had some formatters remove the references as they are "unused".#2017-08-2919:41mikerodYeah, if you wait to do a require in the fn, it could be a pretty big slowdown depending on the size of it#2017-08-2919:42mikerodand perhaps could be better suited at â€œcompilation timeâ€ with whatever else you have to start up the app#2017-08-2919:42mikerodNot to get too lost in the weeds, but Clara does have a few other alternatives instead of loading whole nsâ€™s of rules#2017-08-2919:45mikerodFor example, you can provide collections of rules to r/mk-session 
(defrule r1 <etc>)
(defrule r2 <etc>)
(defrule r3 <etc>)

(def rule-group1 [r1 r2 r3])

(defrule r4 <etc>)
(defrule r5 <etc>)
(defquery q1 <etc>)

(def rule-group2 [r4 r5 q1])

(defrule r6 <etc>)


<....>

(r/mk-session rule-group1 rule-group2 [r6])
#2017-08-3018:24wparker@dadair Agreed with @mikerod â€˜s previous comments. I wanted to add that namespace compilation can have arbitrary effects in Clojure; one notable one is protocol extensions. That is, a linter removing namespace whose vars you arenâ€™t directly using from your requires could be dangerous to things other than Clara. Also, note that require will short-circuits if the namespace already exists unless you specifically request reloading, so the performance question is really whether you pay the cost at initialization of your Clojure environment or the first time you build the relevant session.#2017-08-2919:46mikerodso you can pick in choose at different granularities is my point#2017-08-3017:38mmerHi I am a newbie who is looking to use clara to help understand large nested maps. Is there an easy way to turn a large nested map into a series of facts?#2017-08-3018:27wparker@U4C3ZU6KX Not quite sure what your use-case is, but it seems like you could just use the normal map manipulation functions in clojure.core to create a â€œderivedâ€ sequence of facts to insert. Perhaps just a recursive function that concatenates the facts at each nested level of the map/level of recursion?#2017-08-3116:22dadairis it safe to call insert! from different threads? e.g., within a future? I have a way to not need this (e.g., gather data with the future and then insert! from the main thread), I'm more just curious.#2017-08-3117:42mikerod@dadair I think that is a sort of tough question#2017-08-3117:42mikerodIt seems dangerous to assume semantically#2017-08-3117:43mikerodI do think that implementation-wise, as long as every thread has fully completed their r/insert! prior to r/fire-rules it may work#2017-08-3117:43mikerodThat isnâ€™t to say I think it is a supported use-case#2017-08-3117:43mikerodSo in general, during the â€œfire rules loopâ€ cycle of the rules engine, the memory is in a mutable state#2017-08-3117:44mikerodThis is done primarily for performance. The caller perceives the working memory to be a persistent, immutable data structure that is returned after each call to r/fire-rules on a given sesion#2017-08-3117:45mikerodHowever, r/insert! (and a few other similar ones) is called from rule RHSâ€™s. That means it is sort of in that â€œfire rules loopâ€ part of the lifecycle#2017-08-3117:50dadairyeah that makes sense, I thought as much#2017-08-3121:07souenzzoaccumulators respect saliency?#2017-08-3123:00wparker@souenzzo salience controls when a rule RHS (right-hand side, or consequence in other terms) fires; whether an accumulator is in the rule doesnâ€™t impact it either way. It wonâ€™t control the time you actually run the accumulator, though Iâ€™m not sure why youâ€™d want to do that.#2017-09-0114:31mikerodWell, I know Drools (popular Java-based rules engine)(prior to v6) used to have a good amount of performance issues around accumulators.#2017-09-0114:31mikerodEspecially several in a rule#2017-09-0114:31mikerodso people used to wish that salience would â€œdelayâ€ their evaluation#2017-09-0114:32mikerodLater on, a lot of laziness was added to Drools, but even more importantly (in my opinion) â€œbatchedâ€ propagations of facts and it mostly solved the common issues around performance that came up.#2017-09-0114:32mikerodClara has â€œbatchedâ€ propagation of facts, which seems to typically work out well. The engine basically â€œgathersâ€ up collections of facts at a time that are matching conditions before propagating down the network. This results in typically less churn/rework as the data flows.#2017-09-0114:33mikerodJust pointing that out if the question of salience was more about performance than ordering semantics#2017-09-0118:01dadairI'm not sure if this is directly tied to clara, but I am noticing a severe processing time drop the first time I run a rules session with a specific namespace. So for example, (-> (r/mk-session 'some.ns) (r/insert ..) .. (r/fire-rules)) takes 1000ms the first time it is called, but 50ms the second time. Is there some way I can reduce that first performance hit?#2017-09-0118:02dadairI know I need to profile the app to be sure what's going on, just darn jprofiler is too expensive >.<#2017-09-0119:00mikerod@dadair well, you can use visualvm for free#2017-09-0119:00mikerodwhich Iâ€™ve had enough luck with when profiling rules before#2017-09-0119:01mikerodOh, r/mk-session creates and then caches the rulebase (Rete graph)#2017-09-0119:01mikerodCan you (r/mk-session 'some.ns) sometime earlier - like â€œstartupâ€?#2017-09-0119:02mikerodYouâ€™ll still take the hit though. Just maybe you could move the hit out of the processing where it is more painful.#2017-09-0119:34dadairawesome thank you, that will solve my issues (and thanks for the nudge at visualvm, looks good too!)#2017-09-0119:39dadair@mikerod if I different collections of ns (i.e., (r/mk-session 'ns.a 'ns.b 'ns.c) vs (r/mk-session 'ns.d 'ns.e 'ns.f) can I pre-cache individual namespaces e.g. (r/mk-session 'ns.a)? Or would I have to pre-cache full collections (r/mk-session 'ns.a 'ns.b 'ns.c)? Basically, can I init each individually, if they are used in collections? Or will it only cache on the full collection.#2017-09-0120:05mikerod@dadair glad you can work with that. Building the rulebase graph can be a fairly expensive operation. It could perhaps be further optimized in Clara, but there are tricky aspects.#2017-09-0120:05mikerodFor one, there is some eval going on, which means it is running the clj compiler and I often see that time dominate for larger rulebaseâ€™s#2017-09-0120:06mikerod(terminology things: the â€œrulebaseâ€ term just means the underlying â€œstatessâ€ Rete-based graph that is wired together with working memory within the â€œsessionâ€)#2017-09-0120:06mikerodTo answer your next question, you have to build the r/mk-session with all rules/queries involved at once#2017-09-0120:06mikerodCanâ€™t build piece-by-piece#2017-09-0121:56dadairok great thank you @mikerod#2017-09-0620:03mmerHi there - very simple question - what is the best way to insert a list of records? I am banging my head against a wall - hence the request for help#2017-09-0620:08enn@mmer see insert-all!#2017-09-0620:09mmerI tried that and when I look at the trace it is not inserting anything?#2017-09-0620:12wparker@mmer are you doing this insertion from outside the session or in a rule right-hand side (consequence)?#2017-09-0620:14mmerThe problem is that I have a function returning a lazySeq and that is preventing it from being loaded! Thanks -not a clara issue at all.#2017-09-0620:31wparker:+1: just for completeness - the ! variants are to be used in rules, the variants without ! are to be used outside the session#2017-09-0622:39mmerThanks - I got it working - highly nested maps caught me out along with laziness.#2017-09-0622:40mmerI do have another question - in the [:test] block what expressions can be used. For example is the following valid?#2017-09-0622:40mmerI seem to be getting a NullPointer error.#2017-09-0622:53mmerThe reason for the NullPointer was that I was passing nil into :test.#2017-09-0704:57dadairIs there any reason why a LHS such as [A (= ?x x)] [B (= ?y y)] where x and y definitely exist (non-nil), would not fire with the order [A ..] [B ..] but would fire with [B ..] [A ..]?#2017-09-0713:42mikerod@dadair I donâ€™t see how it should be different. Do you have a more complete rule example?#2017-09-0713:42mikerodJust to be sure you donâ€™t have any extra constructs in play?#2017-09-0714:53wparker@dadair @U0LK1552A I wouldnâ€™t expect that kind of ordering to make a difference for non-accumulator rule conditions normally. If you are using manual retractions in rule RHSâ€™s (right-hand-sides) you might be able to get yourself into some odd situations with undefined behavior that could be impacted. A more concrete reproducing example would be helpful to see if thereâ€™s a bug. For accumulators, it isnâ€™t the easiest edge case to hit, but https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/218 is outstanding.#2017-09-0714:54wparkerAlso, regarding your example 
`[A (= ?x x)] [B (= ?y y)]
` I wouldnâ€™t actually expect whether x or y is nil to impact whether the rule fires at least based on those conditions alone#2017-09-0714:56wparkerthose arenâ€™t result bindings, having a field value of a fact be nil (but the fact itself being nil) is a reasonable possibility and Clara will handle that#2017-09-0715:03mikerodYep, thatâ€™s the reason was asking for more details to be sure there arenâ€™t things like accumulators in play. Things get more complicated then.#2017-09-0716:20dadairThere seemed to be an issue with using a pre-cached rule session. I was looping through some known mk-session configurations and swapping them into an atom so I could avoid the first performance hit. Then later I'd pull the specific session out of the atom and would insert some facts and fire rules. For some reason this was causing really weird rule activation problems#2017-09-0716:21dadairSo for now I've inlined the mk-session and am taking the performance hit until I can figure out what was going on#2017-09-0714:03mmerCould someone please explain the rhs please - I have put a print and an insert! following on from each other on the rhs and the print always happens even if the rule fails?#2017-09-0714:12mikerod@mmer The most typical way to structure rules is in a way that they logically express their constraints, but do not necessarily have a guaranteed order the RHS may fire in. insert! inserts facts that are subject to the â€œtruth maintenance systemâ€ (aka the TMS) of the rules engine. If a rule fires at some point due to a, potentially transient, match of some facts, but later some of those facts are retracted, the engine will automatically retract the facts that relied on that match being present.#2017-09-0714:12mikerodWhen you do a side-effect like a print, there is no way to â€œretractâ€ the side effect#2017-09-0714:14mikerodThere are ways to structure rules that would prevent them from being able to ever fire their RHS â€œearlyâ€. This can be done with setting up the rule to not be able to fire due to some â€œblockingâ€ or â€œguardingâ€ criteria in the LHS that you know will not change itâ€™s truthiness later. Also, you can sometimes do some tricks with :salience. However, in many cases, the best idea may be to just avoid the side-effects in the RHS and perhaps do them outside of the rules based on the facts that are found via queries after performing a fire-rules cycle.#2017-09-0714:15mikerodThere is some documentation on the TMS @ http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/#2017-09-0714:25mmerThat helps. I thought I was going mad!#2017-09-0714:36mikerod@mmer yeah, it can be a tricky detail#2017-09-0714:38mmerThe docs say you can nest the boolean operators [:not, :or] etc. I have tried to do something like [:not [:or [] []] without much success. Is this just plain wrong on my part?#2017-09-0714:56mikerod@mmer things can get a little tricky with that#2017-09-0714:57mikerodSo it is good to note that :or is sort of â€œsyntactic sugarâ€ in rules#2017-09-0714:57mikerodIt can almost be thought of as just splitting the rule into 2 (or more depending on logic in use) rules#2017-09-0714:59mikerode.g. 
(r/defrule with-or
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:or
   [B (= ?id id)]
   [C (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))
Is similar to just writing 
(r/defrule side-one
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))

(r/defrule side-two
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [C (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))
#2017-09-0714:59mikerodThe point in that case is that there isnâ€™t something like â€œshort-circuitingâ€#2017-09-0715:00mikerodand the :or has certain variable visibility issues due to how that works out#2017-09-0715:00mikerodWhen it comes to :not + :or and/or nested :and, it may also be good to note that the engine will convert to DNF (disjunctive normal form)#2017-09-0715:00mikerodThere may be some variable visibility issues in that transition in certain complex cases#2017-09-0715:13mikerod@mmer but if you have an example that demonstrates an issue you are seeing, itâ€™d be probably clearer to just look at that one and explain what is going on#2017-09-0715:14mmerI have eventually just split the rules in two so I do not need the not#2017-09-0715:21mikerodsometimes it is clearer to split things up from an comprehension perspective anyways#2017-09-0715:24mikerodProbably the most details on this subject can be found in the lengthy old issue comments @ https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/149#2017-09-0715:24mikerodas far as some of the transformations that happen#2017-09-0715:25mikerodOnly if you were interesting in details though. ðŸ˜› Probably not super easy to read through.#2017-09-0715:44mmerThanks#2017-09-0716:04mmerTo be more precise - when I load up the rules/queries into the session I get :#2017-09-0716:04mmerExceptionInfo Value does not match schema: {:constraints [(not ("s-expression" ?composition)) (not ("s-expression" a-clojure.lang.Symbol))]} schema.core/validator/fn--1296 (core.clj:155)#2017-09-0716:22wparker@mmer that looks like a syntax error in a rule/query#2017-09-0716:05mmerWhat sort of thing am I looking for in my rule etc?#2017-09-0716:58mikerodItâ€™s hard to decipher without the actual rule DSL that was written (probably could be improved in Clara to try to capture that better) There is probably some missing [ ] if not just having syntax out of order#2017-09-1214:11dadairI have a singleton fact that I insert for referencing that contains a large map (hundreds of KB), and is a part of the LHS of most of my rules, so that the RHS can use the map when inserting more rules. Are there any performance issues to consider here? Or ways to exploit the fact that it is a singleton and will never need to be compared between multiple instances? I know with persistent structures it isn't inefficient to have the large map in multiple places, but was wondering last night if perhaps there was a better way to reference it. The LHS query for it is dead simple: [Tree (= ?root root)] in all cases#2017-09-1216:49mikerod@dadair I donâ€™t know of anything particularly harmful in the big fact like that#2017-09-1216:50mikerodItâ€™s probably best to make sure it has a â€œtypeâ€ that is distinct from anything else#2017-09-1216:50mikerodbeyond that, assuming it is immutable (as facts should be), a cached hashcode may become important#2017-09-1216:51mikerodClojure persistent maps cache hashcode#2017-09-1216:52mikerodYou could also consider wrapping the big map in a custom type that optimizes equality checking and hashing too if you had noticeable perf issues come up#2017-09-1216:54mikerodYouâ€™re example does look like you have a type on it called Tree though, so I am not sure what implications that type has#2017-09-1216:56dadairTree is just a record wrapper around a map so it works with the default Fact type identification#2017-09-1216:58mikerodFor clarity: There are basically 2 situations that come to mind in this scenario: 1) How often is this big fact going to be compared to other different facts? 2) This big fact will be part of a token that is stored in memory. This token is sometimes used as a hash map sort of key. If this is hashed too often, the hash code may become a bottleneck. For (1) If the fact has a unique type that no other facts have, it should only ever be compared to maybe itself. The equals check should be fast tehre since most equals implâ€™s will short-circuit on the identical? (or Java == case) For (2) Clojure maps default to caching hash codes. Clojure records do not, prior to what looks like 1.9 (not yet fully released at least (see https://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-1224))#2017-09-1216:59mikerodSo if anything, if your Tree wrapper is made via defrecord, you may be able to see some time spent recalculating the hash code when if this fact ends up being involved in a lot of rules LHS â€œtokensâ€#2017-09-1216:59mikerodTokens contain a sequence of all the facts that matched for a particular successful invocation of the rule#2017-09-1217:00mikerodThen again, I may not get worked up about this situation unless you can see measurable issues with perf#2017-09-1217:02dadairThanks for the advice, I'm just trying to keep some performance considerations in my back pocket in case I need to improve performance. This Tree is somewhat like a database, so it will continue to grow over time. I'm already seeing processing times approach >= 100ms for the rule engine and I generally want things to be below ~50ms for some soft real-time constraints we have#2017-09-1217:04mikerodhmm#2017-09-1217:04mikerodI typically use VisualVM#2017-09-1217:04mikerodstart the â€œsampling CPUâ€ profiler#2017-09-1217:04dadairto clarify: the tree does not change within a rule session, only between rule sessions#2017-09-1217:04mikerodthen run whatever takes the tiem Iâ€™m interested in#2017-09-1217:05mikerodthen you take a â€œsnapshotâ€, view the snapshot by drilling down through a fairly large callstack#2017-09-1217:05mikerodit has visuals to show how much time is being spent where in the callstacks#2017-09-1217:06mikerodFor this particular concern I had above, Iâ€™d just try to get to the â€œbottomâ€ of the larger time callstacks and see if I can find references to, in this example, the Tree object getting equiv or hash sort of calls on it#2017-09-1217:07dadairgreat I'll give that a try, thanks#2017-09-1217:10mikerodno problem. Iâ€™m always willing to take a look at a profiler snapshot, a portion of it, or just say â€œI see lots of time in Clara function X, any ideas?â€ too if you find those parts to be hard to sort through. Iâ€™m not sure how easy it may be to read profiler snapshots sometimes if not familiar with the codebase and/or the way clj compiles out java class names#2017-09-1300:06olivergeorgeI'm experimenting to see if I can rewrite my webapp form logic using Clara rules.#2017-09-1300:08olivergeorgeThe existing code does multiple passes: Field definitions and values used to generate cleaned field data and errors Field data and errors used by logic which might (1) show/hide fields, (2) disable/enable fields, (3) change field values, (4) manage relationships between fields... (lots of stuff). I borrowed the approach Django uses for form and field validation, they document it well here: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/ref/forms/validation/#2017-09-1300:08olivergeorgeThe current approach has functions which take the form (field definitions, values...) and return a modified version#2017-09-1300:09olivergeorgeIteratively manipulating the data#2017-09-1300:09olivergeorgeI don't think Clara would work in this way#2017-09-1300:11olivergeorgeMy guess is I need each phase to have it's own facts so that each phase of the form processing can use previous phase's facts as inputs.#2017-09-1300:11olivergeorgeNot sure if I'm explaining that well#2017-09-1300:13olivergeorgeSpecific question: Am I correct that it's a bad idea to try and reproduce the "modify data" approach I'm currently using.#2017-09-1300:25dadair@olivergeorge correct, mutating data in Clara is discouraged (though not impossible). I am doing something similar actually with form field- and form-level validation. I don't do multi-pass internally in the rule engine, but rather the rule engine is called multiple times from (essentially) a reduce, which collects the final modifications to perform at the end#2017-09-1300:26dadairso the rule engine doesn't actually modify the forms, rather it returns what operations to perform in order to modify it#2017-09-1300:26dadairthen the reduce can take those, perform them, and send the modified form back to the rule engine, and it goes until it stabilizes#2017-09-1300:40olivergeorgeGotcha, thanks @dadair that makes sense#2017-09-1301:37olivergeorge@dadair how do you check for stability? data comparison or does clara provide a "no new facts" test#2017-09-1301:39dadairstability from the rules side of things would be it returning from fire-rules, otherwise it wouldn keep going. "stability" in terms of your domain is different. For example, in that external reduce you would query the session for operations, if the query returns nothing, you could know that "the form is stable"#2017-09-1301:40dadairit all depends on how you set up your system#2017-09-1301:40olivergeorgeThanks again#2017-09-1301:41dadairI am in no way an expert on rule systems though, I'm just getting into it myself, that's just the approach I've taken so far#2017-09-1301:42olivergeorgeRight, interesting stuff. I imagine there's typical examples we can learn from in other similar rule systems.#2017-09-1303:21dadairAnyone have any advice re: calming Cursive x cannot be resolved warnings when using Clara?#2017-09-1303:22dadaireg ^#2017-09-1303:22dadairfor all the LHS bindings#2017-09-1303:23cfleming@dadair Unfortunately there isnâ€™t a good solution for that yet. If the warnings bother you you can turn them off at Settings-&gt;Languages &amp; Frameworks-&gt;Clojure-&gt;Highlight unresolved symbols.#2017-09-1303:23cflemingThe drawback to that is that you also wonâ€™t get symbols that really are undefined highlighted.#2017-09-1303:24cflemingSadly until Cursive understands Clara better (which I am hoping to get to soon-ish) thatâ€™s the best option.#2017-09-1303:25dadairIs there a pluggable way for lib maintainers/etc to help with those endeavours?#2017-09-1303:26cflemingNot yet, but itâ€™s planned.#2017-09-1303:26cflemingIf you were really keen, one thing that would help a lot would be to develop specs for the Clara macro forms.#2017-09-1303:27cflemingIâ€™m hoping to be able to semi-automatically migrate those to Cursive, and Iâ€™m sure it would be a valuable contribution to Clara too.#2017-09-1303:28cflemingWeâ€™ve discussed doing that in this channel previously, but AFAIK no-one has taken up the torch.#2017-09-1303:28cfleming(me included)#2017-09-1303:32olivergeorge@cfleming what format would you prefer specs in? Wondered if that's what you meant.#2017-09-1303:36olivergeorgeShouldn't be too bad given they've taken the time to document the syntax with railway tracks in the doco (is that the right term)#2017-09-1303:36cflemingRailroad diagrams, yeah#2017-09-1303:36cflemingTheyâ€™re not complete, but they should be a good start.#2017-09-1303:37cflemingI suspect there are lots of gnarly corners though, or at least thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m given to understand. But I think thereâ€™s a lot of code using Clara out there so hopefully if we can convince users to test it then we should get the edge cases out fairly quickly.#2017-09-1303:38olivergeorgeSounds good#2017-09-1303:39cflemingHaving specs would also help non-Cursive users check the grammars too.#2017-09-1303:41cflemingPrevious discussion: https://clojurians-log.clojureverse.org/clara/2017-06-29.html#2017-09-1303:41cflemingOne question would be whether the Clara specs would be best developed in Clara itself or in a separate project.#2017-09-1303:42olivergeorgeYeah, I wondered that. I can create a project to hold the WIP specs and have a go at it, hopefully later this week.#2017-09-1304:20dadairI'll help where I can if you post the repo#2017-09-1304:24cfleming@dadair Great, thanks.#2017-09-1317:18dadairWhat's the best way for debugging rules? Cursive breakpoints aren't reachable it seems (not surprising since the rules aren't "called", but rather exist within a session registry and are also macros). Currently I just add print statements and try to reason things out#2017-09-1317:30mikerod@dadair some of this may be helpful http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/inspection/#2017-09-1317:31mikerodSometimes I end up just mutating some testing atoms state from various points in rules though when Iâ€™m confused. The inspection may be a bit of a nicer approach.#2017-09-1317:32mikerodThere is clara.tools.inspect and clara.tools.trace that could both potentially be useful. The tests for these features in src/test may be helpful to see some usages.#2017-09-1317:37dadairgreat I'll take a look at that thanks#2017-09-1318:00mikerod@dadair Tests of the tracing like https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.15.2/src/test/common/clara/tools/test_tracing.cljc#L67 may be useful#2017-09-1318:00mikerodinspection is more human-readable I think#2017-09-1318:01mikerodbut the tracing sometimes has good data to work with, but can be a lot so have to pikc it apart some#2017-09-1319:42wparkerClara-rules 0.16.0 is released and on Clojars. Relative to 0.15.2 (the previous released version) this is a bugfix release for https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/303#2017-09-1320:00dadairIs there a benefit/drawback to doing: 
[A (false? x)]
instead of 
[A (= ?x x)]
[:test (false? ?x)]
#2017-09-1320:03wparkerFor constraints that can be determined to be true or false without any reference to other facts Clara will evaluate them upfront without trying to join them with anything and if they are false Clara wonâ€™t retain a reference to them#2017-09-1320:03wparkerSo for example, in the latter case, Iâ€™d expect Clara to retain a hard reference to every A inserted#2017-09-1320:04wparkerwhile in the former case, it wouldnâ€™t retain a reference to an A without a value of false in field x#2017-09-1320:05wparkerIn cases where you do joins it can also be more efficient to have Clara do as much filtering as it can on each fact in isolation - apart from evaluating your join criteria, there is some (highly optimized) overhead to keeping track of joins#2017-09-1320:08dadairok great thanks#2017-09-1320:00dadairother than if you want to use ?x later in the RHS#2017-09-1321:19mikerod@dadair Iâ€™d tend to just suggest to not use :test unless you have a use-case that it canâ€™t be avoided#2017-09-1321:19mikerodit just is more opaque to the engine and could mean youâ€™re skipping out on optimizations#2017-09-1321:22dadairmakes sense, thanks!#2017-09-1321:33mikerodAs far as the actual effects of the example you give here, I donâ€™t know there is a big difference. There is definitely a â€œlittleâ€ more overhead to adding the :test node, but Iâ€™m not sure you lose any particular optimizations in this particular case. Iâ€™d have to mess with it more to be sure though. However, still, Iâ€™d just go with my general rule here. ðŸ™‚#2017-09-1321:35dadairabsolutely, thanks for the help!#2017-09-1322:48olivergeorgeI'm trying to encode some form logic which disables dependent fields (e.g. can't pick building if site isn't set, can't pick floor if building isn't set...)#2017-09-1322:48olivergeorgeMy rules don't terminate#2017-09-1322:49olivergeorge
(ns spike-rules.core
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Operation [field-key field-state])

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?ops <- (acc/all :field-state) :from [Operation (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (println :update-fieldstate ?field-key)
  (insert! (->FieldState ?field-key (reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops))))

(defrule rule2
  "Insert field disable operation if a field depends on a field which is not set"
  [FieldState (= ?nil-field-key field-key) (= (nil? (:value field-state)))]
  [FieldState (= ?disable-field-key field-key) (contains? (:depends-on field-state) ?nil-field-key)]
  =>
  (println :disable-dependent ?disable-field-key)
  (insert! (->Operation ?disable-field-key {:disabled true})))

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil})
      (->Field :bl {:value nil :depends-on #{:site}})
      (->Field :fl {:value nil :depends-on #{:bl}}))
    (rules/fire-rules))
#2017-09-1322:50olivergeorgePerhaps rule1 is bad practice. I'm using it to combine the original field state with any operations which modify it. (in this case adding a :disable flag)#2017-09-1322:51olivergeorge@dadair I was trying to avoid having to do the "merge field with ops" manually and refiring rules. That's the approach you were describing, correct?#2017-09-1322:58dadairWe actually do it slightly differently. In our case, the rule engine inserts the current state of the form, and the operation the user is trying to perform. Then there are rules that check if that operation is valid given the current state of the form. If it's valid, it returns a transformation of the input action that can actually be performed/persisted by an external state management service. If it's invalid, it transforms the input action to an action that will invalidate the field (or reject the action out-right), which is then again carried out by the external state management service#2017-09-1322:59defndainesMight add in a 
(println "?ops " ?ops)
as part of rule1.#2017-09-1323:11olivergeorge@defndaines that shows that rule1 is firing repeatedly for the empty ops case. 
Loading src/spike_rules/round1.clj... 
:update-fieldstate :site []
:update-fieldstate :fl []
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:disable-dependent :fl
:disable-dependent :bl
:update-fieldstate :fl []
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:disable-dependent :bl
:disable-dependent :fl
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:update-fieldstate :fl []
Hmm, that makes me think it's not doing what I expect. It should have an operation for disabling that field.#2017-09-1323:12olivergeorge@dadair thanks, as you say it's slightly different to what I'm focused on but sounds interesting... I'll get to that I expect.#2017-09-1323:19olivergeorgeLooks like I'm not best friends with acc/all yet#2017-09-1323:24defndainesMaybe check with some?#2017-09-1323:26olivergeorge@defndaines I don't think that would work. I want field -> fieldstate even if ops is empty. That way rule2 has a full list of field-state facts to consider.#2017-09-1323:27olivergeorgeProblem is that acc/all doesn't seem to ever return the inserted Operations facts#2017-09-1323:29olivergeorgeThere's a feedback loop which seems a possible problem: * rule 1 inserts FieldState (before any Operations are inserted) * rule 2 fires because it sees a FieldState which should be disabled * rule 1 sees a new Operation and does truth maintenance to update the field's FieldState#2017-09-1323:30olivergeorgeOdd thing is that I don't ever see the Operation in Rule 1 via acc/all (the third step described)#2017-09-1323:30olivergeorgeI'm new to this, likely user error or bad assumptions on how things should work#2017-09-1323:43mikerod@olivergeorge acc/all returns an empty collection when no matches.#2017-09-1323:43mikerodIâ€™m not sure that youâ€™ve already realized that, so pointing it out#2017-09-1323:44mikerod
(r/defrule foo
 [?xs <- (acc/all) :from [X]]
 [:test (seq ?xs)]
 =>
 (prn :foo))
Something like that would ensure that the rule wasnâ€™t activated with no matches#2017-09-1323:45mikerodLooks like the acc/all docs could be a bit clearer on that#2017-09-1323:45mikerodBelieve it or not, it actually can be useful for it to match with the empty collection in other use-cases.#2017-09-1323:49olivergeorge@mikerod Thanks Mike. The curious thing is that an inserted Operation is never returned from (all). I'll take a step back to understand truth maintenance better.#2017-09-1323:52olivergeorgeSimpler example 
(ns spike-rules.round1
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Operation [field-key field-state])

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?ops <- (acc/all) :from [Operation (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (println :rule1.ops ?ops)
  (println :rule1.insert! `(->FieldState ~?field-key ~(reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops)))
  (insert! (->FieldState ?field-key (reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops))))

(defrule rule2
  "disable if read-only"
  [FieldState (= ?field-key field-key) (:read-only field-state)]
  =>
  (println :rule2.insert! `(->Operation ~?field-key {:disabled true}))
  (insert! (->Operation ?field-key {:disabled true})))

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil :read-only true}))
    (rules/fire-rules))
Returns 
Loading src/spike_rules/round1.clj... 
:rule1.ops []
:rule1.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->FieldState :site {:value nil, :read-only true})
:rule2.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->Operation :site {:disabled true})
:rule1.ops []
:rule1.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->FieldState :site {:value nil, :read-only true})
:rule2.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->Operation :site {:disabled true})
...
#2017-09-1323:52dadairYou could write a query to return all operations, if that query returns anything, then your memory does have operations inserted and it's your LHS of rule 1 that is incorrect #2017-09-1323:53olivergeorgeOkay, thanks will do.#2017-09-1323:55olivergeorgeActually, not sure how to do a query when it won't terminate.#2017-09-1323:55olivergeorgeI appreciate all the help#2017-09-1323:55olivergeorgeI'll take some time to learn more and try again.#2017-09-1400:02dadairoh right it isn't terminating#2017-09-1400:02dadairin that case I'd write a rule that should match on ANY Operation, and have a println on the RHS#2017-09-1400:02dadairthat way it should activate if an Operation is ever inserted#2017-09-1400:03mikerod@olivergeorge This is rough, but hopefully correct (thought about it quickly) So I think the loop goes like this (only including relevant fields): 1) insert Field{:field-key :site :read-only true} 2) activate rule1 3) fire rule1 - insert FieldState{:field-key :site :read-only true} 4) activate rule2 5) fire rule2 - insert Operation{:field-key :site} 6) retract previous rule1 results since (acc/all) changed 7) retract previous rule2 results since rule1 retracted the matching fact changed ;; due to (6) 8) retract previous rule1 results since (acc/all) changed ;; due to (7) - no actual retraction needed here, just updates the accumulator again (6) already retracted 9) (re-)activate rule1 ;; due to (8) 10) insert Field{:field-key :site :read-only true} ;; no Op1 anymore 11) repeat (4) and (5) 12) repeat (6) (7) ( 8 ) (9) 13) keep repeating (11) (12)#2017-09-1400:06olivergeorgeAh! right. That makes sense. Thank you.#2017-09-1400:06olivergeorgeI missed the op retraction.#2017-09-1400:06mikerodso you have to do something to avoid the cycle that starts there#2017-09-1400:06mikerodperhaps checking some field that would stop the â€œfeedback loopâ€#2017-09-1400:06mikerodbut itâ€™d be domain dependent I think to know the answer in that particular case#2017-09-1400:08olivergeorgeI wondered about having a fire-rules loop and doing (field+ops => field-state) aggregation between iterations.#2017-09-1400:09olivergeorgeI can see other possibilities.#2017-09-1400:09olivergeorgeThanks for putting me on track#2017-09-1400:10dadair@mikerod do you know of any solid references for designing forward inference rule systems? Or some common design patterns, etc?#2017-09-1400:39mikerod@dadair good question. Iâ€™m donâ€™t really think I know a lot off the top of my head. Which is unfortunate#2017-09-1400:39mikerodIâ€™ll have to think about that one#2017-09-1401:52olivergeorgeIs there a simple way to extract all facts from a session?#2017-09-1401:53olivergeorgeMy best guess is query with an expression whose fact type is an ancestor of all records which seems to work just fine for records using [?ret <- Object].#2017-09-1402:38olivergeorge@dadairI was going to suggest that perhaps the Doorenbos paper might be worth checking for references but it's 150 pages long.#2017-09-1404:12olivergeorgeOne technique which might have resolved my problem is using insert-unconditional! for Operations as that would ensure they aren't retracted (no feedback loop).#2017-09-1404:13olivergeorgeNot sure if using insert-unconditional! is considered a code smell / something to be avoided rather than common usage.#2017-09-1404:27olivergeorge
(ns spike-rules.round1
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! insert-unconditional! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Disabled [field-key])

(defn exists
  ([]
   (acc/accum
     {:initial-value     false
      :reduce-fn         (constantly true)})))

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?disabled <- (exists) :from [Disabled (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (insert!
    (cond-> (->FieldState ?field-key (:field-state ?field))
      ?disabled (assoc :disabled true))))

(defrule rule2
  "disable if read-only"
  [FieldState (= ?field-key field-key) (:read-only field-state)]
  [:not [Disabled (= ?field-key field-key)]]
  =>
  (insert-unconditional! (->Disabled ?field-key)))

(defquery export-facts [] [?ret <- Object])

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2 export-facts])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil :read-only true}))
    (rules/fire-rules)
    (rules/query export-facts))
#2017-09-1416:09mikerod> I was going to suggest that perhaps the Doorenbos paper might be worth checking for references but itâ€™s 150 pages long. @olivergeorge I do think that this paper is a great explanation of Rete (skipping some of the out-dated about some of the â€œtestbedâ€ system parts). Iâ€™m not sure it has a lot on â€œhow to structure and design rules in practiceâ€ though.#2017-09-1416:11mikerodWhen looking for that sort of guidance I think Iâ€™ve sort of just hunted around the internet searching for like â€œrules engines best practicesâ€#2017-09-1416:12mikerodI think Drools (popular Java/JVM based rules engine) had a fairly large amount of material with some general guidance on things. Itâ€™s still a search though. I wish I knew more direct sources though.#2017-09-1416:12mikerod@olivergeorge Iâ€™d be careful using insert-unconditional!#2017-09-1416:12mikerodYou start to get into an order dependent situation with your rules#2017-09-1416:13mikerodif an â€œupstreamâ€ fact from a different rule is logically inserted and later retracted, but a downstream insert-unconditional! has already happened, it wonâ€™t be retracted and youâ€™ll get into an inconsistent state#2017-09-1416:13mikerodSo then you end up having to do things like add :salience to try to force the rule to fire later than another and this ends up just becoming increasingly brittle#2017-09-1416:14mikerodAlso, loses the â€œdeclarativeâ€ sort of property that you get with rules all being under control of the truth maintenance system#2017-09-1416:59mmerOrganizing rules sets - My rule set has become reasonably large within a short time. I keep getting issues with Exceptions against the schema. These are really difficult to resolve. I wonder if this is because I am running in a repl rather than outside? However, I thought I would divide my project into 4 namespaces - rules (for those I know work) worker (for any functions that help with processing my data into the working memory) queries . This then leave me with an issue about what to do with the record definitions that need to be available in all of these and in the core where I am creating the session. I either get cyclical dependencies if I put the record defs in any of these files - so I move them out into another records namespace and each of the above and the core require and refer this namespace. However when I run the mk->session if fails to find the record defs. Any ideas?#2017-09-1418:32wparkerâ€œHowever when I run the mk->session if fails to find the record defs. â€ It sounds like the namespace defining the records wasnâ€™t compiled then. In case you donâ€™t know, Clojure wonâ€™t actually compile a namespace until something requires it. It can be weird in that if you have a fully qualified reference, it will resolve even if the namespace in question doesnâ€™t require the namespace, but only if something required the namespace already. I personally think of Clojureâ€™s compiler as a â€œproceduralâ€ one that takes in code and alters the state of the runtime environment accordingly.#2017-09-1417:01dadairI have a shared namespace for shared records, then I build sessions like so: (r/mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x 'rules.y)#2017-09-1417:02dadairyou need to make sure you are requiring the namespace too before making the session, I've run into that before#2017-09-1417:03dadairso either put rules.shared into the (ns .. (:require ..)) or do an explicit (require 'rules.shared)#2017-09-1421:02mmerThanks - what if you have helper functions that need the shared? Do you lead them into the session as well? i.e. if a rule uses a function (private-ref? ?value) its namespace have to be made available to the session?#2017-09-1421:02mmerThanks for the reply, BTW?#2017-09-1422:00dadairshared functions can live in the shared namespace#2017-09-1422:00dadairthen in rules.x you can require rules.shared so you can use the functions#2017-09-1422:01dadairI only call (mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x ..) in a "core" namespace#2017-09-1422:02dadairso for example, rules.x, rules.y, and rules.z can require and use records/functions from rules.shared, and then in some other namespace rules.engine, you can require all the namespaces and call the mk-session function: (r/mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x ..)#2017-09-1422:02dadairthat's how I've avoided circular dependencies#2017-09-1422:10mmerThanks - re-organised the project as you said. I am still getting the issue where the first record typr encountered by the rules engine in the session is saying that the Record type can't be found. This namespace stuff is so hard to handle with the level of error messages from clojure#2017-09-1422:26olivergeorgeThanks for the tips @mikerod#2017-09-1422:49dadairdepends how you are using Operation#2017-09-1422:49dadaircan you post an example rule?#2017-09-1422:53dadairor the exact line of the error?#2017-09-1710:52mmerMore details:#2017-09-1710:54mmerThis must be something very simple about classpaths etc that I am not grasping. The Operation is defined as:#2017-09-1710:54mmer(defrecord Operation [assemblyName name src])#2017-09-1719:19mmerThe erro I am getting is: ClassNotFoundException Thing java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass (URLClassLoader.java:381) - I am trying to isolate the issue into a simple set of files - hence the reference to Thing rather than Operation#2017-09-1721:02mikerod@mmer I donâ€™t see enough information here to be able to see what the problem coulud be#2017-09-1721:02mikerodthe class not foundâ€™s name is AssemblyOperation which you donâ€™t even refer to in the rule debug-rules#2017-09-1721:02mikerodSo Iâ€™m not sure how they are connected#2017-09-1721:03mikerodHowever, if classes are missing, Iâ€™d make sure you are appropriately requiring all necessary namespaces, including those that define types via things like defrecord#2017-09-1722:06mmerHi @mikerod - in trying to get a simple example out I have confused you all. Sorry. I now have a very simple project which is showing the issue.#2017-09-1722:09mmer(apply-rules "name" "description") and I get the errors#2017-09-1722:09mmerClassNotFoundException Thing java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass (URLClassLoader.java:381)#2017-09-1722:10mmerEverything to my eyes looks OK and follows the scheme of project layout that avoids cyclical dependencies, yet I can't get the reference to the rule to see the record defined in the shared files.#2017-09-1722:16mikerod@mmer when defining types via defrecord (and similarly, deftype), a :refer from a :require does not import the class name to be used shorthand. So you need to refer to the class either by itâ€™s fully qualified name, or add something like 
(:import [rules.shared Thing])
to your rules namespaces using the class#2017-09-1815:12wparkerhttps://stackoverflow.com/questions/7143406/what-are-the-differences-among-require-import-and-use has an (IMO) nice concise summary of the differences @mmer. One other potential gotcha - if you define a record with hyphens in the namespace path, the Java class created will have underscores in the corresponding class name, and import needs the Java class name#2017-09-1815:16mmerThanks - Just what I needed.#2017-09-1905:27devn@mmer we built a lib such that you can require a single ns and have access to the records via an alias in addition to some other niceties like inheriting fields and specs on those fields from a parent fact#2017-09-1905:30devnfact/my-fact, (deffact abc (alias abc) :a integer? (variant qrs (alias qrs) :q ::some-spec)))#2017-09-1915:41mmerWhere is this library?#2017-09-1917:44devn@mmer closed source at the moment but will talk to folks about opening it up#2017-09-1918:48mmerok#2017-09-2200:56dadairDo facts inserted by rules with accumulators in the LHS observe truth maintenance retractions if the accumulator changes? i.e., if I have a max accumulator, and 5 facts are inserted, will the RHS facts be retracted for the four facts that aren't the max?#2017-09-2214:40wparker@U0E2EQFME: Yes, accumulator conditions will adjust as necessary to respect truth maintenance. This test is a concrete example: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/common/clara/test_accumulation.cljc#L1102#2017-09-2217:22dadairawesome thanks!#2017-09-2516:45ennI have this clause in an LHS: 
[?last-performed-date <- (acc/max :date)
   :from [fact/test-result
          (= ?test-id test-id)]]
Because the initial value of the max accumulator is nil, it never fires when there are no test-result facts. Am I missing some idiomatic way to have it fire in that case? Do I need to write my own accumulator with a different initial value? Can I do this with :or?#2017-09-2519:52mikerod@enn you should just structure the rules in a way to handle the missing case#2017-09-2519:52mikerodsince acc/max doesnâ€™t necessarily make sense for no facts - that may not always be the behavior that was desired#2017-09-2519:53mikerodYou could give it an :initial-value if you wanted to I suppose though#2017-09-2519:53mikerod
[?last-performed-date <- (assoc (acc/max :date) :initial-value <my-date>)
   :from [fact/test-result
          (= ?test-id test-id)]]
not sure it will always be clear what happened though#2017-09-2519:57enn@mikerod thanks--I ended up adding an [:or ... [:not [fact/test-result (= ?test-id test-id)]]]1#2017-09-2521:16nickowsyIs there a way to use accumulate with multiple fact_contraints? For example, if I have the facts 
{:e 2, :a :type, :v :dog}
{:e 2, :a :age, :v  12}
{:e 3, :a :type, :v :cat}
{:e 3, :a :age, :v 2}
{:e 4, :a :type, :v :dog}
{:e 4, :a :age, :v 10}
I would like to acc/all :type facts, matching :type is :dog and :age > 4. The :fact-type-fn is :a.#2017-09-2521:33mikerod
[:type
 (= (:v this) :dog)
 (= ?id (:e this))]

[?all <- (acc/all)
 :from [:age
        (= ?id (:e this))
        (> (:v this) 4)]
@nickowsy perhaps?#2017-09-2521:33mikerodSo an accumulator that does a join with another fact#2017-09-2521:40nickowsy@mikerod, cool thanks. I had something similar but was seeing the rule run multiple times. Once for each 
[:type
 (= (:v this) :dog)
 (= ?id (:e this))]
match#2017-09-2521:42mikerod@nickowsy yes, it would#2017-09-2821:48souenzzoHow to print/debug all fired rules?#2017-09-2823:39dadairhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/inspection/#2017-09-2823:39dadair@souenzzo#2017-09-2900:53olivergeorgeIn my early experimentation with clara I ended up with infinite loops when firing rules. They were non-terminating due to rules which are directly or indirectly affected by the facts they insert.#2017-09-2900:54olivergeorgeI went looking for documentation around this. I can't see anything apart from an issue about a :no-loop flag.#2017-09-2900:55olivergeorgeDirect question: is Clara smart enough to avoid infinite loops based on bad rules?#2017-09-2912:59souenzzo@dadair not sure if I understand. But my rules was in a loop inside the fire-rules.#2017-09-2915:09mikerod@olivergeorge are you asking if Clara can solve the Halting problem?#2017-09-2915:09mikerodðŸ˜›#2017-09-2915:10mikerodJoking aside: No Clara canâ€™t really detect the loops#2017-09-2915:10mikerodThe RHS can do arbitrary things#2017-09-2915:10mikerodThere is no way to know that something that â€œlooks like a cycleâ€ at runtime isnâ€™t going to eventually stop cycling#2017-09-2915:11mikerodClara could assume if a cycle of rules was happening â€œtoo many timesâ€ that it should stop#2017-09-2915:12mikerodIn Drools (popular Java-based rules engine that I often reference since it was used a lot in the industry) there was a â€œfire until haltâ€ sort of method I believe it was called. This allowed to have a sort of â€œtimeoutâ€ feature that the rules would stop if they reached a certain threshold of time, steps, # rule firings, etc. So something like that is feasible to implement, but not in Clara right now.#2017-09-2915:13mikerodI do tend to try to avoid using something like :no-loop too and instead setup the rules in a way where they logically wonâ€™t loop. :no-loop starts to go against the logical truth maintenance in some cases.#2017-09-2915:14mikerodUnderstandably, there are cases where it is sort of hard to think about how you can make the rule logic you want not form a logical loop.#2017-09-2915:59wparkerThere is work logged for Clara to assume by default that after a certain number of iterations of looping that the rules were written incorrectly and throw an exception: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/275#2017-09-2916:01wparkerI agree with @mikerod â€˜s comments - perhaps another way of thinking about it is that if you just write a normal infinitely recursive function, Clojure or any other programming language can throw a StackOverflowException but canâ€™t automatically recover from it - the language would have to guess what the programmer actually wanted to do in order to accomplish that#2017-09-2916:02wparkerI see Claraâ€™s handling of infinitely looping rules as similar - thereâ€™s no way for Clara to guess what the user actually wanted to do#2017-09-2916:03mikerodCool, forgot you logged that issue before#2017-09-2921:58dadairIs there a way for someone to override what is printed when an exception is thrown? I have a fact with a very large map and when an exception is thrown it tries to print it as a binding and the REPL basically becomes unresponsive.#2017-09-2922:37mikerod@dadair Iâ€™ve had similar issues before#2017-09-2922:38mikerodTrying to think of a workaround#2017-09-2922:39mikerodI think printing the bindings directly in the exception message can be a little ambitious since sometimes there are really large bindings. They can be really big due to things like acc/all too#2017-09-2922:39mikerodFrom the REPL, you may be able to get by with try + catch around when you run the rules?#2017-09-2922:39mikerodso catch the exception to not let it print its default dump#2017-09-2922:40mikerodif you are encountering the error using something like clojure.test it automatically catches and prints exceptions I think. You may be able to override that behavior as well#2017-09-3001:00souenzzoDoes "query" is a slow operation? For lage sets, witch shoud be optimal? - One big query with "all"(possible) facts, with some "garbage" and use just what I really need - Many little query, with just what I really need,#2017-10-0104:54wparkerQueries are really just rules without a RHS, at least in the current implementation. There are some optimizations that could be done on queries that arenâ€™t valid for rules; for my part none of my use-cases have yet had enough of a problem to warrant spending the time implementing them. Note that the results are calculated during fire-rules, and calling â€œqueryâ€ is really just a map get operation. Filters that can be expressed as values of bindings can end up being expressed as just map gets if the query parameters are set appropriately. Otherwise, to be honest its hard to say much about perf without knowing more specifics. My personal bias would be to express as much as possible in declarative logic e.g. â€œlittle queriesâ€ and then address any concrete perf problems that come up, but obviously the optimal strategy depends a lot on your use-case.#2017-10-0102:56olivergeorgeThanks @mikerod & @wparker. No great surprise. I did wonder if keeping track of inputs for truth maintenance provided a mechanism to detect a loop. e.g. If one of my inputs is based on my output then raise exception.#2017-10-0103:40mikerodYeah Iâ€™m not sure. There may be some possibility for the truth maintenance to detect a cycle in the automatic retraction stuff. Havenâ€™t thought that one through before. #2017-10-0518:52dghas anyone ever seen an exception from (explain-activations session) when the rules are all working well? 
UnsupportedOperationException nth not supported on this type: PersistentArrayMap  clojure.lang.RT.nthFrom (RT.java:947)
#2017-10-0519:01dgit seems like explain-activations may just be broken. it expects (:matches explanation) to be a vector of [fact condition] but it's actually a map of {:fact .. :condition ... }#2017-10-0519:03ennI have a clause like this: 
[:not
   [:and
    (x (= ?foo foo))
    (y (= ?foo bar))]]
When it fires, I get this error: > Using variable that is not previously boundâ€¦. Note that variables used in negations are not bound for subsequent rules since the negation can never match. To my thinking, the y clause is not a subsequent rule since itâ€™s part of the same :and. I want the clause to match cases where this combination of x and y facts doesnâ€™t exist, though an individual x or y fact may exist. How can I express this?#2017-10-0519:47mikerod@dg looks like you took care of that with https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/346 ?#2017-10-0519:48dgyeah#2017-10-0519:53mikerod@enn So Clara (similar to some other rete-based engines) convert the logical structures to DNF (disjunctive normal form). This is typically done to simplify the Rete tree construction and data flow.#2017-10-0519:53mikerodSo in this case, itâ€™d be NOT (X AND Y) converted to NOT X OR NOT Y and the OR divides the two clauses into distinct chunks. To deal with this, there is typical special handling for â€œnegated conjunctionsâ€.#2017-10-0519:53mikerodI wouldnâ€™t expect this behavior since Clara has some special handling of a negated conjunction like this.#2017-10-0519:53mikerodIs your rule more complex than just what you posted here?#2017-10-0520:04enn@mikerod yes, a bit more complex--hereâ€™s a more accurate version of that clause, and there are also other clauses in the rule: 
[:not
   [:and
    (x
     (= ?foo foo))
    (y
     ((set (map :id ?foo)) foo_id)
     (= ?previously_bound_lvar other_id))]]
#2017-10-0520:04ennI wonder if the set membership check was messing things up?#2017-10-0520:04ennI ended up working around it by getting all values of x.foo in an accumulator, then doing a :not clause checking those values (if any) against y.foo_id#2017-10-0520:05mikerod> I wonder if the set membership check was messing things up? I donâ€™t think it should#2017-10-0520:05mikerodSo the :not clause is not nested within anything else though right?#2017-10-0520:05ennno#2017-10-0520:07mikerodIâ€™d have to mess around with that one to see what may be teh issue#2017-10-0520:07mikerodHowever, https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/342 could also be related to that sort of logic. There was some edge cases to how it was handled.#2017-10-0520:07mikerodThis isnâ€™t the same as the binding not being present in the rule though#2017-10-0520:08ennItâ€™s interesting to hear that it should work. Iâ€™ll see if I can come up with a minimal test case, and open a ticket if so.#2017-10-0520:12mikerodthatâ€™d be good to see#2017-10-0520:17mikerod
(r/mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:not
                     [:and
                      [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]]])])
#2017-10-0520:17mikerod
ExceptionInfo Using variable that is not previously bound. This can happen when an expression uses a previously unbound variable, or if a variable is referenced in a nested part of a parent expression, such as (or (= ?my-expression my-field) ...). 
Note that variables used in negations are not bound for subsequent
                                    rules since the negation can never match.
Production: 
{:lhs [[:not [:and {:type :x, :constraints [(= ?z (:z this))]}]]], :params #{}}
Unbound variables: #{?z}  clojure.core/ex-info (core.clj:4593)
#2017-10-0520:18mikerodThat is pretty minimal#2017-10-0520:33mikerod@enn I think the issue is that Clara it not allowing a condition within a negation to introduce a new bound variable#2017-10-0520:35mikerodThis gets even more minimal: 
(mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:not [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]])])
fails due to Unbound variables: #{?z} yet this is ok: 
(mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:y ( = ?z (:z this))]
                    [:not [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]])])
#2017-10-0520:35mikerodThe case of a single condition making a bound variable within a negation doesnâ€™t make sense. However, in negated conjunction like in your previous example it does. I think this may be an edge case that Clara isnâ€™t appropriately handling.#2017-10-0520:36mikerodI can log the issue#2017-10-0520:45mikerodLogged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/347#2017-10-0521:27ennThank you!#2017-10-0521:33afurmanovHi, I wonder if I have facts like Shape, Rectangle, Square, what would be recommended way to query all shapes?#2017-10-0521:58afurmanovI am new to Clojure/Clara, and what I am trying to achieve is to make query find-all-shapes to return rectangles as well as squares: 
(ns dsl.test
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]
    ))

(defrecord Shape [center])
(defrecord Rectangle [center width height])
(defrecord Square [center width])


(defquery find-all-shapes
  []
  [?result <- Shape]
  )

(println (-> (mk-session 'dsl.test)
           (insert
             (->Rectangle [1 1] 2 3)
             (->Square [3 3] 5))
           (fire-rules)
           (query find-all-shapes)))
#2017-10-0521:59afurmanovFrom clara documentation I guess I have to make Shape an ancestor of Rectangle and Square, but not sure how to do this and wether it is right direction at all.#2017-10-0522:00mikerod@alex.furmanov Claraâ€™s defaults are to use the type and ancestors fnâ€™s from Clojure#2017-10-0522:01mikerodSo you can work it into those in several different ways#2017-10-0522:01mikerodIâ€™m not sure if you are using clj or cljs#2017-10-0522:01afurmanovclj#2017-10-0522:02mikerodif you are using clj and like defrecord to define your types you could just make a marker interface and use the standard Java type hierarchy 
(definterface Shape)
(defrecord Rectangle [center width height] Shape)
<etc>
#2017-10-0522:02mikerodYou could also utilize Clojureâ€™s derive#2017-10-0522:03mikerodFrom your example it isnâ€™t completely clear, but I donâ€™t think you actually have facts that are actually the type Shape e.g. (->Shape [1 1]) right?#2017-10-0522:04afurmanovNo, the real case is different: facts are indications of some sort of progress.#2017-10-0522:06afurmanovSome could be as simple as counter, others are pairs [invites, money], other type of progress possible#2017-10-0522:07afurmanovThanks, @mikerod! The (definterface ...) works!#2017-10-0522:11mikerodNo problem. Technical note: for Clojure I would choose definterface as the way to mark the record hierarchy just because using defprotocol for itâ€™s underlying generated interface is a bit of a gray area. You could get away with defprotocol as well though. It has edge cases though and it may be better to avoid.#2017-10-0522:14mikerodIf you are still interested, what I mean is, e.g. 
(defprotocol Shape)

(extend-type String Shape)
Doesnâ€™t mean that Stringâ€™s are now considered to be Shapeâ€™s by the built-in Clojure type hierarchy. Also, the protocol will leave a var by the name of Shape that will clash with the classname produced in your ns and that is confusing as well.#2017-10-0522:25afurmanovI did not know that, thanks for explanations!#2017-10-0523:41afurmanovHow to call interface method in LHS constraint? 
(definterface IProgress
  (^int counter [])
  (^int customer [])
  )

(defrecord SpecialIProgress [counter_ customer_ details] IProgress
  (counter [this] (+ counter_ 1))
  (customer [this] 1)
  )

(defquery find-all-i-progresses
  []
;;  [?result <- IProgress (= 1 .customer)] ;; DOES NOT WORK
  [?result <- IProgress]
  )

(println (-> (mk-session 'dsl.test)
  (insert
    (->SpecialIProgress 2 1 "2 out of 3"))
  (fire-rules)
  (query find-all-i-progresses)))
#2017-10-0523:42afurmanovIf I uncomment [?result <- IProgress (= 1 .customer)] line I am getting an error: "Unable to resolve symbol: .customer in this context"#2017-10-0523:44afurmanovCannot use customer in constraint either, same type of error#2017-10-0523:47afurmanovThis: https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/definterface#example-5568aadfe4b03e2132e7d175 is saying that "Using an interface, only the dot form of the method is available with defrecord"#2017-10-0613:16zylox.customer is a method isnt it?#2017-10-0613:16zyloxhave you tried (= 1 (.customer this))#2017-10-0613:18zyloxjust tried it with your code and it worked for me#2017-10-0613:19zylox@alex.furmanov#2017-10-0613:44huwigsI have a question about accumulators â€” is there a reason to do aggregation in a clara accumulator vs. in a RHS of something that uses all to get the values?#2017-10-0613:45huwigsuse case is a value computed from each fact that is then averaged#2017-10-0614:13afurmanovThanks @zylox - that is indeed working!#2017-10-0614:14mikerod@steve313 Technically there may be performance advantages in that you are allowing the engine to have potential optimizations to avoid doing unnecessary work. However, some of that would relate to how performant the accumulator implementation is.#2017-10-0614:15huwigsthanks#2017-10-0614:15mikerodAlso, you keep things a bit more structured and declarative to pull as much out of the RHS as you can#2017-10-0614:15mikerodHowever, there are times when the RHS may be justified just due to it being too complicated to try to fit into an accumulator. There is somewhat of a judgement call at times.#2017-10-0614:15mikerodItâ€™s a good question for sure. Iâ€™ve seen it come up fairly often.#2017-10-0614:20huwigsI am still early in the learning curve; think I figured out how to do the LHS relatively simply#2017-10-0614:20mikerodthatâ€™s good#2017-10-0614:21mikerodOne pattern that is easy to fall into, when new to trying to implement logic via rules, is to have a tendency to put a lot of code in the RHS#2017-10-0614:21mikerodwhich sort of defeats the purpose. Accumulators are a bit of a more complex case, but in general it is often beneficial to try to keep the RHS as minimal as possible. Typically just â€œinsert some factsâ€#2017-10-0615:09huwigsI have pretty large tables of valuesâ€¦ do people find that itâ€™s often necessary to do some â€œfactâ€ lookups outside of the engine?#2017-10-0616:05zyloxNot really no, but im not 100% sure what you mean.#2017-10-0616:19huwigsWell, there are facts related to combinations of values (i.e. if a person is female, 18, and single, the value of some new fact should be X, but if they are male, 29, and married, the value of some new fact should be Y) â€” seems like I could use unification and declare each one of those mappings to be facts (->MyValue :female 18 :single X), (->MyValue :male 29 :married Y)#2017-10-0616:19huwigsor i could just look up those values in an RHS that takes a Person fact#2017-10-0616:19dadairCouldn't you use a DSL to parse your table into rules?#2017-10-0616:20dadairOr you could have condition facts#2017-10-0616:20huwigsIâ€™m sure I could generate rules from the table values but Iâ€™m not sure if that is a good approach#2017-10-0616:20huwigssome tables have thousands or tens of thousands of rows#2017-10-0617:47mikerod@steve313 I am trying to understand the situation still. It isnâ€™t clear to me what a row of this table represents or what information it has#2017-10-0617:47mikerodany dummy example?#2017-10-0617:49huwigsThe table itself is structured like (k1, k2, k3, v1, v2, v3, v4, v5)â€¦ imagine something like that#2017-10-0617:49huwigser, like this:#2017-10-0617:49huwigs`#2017-10-0617:51huwigsFor many many permutations of k1,k2,k3#2017-10-0617:52huwigsnot sure if that snippet came through? slack saying i ran out of space#2017-10-0617:52huwigs
k1  k2  k3  v1  v2  v3  v4  v5  v6  v7  v8
17  F   S   2.1647  3.8128  2.9743  1.4490  2.7630  0.3837  3.4900  1.1400  3.1700
18  F   S   2.8955  3.4350  1.4777  1.4490  2.4809  0.9656  2.9640  1.1058  2.6980
19  F   S   2.2341  2.7573  1.3664  1.4490  2.2500  0.8800  2.5947  1.1058  2.3622
20  F   S   1.8131  2.1821  1.9299  1.4490  1.7000  0.8900  2.2692  1.0944  2.0646
21  F   S   1.7448  2.0645  1.9294  1.4490  1.6500  0.8800  2.2176  1.1286  2.0196
#2017-10-0617:53huwigsnow, in the rules engine we have facts that can provide (k1, k2, k3) values and want to know what a v1 value for that combination is#2017-10-0617:54huwigsright now i just looked it up in a map i read from the file in an rhs#2017-10-0617:54mikerodok, that does make the idea clearer to me to think about#2017-10-0617:54huwigsbut in theory those could all be facts#2017-10-0617:54mikerodYou could put the table as a fact#2017-10-0617:54mikerodItâ€™s still a bit odd since the table would be big of course#2017-10-0617:55mikerodHowever, Iâ€™m not too sure it would even be an issue to just put each row in as a fact#2017-10-0617:55mikerodand then do a join between Person to one of those rows based on the k-criteria#2017-10-0617:55mikerodFrom the looks of it, these would be = based joins#2017-10-0617:56mikerodWhich are going to be the most efficient type in the engine too#2017-10-0617:56huwigsWell, I am ignoring the <lowest and >highest for the first column#2017-10-0617:56mikerodClara will automatically hash on binding keys and use that hash-based lookup for equal-based joins#2017-10-0617:57huwigsthere are values that arenâ€™t strict equality based for that. I can probably hack it so the engine would only use equality based#2017-10-0617:57mikerodSo if the majority are equal based you may be fine still.
