Not completely sure though.#2017-10-0617:57huwigsyeah the comparison ones are edge cases#2017-10-0617:57mikerodHowever, if it is like 10K sort of facts doing < comparisons#2017-10-0617:57mikerodIâ€™m not convinced youâ€™d see much perf issues anwyasy#2017-10-0617:58mikerodIt may be a good idea to use a different fact type#2017-10-0617:58mikerodfor the ones that arenâ€™t equal based#2017-10-0617:58mikerodmay help partition up the network#2017-10-0617:59mikerodsome of this is just high-level talk to. so may be too vague for you to go off of#2017-10-0618:00mikerodbut at a really high level#2017-10-0618:00mikerodsay you have 10K people - call that P#2017-10-0618:00mikerodand 100K rows that are eq join capable - call that E#2017-10-0618:00mikerodThen only 100 rows that are more expensive than eq - call it F#2017-10-0618:01mikerodYouâ€™ll have the P joining to E part will all be done with hash-based lookups/joins#2017-10-0618:01mikerodso youâ€™ll just have P x F comparisons on the non-eq, â€œmore expensiveâ€ join tests#2017-10-0618:01mikerodSo the P, E factor is â€œconstantâ€#2017-10-0618:02mikerodBut the non-eq-based table rows Iâ€™d put under a differnet fact type since that would ensure partitioning into groups like this#2017-10-0618:02mikerodignore my â€œmore expensiveâ€ phrase#2017-10-0618:03huwigsso if we have a fact type for the E and a fact type for the F cases#2017-10-0618:03mikerodnot that relevant, itâ€™s more about the multiplier#2017-10-0618:03huwigswould there be two rules, one joining PxE and one joining PxF ?#2017-10-0618:03mikerodyeah#2017-10-0618:03huwigsor use :or in one rule?#2017-10-0618:03mikerodIâ€™d probably do 2 rules#2017-10-0618:03mikerod:or may be able to get you equivalent, but it may just be less readable#2017-10-0618:04huwigsright#2017-10-0618:04mikerodor more confusing#2017-10-0618:04mikerod:or is for the most part â€œsyntax sugarâ€#2017-10-0618:04mikerodit isnâ€™t short-circuiting#2017-10-0618:04huwigsOK#2017-10-0618:04mikerodit splits at that point and all the data flow goes down both â€œbranchesâ€ of logic#2017-10-0618:05mikerodthe only reason Iâ€™d use :or in a case like this is something like#2017-10-0618:06mikerod
(r/defrule tester
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  [:or
   <your P,E and P,F joins here using the result from A,B above>]
=>
<etc>)
#2017-10-0618:06mikerodMeaning if you had some more conditions needed by both joins#2017-10-0618:07mikerodUsing :or above makes it so the network will share the work done in the prior conditions in the rule before the :or. So â€œnode sharingâ€, as it is called in Rete terminology.#2017-10-0618:07mikerodIf you do it in separate rules, there still may be node sharing though. Clara tries to detect duplicate conditions.#2017-10-0618:07huwigsOK#2017-10-0618:07huwigsIt probably reads better as multiple rules almost always?#2017-10-0618:07mikerodJust pointing out times when :or may be nice. It also lets you not write stuff twice.#2017-10-0618:08mikerodI tend to say avoid :or unless you have noticeable/annoying duplication#2017-10-0618:08mikerodof previous conditions before the :or branching#2017-10-0618:09mikerodand back on your topic#2017-10-0618:09mikerodif you have 10-100K rows in a table, I may think inserting all these facts is fine#2017-10-0618:09mikerodif it were like 1 million rows, then maybe be a bit more concerned#2017-10-0618:10mikerodand Iâ€™d still probably try it and profile/ take note of the runtime degradation before trying a non-fact based approach#2017-10-0618:12mikerodAlso, itâ€™s good to be aware of your â€œhot spotsâ€. A rule like 
(r/defrule joining
  [P (= ?age age)]
  [F (< ?age (:threshold this))]
=>
<etc>)
Is going to evaluate (< ?age (:threshold this)) (number of P) X (number of F) times#2017-10-0618:12mikerodso if that is a big number, then it becomes a hot spot and you may end up just being able to improve whatever test is done tehre#2017-10-0618:12huwigsOK. So if many of these facts would be reused from case to case, is the right thing to do to load the standard facts (from the tables above), keep around a binding to the initial session, and then for each subsequent set of queries, reuse the initial session?#2017-10-0618:12mikerodOr eliminate P facts that you know wonâ€™t match F (because they match something else with eq already perhaps).#2017-10-0618:12huwigsassuming that works on account of persistent data structures etc., just donâ€™t want to load stuff from files many times#2017-10-0618:13mikerodI think what you said makes sense#2017-10-0618:13mikerodas long as your rules arenâ€™t changing#2017-10-0618:13huwigsnope#2017-10-0618:13mikerodyou can reuse an â€œinitially loadedâ€ working memory state for those rules for different runs of new facts#2017-10-0618:13mikeroddefinitely a big win of Claraâ€™s persistent, immutable working memory approach#2017-10-0620:56souenzzoThere is some way to dedup on insert? Example, if I insert (insert! ^{:type :foo}{:foo 33}) and then (insert! ^{:type :foo}{:foo 33}), then querty all :foo get just one?#2017-10-0620:57souenzzoYes, I know that (= ^{:type :foo}{} ^{:type :bar}{}) ;=> true#2017-10-0621:01wparker@souenzzo if youâ€™re using queries, you could put an accumulator or an :exists on your query conditions to remove duplication in your results#2017-10-0621:06souenzzoIt's not about query... It's about session Duplicated facts are fire'ing rules in a loop..#2017-10-0621:10mikerod@souenzzo one approach Iâ€™ve done#2017-10-0621:10mikerodintroduce an â€œintermediate factâ€#2017-10-0621:10mikerodthat can be duplicated#2017-10-0621:11mikerodthen have a rule that uses an accumulator acc/all on those possible duplicates#2017-10-0621:11mikerodand inserts only one in the presence of any number of them#2017-10-0621:12souenzzoGot it. I will try;#2017-10-0621:13mikerodAssuming you want to go from X facts to B facts, but do not want duplicates of B â€œdownstreamâ€: 
(r/defrule a-rule
  [X (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Intermediate ?v)))

(r/defrule aggregate-rule
  [?all <- (acc/all) :from [Intermediate]]
  [:test (seq ?all)]
  =>
  ;; Assume everything in `?all` is `=` otherwise do some merge, etc
  (r/insert! (map->B (first ?all))))

(r/defrule b-rule
  [B]
  =>
  <etc>)
#2017-10-0912:59souenzzoThis method is not working because I need acc both Intermediate and 'B`, to ensure that there are no repeated elements#2017-10-0621:15mikerodIâ€™d use better naming though ðŸ˜›#2017-10-0914:35zyloxwhy. no amount of intermediates can insert more than one B under this pattern. If you are saying you want to insert B only if there is only distinct Intermediates, you will need to use a smarter accumulator.#2017-10-1120:21devnWho's gonna be at the conj?#2017-10-1120:21devnAnyone?#2017-10-1120:24mikerod@devn not me this time around unfortunately#2017-10-1120:24devnah, too bad#2017-10-1120:24mikerodIâ€™m jealous too. An anniversary#2017-10-1120:24mikerodand lots of good speakers#2017-10-1120:24devnthere wil be cake#2017-10-1120:24devnwill*#2017-10-1120:24mikerodIâ€™ve never been on a cake one#2017-10-1200:59ryanbrushUnfortunately I'm not able to make it, either. Too many things going on this fall.#2017-10-1309:02mmerIs there a way to change facts that have been inserted - what I want to do is to change the Records to include more information as it becomes available.#2017-10-1312:43mmerAnother question - is it possible to reference the name of a rule in a rule?#2017-10-1315:23zyloxas for the first question, you would want to retract the original and insert the newer one. This will require some logic outside of the rules network. Clara assumes immutability in its facts im pretty sure.#2017-10-1315:25zyloxsecond one: What are you wanting to do with a rule reference? You should be relying on the consequences of the right hand side of said rule on the state of the facts in the session to infer things. Maybe if you had a more specific case of what you are trying to do i can provide more specific advice there.#2017-10-1315:51mikerod> as for the first question, you would want to retract the original and insert the newer one. This will require some logic outside of the rules network. Clara assumes immutability in its facts im pretty sure. Yeah, I think that is common. If you arenâ€™t concerned with a constantly growing working memory, i.e. append-only, you can get by with doing it all in rules#2017-10-1315:51mikerodIt seems to me that Clara should offer something to better support the â€œupdateâ€ pattern#2017-10-1315:53mikerodSomething like: 
(r/defrule update-fact
  [?current <- FactType (= ?id id)]
  [?update <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [UpdateFact (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/retract! ?current) ;; or if you wanted to remove updates altogether - with no accumulator on LHS `(apply r/retract! [?current ?update])`
  (r/insert! (do-update ?current ?update)))
To me seems like a pretty natural thing to do, but it violates truth maintenance since the supporting facts ?current and ?update are retracted that logically supported the r/insert!#2017-10-1315:54mikerodHowever, r/retract! is a bit at odds with Truth maintenance since it is â€œorder-dependentâ€#2017-10-1315:54mikerodif you r/retract! something, but later the rule is found to be invalidated by some other retractions, youâ€™d expect the r/retract! operation to be rolled back#2017-10-1316:02mikerodif you do append-only style, I think something like this works though: 
(defrecord UpdateFact [id timestamp stuff])
(defrecord FactType [id timestamp x y])
(defrecord FactTypeSnapshot [id timestamp x y])

(r/defrule current-fact
  [?current <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [FactTypeSnapshot (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (map->FactType ?current)))

(r/defrule update-fact-type

  [?update <- (acc/all) :from [UpdateFact (= ?id id) (= ?ts timestamp)]]
  [?current <- FactType (= ?id id) (< timestamp ?ts)]
  =>

  ;; Inserts a `FactTypeSnapshot w/ updates applied and `:timestamp` = `?ts`
  (r/insert! (do-update ?current ?update ?ts)))

(r/defrule using-fact-type
  [FactType (= ?id id) (= ?x x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (prn ?x))
#2017-10-1316:11mikerodThe key is to have way to represent snapshots of a fact over time - the FactTypeSnapshot, a way to select the one you want to use in rules - the FactType, a way to apply updates - via UpdateFact to those facts in a way that doesnâ€™t cause a logical loop. Didnâ€™t test this specifically, but I believe the idea plays out alright (for append-only working memory). Externally may tend to be smoother, as @zylox said, so often Iâ€™d go with that. I wonder if Clara could provide some sort of helpers for that though 
;;; Add a query to your ruleset to fetch facts you want to update 
(r/defquery find-fact [find-id]
  [?fact <- FactType (= id find-id)])

;;; Example external update fn
(defn do-update [session update]

  ;; Assumes :id uniquely identifies facts here
  (let [old (first (mapv :?fact (r/query sesssion find-fact :id (:id update))))]
    (-> session
        (r/retract old)
        (r/insert (update-fact old update))
        r/fire-rules)))
#2017-10-1414:22mmer@zylox Thanks for the reply.#2017-10-1415:20mmerSorry another simple question - do all facts have to be records?#2017-10-1418:21mikerod@mmer no. Clara allows for you to provide your own :fact-type-fn, for arbitrary â€œtype dispatchâ€, as well as :ancestors-fn for setting up â€œtype hierarchiesâ€. This is all in much the same was as Clojureâ€™s ad hoc hierarchies work via derive and isa? etc#2017-10-1418:21mikerodBy default, Clara uses clojure.core/type as to map a fact to type#2017-10-1418:21mikerodand clojure.core/ancestors to determine the isa? style relationships#2017-10-1418:21mikerodSo changing nothing, you can use plain maps with :type metadata#2017-10-1418:23mikerod
(r/defrule my-rule
 [:my-fact-type (= (:x this) ?x)]
 =>
 (println "hello"))

(-> (r/mk-session [my-rule])
     (r/insert (with-meta {:x 10} {:type :my-fact-type}))
    r/fire-rules)
#2017-10-1418:24mikerodHere are some docs on it http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2017-10-1513:43mmerAs usual thanks#2017-10-2119:24wadi.chemkhiHello#2017-10-2119:25wadi.chemkhii find my self having to restart the repl every time i change the rules in a different namespace#2017-10-2119:25wadi.chemkhii require it with :reload#2017-10-2119:26wadi.chemkhibut still changes are ignored#2017-10-2119:27wadi.chemkhii have a main namespace with (defsession my-session 'myapp.corerules 'myapp.module.morerules)#2017-10-2119:42wadi.chemkhii'm new both to clojure and clara#2017-10-2119:42wadi.chemkhiis there a way to simplify the workflow#2017-10-2120:12ryanbrush@wadi.chemkhi By default Clara caches rule sessions for efficiency, but this' isn't great for a REPL-based workflow. I like to set :cache false when working from the REPL to avoid this. The page is a bit old, but there's an example here: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Using-Clara-from-the-REPL#2017-10-2120:13wadi.chemkhithnx @ryanbrush ðŸ˜„#2017-10-2120:16ryanbrushSure thing!#2017-10-2122:00wadi.chemkhiwith clojurescript is it possible to define facts in different namespaces and have defsession work properly and require everything ?#2017-10-2122:00wadi.chemkhior do i need to require all facts from each rules namespace#2017-10-2122:00wadi.chemkhi?#2017-10-2122:05ryanbrushI don't use the Clojurescript version much but it should be as long everything is properly required.#2017-10-2122:10wadi.chemkhiI see, thnx again @ryanbrush#2017-10-2500:58souenzzo{:salience java.lang.Long/MIN_VALUE} is a bad idea?? It's a "final" accumulator.#2017-10-2504:30devn@souenzzo in what sense do you mean?#2017-10-2504:33devnWhy do you think it might be a bad idea?#2017-10-2512:18souenzzoThere is another way to tell "this should be the last one"?#2017-10-2514:20wparker@souenzzo using MIN_VALUE would work, it just wouldnâ€™t necessarily be the last thing if you accidentally added another rule with the same salience value. If the rulesets are small and/or youâ€™re the only one working on them that might not be a problem. For our large rulesets with lots of people working on them we find it convenient to have salience with domain-specific categories defined in a single location. If you do need other functionality the salience function is user-configurable, although it defaults to a simple numeric comparison.#2017-11-0120:49wparkerClara-rules release 0.16.1 is now available on Clojars. This contains several bugfixes and other minor improvements relative to 0.16.0. See the changelog for further details. As always please log an issue if you encounter regressions or other problems. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#2017-11-0120:53wparkerAlso, thanks to everyone who contributed to the release - @zylox @ethanc \@dgoeke#2017-11-0617:14souenzzoCan you put a time on each rule? Or a route to view the profile/debug the rules? There is something slow in my engine but I'm not sure how to find what it is.#2017-11-0617:29dadairmaybe run your engine under a profiler like VisualVM? can see what methods may be using the most time and go from there?#2017-11-0620:27wparkerIf the problem is a function in your rules (RHS, accumulator function, etc.) thatâ€™s taking a lot of time then something like VisualVM would likely be helpful. Thatâ€™s where Iâ€™d start. If the problem is that the rules are firing in a bad/suboptimal way then Claraâ€™s tracing could provide some info, but that is harder to use. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.cljc, the discussion on https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/344 around potential tracing enhancements could give some insight into how it works as well#2017-11-0622:16souenzzo@wparker I made a macro that wrap rhs inside a time-like macro, that time RHS and store it's time on a global atom (just for use on repl). It allow's me to see how many times each rule is fired, how many time each "burn" takes, avg, "total time" from each rule. Simple and usefull ðŸ˜„#2017-11-0622:16souenzzo(now I'm using my-ns/defrule in place of clara.rules/defrule)#2017-11-0622:37wparkerGlad youâ€™ve found a working solution @souenzzo FYI, there are some cases where Clara could repeatedly add a rule to the queue of things waiting to be fired, remove it, add it again, etc. without ever actually firing it (and thus avoiding that macro) but my guess is those cases are a small though nontrivial minority of perf problems#2017-11-0622:45souenzzo@wparker I'm just trying to find any slow rhs. Insert or not insert, use or not, not matters. I find a single rule that takes 100x more time that any other. I think that not matter if it will be used or not, in this case.#2017-11-0715:49wparkerExcellent, sounds like youâ€™ve found your performance problem. :+1:#2017-11-0622:38wparkerso that sounds like it would work most of the time#2017-11-1316:43ggaillardHi ! I have troubles understanding how destructuring works in clara. If I understand the documentation correctly, I would expect this rule to match any record of type Foo and bind the symbol foo to the record itself, so I can use it afterward. 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [foo]]
  =>
  (do-something-with  foo))
I always get an Unable to resolve symbol: foo in this context, where context is the RHS. Am I missing something ?#2017-11-1317:07mikerod@ggaillard the destructured bound symbols are scoped locally to the expressions of the single condition doing the destructuring bind#2017-11-1317:08mikerodYou have to bind a variable to use throughout other conditions or the rule and/or the RHS#2017-11-1317:08mikerod
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [foo] (= ?foo foo)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?foo))
#2017-11-1317:11mikerodIn this case, it isnâ€™t too useful#2017-11-1317:11mikerodThis would make more sense 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [?foo <- Foo]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?foo))
#2017-11-1317:12ggaillardOh I get it ! Thank you !#2017-11-1317:12mikerodtimes like: 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [{:keys [x y]}] (< 10 x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?y))
are where it may be more useful#2017-11-1317:14mikerodAlso note that when using Clojure records (i.e. defrecord classes) and/or, on the JVM side, Java POJOs adhering to the Java bean spec, Clara automatically makes the field names visible in the local scope of a conditionâ€™s experssions 
(defrecord Foo [x y])

(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo (< 10 x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?y))
Would work without the explicit destructuring syntax#2017-11-1317:24ggaillardI was using your last example until now to extract my records' fields, and since I missed the <- part of facts expressions it quickly became inconvenient when I needed to work with every fields â€¦ Thanks for this clarification ðŸ™‚#2017-11-1318:46mikerod@dave.dixon that is surprising to me#2017-11-1318:47mikerodI want to take a look#2017-11-1319:00mikerod@dave.dixon I think there is some sort of compilation issue happening with that rule#2017-11-1319:00mikerod
(defrule lost-game
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]
  =>
  (insert! (->Loser)))
#2017-11-1319:00mikerodworksaround it#2017-11-1319:00mikerodIâ€™m not sure the cause still#2017-11-1319:02sparkofreason@mikerod Thanks. I had several puzzling cases like this, will try the work-around when I get home #2017-11-1319:02mikerodTo me it is looking likely to be worthy of logging an issue to clara github though#2017-11-1319:02mikerodif you have more examples of different shapes, thatâ€™d be interesting too#2017-11-1319:07zyloxIs the test node making a binding somehow instead?....thatd be weird#2017-11-1319:10mikerod@zylox I think it is misintepreting it somehow along those lines#2017-11-1319:10mikerodno good#2017-11-1319:10mikerodI looked a a bit in clara.rules.compiler but I donâ€™t see the issue yet#2017-11-1319:11mikerodIf you look at the rulebase for the network without the do (the problem case), the TestNode is a beta root with no parents#2017-11-1319:12mikerodAnd itâ€™s children are the accumulate nodes#2017-11-1319:12mikerodThis made me suspicious of the function clara.rules.compiler/sort-conditions which does a topological type of sort of accumulators that rearranges some conditions#2017-11-1319:12mikerodThe topo sort is supposed ensure that any used variable binding is pushed below itâ€™s creation unification binding condition#2017-11-1319:15mikerodAdding the do in the :test node pushes it down as a child of the accumulate nodes in the network and then it works#2017-11-1319:22mikerodIt may be completely a problem with the sort, as the below demonstrates 
(ns test.ns
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]
            [clara.rules.compiler :as com]))

(defrecord Ship [])
(defrecord Destroyed [])
(defrecord Loser [])

(r/defrule lost-game-fixed
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]                           ;; Notice the `do` surrounding form is important for the sort
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Loser)))

(r/defrule lost-game-broken
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (= ?ships ?destroyed)]                                  ;; Condition with problem, doesn't work without surrounding form (`do` above)
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Loser)))


(com/sort-conditions (-> lost-game-fixed :lhs))
(comment
  ({:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Ship, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?ships}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Destroyed, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?destroyed}
   {:constraints [(do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]}))

(com/sort-conditions (-> lost-game-broken :lhs))
(comment
  ({:constraints [(= ?ships ?destroyed)]}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Ship, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?ships}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Destroyed, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?destroyed}))
#2017-11-1319:22mikerodUnless Iâ€™m missing something else prior to this#2017-11-1319:30zyloxjuxt#2017-11-1319:48zyloxseems to be that classify-variables considers it an equality-expression?, resulting in them being considered "bound", but "unbound" in the workaround case#2017-11-1320:17zyloxand when they are bound, this fn https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L790 will consider it satisfied because #{} is a subset of #{?ships ?destroyed}, meaning newly-satisfied will contain the test constraint (https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L797) and be put in the front of the order in the into at the end https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L828#2017-11-1320:19zyloxim not sure of a good way to fix this. i can see why it thinks its a bound variable.#2017-11-1320:28sparkofreasonThat fixed it, as well as the other cases, which were essentially the same, with an equality check inside of [:test].#2017-11-1320:33wparkerThe compilation of this rule does seem to be wrong. When I inspect the rule network the :test condition seems to completely not exist in the network. Gist with the pretty-printed network: https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/a3adaa3db730229bc01586009bb7178a#2017-11-1320:35wparkerHowever, if I use join-filter-equals it is there: https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/347ba6ca3f7e0afc2c9f183e0731111e#2017-11-1320:35wparkerJoin-filter-equals just dispatches to =:#2017-11-1320:36wparker
(defn join-filter-equals
  "Intended to be a test function that is the same as equals, but is not visible to Clara as such
  and thus forces usage of join filters instead of hash joins"
  [& args]
  (apply = args))
it is a helper function for Claraâ€™s tests#2017-11-1320:36wparkerSame idea really as wrapping in a do like @mikerod did#2017-11-1320:38wparkerClara has special cases around constraints having = as the first symbol in order to create variable bindings, but when the first symbol is something else if becomes a â€œnormalâ€ call to clojure.core/=. @zylox is probably on the right track here with looking at different paths depending on whether equality-expression? returns true#2017-11-1320:40wparkerIâ€™ll need to look more closely at it to have an informed opinion on the exact cause and what to do about it but this does look like a bug to me @dave.dixon You should be able to avoid it for the moment with strategies that prevent = from being the first symbol in a :test constraint for the moment though#2017-11-1322:13wparkerI logged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/357 for this @dave.dixon @zylox @mikerod#2017-11-1322:15mikerod@wparker thanks for making it#2017-11-1322:15mikerodthe only thing maybe worth adding is my comment showing how the sort conditions comes out incorrect#2017-11-1322:15mikerodI can add as a comment though, or perhaps it isnâ€™t necessary since everyone looking at it already knows anyways ðŸ˜›#2017-11-1322:15wparkerFeel free to comment on it with thoughts anyone ðŸ™‚#2017-11-1322:16wparkerI havenâ€™t dug too deeply into it yet#2017-11-1322:25mikerodsame#2017-11-1418:21zyloxwhen are you getting that exception#2017-11-1418:23zyloxsession creation time it would appear#2017-11-1418:33sparkofreasonYes, it's at session creation.#2017-11-1418:36zyloxya sort-conditions specifically it would appear. im not as versed on queries though#2017-11-1418:37zyloxi cant get parameters to work unless they are used in a binding though. that doesnt seem right.#2017-11-1418:45zylox
(clara.rules/defquery ship-destroyed-at?
          [:?point]
          [?destroyed <- Destroyed (= ?ship ship)]
          [?placement <- ValidPlacement 
           (= ?ship ship)
           ((spaces this) ?point)])
for the record this doesnt seem to work either so its not the test node#2017-11-1418:45mikerodYeah, my first recommendation was going to be to not use a :test node when it isnâ€™t necessary (although Iâ€™d still expect that to work)#2017-11-1418:45mikerodHowever, @zylox has found that that is still a problem#2017-11-1418:47zyloxif i had to guess, the check this exception uses is too special cased and doesnt consider parameters.#2017-11-1418:47zyloxits the whole unbound vs bound thing again#2017-11-1418:48zyloxso its at least partially related to the thing from yesterday#2017-11-1418:51ryanbrushThe above queries won't work because ?point is not bound, although we could be more clear in our error messaging here.#2017-11-1418:52ryanbrushThe :?point is a query parameter, which just does a lookup. A query parameter is not "bound" when the rule engine is processing...it is simple used to look up bound values.#2017-11-1418:52ryanbrushSince ?point is never bound in the query itself, we get that error message.#2017-11-1418:54ryanbrushThese semantics are a bit confusing in this case because we're conflating query parameters (which do not bind a variable) with variables that must be bound with an (= ?my-variable ...) or similar expression.#2017-11-1418:58mikerodWoops, that makes sense to me. I blanked about how they were supposed to work here.#2017-11-1419:00sparkofreasonSo presumably the way to attack this is to make a new fact using those conditions, rather than trying to just query?#2017-11-1419:06zyloxClearly I need to brush up on queries#2017-11-1419:06zylox...pun not intended#2017-11-1419:38ryanbrush@dave.dixon Separating this out into another fact makes sense. I'm not quite sure what your objective for these rules is, but any approach that explicitly binds ?point in the query logic (not just the parameter) should work.#2017-11-1423:03sparkofreasonThat worked great, thanks.#2017-11-1922:29sparkofreasonSorry if this is documented somewhere, but I didn't catch it. Is there some best practice around handling fact identity for updates? For example, if have (defrecord Person [name address]), and I want to update the address, or perhaps even insert the same Person (by value) twice. Is there some way to tell clara to use name to identify the Person and change the replace the existing fact, or do I have to explicitly retract the existing instance? Or am I totally missing something for modeling this situation?#2017-11-1923:30mikerod> do I have to explicitly retract the existing instance? Yes, the idea is to do this sort of change explicitly#2017-11-1923:31mikerodand there is no concept of mutating a fact â€œin placeâ€#2017-11-1923:31mikerodThere are several ways to approach the problem#2017-11-1923:34mikerod@dave.dixon one idea is if you donâ€™t actually care about deleting old data (perhaps you want to have it for historical rules etc), you could put an intermediary between external â€œperson data at a point in timeâ€ vs the â€œcurrent personâ€ being processed: 
(r/defrule current-person
  [?latest <- latest-person-acc :from [PersonSnapshot (= ?name name)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Person ?latest)))
#2017-11-1923:34mikerodThis is if you made some sort of latest-person-acc that chose the latest by some criteria of yours (like a PersonSnapshot timestamp)#2017-11-1923:34mikerodYou could use the clara.rules.accumulators/max for this#2017-11-1923:35mikerod
(r/defrule current-person
  [?latest <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [PersonSnapshot (= ?name name)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Person ?latest)))
#2017-11-1923:36mikerodYou may not want to leave facts in though due to a concern, like memory use or something. Then a common way to deal with the update is somewhat external to the rules processing themselves#2017-11-1923:48mikerod
(defrecord Person [name x])

(r/defquery person-with-name [:?name]
  [?p <- Person (= ?name name)])

(def init
  (-> (r/mk-session [person-with-name])
      (r/insert (->Person "joe" 10)
                (->Person "mary" 20))
      r/fire-rules))

(defn find-person-by-name [session pname]
  ;; Assumes name is unique (you could do something different)
  (-> session
      (r/query person-with-name :?name pname)
      first
      :?p))

(defn update-person [session new-person]
  (let [existing (find-person-by-name session (:name new-person))]
    (-> session
        (r/retract existing)
        (r/insert new-person)
        r/fire-rules)))

(def updated
  (update-person init (->Person "joe" 50)))



;; Then try:

(find-person-by-name init "joe")
(find-person-by-name updated "joe")
#2017-11-1923:49mikerodThat sort of pattern would allow you take rm and old version of the person and insert an update#2017-11-1923:49mikerodand it avoids getting into situations within the engine where you have to deal with logical loops in the truth maintenance system and/or unconditional inserts, RHS retracts, etc#2017-11-1923:50mikerodYou could impl the update-person differently where you just make a change to the existing fact to get some data structural sharing too though instead of a brand new fact like I had#2017-11-1923:52mikerode.g. 
(defn update-person [session new-person-data]
  (let [existing (find-person-by-name session (:name new-person-data))
        up (merge existing new-person-data)]
    (-> session
        (r/retract existing)
        (r/insert up)
        r/fire-rules)))

;; e.g.
(update-person init {:name "joe" :x 50})
#2017-11-2000:31sparkofreason@mikerod Thanks for the excellent and detailed answer!#2017-11-2317:33sparkofreasonI think I found the problem. The call to resolve-vars at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/macros.clj#L183 only binds the Clojure namespace. At this point in compilation, the CLJS namespace is not correct. Adding this to the binding fixes the issue: cljs.analyzer/*cljs-ns* (:ns-name production)#2017-12-0213:51mikerodItâ€™s on Twitter, but I thought it was cool enough to share here too: Clara on the ThoughtWorks Technology Radar https://www.thoughtworks.com/es/radar/languages-and-frameworks/clara-rules#2017-12-0223:59alex-dixonJust came to say congratulations!#2017-12-1320:11dadairIs there any way to get cloverage coverage statistics for clara defrules?#2017-12-1322:47wparkerI suspect that Clara does enough code generation and evaluation behind the scenes to confuse tooling like Cloverage, at least without some modification to specifically support Clara, but it isnâ€™t something Iâ€™ve looked into. I donâ€™t think the rules network could be effectively statically analyzed but perhaps something could be created that looked at what rules were interacted with; that information is available via Claraâ€™s tracing#2017-12-1401:56mikerodIâ€™m not even sure how Cloverage performs its analysis. Is it via tools.analyzer ?#2017-12-1418:16dadairI'm not exactly sure how it works; but a search in the repo for tools.analyzer returns empty#2017-12-1418:17dadairI'm mostly just interested in seeing what rules are firing during tests, to make sure I have sufficient tests.#2017-12-1420:10devn@U0E2EQFME you could do some reading of the inspected session #2017-12-1420:10devnOr maybe attach a tracing listener to track the rules fired #2017-12-1420:10devnThat information should be available via either method #2017-12-1420:20mikerodYeah, I think I looked at it before and it didnâ€™t use analyzer. Not sure how it can check coverage. Especially via macros.#2017-12-1420:20mikerodperhaps magic#2017-12-1920:04mikerod@amarjeet you cut it off I think#2017-12-1920:07mikerodIt only shows about 5 lines#2017-12-1921:27wparker@mikerod I can see a larger snippet after I expand it in my OS X Slack client. @amarjeet Iâ€™d have to see lines creating sessions and inserting facts to fully understand what youâ€™re doing, but it sounds like you may believe that a fact {:some :value} will match a condition like [{:some :value}]. This is not the case; Clara uses the fact type, not the fact itself, to match on conditions. So for example {:some :value} would match [java.util.Map] by default, though you can customize the function used for this dispatch. This is documented at http://clara-rules.org; I canâ€™t hit the site right now but the pageâ€™s markdown source is https://github.com/cerner/clara-site/blob/gh-pages/_docs/fact_type_customization.md#2017-12-1921:28mikerod@wparker I can see it on the side bar (same client as you), not sure why it wonâ€™t expand otherwise. Anyways, irrelevant than woops.#2017-12-2005:50amarjeet@wparker#2017-12-2014:50mikerod@amarjeet thatnks for sharing more there#2017-12-2014:50mikerodSo the first level of discrimination in the rules network is going always â€œfact typeâ€#2017-12-2014:51mikerodHowever, the combination of :fact-type-fn and :ancestors-fn give you flexibility into what that means#2017-12-2014:52mikerodThe default :fact-type-fn is Clojureâ€™s clojure.core/type, which is just (or (get (meta x) :type) (class x))#2017-12-2014:52mikerodThe default :ancestors-fn is clojure.core/ancestors which respects the â€œglobal hierarchyâ€ in Clj which can be altered via things like derive#2017-12-2014:53mikerod:ancestors-fn is just for making the supertype subtype relationships that factor into the fact type dispatch#2017-12-2014:53mikerodYou donâ€™t necessarily have to have a â€œfact typeâ€ if you really donâ€™t want, or you can make it something that is based on the data of the map entities you have#2017-12-2014:54mikerod(def session-one (mk-session 'modelxt.absmodel :fact-type :name)) for example, although that isnâ€™t very suitable for the rule add-entity that you have#2017-12-2016:03amarjeethmm, understood#2017-12-2016:04amarjeetWill re-look at the fact-type-fn/ancestors-fn#2017-12-2016:05amarjeetthanks @mikerod#2017-12-2016:08mikerodNo problem#2017-12-2202:02cflemingIs Claraâ€™s fact destructuring as described here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/ the same as Clojureâ€™s destructuring?#2017-12-2202:17mikerod@cfleming the part of the syntax shown there uses Clojure destructuring. It basically ends up being a clojure function arglist that takes a single object. #2017-12-2202:18mikerodBut yes. It just â€œflows throughâ€ to standard destructuring. #2017-12-2202:18cflemingOk, great, thanks.#2017-12-2202:18mikerodNo problem. #2017-12-2202:24cfleming@mikerod One more question while I have you - in the doc, is FACT_CONSTRAINT always a Fact Expression as defined in the doc, or is it any condition?#2017-12-2202:25cfleming(Iâ€™m working on specs for the Clara macros right now)#2017-12-2202:27mikerodtaking a look#2017-12-2202:28mikerodI donâ€™t see a FACT_CONSTRAINT referenced in http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/ ?#2017-12-2202:28mikerodnevermind see it#2017-12-2202:29cflemingItâ€™s in Boolean Expressions and also Accumulators#2017-12-2202:30mikerodOk, it is a fact expression as referred to above#2017-12-2202:31cflemingGreat, thanks.#2017-12-2202:31cflemingHopefully Iâ€™ll have something basic working soon, Iâ€™ll push it for comments - there are still a bunch of TODOs in there.#2017-12-2202:31mikerodThere may be times when it is odd to do something like bind a fact to a variable, but I think the syntax typically allows these cases - even if they donâ€™t end up being useful.#2017-12-2202:31mikerodThat is cool. Sounds interesting#2017-12-2202:32mikerodIâ€™ll try to give a look at it too once you have it out there.#2017-12-2202:32cflemingGreat, thanks - this is re: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/367#2017-12-2202:32mikerodIâ€™m still catching up on the GitHub conversation from earlier#2017-12-2202:32cflemingCool, no rush.#2017-12-2203:09cflemingIâ€™ve pushed https://github.com/cursive-ide/clara-specs#2017-12-2203:10cflemingIt contains a first cut at specs to match the macros in the Clara DSL - they match all the examples from the documentation correctly as far as I can tell.#2017-12-2203:10cflemingThere are still some TODOs in there which werenâ€™t clear to me from the doc, mostly stubbed out with any?#2017-12-2203:11cflemingMy next task is to try it on the clara-examples repo and make sure it works for the examples there too.#2017-12-2203:12cfleming@alex-dixon @mikerod ^^ FYI#2017-12-2203:19mikerod@cfleming nice. So thatâ€™s a harder one I think. #2017-12-2203:23mikerodYeah RHS is just like an implicit do#2017-12-2203:23mikerodBlock#2017-12-2203:23cflemingOk.#2017-12-2203:24cflemingBut I guess it should always have at least one form?#2017-12-2203:24mikerodYeah I believe the RHS needs at least one form. #2017-12-2203:25mikerodIf it didnâ€™t it wouldnâ€™t be a useful rule at least. Hah#2017-12-2203:25cflemingHehe#2017-12-2203:25mikerodThanks for trying this out!#2017-12-2203:26cflemingAlso, in the defquery doc it shows CONDITION repeated inside []#2017-12-2219:14mikerodThis is just a mistake in the docs. it should be the same as a rule in this part of a query#2017-12-2219:16mikerodwhat you have @ https://github.com/cursive-ide/clara-specs/commit/fa9f7aca57b7a4735d356f54e22399efc4534f72#diff-21ed98cbfbc6578b6ba48146b1f5b9aaR44 looks right#2017-12-2302:08cflemingGreat, thanks Mike#2017-12-2302:09cflemingLooks like these are pretty close to correct then. So it wouldnâ€™t be the first of that sort. #2017-12-2302:28mikerodWe should reference your repo in the github issue on Clara related to this specâ€™ing too to be sure everyone sees it#2017-12-2302:31mikerodIâ€™m sure people will like to get some cursive support from this too. Have better understanding now. Your note helped ðŸ™‚#2017-12-2213:31souenzzoThere is docs about props? http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/ :salience is the unique "relevant" value inside this map?#2017-12-2214:15mikerod@souenzzo Iâ€™m not sure if there are docs about all props#2017-12-2214:16mikerodIt is a map of keyword to anything. :salience is one supported one. The only other I can think of is :no-loop#2017-12-2214:18mikerodand usually you shouldnâ€™t need to worry about :no-loop#2017-12-2214:25souenzzoI'm annotating some data to use on inspect. outside a name conflict, should not be a problem, right?#2017-12-2214:26mikerodYou want to put additional information in the props map for your own purposes you mean?#2017-12-2214:27souenzzoYep#2017-12-2214:27mikerodI think that should be ok. You probably want to do something like use namespaced keywords though as keys#2017-12-2218:14alex-dixon@mikerod Could no loop could be used as a modify? Like if I wanted to increment each match at most once per fire rules?#2017-12-2218:35mikerod@alex-dixon like:#2017-12-2218:36mikerod
(r/defrule demo
  {:no-loop true}
  [?a <- A]
  =>
  (r/insert! (update ?a :some-val inc)))
#2017-12-2218:36mikerod?#2017-12-2218:36mikerodand perhaps with a RHS (r/retract! ?a) before - actually not sure on this part - it is a secondary part of the question#2017-12-2218:40alex-dixonWith retract yeah. To simulate mutation #2017-12-2218:50mikerodIt may be feasible, something youâ€™d want to be careful for proliferating everywhere#2017-12-2218:50mikerodwith r/retract! I actually dontâ€™ know#2017-12-2218:50mikerodI canâ€™t remember if :no-loop will stop a truth maintenance retraction sort of loop - perhaps youâ€™ve tried?#2017-12-2218:51mikerodIâ€™ve mentioned on here before as well, if you donâ€™t have a big concern with an always growing set of facts in working memory, you donâ€™t need to retract. You can just â€œmodifyâ€ and only base downstream logic on the â€œlatestâ€#2017-12-2218:52mikerodhowever, for something long running or with many of these changes, memory use would get too high#2017-12-2222:20alex-dixon@mikerod This is the first Iâ€™ve heard of no loop! Iâ€™m excited by it. Hereâ€™s an issue you raised a few years ago, looks like it led to truth maintenance being brought under the â€œno loopâ€ umbrella as well: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/99#2017-12-2223:04mikerod@alex-dixon oh nice. The memory has returned to me now (after reading that issue and comments again) hah#2017-12-2223:05mikerodItâ€™d be interesting to see how doing something like you said would go then#2017-12-2223:05mikerodif you retract the fact and insert the updated version of it#2017-12-2223:06mikerodthen all other rules that were based (or transitively based) only that removed fact would be retracted. However, the new updated version of the fact would then be available to rebuild those downstream results#2017-12-2223:06mikerodThat ma work out alright.#2017-12-2223:10mikerod@alex-dixon but be aware there are some edge cases to RHS retracts still.#2017-12-2223:10mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/229 https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/321 are 2 I can immediately find#2017-12-2223:18alex-dixonIâ€™m trying to understand the difference with that behavior and insert logical vs insert unconditional with an explicit retractionâ€¦.kind of a head spinner. It seems a lot of the landmines and complexity are tied up with insert logical. Would you agree?#2017-12-2223:35mikerod@alex-dixon Hmm. I think sticking to all logical insert is a reduction of complexity#2017-12-2223:36mikerodThere are just cases when it is difficult to express what you want with only the built-in logical truth maintenance.#2017-12-2223:36mikerodDoing things like unconditional insert and RHS retracts are subversions to the truth maintenance system (aka TMS). With that comes difficulty#2017-12-2223:37mikerodThe reason TMS and logical insertion are so useful is that they allow for a much larger degree of rule order evaluation independence.#2017-12-2223:37mikerodI think what Clara may be lacking most is a way to explicitly â€œupdateâ€ a fact.#2017-12-2223:38mikerodThe more I think of it coming up, the more it seems like itâ€™d be a nice first-class thing that ensured that it had well defined semantics with how it interacted with TMS.#2017-12-2223:39mikerodHowever, I have mentioned before, that you can also make an external process that handles â€œupdatesâ€ or retractions - leaving the rules part all logical insert + TMS.#2017-12-2223:39mikerodHowever, that is still a manual thing right now. Iâ€™ve posted on here a few times what that sort of thing looks like though.#2017-12-2300:46alex-dixonInteresting. And yeah seems weâ€™re talking about the same with update/modify. Iâ€™m only slightly familiar with it from Drools.#2017-12-2300:48alex-dixonI searched the slack history at clojureverse and wasnâ€™t able to find your explanation ðŸ˜ž. Sounds very intriguing. Iâ€™ll keep looking and thinking about this over the holiday. Thanks so much for your responses they give me a lot to think about ðŸ™‚#2017-12-2300:48mikerodI think Iâ€™ll just make a blog post on the external update thing#2017-12-2300:49mikerodYeah, Drools had an update mechanism. I think they had some interesting optimizations done with it. Even more so in 6+ of it when they had a large overhaul to how the fact propagation of the rule network worked I think.#2017-12-2300:50mikerodI used to spend quite a bit of time trying to parse through the Drools codebase. Itâ€™s pretty â€œintenseâ€ though ðŸ˜›#2017-12-2316:24alex-dixonHave you read Claraâ€™s source? ðŸ˜„#2017-12-2316:25mikerodHaha. Oh yes. Iâ€™m all caught up on that one. #2017-12-2316:22alex-dixonIs 6+ with the Phreak algorithm instead of Rete?#2017-12-2316:23alex-dixonSorryâ€¦I should just google thatâ€¦.:)#2017-12-2316:25mikerodYep#2017-12-2316:26mikerodI donâ€™t know that I fully consider it separate. But they do. It does have a lot of modifications over rete. However all modern rete implâ€™s do. #2017-12-2316:27mikerodThere are some good ideas there though. I think Clara is competitive with the optimization it has though in many cases. #2017-12-2316:29mikerodDrools 5 vs 6 added a lot of things at once. It makes it hard to know which ones are paying off the most. At least from what is public. I think the most important optimization was just the batched fact propagation across the network. That is done in Drools 6 phreak via a â€œlazyâ€ sort of evaluation of rules. #2017-12-2316:30mikerodClara could potentially do a bit better with lazy propagation. However just having the batched propagation seems to work pretty well already. #2017-12-2316:31alex-dixonI thought Phreak was more eager#2017-12-2316:33alex-dixonOverall Iâ€™m under the impression Clara was written with distributed computing in mindâ€¦I donâ€™t know if other rule engines compete with that, and to me it seems like a ridiculously powerful feature#2017-12-2316:40mikerodHmm. It should be more lazy. Hah. There are lots of blogs on it by Drools people. Good blogs really. They put out some good content that is helpful more generally#2017-12-2316:41mikerodBut yes Clara does a good job in terms of its flexibility to be used in different ways. #2017-12-2316:41mikerodSome good abstractions in place. #2017-12-2316:46alex-dixonHave you used clara-storm or have any desire to run Clara across multiple instances?#2017-12-2316:57mikerodThat was Something Ryan put together early on with Clara. I believe he said it was mostly an experiment or demonstration of how it might be done. Not a production worthy product. #2017-12-2316:58mikerodAnd early on I think he had some thoughts about where to apply it but went in a different direction instead. I havenâ€™t had the need but Iâ€™ve spent a little time thinking about it. I think itâ€™d be cool to see Clara used across Something like distributed processes#2017-12-2318:07ryanbrushYeah, Storm support was just an experiment for a need that never really materialized so we didn't pursue it further. The internals of Clara were designed to support a distributed working memory, so it could be something we pick up at some point.#2017-12-2318:19alex-dixonAll tests are passing last I checked ðŸ™‚#2017-12-2318:22alex-dixonIâ€™ve been interested in two applications related to it. Mainly stream processing with Kafka but also web workers in the browser#2017-12-2320:16ryanbrushThe test coverage in that project is pretty weak, though. We're using Clara in Spark now, but are keeping working memory local to each worker...basically our workload lets us do groupby operations to group needed facts into a common process and then using Clara there.#2017-12-2400:44mikerod@alex-dixon I made a blog post on the topic of â€œfact updatesâ€ in Clara @ http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html Perhaps something like it could be added to Clara docs later.#2017-12-2400:44mikerodIt is basically just reiterating things Iâ€™ve discussed before in this Slack channel on the topic. We discussed this a little a day or so ago.#2017-12-2400:45alex-dixonAwesome. Thanks. Will read and share#2017-12-2400:46mikerodcool. feel free to let me know if you see problems with it or anything too#2017-12-2416:18alex-dixonVery well written. Really impressed at how quickly you were able to produce thatâ€¦ ðŸ™‚#2017-12-2416:24mikerodThanks!#2017-12-2416:31alex-dixonI havenâ€™t figured out a good solution for â€œdefault valuesâ€ of facts. E.g. I have some rules Iâ€™m working on now for precept-devtools where Iâ€™m trying to allow the user to view history for a rule. When the user first selects â€œshow historyâ€, I want to provide a default (e.g. the first rule firing). After that I want the user to be able to switch through the selected history. Iâ€™d like to have one â€œselected historyâ€ fact. If it doesnâ€™t exist because the user hasnâ€™t set it, it should be derived from other facts. If the user sets it though, then â€œselected historyâ€ should be whatever the user says.#2017-12-2416:33mikerodThat sounds like you could encode that as 2 separate rules that both insert the selected history fact#2017-12-2416:33alex-dixonTo get a default Iâ€™m writing something like â€œ[:not {SelectedHistory} => (insert-unconditional! [SelectedHistory 0])â€#2017-12-2416:33mikerodOne rule would only fire if some user provided fact is not present. #2017-12-2416:33mikerodYeah. Use a different fact type as the â€œtriggerâ€#2017-12-2416:34mikerodAnd no need for unconditional #2017-12-2416:36mikerod
[:not [SelectHistoryEvent]]
=>
(insert! (->SelectedHistory 0))
#2017-12-2416:37mikerodThe other rule would be the same, but would use the event to build the SelectedHistory with the provided value#2017-12-2416:37mikerodAnd if you want the ability to retract/toggle do some sort of external retract like I described in blog perhaps.#2017-12-2416:38alex-dixonOk. Iâ€™ll try that. Thanks#2017-12-2417:45mikerodTime to write a â€œdefaulting factsâ€ blog! ðŸ˜›#2017-12-2419:01alex-dixonSorryâ€¦.donâ€™t mean to create work for you. Iâ€™m still figuring out patterns. I think UI might be different from the way Clara is normally used? Maybe not but there are facts coming from the outside virtually all the time and Iâ€™ve often wondered if thatâ€™s significantly different from the use case at Cerner#2017-12-2419:24mikerodOh no not a problem. I like to read open-source libs doing interesting things anyways.#2017-12-2402:27sparkofreasonBrain bubble: clara and onyx might be a great match for distributed processing. #2017-12-2422:32sparkofreasonAfter reading this (https://clojurians-log.clojureverse.org/clara/2015-12-11.html) and @mikerod's article (http://www.metasimple.org/2017/02/28/clarifying-rules-engines.html), I think there may be something there. It's all sky pie at this point, but it certainly seems like the network should be translatable to an onyx job. Onyx has fault tolerance for stateful tasks, and has taken a pretty good beating from jepsen.#2017-12-2521:15alex-dixonThanks for the links. Read both and very helpful. This was the inspiration for me: https://www.confluent.io/blog/turning-the-database-inside-out-with-apache-samza/#2017-12-2521:18alex-dixonIâ€™ve only worked with Kafka a bit, but I like it a lot. Thereâ€™s ksql and kafka-streams to deal with joins between topics, but neither seem as good a solution as a rules engine#2017-12-3000:26sparkofreasonAgreed. I think Kafka is suitable as a source of facts, but the rules engine gives you both logic and materialized views for "complex event processing". If we could implement the distributed working menu in Onyx and feed the whole thing with Kafka, it seems pretty cool.#2017-12-2710:59amarjeetWhen i inspect a session, the value of :fact->explanations key is always nil, despite facts being inserted into the session. CC: @mikerod#2017-12-2711:03amarjeetThe session->fact-graph too returns nil: {:forward-edges {}, :backward-edges {}}#2017-12-2714:59mikerod@amarjeet I think Iâ€™d need more of an example to see what you mean#2017-12-2715:00mikerodHowever, if you are just doing this for some sort of debugging, you could also add a query that matched any fact and use that to see what is in the session. This query could be a performance issue in a production usage though,.#2017-12-2715:05amarjeetI was debugging basically, so with queries I can test things#2017-12-2715:05amarjeetin the process of debugging, I tried inspect and fact-graph...thats when I came across nil values#2017-12-2715:06amarjeetBut, queries clearly shows that facts are there. One for base-session and one for mysession. I donâ€™t see what you called to try inspecting and looking at the inspection results. Thatâ€™d be useful too. Pending the above comment I had was just a typo#2017-12-2716:03mikerod@amarjeet did you call fire-rules on the mysession?#2017-12-2716:04amarjeetno actually#2017-12-2716:04amarjeetI see thats the problem? Because, I just tried with fire-rules, and I see the facts#2017-12-2716:06amarjeetBut, without firing the rules, the insertion is happening#2017-12-2716:07amarjeetwith fire-rules, only matched facts are being returned under the fact->explanation#2017-12-2716:07amarjeetI thought, with inspect, I could see all inserted facts, not just the matched ones#2017-12-2716:10mikerod@amarjeet I think in general you shouldnâ€™t assume much about the state of working memory prior to fire-rules#2017-12-2716:11mikerodTake that as a general principle. Things are done sometimes â€œlazilyâ€ in some respects#2017-12-2716:11mikerodThat doesnâ€™t answer the 2nd part of your question as to what is missing post-rule firing though#2017-12-2716:14amarjeethmm, understood the issue now regarding 'before fire-rule' part.#2017-12-2716:20amarjeetI re-checked, post fire-rules, I can see only matched facts, not all inserted ones (in that session)#2017-12-2716:32mikerodIâ€™ll have to take a look at things a bit to have a better answer on that#2017-12-2716:33amarjeetcool cool, thanks much#2017-12-2717:10mikerod@amarjeet it seems the purpose of the key :fact->explanations is to explain derived facts within working memory#2017-12-2717:10mikerodnot facts explicitly given via an external insert or insert-all#2017-12-2717:10amarjeetokay, that makes sense then#2017-12-2717:11mikerodYou can dig out that info in some sense#2017-12-2717:11amarjeetyeah#2017-12-2717:11mikerodTake for example: 
:fact->explanations
{#clara.test_rules.B{}
[{:rule {:ns-name clara.test-rules, :lhs [{:type clara.test_rules.A, :constraints []}], :rhs (do (insert! (->B))), :name "clara.test-rules/test-a"},
:explanation #clara.tools.inspect.Explanation{:matches ({:fact #clara.test_rules.A{}, :condition {:type clara.test_rules.A, :constraints []}}), :bindings {}}}]}
#2017-12-2717:11mikerodclara.test_rules.B is the derived fact#2017-12-2717:12mikerodthe value under it is a list of rules deriving it. Thereâ€™d be more than one if multiple of these facts were = in working memory.#2017-12-2717:13amarjeetyes, I did got that when I checked with fire-rules#2017-12-2717:13amarjeetunderstood it now#2017-12-2717:14mikerod
(into []
      (comp cat
            (map :explanation)
            (mapcat :matches)
            (map :fact))
      (vals (:fact->explanations inspect-results)))
combined with (keys (:fact->explanations inspect-results)) sort of gets you there#2017-12-2717:15mikerodAlso, an important consideration is that Clara doesnâ€™t hold references to any inserted facts that cannot contribute to any rule#2017-12-2717:15mikerodSo those effectively are not in working memory at all anymore#2017-12-2717:15amarjeethmm, yeah, got it#2017-12-2717:16amarjeetmakes sense now#2017-12-2717:16mikerod
(defrecord A [])

(defrule not-using-a
  [:not-a]
  =>
  (insert! {:not-a true}))

(-> (mk-session [not-using-a])
    (insert (->A))
    fire-rules)
#2017-12-2717:16mikerodyouâ€™d find no references to A fact instance in working memory at all#2017-12-2717:16mikerod@alex-dixon has done some more interesting things with session inspection I believe. He may have thoughts on this though.#2017-12-2717:17mikerodOn the topic of analyzing all facts inserted or that sort of thing. Then again, for dev only, if you are using the typical type hierarchy you could just do 
(defquery find-any-fact []
   [?f <- Object])
#2017-12-2717:20amarjeetyeah, this testing trick works, I tried testing with different types of queries.#2017-12-2717:23alex-dixonhttps://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/blob/master/src/cljc/precept/listeners.cljc#2017-12-2717:24alex-dixonExample of abusing clara.listeners ðŸ˜Š#2017-12-2717:29alex-dixonItâ€™s a tremendously well designed interface. This is just one implementation. We set up a core async pipeline to process insertions from outside the session (see in precept.core if interested). Each time thereâ€™s an insert we add and remove a listener and divide the listener ops into additions and removals#2017-12-2717:31alex-dixonFrom there we apply the ops to an atom that represents â€œcurrent stateâ€#2017-12-2717:34alex-dixonPart of motivation over a query is that queries become part of the rete network so having one that matches on everything wasnâ€™t performant#2017-12-2718:27alex-dixon@amarjeet Just making sure you saw this in case it might be helpful#2017-12-2718:28amarjeetoh, just saw, gonna look at it#2017-12-2718:29amarjeetthanks ðŸ™‚#2017-12-2916:50amarjeet@alex-dixon In general, the approach behind precept is interesting. I m gonna dig into it a bit. A few months ago I was thinking about logic-based UIs, using core.logic, before I had explored Clara. I think, understanding precept will help.#2017-12-2916:51alex-dixon@amarjeet Awesome. Donâ€™t hesitate to ask any questions you may have Iâ€™m happy to answer as best I can. You can DM me or thereâ€™s also a #precept channel if you like ðŸ™‚#2017-12-2916:52amarjeetoh, great, will join the precept channel as well#2018-01-0219:37wparker@mikerod @alex-dixon I see that there was some discussion of patterns for updating facts; just a heads up/reminder of the â€œcancellingâ€ functionality added in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/249 and documented at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L38 It doesnâ€™t really solve the hassles of updates though, more of a perf optimization. Also, we havenâ€™t ended using it at Cerner yet due to the work involved in testing, so there could well be problems I missed.#2018-01-0219:47alex-dixonThanks for bringing this up again. This is really exciting. I only skimmed 249 but will review it more later. If Iâ€™m understanding correctly the modify would increase performance because it would basically be â€œmutable data structuresâ€. I really, really at the same time donâ€™t like the sounds of that â€¦but if it allows us to easily trade immutability for performance in certain situations then it seems like a great feature#2018-01-0219:49wparkerThe mutability is purely internal to Clara, not user-facing. Or at least if it is user-facing that would be a bug. ðŸ™‚#2018-01-0219:50wparkerSimilar to the way the memory is mutable internally, but that isnâ€™t shown to the user#2018-01-0219:51alex-dixonAh! Ok. I was thinking about a (modify!) which I think was discussed if only briefly#2018-01-0221:24mikerod@wparker yes, this thing you wrote came to mind and then I realized you actually had parts of it already merged to master. I forgot you didnâ€™t just have it on a branch.#2018-01-0221:24mikerodHowever, it is not the same thing as the update! or modify! proposal I was considering.#2018-01-0221:25mikerodI think there is likely some value for the engine to explicitly â€œunderstandâ€ the idea of doing a RHS retract + insert of an entity that logically represents the â€œsame factâ€.#2018-01-0221:25mikerodReasoning is: 1) RHS retract is clunky right now and even worse has some fairly broken behavior with truth maintenance/batched logical insertion etc. 2) Optimizations similar to your â€œupdate factsâ€ optimizations posted above here may also be applicable.#2018-01-0221:26mikerodDrools does have some optimization to the path of modifying a fact in place - via some of the property reactive hooks. I think Drools also has an explicit â€œmodifyâ€ sort of statement that gives it awareness of a fact in working memory that needs to change.#2018-01-0221:27mikerodIn our case, weâ€™d not do any in-place mutation of course (structural sharing is good though). I think something like a modify! or, I prefer, update! could be done in a way that was sure to have well defined behavior with the truth maintenance as well as batching behavior of logical inserts etc#2018-01-0221:28mikerodI think the update! scenario is one of prominent use-cases for retract! on the RHS. Although I think there are other reasons to retract, such as â€œno longer relevant eventâ€ scenarios perhaps, so retract! isnâ€™t completely useless still (and needs to get fixed to behave sanely with batched inserts and truth maintenance).#2018-01-0221:37wparkerYeah, I realize thereâ€™s some other stuff being discussed. Iâ€™ll have to read up on those features in Drools. Re updates and truth maintenance - it isnâ€™t clear to me what sorts of semantics would make sense to manually mess with a logically inserted fact. My intuition there is that manual modification to something that is logically derived doesnâ€™t make sense, since if A implies B, then A should continue to imply B until/unless A changes.#2018-01-0221:38wparkerI realize that isnâ€™t the current implementation though - Iâ€™ve toyed with changing things so that a RHS retract of a logically inserted fact simply wouldnâ€™t happen in the same way that an external retract of a fact not in the session doesnâ€™t do anything. The fact that it does do something now always seemed like a leaky impl detail/bug to me actually#2018-01-0221:44mikerodI think there is a lot of value to be had in the ability to â€œupdate a factâ€#2018-01-0221:44mikerodWhich would require something like a retract/insert at some level conceptually to the rest of the network - something may not be affected by the thing that changed though#2018-01-0221:45mikerodand with truth maintenance and all logical inserts (something I think is very valuable), it gets near impossible to actually retract something because you immediately invalidate it against the truth maintenance#2018-01-0221:46mikerodI think something liek this: 
(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc)))
#2018-01-0221:46mikerodThe truth maintenance should not have an issue with this. and it should propagate and participate in the truth maintenance downstream as expected#2018-01-0221:47mikerodmore interesting even#2018-01-0221:47mikerod
(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A (= value 10)]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc)))
Here the update! actually contradicts the LHS condition - I still think that should be ok#2018-01-0221:47mikerodIt should participate in a well-defined way with the truth maintenance is the point.#2018-01-0221:48mikerodThen there would have to be considertaion of something like: 
(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A (= value 10)]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc))
  (insert! (->B)))
#2018-01-0221:49mikerodHere you have a new fact that relies on truth maintenance and this rule as itâ€™s â€œlogical supportâ€. Itâ€™s a tougher case to consider due to the LHS no longer being true. Iâ€™m thinking the token should be constructed in a way taht makes the updated ?a support the new B#2018-01-0221:52mikerodI might agree that retraction of a logically derived fact doesnâ€™t make sense. You could always just retract the â€œroot factsâ€ that caused it. I do think that would make sense to be able to be done in the RHS and behave as expected with respect to the batched insertions of other rules in the same activation group though#2018-01-0222:20wparkerBy â€œbatched insertionsâ€ do you mean the stuff in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/229 ?#2018-01-0222:28mikerodyep#2018-01-0219:48alex-dixon@wparker Also over the break @mikerod and I discussed short circuiting the evaluation of LHS along with Droolsâ€™ â€œproperty reactiveâ€#2018-01-0221:52mikerodThis one is unrelated a bit to our other thread concerning update!.#2018-01-0221:53mikerodIt shouldnâ€™t be too difficult to have Clara do something like â€œunlinkingâ€ conditions from evaluation when required prior conditions havenâ€™t been satisfied yet.#2018-01-0221:54mikerodA good example of the problem is something like: 
(defrule do-things
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id) (expensive-constraint x)]
  =>
  (insert! (->C)))
Clara will currently do the (expensive-constraint x) when Bs are inserted, with no A in working memory at all, even if this condition is only used in this rule#2018-01-0221:56mikerodYou can write rules to avoid it like: 
(defrule find-things
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [?b <- B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (insert! (->ReadyB ?b)))

(defrule do-things
  [ReadyB (expensive-constraint x)]
  =>
  (insert! (->C)))
#2018-01-0221:56mikerodHowever, that is not super obvious and also may not always be so straightforward to correctly split#2018-01-0222:22wparkerIf you have ideas on how to implement that in a simple way Iâ€™d be interested. ðŸ™‚ It seems like it could get complicated though.#2018-01-0222:24wparkerOn a possibly similar note, Iâ€™ve toyed with changing the structure where a rule only has one parent before - if there are independent conditions, they donâ€™t inherently need to propagate through each other. That would be a lot of work to change though#2018-01-0222:29mikerodI think the case you are describing is interesting. Iâ€™m not sure how great it is to have a rule with unrelated conditions, but I know that idea comes up for doing things like aggregations onto a larger â€œaggregated factâ€#2018-01-0222:30mikerodIn terms of what I mentioned above, Iâ€™m not sure itâ€™d be that difficult#2018-01-0222:30mikerodI am at least thinking about it like:#2018-01-0222:30mikerod1) during compilation, track if rule conditions rely on others#2018-01-0222:31mikerod2) during rule evaluation, avoid testing conditions if their upstream dependencies havenâ€™t yet had any matches. Just batch the facts to test â€œlaterâ€#2018-01-0222:31mikerod3) the batch is â€œflushedâ€ when the condition is reached via the left activation#2018-01-0222:31mikerodNegation nodes sort of work by batching fact evaluation already#2018-01-0222:32mikerodI think it may not be too terribly difficult at least. Of course I havenâ€™t tried at all yet ðŸ˜›#2018-01-0222:30tcarlsHmm -- the railroad diagram link in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/guide appears to be broken.#2018-01-0222:41ryanbrush@tcarls Thanks. All of that content now lives over on the web site at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/, so we need to delete/redirect those wiki pages.#2018-01-0402:26cflemingI have some questions about the fact-expr grammar over here: https://github.com/cursive-ide/clara-specs/issues/4#2018-01-0402:28cflemingActually, looking at the schema I see that FactCondition :type is s/Any, bummer.#2018-01-0412:54mikerod@cfleming Yeah, I can see where that is difficult and yes the â€œfact typeâ€ being anything makes things complicated#2018-01-0412:55mikerodIâ€™m pretty sure you can break Clara parsing if you try to use a fact type that seems too much like something else.#2018-01-0412:56mikerodOne thing that is interesting and probably should be part of the spec (I donâ€™t believe it is now), is that variable bindings should always start with â€œ?â€#2018-01-0412:56mikerodSo in the case of the fact binding, it is the ::variable-binding from that PR#2018-01-0412:57mikerodAnd perhaps we should just list a few things that a fact type should not be, like it shouldnâ€™t be a symbol that starts with a â€œ?â€#2018-01-0412:57mikerodI think it may not be ok for it to be a vector either. I seem to recall a bad parse example from long back where a fact type as a vector would mess up things.#2018-01-0413:25tcarlsAre there suggested patterns for rules that can require potentially-expensive lookups? If I have a rule that depends on content that could be retrieved from an API call / database hit / etc., is there a way to trigger that retrieval (and insert any facts it results in) only when the rule's other conditions are satisfied?#2018-01-0413:32mikerod@tcarls thatâ€™s funny you bring that up since this topic came up fairly recently here#2018-01-0413:32mikerodIn short: I think in the future Clara could do better to avoid doing work when required previous conditions arenâ€™t yet satisfied.#2018-01-0413:32mikerodHowever, there is a workaround pattern:#2018-01-0413:34mikerod
;; Say you have this:
(defrule original
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id) (do-expensive-thing x)]
  =>
  (insert (->C)))


It can be transformed to this:
(defrule part-1
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [?b <- B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (insert (->MatchedB ?b)))

(defrule part-2
  [MatchedB (do-expensive-thing x)]
  =>
  (insert (->C)))
#2018-01-0413:38mikerodIf you are in a situation where there may be some thrash of insert/retracts of A and B (from example) due to the truth maintenance of the network, then you can also consider adding either :salience or setup â€œactivation groupsâ€ for rules like part-2. However, Iâ€™d only do that if there is actually a situation where it could be an issue.#2018-01-0413:50tcarlsThank you -- that's useful advice.#2018-01-0413:55mikerodSome details on salience and activations groups is written here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/conflictsalience/ If you end up needing it. However, like I said, avoid it if unnecessary. It is additional complexity to deal with.#2018-01-0422:22sparkofreasonIs there a way to establish a conditional relationship between facts outside of a rule RHS? The case I'm thinking of is something like an article app, where articles have comments. Selecting an article makes it "active", and also triggers a request to fetch comments from the server. When the async request completes, comments will be inserted. It would be slick if retracting the active article fact also automagically retracted the inserted comments, but since the response handler for the comments request executes outside of a rule context, I don't see an obvious way to enforce that logical connection.#2018-01-0422:48zyloxYou could write something fairly easily to "deactivate" them (by joining the comment fact to the article and inserting an ActiveComment or something) but that wouldnt retract the base comment fact which could lead to build up over time. I don't know of any way to do what you are talking about without an external handler atm#2018-01-0422:50zyloxthey would have to come in on the same data object into the session which doesnt match the timeline you describe#2018-01-0514:57mikerod@dave.dixon I think that works. The only caveat is just that there are a few outstanding issues with RHS retract!. There are some edge cases with how they may work with logical insertions. I think it doesnâ€™t typically come up. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/229 https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/321 I mention both in http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html#2018-01-0515:01mikerodOther than that though, the rules above seem reasonable. That is something Iâ€™d expect should work. To the point @zylox made: It looks like you do have some sort of external retract that is removing the ActiveArticle in your example.#2018-01-0515:03zyloxYa, i was approaching it from the perspective of using truth maintenance for it because of the "outside of a rule RHS?". glad you found something that works for you.#2018-01-0515:05sparkofreasonYes, ActiveArticle is removed externally. It does work nicely.#2018-01-0515:15sparkofreason::handle-cancelled-response is arguably just "nice to have", catches the case of ActiveArticle changing before the response to the comments request is received. If one ran into the edge-cases around retract! I think you could just have some sort of periodic clean-up of dangling CommentsResponse facts.#2018-01-0515:19mikerodI like it overall. But either way, it is nice to be able to cleanup old facts liek that#2018-01-0615:44alex-dixonMay not have had enough coffee yet butâ€¦.how do I do something like this without getting an unbound variable error?

[:not [:and [Fact1 (= e ?e) (= a ?a)]
                   [Fact2 (= e ?e) (= b ?b]]]

Let me unwind my attempts that arenâ€™t working and attempt that#2018-01-0622:02mikerod
(defrule r1
  
   [Fact1 (= e ?e) (= a ?a)]
   [Fact2 (= e ?e) (= b ?b)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Fact3 ?e ?a ?b)))


(defrule r2
  [SomeFact (= a ?a) (= b ?b)]
  [:not [Fact3 (= a ?a) (= b ?b)]]
  =>
  (prn {:a ?a
        :b ?b
        :e ?e}))
#2018-01-0622:02mikerodI believe that is the extraction#2018-01-0622:03mikerodThat would pair all Fact1 and Fact2 facts together in the r1 join to make the Fact3 facts#2018-01-0622:03mikerodThen r2 would be looking for the non-existence of any of those join results to match the same a and b of a SomeFact fact#2018-01-0622:04alex-dixonJust to clarify my understanding is the :and necessary in r1?#2018-01-0622:13mikerod@alex-dixon no, sorry#2018-01-0622:14mikerodI just quickly extracted it and forgot I had the :and there still#2018-01-0622:14mikerodIâ€™d leave it out ðŸ˜›#2018-01-0622:14mikerodedited to avoid more confusion#2018-01-0622:15alex-dixonWill try asap. Had to take a break #2018-01-0622:15alex-dixonThanks for your responses#2018-01-0622:17mikerodNo problem. That is unfortunate that there are still several caveats to nesting conditions within negation#2018-01-0622:17mikerodA lot of the time it can be solved by just pulling everything complex out of the :not and put it into a different rule where an â€œbridgeâ€/intermediate fact is used to communicate the logic across the rules#2018-01-0622:18mikerodI read through some of the outstanding issues on negation. However, I thought that I remember Will mentioning that he maybe had a few more broad concerns with the current way of dealing with them#2018-01-0622:19mikerodBasically, the currently process is to extract rules out from within the :not transparently#2018-01-0622:19mikerodIn a way that is similar to what I proposed that you do in the above.#2018-01-0622:21mikerodIâ€™m surprised that https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/347 is still an issue though. #2018-01-0801:13mikerodItâ€™d consider the whole thing to be the â€œfact typeâ€. Which is related to the issue of ambiguity of syntax when you allow any arbitrary structure for a fact type. We discussed this on some issue recently#2018-01-0801:13cflemingAs the unofficial ranter about macro error messages, thatâ€™s a very nice message indeed.#2018-01-0801:14mikerodOh nice. Yeah I guess that case was special cased. Due to it being fairly easy to mistakenly do#2018-01-0815:51wparker@mikerod I havenâ€™t gotten around to doing a comprehensive writeup, but basically I was looking at how to address https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/343 and ran into what I think are some issues with to-dnf. Basically since the :or operation is actually more of a union in the set theory sense, I think the to-dnf transforms can end up messing with cardinality. For example, [:not [:and A B]] is equivalent to [:or [:not A] [:not B]] in a boolean sense, but the second can match twice and the first canâ€™t in the context of Clara.#2018-01-0816:12mikerod@wparker thanks. I remember the topic better now.#2018-01-0901:48cflemingIn the example query: 
(defquery get-promotions
  "Query to find promotions for the purchase."
  [:?type]
  [?promotion <- Promotion (= ?type type)])
#2018-01-0901:49cflemingDoes the parameter :?type create a unification variable? i.e. are the param and the local variable ?type then the same thing?#2018-01-0901:49cflemingIâ€™m not sure Iâ€™m explaining that correctly.#2018-01-0903:18mikerod@cfleming the keyword arg allows the caller to bind a value to the variable. The same variable name as a symbol then should appear somewhere in the query conditions. #2018-01-0903:18mikerodSo I think that is what you were saying. #2018-01-0909:55cfleming@mikerod Thanks, thatâ€™s what I meant, yes.#2018-01-0914:48wparkerPut differently: looking at the example in http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/queries/ if you removed the :?type from the get-promotions query definition you wouldnâ€™t have â€œ:?type :lunchâ€ in the arguments in this call: (query session get-promotions :?type :lunch) @cfleming#2018-01-0919:31wparkerClara-rules 0.17.0 is released and on Clojars.
