Is there a best practice for capturing that context? The use case would be leveraging truth maintenance for facts inserted async, e.g. results from an http request. #2018-01-1219:35mikerod@dave.dixon Iâ€™d expect the async response to be do an external insert when it is done#2018-01-1219:35mikerodYouâ€™d â€œcapture contextâ€ just via the variable bindings you passed to the async call#2018-01-1219:36mikerodOh, woops, missed part of your purpose#2018-01-1219:36mikerodI think youâ€™d have to model the fact that you caused the effect externally as a fact for TMS to help you. Example:#2018-01-1219:43mikerodI donâ€™t really like the maybe-undo-async-thing part of that. It doesnâ€™t know which DownstreamResult may now be invalid and offloads it all to the external fn ext-maybe-undo-async-thing#2018-01-1219:43mikerodI think there may be a better way around that#2018-01-1219:47mikerodI made it so original-rule is always satisfied via the accumulator#2018-01-1219:47mikerodSo you can carry that information forward on which path you should take#2018-01-1219:47sparkofreasonYes, that's how I'm doing it now. Like you say, it's fine when all the relationships are clean, but otherwise gets messy. #2018-01-1219:47sparkofreasonReferring to the first example. #2018-01-1219:48mikerodSo in my 2nd example, you can actually filter DownstreamResult if you track which bs they originally were associated with via that information being conveyed externally and back on the inserted new facts#2018-01-1219:48mikerodIt isnâ€™t perfect, you still have to make an association on the facts, however, I think it could be practical#2018-01-1219:48mikerodThis is regarding one part of the overall problem#2018-01-1219:49mikerodYou also have the problem of when the async request is finished, ensuring it inserts to the session that it came from in its final state#2018-01-1219:49mikerodso after the fire-rules that triggered the async request has completed#2018-01-1219:49mikerodIn a single-thread, I think that is not an issue#2018-01-1219:50mikerodAnd you may be doing this single-threadedly#2018-01-1219:50mikerodThe async call though would need to have a way to access the session when it is finished#2018-01-1219:54sparkofreasonI have a way of handling session. But what I really want is to be able to do the final insert such that the fact is a logical consequence of the rule lhs. Not sure if that actually is meaningful given how rete works. #2018-01-1319:02alex-dixonIâ€™m not sure whether using Claraâ€™s truth maintenance directly allows that, but you should be able to simulate it using unconditional inserts/retracts, other rules, and facts that represent the async event cycle. A poor attempt: 
(defrule make-request-when
  [?task <- AsyncTask]
  =>
  (retract! ?task)
  (insert-unconditional (->AsyncRequest ?task))
 (async-side-effect! my-session ?task)

(defn async-side-effect! [session fact] (request! fact (fn [err res] 
(if err (insert session (->AsyncTaskError err fact)
(insert session (->AsyncTaskSuccess res fact))

(defrule on-async-task-success
  [?success <- AsyncTaskSuccess ?res ?fact]
  [?request <- AsyncTaskRequest ?fact]
=>
(retract! ?success ?request)
(insert-unconditional! (->SomeFactRepresentingResponseFromThisKindOfRequest ?res)
 
  ;; similarly with error
#2018-01-1319:26sparkofreasonI have something similar, and it works nicely. But it would be nice if I could avoid the manual truth maintenance. #2018-01-1221:16mikerodI donâ€™t think anything built-in would allow you to reliable have an actual â€œhandleâ€ on the mutable session state during fire rules for an insert! to go off later yet, still correctly be tracked with TMS#2018-01-1221:16mikerodthereâ€™d be quite a bit of complications for the engine to try to support that even I think#2018-01-1221:16mikerodNot to mention the fire-rules wouldnâ€™t be able to be â€œdoneâ€ until all async actions were done#2018-01-1221:17mikerodand itâ€™d have concurrency issues in a multi-threaded environment#2018-01-1221:59sparkofreasonAgreed. Maybe the right(ish) answer is to model facts as something like a promise. The semantics and behavior would have to be constrained, so it isn't just mutating facts behind your back without properly updating the session. But the basic concept seems like a way forward, because conditionally inserting a promise as a fact means it and whatever value it returns will get retracted when TMS requires it.#2018-01-1222:02sparkofreasonThe thing I'm trying to avoid is having to manually perform truth management for facts inserted as the result of async effects. In the big picture, those facts are logical consequents of whatever condition triggered the async effect.#2018-01-1222:46mikerodYeah,I think the case is interesting#2018-01-1316:02sparkofreasonI took a shot at forcing conditional inserts in the async handler, if only as an exercise to understand the code better. I got as far as actually getting the insert to occur, basically grabbing the *rule-context* and making it available to the handler, and adding an overload of fire-rules that would accept that as an extra parameter. The rule context was modified so it only contained non-empty :batched-logical-insertions with the facts being inserted as a logical consequence of the rule triggering the async effect. clara.rules.engine/*fire-rules* then also had an extra arity to deal with externally supplied rule context. At this point, I guessed that this approach probably wouldn't work in general, because it looks to me like the :token in the rule context contains the fact bindings which are the logical antecedent. If any of those facts had been retracted in the session between the request and response of the async effect, I assume that clara.rules.memory/add-insertions! would be unhappy, as the token would be inconsistent with the state of working memory. Is that correct?#2018-01-1316:52mikerodYeah. I donâ€™t think thatâ€™d be very tractable. #2018-01-1316:52mikerodAlso working memory is in a mutable state. I think things could easily become inconsistent. #2018-01-1318:13sparkofreasonMakes sense.#2018-01-1318:14sparkofreasonIs there a way to force a rule to fire, even if the fact values don't change? I'm playing around with using an atom to solve this case, but of course the atom reference doesn't change when the atom is reset, only the wrapped value changes, so the rule won't fire after the first time.#2018-01-1319:06alex-dixon@dave.dixon > Is there a way to force a rule to fire, even if the fact values donâ€™t change? If you could make like a small example where it isnâ€™t working thatâ€™d be nice to see. #2018-01-1320:36dadair
(ns abc.other)

(defrecord SupportRequest [client level])

(defrecord ClientRepresentative [name client])

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

(ns abc.core
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all]
            [abc.other :as other]))

(defrule is-important
  "Find important support requests."
  [abc.other.SupportRequest (= :high level)] ;; full path here works; change to other/SupportRequest and an exception is thrown
  =>
  (println "High support requested!"))

(defrule notify-client-rep
  "Find the client representative and request support."
  [abc.other.SupportRequest (= ?client client)]
  [abc.other.ClientRepresentative (= ?client client) (= ?name name)]
  =>
  (println "Notify" ?name "that"
          ?client "has a new support request!"))

(-> (mk-session 'abc.core)
    (insert (other/->ClientRepresentative "Alice" "Acme")
            (other/->SupportRequest "Acme" :high))
    (fire-rules))
#2018-01-1320:37dadairthe above example reproduces the problem#2018-01-1320:38mikerodRecord types in clojure are referred to by their Java Class name#2018-01-1320:39mikerodYou have to use import for those. #2018-01-1320:39dadairah right#2018-01-1320:39mikerodThey donâ€™t support ns aliasing. Their builder functions do but not the type class itsel#2018-01-1320:39mikerodSort of a clj quirk that is unfortunate. #2018-01-1320:39mikerodClara is just using clj for the symbol resolution there though. #2018-01-1320:42dadairI always forget about imports, thanks!#2018-01-1323:22alex-dixon@dave.dixon so in the one that works are there different time facts with different time values?#2018-01-1323:24sparkofreason@alex-dixon I haven't tried multiple time facts. I think it should work correctly with upsert, though. Retracting existing fact would lead to retraction of the generated Tag facts, and the subsequent insert would generate an updated set.#2018-01-1323:27sparkofreasonI was hoping to get away from having auxiliary unconditional facts like Time. The other version of async is structurally similar, but there the external fact is Response, which is correlated via a rule with the original Request. There's an additional rule that forces retract of Response when the corresponding Request no longer exists.#2018-01-1323:29sparkofreasonGiven that both approaches require unconditional inserts, the Request/`Response` pattern is arguably cleaner, as the atom approach requires some extra coordination outside of the rulebase to correctly update the session when the atom value changes.#2018-01-1323:37alex-dixonIâ€™ll definitely keep this in mind as I try to do similar things. Wish I could be more help but it gets hard for me to reason about and I find my thinking tending toward more immutable approaches which seems like the opposite of the overall approach (fewer intermediate facts/garbage). Iâ€™ll try to experiment next time Iâ€™m at a laptop #2018-01-1323:38alex-dixonCurious, did you try a callback in the rhs and logical insert? Seem to recall that being your first approach. If so what happened? Loss of session context?#2018-01-1400:29sparkofreasonI have it working with a callback and unconditional insert. I don't think there's a way to do a logical insert in the context of the callback. The session has already moved forward, could have been modified further by the time the callback is called, etc.#2018-01-1414:43alex-dixonI havenâ€™t played around with it much. Typically I do the same as you I thinkâ€¦.wait to handle it on the next fire-rules iteration, but that can be problematic in certain cases. So Iâ€™m kind of curious about being able to park/block within the RHS but I havenâ€™t thought about it much. It might be convenient for Javascript but in a parallel or multiple thread environmentâ€¦I dunno. I forget the case I ran into where I really did want to stop the world / rule activations until I could get a result, but I feel like thatâ€™s more an error in my thinking than a feature I need to figure out how to support. Donâ€™t know though#2018-01-1400:42sparkofreasonPart of what I was finding was that beyond the simple request/response case there was a proliferation of auxiliary fact types to deal with requests from the UI. For example, if the user toggled the "Favorite" button on an article, I would insert a FavoritedArticle fact, which in turn triggered Request to be inserted, along with a rule to handle the response to that Request. I also had to add clean up rules to get rid of these FavoritedArticle facts when the page changed, as well as properly manage upsertion vs. insertion, etc. It was all starting to feel a bit fiddly. But I think you could actually do this with the same Request/`Response` pattern, just replacing making an HTTP request with rendering the UI which will generate the Response.#2018-01-1414:34alex-dixonSo for precept I implemented something like the following. Below is somewhat similar to Redux in Javascript which also reifies this and request/response/fail for api calls for front-end state management. 
(defrecord Action [type payload])

(defrule actions-only-survive-one-call-to-fire-rules
{:salience -100}
 [?fact <- Action]
=>
(retract! Action)

(defrule on-article-favorited
{:salience 100}
[Action (= ?type :article-favorited) (= ?payload payload)]
=>
;; Still have the async dance but Action facts are automatically cleaned up at the end
(do)
#2018-01-1415:36sparkofreasonRight. I'm trying to do this without salience, just to see where it takes me in terms of design, possible changes to clara, etc. One thing that has fallen out is that I think the fact-based immutable history approach of precept is probably the way to go, as opposed to using whole entities as facts and trying to update "in place".#2018-01-1417:39alex-dixonWould you consider agenda groups? Iâ€™ve very little experience with systems that use them but we try to simulate them partially in precept by using Claraâ€™s :activation-groups and :activation-group-sort-fn http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/conflictsalience/#2018-01-1417:40alex-dixonSo we have :group :cleanup I think, which is given least precedence in the sort fn#2018-01-1417:47alex-dixonI still run into wanting update in place but Iâ€™m on the fence about it because immutability is easier for me to understand. Case that comes up a lot is a default value: 
(rule when-no-user-selected-article
 [:not SelectedArticleId]
  [?most-recent <- (acc/min :time :returns-fact true) :from [Article]]
=>
(insert! (->SelectedArticleId (:id ?most-recent)))
#2018-01-1417:49alex-dixonSo that loops#2018-01-1417:57alex-dixonThereâ€™s a :no-loop prop thatâ€™s relatively undocumented. Havenâ€™t played with it but seems like it would solve this case. A (modify!) wouldnâ€™t I guess because the SelectedArticleId doesnâ€™t exist. If it did as something like (SelectedArticleId :unset) then you could match on (= id :unset) and (modify! ?selected-article :id (:id ?most-recent))#2018-01-1420:28sparkofreasonI need to think about it. But I really am trying, as an exercise, to see what happens if you constrain yourself solely to the logical consistency implied by clara. I think I'm converging on something, but I've thought that before only to trip over an ugly fact that ruined my beautiful theory.#2018-01-1420:30sparkofreasonBTW, the "real world" example app (conduit) is proving to be a great way to exercise this stuff. You might find it useful for precept development. https://github.com/jacekschae/conduit#2018-01-1420:32alex-dixonYeah was thinking same! Would be nice to see it and Clara on their official list as well#2018-01-1518:02alex-dixon@dave.dixon just curious Re part of issue 371: if you had something like s/querydef would you still want ns kw names for defquery?#2018-01-1518:05sparkofreasonWhat is s/querydef?#2018-01-1518:06alex-dixonDoesnâ€™t exist. ðŸ™‚ Thinking it could be like s/fdef for queries#2018-01-1518:26sparkofreasonThat's a good idea. But I'd still want keyword names. It's not a big deal, just a nice option to give more flexibility to DSL authors. I have it working in my local branch in CLJS, pretty minor change.#2018-01-1518:29alex-dixonWhat do the vars end up being named? e.g. (defquery ::some-alias/my-spec ..) => #â€™rule-ns/ â€¦ ?#2018-01-1518:38sparkofreasonThere are no vars. I'm not defining the queries as ns-level defs. They're grouped inside of a named object, and that symbol winds up holding the collection of productions that is provided to defsession.#2018-01-1520:21alex-dixonLike most of your suggestions and changes I like that. Using defs/the ns as a kind of data structure is something I like sometimes and not others#2018-01-1520:24alex-dixonIs that part of your proposal? If not how would you envision this working for users of Clara? Would it affect session reloading?#2018-01-1521:28sparkofreasonI'm putting together my own DSL that has those characteristics, not proposing to alter the existing rules DSL packaged with clara. I handle reloading in the implementation of my DSL. Since rules are just grouped in vars, it's pretty straightforward, don't have to deal with the subtleties of CLJS namespace reloading etc.#2018-01-1603:43dadairis there a way to compose accumulators outside of writing a custom reducer? e.g., I want to get the latest timestamp of all facts, so some combination of (acc/all) and (acc/max :tx)#2018-01-1606:33mikerod@dadair there isnâ€™t anything directly for that. On a case by case you may able to get the behavior you want from an accumulator like the max above. #2018-01-1606:35mikerodIf you had a unique ID on all facts for example, you could just do ?l <- (acc/max :tx) :from [A (= id? ?id)] #2018-01-1606:36mikerodIâ€™m not sure that makes much sense though. acc/max is intended to find the max among all facts. Accumulators are mostly for reasoning about aggregates. I may have misunderstood your usage you were looking for. #2018-01-1606:54dadairThe rule engine I work on takes the general from (state, action) -> actions, where action and actions are actions to perform (in aggregate) to transition state to a new state (basically the RE is a reduce, but instead of reducing to a new state, it returns â€œdiffâ€ operations through querying the resulting state that external service(s) can use to transition the state). A difficulty that Iâ€™ve had in general with this pattern is that I need to track changes to state as rules propagate, and then insert output actions based on those changes. So for example, given an initial entity A {:id 1, :x true}, there may be cascading changes over the (short) life of the session that cause it to transition to any number of {true,false} values. I always want the stable result, so I have added tx values to track â€œtimeâ€. Given that, I may have a rule that â€œsubscribesâ€ to a number of those facts (e.g., all :ids), but I want the max :tx of each of those entities.#2018-01-1606:55dadairIn summary: [?entities <- (acc/all) :from [TimestampedEntity]] ;; ?entities => [{:id 1, :x true, :tx 1} {:id 1, :x false, :tx 2} {:id 2, :x true, :tx 3}] but I only want the latest :tx for each unique entity, so desired: ?entities => [{:id 1, :x false, :tx 2} {:id 2, :x true, :tx 3}]#2018-01-1607:00dadaire.g., to calculate a ratio of true entities over all entities (but only for their final states)#2018-01-1616:02mikerod@dadair if you use a variable binding bound to the :id field then the accumulator will give you the latest :tx per :id #2018-01-1616:04mikerod
[?latest <- (acc/max :tx) :from [TsEntity (= ?id id)]]
#2018-01-1616:05mikerodThatâ€™s the â€œlatest :tx â€œ of each fact group where they are grouped by :id #2018-01-1702:15cflemingWhat is the logic by which class members from fact types are used to create local variables for the constraints?#2018-01-1702:16cflemingIn clara.examples.java.shopping, there are some examples [Customer (= true VIP)] and [Order (> total 200)]. I assume VIP is mapped to the isVIP() method and total is mapped to the getTotal() method?#2018-01-1702:17cflemingAre the rules around this defined anywhere, or could someone point me to the relevant DSL code?#2018-01-1702:21alex-dixon@cfleming https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/941b776221690edab4904e3728715d0680bd6121/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L308#2018-01-1702:22cfleming@alex-dixon Isnâ€™t that dealing with unification vars?#2018-01-1702:22cflemingOh, it looks like field-name->accessors-used, right?#2018-01-1702:24alex-dixonhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L149#2018-01-1702:26alex-dixon@cfleming Er. get-fields a few down from there what youâ€™re looking for?#2018-01-1702:26cflemingYes, I think so - thanks!#2018-01-1823:11zyloxso you essentially want a history as long as all members of that history are present#2018-01-1823:12zyloxgiven how much the tms relies on present state alone that would be quite a doozy#2018-01-1823:20sparkofreasonYeah, digging around the code, I'm not sure it even makes sense with how rete works. It seems like it would require some modification.#2018-01-1823:21sparkofreasonSeems similar to a join-node, but has to appear in a different place in the network or something.#2018-01-1823:22zyloxyou could envisions something like layered sessions that join their nodes (3d memory from a visulization point of view) and query "downward" but thats all a ton of work#2018-01-1823:23zyloxbut ya i agree....doesnt really mesh with rete imo#2018-01-1915:04mikerod@dave.dixon I mostly never would recommend many patterns that make pervasive use of insert-unconditional!#2018-01-1915:05mikerodThe one case I keep seeing that is difficult to work around is when needing to retract internally for something like â€œold eventsâ€. Other than that, I think itâ€™s best to avoid. Even then, there are several RHS retract related issues outstanding that can be seen in the GitHub#2018-01-1915:05mikerodIâ€™m looking at your example to see if I see anything you could do#2018-01-1915:41mikerodWoops missing a part in that, will edit#2018-01-1915:58sparkofreason@mikerod Interesting. Let me ponder that.#2018-01-1915:59mikerodI am missing a part still. Trying to get that done. The concept I think can work though in terms of marking a timestamp at each stage. However, the above fails because it is letting TMS remove the intermediary collections from previous runs#2018-01-1916:00mikerodI think you have to signal each â€œstageâ€ as an explicit fact though. Without something like that, the network never knows what each conceptual step is to you. It doesnâ€™t distinguish one fire-rules from another really#2018-01-1916:00mikerodSo usually when that sort of info is missing, you end up adding it as a fact to represent the idea#2018-01-1916:52mikerod@dave.dixon I updated it now#2018-01-1916:53mikerodIt is hard to say that it exactly captures what you want. If you look at :before-retract though, you get the multiple accumulated groups idea that you were wanting#2018-01-1916:53mikerodJust requires each fact to be externally stamped with the same â€œtimestampâ€ as the â€œfire eventâ€ that they were inserted with#2018-01-1916:53mikerodI couldnâ€™t work out a way for rules to express that stamping due to logical TMS.#2018-01-1916:53mikerodRetracting is slightly harder, since you need to retract all matching facts across all timestamps (at least from your sort of example)#2018-01-1916:54mikerodThis retraction results in all prior groups being updated as well to remove the fact that is gone. That isnâ€™t exactly what you wanted I dontâ€™ think, but it conveys somewhat similar information.#2018-01-1916:57mikerodThe accumulation for Nums could tag it with the FireEvent ts it went with. Then that could be used to do a duplicate removal and/or â€œnewestâ€ result lookup on the :before-retract vs :after-retract#2018-01-1918:57wparker@dave.dixon Perhaps a model like the following might work if youâ€™re OK with accumulating some â€œgarbageâ€ over time. 
- Logically insert a "Request" fact.
- Have a query like [Request (= ?id id)] [:not [RequestResponse (= ?id id)]].
- The client would externally insert a RequestResponse fact when it wanted to "close" a request.
- A todo could be done like [Request (= ?id id)] [:not [RequestResponse (= ?id id)]] => (insert! (->ToDo ?id)).
Then further logic downstream could dispatch on the TODOs as required, say if too many were outstanding.
If you need to clean up garbage, it almost sounds like youâ€™re asking about retracting a fact without removing downstream insertions due to it.. is that on target at all?#2018-01-1919:28sparkofreason@wparker I think in your 4th bullet you would remove the :not. But otherwise, that's basically it. The "garbage" is okay, I'm experimenting with rulesets that enforce logical consistency over time, e.g. of some process of interacting with the user and an external server. So the "garbage" is really the history. What I'm finding is that you generally have some "anchor" facts from which the rest of the process logic flows, so when you change the anchor the "garbage" gets collected. For example, in the conduit example, an anchor fact is the filter which retrieves a set of articles from the server, So articles wind up inserted with conditional dependence on the filter fact. Then the user can do a number of things, like change the favorite status of an article, edit if they are the author, etc. So all of that history gets accumulated, but when you change the filter it's all retracted.#2018-01-1919:32sparkofreason@wparker It wasn't specifically that I was looking to retract a fact without removing downstream insertions, rather modify the set of facts that went into an accumulator without retracting downstream insertions created by previous activations of the accumulator rule. It makes sense from a purely logical standpoint (I think), but the semantics of accumulators in the rule network are slightly different - not wrong, just making a different logical assertion, and one that is feasible within rule network architecture.#2018-01-2901:18tcarlsIf I have records having a field used for ordering -- like a timestamp -- and want to make rules that reason about or refer to "the immediately preceding X", or "the most recent X to have attribute Y", is Clara well-suited to the purpose?#2018-01-2901:18tcarls("immediately preceding" relative to another record, that is, as opposed to, say, an accumulator reflecting the globally most recent insert/assertion).#2018-01-2902:54dadairIt can be, Iâ€™m currently using it to reason about entities that change over time. I have to admit though that I donâ€™t find it that easy to model (although I could be doing things horribly wrong).#2018-01-2902:56dadaire.g., I have entities of type A that can change over time (tracked through a timestamp), and other entities of type B that can change over time in response to the changes to type A (that is, there is a relation B = f(A)), and other entities of type C = f(B) that also change over time in response to changes in B#2018-01-2902:57dadairI find the rules Iâ€™m writing to be quite.. cumbersome, and I find myself inserting special facts just to facilitate rule propagation, to prevent e.g., infinite activations#2018-01-2902:59dadairhowever, the challenges I face come from the /fact/ that changes are inserted as a consequence of rules, if all history was known prior to rule activation, and I wasnâ€™t inserting new facts from rules (that is, growing/extending time within a given sessionâ€™s fire-rules), and I was simply querying certain states throughout a known and unchanging history, that would be perfectly suitable#2018-01-2915:20mikerod@tcarls I think that @dadair has some good things to think about in terms of what you are trying to accomplish. Some of it varies according to the situation. Here is an example that I think meets at least one part of your question though 
(defrule immediately-preceding
  [A (= timestamp ?ts)]
  [?preceding <- (acc/max :timestamp :returns-fact true) :from [B (< timestamp ?ts)]]
  =>
  <etc>)
#2018-01-2915:21mikerodYou can use an accumulator that constrains the facts that it accumulates over. By doing this, you can match things more specific/localized/â€œparameterizedâ€, rather than â€œglobalâ€ accumulations.#2018-01-2916:03tcarls@mikerod, that's extremely helpful; thank you.#2018-01-3016:05afurmanovHello, I have question about acc/all behavior, the following snippet of code: 
(ns rules-acc-all
  (require [clara.rules :as rules]
           [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]
           [clojure.pprint :refer [pprint]]))

(defrecord Customer [id])
(defrecord Reward [id])
(defrecord CustomerReward [id customer-id reward-id])

(rules/defrule quals
  [Customer (= ?C id)]
  [Reward (= ?R id) (= id "bonus-1")]
  ;;[?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= id ?I) (= ?C customer-id)]]
  [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= ?C customer-id)]]
  =>
  (pprint {"?items" ?items}))


(let [session (-> (rules/mk-session 'rules-acc-all)
                  (rules/insert (->Customer "customer-1")
                                (->Reward "bonus-1")
                                (->Reward "offer-1")
                                (->Reward "offer-2")
                                (->CustomerReward "cr-1" "customer-1" "offer-1")
                                (->CustomerReward "cr-2" "customer-1" "offer-2")))
      fired (rules/fire-rules session)]
  )
#2018-01-3016:05afurmanovPrints 
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-1", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-1"}
  {:id "cr-2", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-2"}]}
#2018-01-3016:06afurmanovi.e. ?items contain two elements.#2018-01-3016:07afurmanovHowever if condition [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= ?C customer-id)]] is replaced with [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= id ?I) (= ?C customer-id)]] (pretty much same with unification added for CustomerReward (= id ?I) the the output would be:#2018-01-3016:07afurmanov
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-1", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-1"}]}
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-2", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-2"}]}
#2018-01-3016:07afurmanovI.e. ?items contain single element, but rule gets triggered twice.#2018-01-3016:09afurmanovI am trying to wrap my mind around this, but cannot - those two rules set look pretty much same to me#2018-01-3017:01sparkofreasonI believe it's because when you specify (= id ?I) in the accumulator, clara will now make a unique binding for each unique value of id, so the rule fires once for each id of CustomerReward rather than accumulating over all CustomerReward's with different id's.#2018-01-3017:12afurmanovThanks @dave.dixon - that kind of explains it. I guess my confusion was due thinking that binding (= id ?I) is kind of "local" to accumulator, in other words it works as sub-select in SQL, however it appears such binding makes ?I "available" to "outer scope", i.e. I could refer it for unification in clauses which are siblings of accumulator.#2018-01-3017:13sparkofreasonCorrect. Or you could refer to ?I in the RHS of the rule, where it would have to be unique.#2018-01-3017:13afurmanovYep, then it makes sense#2018-01-3102:07tcarlsI'm seeing rules no longer firing after I reloaded the namespace that contains them in the REPL, even if I create an entirely new session with (mk-session :cache false). What am I missing?#2018-01-3104:45dadair@tcarls might need a code example, numerous things could be happening, depending on the state of the namespace#2018-01-3116:11tcarls@dadair, in hindsight, I'm pretty sure what's happening is caused by new defrecords being run, but trying to run rules against data from an atom that includes (expensive-to-calculate) cached previous instances of input data. Going to move the definitions into their own namespace; I expect that'll help.#2018-01-3116:12mikerod@tcarls that is common#2018-01-3116:13mikerodThe potemkin lib had some extensions to defrecord and other related macros to avoid that sort of redefinition of classes to help with reloading workflows in the REPL#2018-01-3116:13mikerodI think one workaround people do for Clara has been to do defrecord in a separate ns that you donâ€™t plan to reload much#2018-01-3116:14mikerodSo the rules donâ€™t get mismatched definitions of the â€œsame classâ€#2018-01-3122:19tcarlsOne thing that's surprising me in using Clara is how one needs to take explicit steps to avoid getting two equal records created if arriving at the same fact via two different rules.#2018-01-3122:40mikerod@tcarls yeah, there are proâ€™s and conâ€™s to that#2018-01-3122:40mikerodThere are definitely use-cases where â€œcardinalityâ€ matters#2018-01-3122:41mikerodIâ€™ve had quite a few of those before. So if you â€œremoved the duplicatesâ€ youâ€™d fail to meet the needs of someone who wanted to count things#2018-01-3122:41mikerodFor whatever purpose#2018-01-3122:42mikerodIn Drools (popular Java-based rules engine), they went with â€œlogical insertsâ€ never are duplicated, but â€œunconditional insertsâ€ are duplicated if they are not identical?#2018-01-3122:42mikerodIt was nice, when you really just didnâ€™t want duplicates, but difficult to work with when you did#2018-01-3122:42mikerodIn Clara, if you need some â€œsingle countâ€ fact in the end, you can just use an aggregation sort of rule#2018-01-3122:45mikerodI do think it could be interesting if Clara had an options where it made working memory â€œset-likeâ€ and duplicates didnâ€™t show up. There are definitely costs to doing this though.#2018-01-3123:18tcarlsheadscratch#2018-01-3123:24tcarls
{:lhs [{:type pdfsort.types.Warning, :constraints [], :fact-binding :?warning}], :params #{}, :name "pdfsort.core/get-warnings"} is invalid or not included in the rule base.
...seems to be happening consistently for me right now when invoking code from lein run, but not when invoking the same functions from Emacs/Cider.#2018-01-3123:33dadair@tcarls where is the mk-session youâ€™re using (e.g., same ns as the rule? other ns?), and what does the function call look like?#2018-01-3123:33dadairand can you post a snippet of the rule?#2018-02-0100:30tcarls@dadair, same ns, called from the -main function with :cache false. The get-warnings rule is basically as simple as the above implies -- it just retrieves every single record we have of type Warning with no filters/joins/etc: (r/defquery get-warnings [] [?warning <- Warning])#2018-02-0100:48tcarlsHmm. Unrelated issue, but I have a theory on why I'm getting more fact insertions than I expected. Looking through the explain output... 
{:ns-name pdfsort.core,
   :lhs
   [{:type pdfsort.types.Document,
     :constraints [(= ?type (or name-type header-type))],
     :fact-binding :?doc}],
   :rhs (do (r/insert! (->DocumentType ?doc ?type))),
   :name "pdfsort.core/use-document-type"}
I expected the (or name-type header-type) to mean that we bind the first non-falsey item of name-type or header-type to ?type, but it looks like it actually results in both paths being followed. Changing it to (if name-type name-type header-type) results in the initially-expected behavior, of performing one DocumentType insertion per Document.#2018-02-0115:50wparker@U2V9F98N8 Iâ€™d expect the or in the above rule to be short-circuiting i.e. just clojure.core/or. Something like this is a Clara-specific non-short-circuiting or: 
[:or [DocumentType1] [DocumentType2]]
but that doesnâ€™t apply to the case you describe; note the keyword :or not the function invocation of â€œorâ€. If you can create a reproducing case it would be helpful if you could log a GitHub issue - tbh I suspect something else is going on, but you never know#2018-02-0221:16mjmeintjesWhat's the best way to ensure that a fact doesn't get inserted twice. Is there a way to ensure that duplicate facts don't get inserted into the same session?#2018-02-0221:30mikerod@mjmeintjes I talked about this in a few posts above if you can see them?#2018-02-0221:30mikerodI discussed â€œcardinalityâ€ of equal facts in clara and ways to work with it#2018-02-0221:30mikerodand tradeoffs etc#2018-02-0221:40mjmeintjesThanks for the information. I was thinking more about how to efficiently update the session - for example, I have a list of rows from the database. Before firing the rules I need to make sure that all the db rows are included in the session. However, I do not want all the rules to be inserted each time (which causes lots of duplicates), and I also don't want the session to be recreated each time. What I've done now is create a query to retrieve the already inserted rules from the session, and then I'm comparing that against the db rows, and then I only insert the new ones. I was just wondering whether that is the best solution.#2018-02-0221:45mikerod@mjmeintjes I think that is a fine way to do it. I think there may be a potential enhancement to clara to do something like an â€œupdateâ€ of facts and/or a â€œmodeâ€ that had the working memory act in a set-based way there werenâ€™t duplicates. For now though, the external query idea is good if it can work for you#2018-02-0221:48mjmeintjesYeah, being able to efficiently update the session would be great, as each time I've used Clara that's something that I've run up against. The only problem with the query approach is that queries are only updated once fire-rules has run, which means you can still get duplicates if you aren't careful to run fire-rules before inserting any new data.#2018-02-0221:52mikerod@mjmeintjes Yeah, you should never query prior to fire-rules. Iâ€™d call that an â€œundefinedâ€ state#2018-02-0221:52mikerodClara does some â€œlazyâ€ sort of batching that isnâ€™t forced until fire-rules. It can do some good optimizations with this and could even get more â€œlazyâ€ in the future Iâ€™d think.#2018-02-0221:53mikerodI think it can be difficult to do â€œlogical updatesâ€ to facts with what Clara currently offers#2018-02-0221:54mikerodit relies basically entirely on the caller to query facts and figure out what inserts/retracts to make externally. That is if the rules are going to be written in a way that can smoothly work with the truth maintenance system and logical inserts (ie not insert-unconditional! and right-hand-side based retract!).#2018-02-0221:54mikerodThese sort of discussions have came up quite a bit here lately.#2018-02-0221:55mikerodI wrote this a while back http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html Not sure if it is really useful to you. You seem to already have a setup youâ€™ve been using to do your de-duping anyways#2018-02-0221:56mjmeintjesThanks for that post, I'll have a read. Love reading information about Clara, as it is such a great programming model. Always trying to find places to use it.#2018-02-0221:57mikerodWell thatâ€™s good.#2018-02-0221:57mikerodYeah, Iâ€™d like to try out some ideas to deal with these sorts of things. I think some sort of rule-triggered â€œupdateâ€ would be interesting.#2018-02-0221:58mikerodAs well as externally specified updates#2018-02-0221:58mikerodThe challenge would be to do so in a way that interacted in a well-defined way with the truth maintenance system and logically inserted/retracted facts.#2018-02-0222:24mjmeintjesThanks, useful post, helped clarify/validate the approach I'm taking.#2018-02-0222:25mikerodOh, good#2018-02-0503:58cflemingBTW Cursive 1.6.3-eap3 is out now, which contains support for Clara! Many thanks to @mikerod and @alex-dixon for help with that. Iâ€™m interested in any feedback, as always, either here or over in #cursive.#2018-02-0510:53urzdsHi!#2018-02-0602:07sparkofreasonIs there any documentation of the :exists feature? I saw some discussion about it on google groups and maybe in an issue, but haven't found much else.#2018-02-0615:02mikerod@dave.dixon not sure if there are any docs on it#2018-02-0615:02mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/130 has some discussion#2018-02-0615:03mikerodthatâ€™s the best Iâ€™ve found as far as docs on it#2018-02-0615:03mikerod(didnâ€™t do an exhaustive search)#2018-02-0615:12wparker@dave.dixon I donâ€™t see any docs on it based on a search for â€œexistsâ€ in the clara-site repo. Having doc would be desirable. In the meantime it is really a pretty form of syntax sugar - you can just mentally make the substitution the compiler does at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L618 if youâ€™re trying to understand the behavior#2018-02-0615:41sparkofreason@wparker Thanks. So looking at that, [:not [:exists ...]] should work as expected, i.e. that "no fact satisfying the conditions exists" as opposed to "maybe some fact exists that doesn't satisfy the conditions"?#2018-02-0615:43wparkerUnfortunately not at the moment; see https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/329#2018-02-0615:44wparkerIn the case of :not :exists there isnâ€™t much reason to write it like that though, as I mentioned on the issue#2018-02-0615:44sparkofreasonAh. Okay, I thought maybe I was just writing the expression, wrong. I'll take a look at the discussion.#2018-02-0615:44wparkeras a general API concern, it is something that seems like it should work.. but havenâ€™t gotten around to fixing it#2018-02-0616:40sparkofreasonIt does seem to work. I was having some issues and thought this may be the culprit, but it was other things (which had nothing to do with clara per se). I was a little suspicious of that binding inside the negation as well, but is seems to operate as intended, i.e. "There is no Request fact equal to the Request entry on the Response fact".#2018-02-0621:46sparkofreasonIt looks like the current behavior of parameterized queries is to just return an empty seq if all of the arguments are not bound in the call to query. It would be useful sometimes if leaving out a parameter just treated it as unbound, though I think you could only get away with this when the parameters are used in simple equality constraints, e.g. [?:foo] [Foo (= ?foo foo)]. I can get this behavior by wrapping query, but was wondering if there was a way to achieve it directly in clara.#2018-02-0716:55wparker@dave.dixon the query params are defined at query creation time and then used to key the results for the query in a map. This results in the actual call to â€œqueryâ€ basically just being a map lookup. If arbitrary keys could be missing, I donâ€™t think you could look things up that way without creating a lookup table for every possible permutation of absent and present bindings during fire-rules time, which could become costly. Looking at the code it seems perhaps we could add logic allowing the user to either pass all present params or none, providing all results regardless of bindings in the later case. Relevant code sections: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1959 for the query implementation in the engine, note the mem/get-tokens call. In QueryNode note the memory calls as well: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L431 with the join-bindings coming from the param-keys via this: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L149 Then see get-tokens and get-tokens-all: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/memory.cljc#L451 ; get-tokens-all would ignore the bindings#2018-02-0718:05sparkofreason@wparker Thanks, good insight on working memory. It looks like the inspect function illustrates how to get at the bindings via get-tokens-all.#2018-02-0814:34alex-dixonAnyone tried the new Cursive yet?#2018-02-0814:56zyloxive been using it#2018-02-0814:56zyloxthough i havent had tooo much time to actually code in it#2018-02-0815:03zyloxbut it works#2018-02-0815:06alex-dixonAwesome. Think it might be available in non-eap now. Havenâ€™t tried yet#2018-02-0815:08zyloxah, ya im still on eap#2018-02-0818:09cfleming@alex-dixon Yes, 1.6.3 went out yesterday.#2018-02-1216:16yyonchoHere is simplified example of what I am trying to accomplish: I have fact FnHolder which contains how the Temperature facts will be compared/processed. I want to have a rule which produces another fact from the FnHolder and the Temperature but it doesn't trigger the depending rules when a new Temperature which doesn't change the produced value(thus I cannot do the accumulation in the body). This behavior is similar to acc/max which does not trigger if a non-maximal Temperature is inserted. Ideally I would have been able to write the following code but it doesn't run since ?fn is not visible in the custom-accum block. Can you advice? code (defrecord Temperature [location temperature]) (defrecord FnHolder [location other-params]) (defrule chaning [?fn <- FnHolder (= location ?loc)] [?t <- (custom-accum ?fn) :from [Temperature]] => ;; insert facts... ) code#2018-02-1217:53mikerod@yyoncho I donâ€™t have an immediate complete answer to that question, but perhaps you could accomplish what you are wanting with a :test condition after the accumulation. Accumulate with something that doesnâ€™t need to be â€œparameterizedâ€.#2018-02-1217:54mikerodAnother possibility is to use a sort of joined fact. Iâ€™m not sure how appropriate it will be for you, but it would look like:#2018-02-1217:55mikerod
(defrecord Temperature [location temperature])
(defrecord FnHolder [location other-params])
(defrecord TempWithFn [temp fn-holder])

(defrule combine
  [?fn <- FnHolder  (= location ?loc)]
  [?t <- Temperature]
  =>
  (insert (->TempWithFn ?t ?fn)))

(defrule chaning
  [?t <- (custom-accum :fn-holder) :from [TempWithFn]]
  =>
  ;; insert facts...
)
#2018-02-1217:56mikerodI think the custom-accum doesnâ€™t really need the :fn-holder key anymore though. it has the whole fact with all that info on it.#2018-02-1307:15yyoncho@mikerod if I do that I will be able to process the Temperature facts one by one in FnHolder which won't work since FnHolder is stateful processing over the whole collection of Temperature facts, e. g. find the max Temperature for particular day of the week.#2018-02-1922:43souenzzo48260 facts is something that I can call "huge"? Or there is other problem on my rules?#2018-02-1922:44souenzzo(my application hangs/out-of-memory/stranges exceptions on fire-rules)#2018-02-2000:23mikerod@souenzzo I wouldnâ€™t normally expect that number of facts to be much of a problem#2018-02-2000:24mikerodhowever, you can certainly write rules in a way that cause a problem (for smaller numbers even)#2018-02-2015:39wparker@souenzzo what do you mean by â€œstrange exceptionsâ€? In terms of number of facts, the only real limit in Clara should be the memory available.. but of course if you have problematic rules (not necessarily incorrectly written, just poorly performing) you can run into problems. If you can find a reproducing case that seems like it performs more poorly than it should feel free to log an issue. Weâ€™ve mostly optimized Clara against the examples we have at Cerner but representative benchmarks of other workloads could be interesting/useful.#2018-02-2813:51wdullaerI'm doing some stress testing of clara and i'm seeing some weird behaviour#2018-02-2813:51wdullaerthe background is that I want to build a sort of access control engine#2018-02-2813:52wdullaerthere are 3 fact types: a consent, a processor and a processingallowed fact#2018-02-2813:52wdullaerthere's just one rule which inserts processingallowed if there is sufficient amount of concent for a given processor#2018-02-2813:53wdullaerwhen I insert 1 million random consents, firing the rules takes just a few seconds#2018-02-2813:53wdullaerif I insert 1 million more into the previous session, firing the rules takes over an hour (I never waiting long enough for it to complete)#2018-02-2813:54wdullaerif I insert 2 million random consents in an empty session, firing the rules still only takes a few seconds#2018-02-2813:56wdullaerwhile this isn't a truly realistic scenario (updates to consent would arrive in batches of a few 100 once initialised), I'm still kind of surprised by this behaviour#2018-02-2814:57mikerod@wdullaer that is interesting. it would seem that the insert 1 mil then 1 mil later is triggering some heavy â€œretractionâ€ work#2018-02-2814:57mikerodHowever, with that sort of time being taken up, itâ€™d be good to have some profiling#2018-02-2814:58wdullaerthere is no rule which retracts facts#2018-02-2814:58mikerodUnless you can reproduce it in a small case, which may not be easy. I wonder if you could do some CPU sampling snapshot while it is running excessively via a tool like â€œvisual vmâ€ or similar#2018-02-2814:58wdullaerI haven't found a good way to do detailed profiling / tracing yet, so all suggestions are welcome ðŸ™‚#2018-02-2814:58mikerodWell, retracts can happen due to logical inserts (normal insert! in Clara). Also, accumulators may be updated and have to retract previous results. There are quite a few reasons to have â€œimplicitâ€ retracts happening in working memory#2018-02-2814:59wdullaermake sense#2018-02-2814:59wdullaerI am using an all accumulator in the rule#2018-02-2814:59mikerodVisualVM is free. Iâ€™ve used it mostly just since it was good enough for seeing many things like this.#2018-02-2814:59wdullaerbut the funny thing is that it works just fine when doing 2 million in bulk on an empty session#2018-02-2815:00wdullaerI'll give that a spin#2018-02-2815:00mikerodThat isnâ€™t entirely surprising to me - if youâ€™ve found a bad retraction sort of scenario#2018-02-2815:00mikerodIn bulk, Clara does a lot of work in batches#2018-02-2815:00mikerodWhich has one benefit of avoiding â€œreworkâ€ - aka retractions/insertions to update â€œincorrectâ€ earlier working memory states#2018-02-2815:01wdullaerI'm comparing 2 million in 1 go, vs 2 batches of 1 million#2018-02-2815:01wdullaer(I was expecting memory usage to be a bottleneck, but it's doing pretty fine on that front)#2018-02-2815:01wdullaeranyway, visualvm it is ðŸ™‚#2018-02-2815:01mikerodSo running with the VisualVM idea. 1) Download it, 2) open it, 3) find your JVM process (it has a list on in the UI) running the bad performance case with#2018-02-2815:02mikerod(4) click â€œSamplerâ€ tab (5) click â€œCPUâ€ (6) start running whatever is taking a long time#2018-02-2815:03mikerod(7) let it run for a bit, perhaps like a minute or so, then click â€œsnapshotâ€#2018-02-2815:03wdullaer:+1:#2018-02-2815:05mikerodOnce you have a snapshot, you can dig around the callstack to see where the time is. If you want help with that, you can perhaps explain what is taking such a long time in the Clara functions of the callstack and perhaps I (or someone) will know enough by that. Or you can you can â€œexport toâ€ via an icon in the UI and itâ€™ll give you an nps file to share. If you have proprietary stuff (I donâ€™t think much proprietary info shows up in these though, but still.) you donâ€™t want to show, you could try to just find good screenshots that cut the callstack down to just the Clara functions parts.#2018-02-2815:05wdullaerI have to run now, but I'll do the test later today and post back with the results#2018-02-2815:05wdullaerthanks a lot already!#2018-02-2815:05mikerodItâ€™s probably not a bad idea to get some familiarity with digging through some cpu sampling snapshot results though. Can definitely be useful for finding bottlenecks quickly#2018-02-2815:05mikerodNo problem#2018-02-2816:21wparker@wdullaer are you inserting the facts like this: 
(-> session (insert first-fact) .... (insert millionth-fact))
or like this: 
(insert session [first-fact .. millionth-fact]
It seems odd to me that simply breaking a single batch into two would have such a huge performance impact - OTOH smaller batching could do it. Arguably Clara should try to batch the first case together anyway, but it doesnâ€™t. See how facts are added into the â€œpending-operationsâ€ on insertion at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1818 and removed from the queue in fire-rules at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1870#2018-02-2816:26wparkerIf a simple division into two batches really does increase runtime like that Iâ€™d be curious to see a reproducing case and if there is some performance optimization we could do - at first glance it doesnâ€™t seem like it should happen, but as always it is hard to say without a concrete case. On profiling, seconding mikerodâ€™s suggestion of VisualVM. Another possible route would be to look at the trace of the rule execution for a smaller number of facts - manual examination wouldnâ€™t be practical for millions of facts, but a batch of 2 facts vs 2 batches of 1 fact each might show insights. Iâ€™d probably start with VisualVM though especially since traces generally require some understanding of Claraâ€™s internals to yield much insight. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.cljc#2018-02-2816:32mikerod@wparker sounded like he had batches of 1 million. so not really â€œsmallâ€ hah#2018-02-2816:32mikerodhowever, I was thinking that the scenario was â€œinsert 1 million, then fireâ€, later on, â€œinsert 1 million, then fireâ€#2018-02-2817:10wdullaerthat's exactly it#2018-02-2816:32mikerodTrying to reuse and old session state basically#2018-02-2816:33mikerodIt certainly sounds like the batching behavior was critical to the performance of the scenario they were having.#2018-02-2816:34mikerodIt seems that there is potentially found some bad performing case in terms of updating working memory state that this uncovered. Also, I think I assumed this was on the JVM. Not sure if that was actually stated before. Iâ€™m guessing so with the millions of facts and the discussion around using visualvm#2018-02-2816:34wparkerMy point was that I think it would be possible to think the batch was a million, but actually end up being one at a time when rules fire, so just wanted to make sure that it was batched#2018-02-2816:34mikerodyeah, true#2018-02-2816:35wparkerPerhaps Clara should probably take (-> session (insert A) (insert B) fire-rules) and turn it into a single batch - but I think it is 2 at present#2018-02-2816:35mikerodYeah#2018-02-2816:36mikerodIf they were inserting a million things though, they probably did it in a single insert#2018-02-2816:36mikerodotherwise theyâ€™d have to do something like (reduce insert session million-things)#2018-02-2816:36mikerodI donâ€™t think theyâ€™d write out a million (insert thing1) by hand ðŸ˜›#2018-02-2816:36wparkeranyway a VisualVM snapshot would be informative, spending time in memory updates would be a possible culprit#2018-02-2816:40mikerodyeah, I thought it would be good to se#2018-02-2816:40mikerodhopefully some can be obtained#2018-02-2816:41mikerodI agree in general though that Clara should just batch the work from multiple insert calls#2018-02-2816:41mikerodShould batch as much as possible#2018-02-2816:42alex-dixonWould insert-all be preferable here?#2018-02-2816:43mikerodIf you have a big collection of things to insert, yes insert-all#2018-02-2816:43mikerodor you call insert via varargs if you have compile-time known ones#2018-02-2816:44mikerodYou could also do apply insert, but no reason too since insert-all exists#2018-02-2816:44mikerodBatched propagation through the rete network can be a big performance boost#2018-02-2816:44mikerodSo itâ€™s best to be as batchâ€™ful as you can be#2018-02-2816:46alex-dixonA while ago I think I noticed retracts were slow. Not the result of insert logical though#2018-02-2816:46mikerodto clarify, external retract or RHS retract!?#2018-02-2816:48mikerodFor no good reason (that Iâ€™m aware of) there isnâ€™t a retract-all for external retraction right now. So you should use apply retract if you have a batch there.#2018-02-2818:56alex-dixonExternal #2018-02-2819:05mikerodSo yep, apply retract#2018-02-2819:06mikerod(we should get a retract-all added for convenience and symmetry with insert#2018-02-2819:06alex-dixonFaster than doseq?#2018-02-2819:07mikerodI donâ€™t know how you would doseq external retract - returns a new version of the session, not mutation#2018-02-2819:07mikerodIf you have a collection of facts to externally retract Instead of (reduce retract session facts) do (apply retract session facts)#2018-02-2817:12wdullaerhere's roughly what's happening:#2018-02-2817:13wdullaer
(->session 
    (insert-all (generate-consents 1000000 test-purposes test-attributes))
    (fire-rules)
    (insert-all (generate-consents 1000000 test-purposes test-attributes))
    (fire-rules))
#2018-02-2817:13wdullaerwith some log statements to see where I am#2018-02-2817:13wdullaerthis is on the jvm#2018-02-2817:14wdullaerI still have to take the snapshot#2018-02-2817:14wdullaermaybe I'll try to reduce the code to the size of a gist so I can share it#2018-02-2817:16mikerod> maybe Iâ€™ll try to reduce the code to the size of a gist so I can share it Yeah, that is best-case scenario#2018-02-2817:32wdullaerI'll report back tomorrow#2018-03-0108:33wdullaerSo I fired up visualVM#2018-03-0108:34wdullaerand it seems to be spending all the time in clara.rules.engine$retract_accumulated.invoke()#2018-03-0108:35wdullaerwhich lines up with the theory that implicit retractions are causing this#2018-03-0108:36wdullaerI can share the snapshot if that would be interesting for people#2018-03-0108:36wdullaerI'll spend some time trimming the example down to a bare bones app I can put in a gist#2018-03-0112:49wdullaerthe gist can be found here: https://gist.github.com/wdullaer/cecf88b3266ba0ac90b4f060eefe5208#2018-03-0112:49wdullaerwhen making this I noticed that the 2 million case is not exactly the same as 2x 1 million, because of how the attributes are randomly generated#2018-03-0112:50wdullaer2x 1 million will generate much more consent for a given personId#2018-03-0112:50wdullaer(giving the accumulator more work)#2018-03-0112:50wdullaer2x 1 million goes fast enough if I make sure they generate distinct sets#2018-03-0112:51wdullaerhowever 1x 2 million tweaked to have the same overlap in consent as 2x 1 million still goes an order of magnitude faster#2018-03-0112:52wdullaerI know clara doesn't deduplicate facts, but I think in this case that would prevent me from running into this scenario#2018-03-0114:10mikerod@wdullaer thanks for the details#2018-03-0114:10mikerodI will take a look. It may be about an hour or so though. Doing a few other things at the moment.#2018-03-0114:11wdullaerno worries, take all the time you need#2018-03-0114:11wdullaerI can supply the vm snapshot as well (just need to find a quick place to upload it)#2018-03-0114:11mikerodYeah, if you have one you can share, thatâ€™d be good to take a glance at.#2018-03-0114:11mikerodHow to share hmm#2018-03-0114:13wdullaerI'll put it into dropbox, just a sec#2018-03-0114:14wdullaerhttps://www.dropbox.com/s/no6h9pwa03hzt7w/clara-perf.nps?dl=0#2018-03-0114:14mikerodok#2018-03-0116:23mikerod@wdullaer Iâ€™ve only got to look at this briefly so far today#2018-03-0116:25mikerodIt seems like these collections created via acc/distinct would be fairly large. Also, there are many of them after the first 1mil facts. Thereâ€™d be a big acc/distinct collection associated with each personId + purpose grouped Consent facts. When the next 1mil facts come in, I believe they will contribute to many (or perhaps even all) of those same big collections.#2018-03-0116:26mikerodThe work from the first 1 mil facts is stored in working memory. Clara builds the new collections on the 2nd wave of inserts. It then must remove the old accumulated work it did from working memory - in order to replace it with the updates.#2018-03-0116:26mikerodI think the fact that there are many of these large collections in working memory is making it get really expensive to remove them all from working memory. Clara tries to be efficient in finding and removing things in memory. I think huge collections may be a pitfall.#2018-03-0116:28mikerodIâ€™d like to look a little deeper at it, but havenâ€™t been able to yet. Iâ€™m not sure what a reasonable workaround may be, other than inserting everything in one batch (as youâ€™ve found).#2018-03-0116:28mikerodItâ€™s an interesting case to explore some more for sure.#2018-03-0117:41wdullaerthanks for the input#2018-03-0117:41wdullaerI can see how this is a worst case scenario#2018-03-0117:43wdullaerwe probably wonâ€™t see this amount of massive updates in a real life scenario, and if it does (say a big data migration), we can always consider starting from scratch#2018-03-0117:43wdullaerit was a bit surprising that updating these structures is a lot more expensive than creating them#2018-03-0117:44wdullaerif I can help in any way here, just let me know#2018-03-0117:44wdullaerI have a few other benchmarks Iâ€™m going to run over the coming days as well#2018-03-0117:58mikerodI need to look deeper at what is happening to have a stronger sense of what could be done#2018-03-0119:10wparkerIâ€™ve logged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/385 for this @mikerod @wdullaer , Iâ€™d suggest that we post findings there when we have them#2018-03-0119:15wparkerFrom the snapshot it looks like the memory is the bottleneck, which isnâ€™t too surprising. From my first glance over it I suspect there are some performance optimizations we can make for cases like this, but it may be a bit before I have time to write my thoughts down in a sufficiently articulate form. The benchmark and snapshot are really helpful and make diagnosing things like this much easier - thanks for that. It is useful to have benchmarks of realistic rule patterns that stress-test Clara.#2018-03-0209:52wdullaerthe insert 1 million is realistic, the update 1 million slightly less so#2018-03-0209:53wdullaerthanks for all the help so far!#2018-03-0216:10alex-dixon@wparker @mikerod Thanks for the clarification on https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/386. Re: breaking changes, Precept recently experienced some with 0.17.0 and realized I should probably speak up about anything that might affect the implementation since Iâ€™m the only one that would really know ðŸ™‚ Sorry if Iâ€™m being overly concerned. Itâ€™s hard for me to investigate the effects of changes in detail myself due to time constraints lately, and hard in general since to me thereâ€™s a fair amount of complexity at work in Clara ðŸ™‚#2018-03-0216:18wparker@alex-dixon what sorts of breaking changes? Itâ€™s my responsibility. You guys do a great job. Itâ€™s been inspiring to me to see how much effort is put into backward compatibility. Iâ€™ve narrowed it down to a couple of commits but since itâ€™s not something thatâ€™s fun to solve I havenâ€™t looked very far ðŸ˜„ https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/issues/112#2018-03-0216:29alex-dixonBasically I had some rules that I baked into every Precept session and in 0.17 theyâ€™re not making it in. Thatâ€™s definitely a fix I want so just need to take some time to make this work on my end#2018-03-0216:32wparkerYeah, just giving it a fast glance it seems like youâ€™re doing custom stuff with loading rules and such, and the changes in 359 could have impacted that somehow (again without looking at it in any detail). 359 was an obvious bug that needed to be fixed, but if we broke something else with it that ought to work let us know#2018-03-0219:37ProbablyJody@wdullaer for a workaround in your use case, would it make sense to first filter the consents? Your example shows 1/10th as many persons as events. Shrinking the search space by explicitly filtering the duplicates may speed things up.#2018-03-0219:42ProbablyJodySo adding an additional defrecord DistinctConsent and a new rule to map from Consent to DistinctConsent The rest of the rules would just use DistinctConsent going forward#2018-03-0219:42ProbablyJodyas an example#2018-03-0219:42wdullaeryes, Iâ€™ll probably try to prevent duplicate consent from being created#2018-03-0219:43wdullaerthatâ€™s also a cool way to handle it actually, I thought about querying before inserting#2018-03-0219:43ProbablyJodyacc/distinct will still be managing a large object for retractions#2018-03-0219:44ProbablyJodybut it will be smaller than the cross product of Consents and Processors#2018-03-0219:45wdullaerI donâ€™t fully control how many consent items weâ€™ll have for a given user#2018-03-0219:45wdullaerit depends on the granularity at which this will be recorded and that is not fully within my control#2018-03-0219:46ProbablyJodyBut you expect duplicate consents?#2018-03-0219:46wdullaermost certainly#2018-03-0219:46ProbablyJodycool#2018-03-0219:58ProbablyJodyanother thought (possibly in addition to the previous one) was to explode the Processor facts into something like DesiredConsent [processorId purpose attribute], use a rule to match them to a Consent and dump into another intermediate fact ApprovedDesiredConsent [processorId personId purpose attribute]. Then accumulate and match your ApprovedDesiredConsent to the Processor. I havenâ€™t tested it, so I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s more performant, but the idea/hope is that youâ€™d accumulate less when creating the AllowedProcessor#2018-03-0220:29wdullaerIâ€™ll experiment with some of these on Monday#2018-03-0220:29wdullaerthe easiest I think is to just ensure that no duplicate consents are asserted, which I think I can do out of band (the consent will intially be put on a log)#2018-03-0306:13olivergeorgeNewbie question... I'm struggling to write a rule which boils down to "This or that".#2018-03-0306:13olivergeorge
(defrecord This [x])
  (defrecord That [y])
  (defrule this-or-that
    "Print This if fact exists, else print That."
    [:or [?x <- This] [?x <- That]]
    =>
    (println :this-or-that ?x))

  (-> (mk-session 'labs-costs-clara.core)
      (insert
        (->This 1)
        (->That 2))
      (fire-rules))
#2018-03-0306:13olivergeorgeThis will print twice which isn't what I'm after.#2018-03-0306:14olivergeorge(my real example is patching data... if X exists use it else use some other facts to fill in the gap)#2018-03-0306:14zyloxya, or isnt a xor, it can indeed follow both paths#2018-03-0306:14zyloxi tend to think of it as if you had two disjunct rules#2018-03-0306:14zyloxbecause that is pretty close to what it does#2018-03-0306:15zyloxif you want one but not the other...well you are going to want to use two rules with :not on This in one and That on the other#2018-03-0306:15olivergeorgeThat makes sense. My rules got a bit verbose which is what got me wondering.#2018-03-0306:15olivergeorgeThanks#2018-03-0306:16olivergeorgeThe only alternative I could imagine was some kind of maybe accumulator#2018-03-0306:16olivergeorge(e.g. distinct but expecting one fact)#2018-03-0306:17zyloxare you expecting only one, or potentially many#2018-03-0306:17olivergeorgeMy code was really "if summary value exists use it, else calculate from many other facts" but that's not critical to the general question.#2018-03-0306:18olivergeorgeThanks for your thoughts @zylox that makes me feel more confident#2018-03-0306:20zyloxgotcha. id suggest something like 
(defrule with-summary
  ""
  [Summary (= ?data data)]
  =>
  (println ?data))

(defrule without-summary
  ""
  [:not [Summary]]
  [?others <- (acc/all) :from [SecondaryFacts]]
  
  =>
  (println ?others))
then#2018-03-0306:20zyloxbest of luck#2018-03-0306:20olivergeorgeThank you#2018-03-0306:21zyloxwithout all the horrible syntax errors i just edited out haha#2018-03-0416:29sekaohey, has anyone tried clara with clojurescript 1.10.126? i'm getting a bunch of arity warnings about MapEntry and at runtime i'm getting Maximum call stack size exceeded from schema.core (where mapentry is defined)#2018-03-0416:30sekaoi'm guessing schema is not playing well with it. i noticed in their changelog that they had to fix some MapEntry warnings in 1.1.6, but clara is already using that version so this must be a new problem#2018-03-0416:46alex-dixon@sekao Havenâ€™t tried that version. Iâ€™m on 1.9.854#2018-03-0416:47alex-dixonIâ€™ve had problems with the schema library in the past though. I think I got around it by excluding claraâ€™s version and using a newer one. That might not work in this case though#2018-03-0416:47alex-dixonWhat version of Clara are you using?#2018-03-0416:49sekaoi'm using 0.17.0 but it happens with master as well. i just mentioned it on the clojurescript channel and it sounds like it is conflicting with MapEntry in cljs.core#2018-03-0419:20mikerod@sekao so this is a schema issue with the new cljs version then?#2018-03-0419:31sekaoyep it seems so#2018-03-0419:33mikerodAlright.
