(ns experiments.a
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules]

            [clojure.pprint :refer [pprint]]))

(defrecord A [id])

(rules/defrule create-a-if-not-exists
  ""
  [:not [A]]
  =>
  (println "creating A")
  (rules/insert! (->A "a")))

(-> (rules/mk-session)
    (rules/fire-rules))
#2018-03-1418:20afurmanovcreates infinite recursion?#2018-03-1418:27ethancThe initial state of the session makes the LHS of your rule evaluate as true thus it inserts an A, which then makes your rule's LHS evaluate as false causing the truth maintenance of clara to logically retract the A that was insert. repeat#2018-03-1418:27ethancforever#2018-03-1418:28ethanc@alex.furmanov#2018-03-1418:28zylox"ok i'll insert a if there is no A. Inserting. Ok now lets look at the state of things. Oh there is an A. Retract That thing i inserted. Ok now lets look at the state of things. Oh there is no A. Time to insert A...." ~ Internal monologue of the session repeat ad infinitum#2018-03-1418:30zyloxhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ truth maintenance is the name of the game#2018-03-1418:35afurmanovThanks!#2018-03-1815:10sparkofreasonThe trace listener feature is very helpful for finding the cause of loops.#2018-03-2116:01talgiatis there a way to query for all types but one?#2018-03-2116:05mikerod@talgiat the main problem Iâ€™d see with doing something like that is that the query may become a performance problem#2018-03-2116:05mikerodIt would be heavily hit since itâ€™s working memory will change any time any fact in working memory is inserted/retracted (including from truth maintenance)#2018-03-2116:07mikerodYou could probably do what you ask though: 
(r/defquery []
  [?o <- Object]
  [:test (not (isa? (type ?o) ExcludedType))])
#2018-03-2116:07mikerodIf you have a custom :fact-type-fn you could still accomplish similar#2018-03-2116:30talgiatI do have a :fact-type-fn#2018-03-2117:01mikerod@talgiat youâ€™d have to define an hierarchy then more than likely#2018-03-2117:02mikerodSee http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2018-03-2117:02mikerodPotentially you could derive all your types to a common ancestor type.#2018-03-2117:03mikerodYou could leave out the excluded type from that grouping too, and then your query would just be r/defquery my-q [] [?x <- :parent-type]#2018-03-2117:12talgiatyeah, thought about that#2018-03-2117:13talgiatprob. better with records implementing a common protocol that will be the parent#2018-03-2118:02mikerod@talgiat it can go either way really#2018-03-2819:51talgiatIs there a way to have a short circuiting :or in clara, not sure why it is designed that way#2018-03-2819:52mikerod@talgiat they arenâ€™t meant for that. They are mostly just syntax sugar for multiple rules#2018-03-2819:53mikerodIn the case of you were sharing the stuff around the :or (prior conditions) and the RHS#2018-03-2819:53mikerodyou can implement a â€œshort circuit â€ pattern via multiple rules by making rules that are prioritized over one another#2018-03-2819:53talgiatcan you give an example?#2018-03-2819:56mikerodhere is one I made for unrelated reasons mostly https://gist.github.com/mrrodriguez/6a6f8373b25d69826b3efe154c928fac#2018-03-2819:56mikerodI can probably do a shorter one in a min#2018-03-2819:57talgiatyeah this example is in response to my colleague#2018-03-2819:57talgiatweâ€™re working on the same problem#2018-03-2819:58talgiatjust seems kinda hackish#2018-03-2819:58talgiatalso you need to know about the other rules#2018-03-2819:58mikerod
(r/defrule short-circuit
  [X] ;; whatever here
  =>
  (r/insert! <your fact here>
             :rule-marker/short-circuit))

(defrule fallback
  [:not [:rule-marker/short-circuit]]
  [Y]
  =>
  (r/insert! <your fact here>))
#2018-03-2819:58mikerodI see#2018-03-2819:59mikerodI donâ€™t know that I see it as hackish. I do understand it could be brittle to more rules added#2018-03-2819:59talgiathere is what we have#2018-03-2819:59talgiat`#2018-03-2819:59talgiat(defrule premium-video [Video (= ?id id)] [:or [PremiumChannels (= id ?id)] [LessThanTwoHours (= id ?id)] [PremiumTopics (= id ?id)]] => (insert! (create-rule-result ->MarketplacePremiumVideoContent ?id (->Rule 1 â€œPremium Videoâ€ :points 6)))))#2018-03-2819:59talgiat`#2018-03-2819:59talgiatignore the create rule-result#2018-03-2819:59mikerodhowever a big short-circuiting :or would also be just order dependent on all the logic pushed into it#2018-03-2820:00mikerodanother thing you can do#2018-03-2820:00mikerodIs let the :or fire as much as it can#2018-03-2820:00mikerodthen reconcile in a separate rule to â€œchoose the bestâ€#2018-03-2820:00talgiatthere is no best per se#2018-03-2820:00talgiatthey are all equal importance#2018-03-2820:01mikerodso what is the reason to want short-circuit#2018-03-2820:01mikerodDo you just not want multiple facts inserted?#2018-03-2820:01talgiat`#2018-03-2820:01talgiat
(defrule premium-video
  [Video (= ?id id)]
  [:not [MarketplacePremiumVideoContent (= id ?id)]]
  [:or
    [PremiumChannels (= id ?id)]
    [LessThanTwoHours (= id ?id)]
    [PremiumTopics (= id ?id)]]
  =>
  (insert! (create-rule-result ->MarketplacePremiumVideoContent ?id (->Rule 1 "Premium Video" :points 6)))))
#2018-03-2820:01talgiatI tried this#2018-03-2820:01talgiatbut it went to an infinite loop#2018-03-2820:01talgiatnot sure why#2018-03-2820:01talgiatyeah I just want one fact to be inserted#2018-03-2820:02mikerod
(r/defrule rule-with-or
  [:or
   [A]
   [B]
   [C]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->FoundIt)))

(r/defrule aggregate-found
  [?found <- (acc/all) :from [FoundIt]]
 [:test (seq ?found)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (do-aggregation ?found)))
#2018-03-2820:02mikerodInsert a middle-fact#2018-03-2820:02mikerodthat you aggregate to a single fact#2018-03-2820:02mikerodfor â€œdownstreamâ€ rules to only see 1 fact#2018-03-2820:02mikerodthis can be either a merge or just pick one if they are all the same, etc#2018-03-2820:03mikerod
(r/defrule aggregate-found
  [?found <- (acc/all) :from [FoundIt]]
 [:test (seq ?found)]
  =>
;; They are all the same, so I dont' care
  (r/insert! (first ?found)))
#2018-03-2820:03mikerodI should add a non-empty check to just avoid useless fires#2018-03-2820:05mikerod> but it went to an infinite loop I believe your rule is invalidating itself#2018-03-2820:05mikerodlogically#2018-03-2820:05mikerodhowever, I donâ€™t know for sure not knowing what create-rule-result does#2018-03-2820:05talgiatit just creates a record and adds some other metadata to it#2018-03-2820:05mikerodif somehow the RHS (or later rule) leads to a MarketplacePremiumVideoContent to be inserted with that ?id then youâ€™d get a loop#2018-03-2820:06mikerodbecause itâ€™d get inserted, which would make the :not become false#2018-03-2820:06mikerodso itâ€™d be retracted#2018-03-2820:06mikerodbut then :not would be true again, so itâ€™d get reinserted, but then :not would be false again, so itâ€™d be retracted - and repeat#2018-03-2820:06talgiatI see#2018-03-2820:06talgiatyeah, a bit of a mind bender#2018-03-2820:06talgiatðŸ™‚#2018-03-2820:06mikeroditâ€™s best to try to think of the rules as declarative and order-independent#2018-03-2820:07mikerodwhere possible#2018-03-2820:07talgiatat least for people who are not used to rule engines or logic programming#2018-03-2820:07mikerodand their job is to bring working memory into a steady and logically consistent state with all of the LHS of all rules#2018-03-2820:07mikerodIt can be a trick sometimes#2018-03-2820:08talgiatthe multiple inserts donâ€™t impact our end results correctness#2018-03-2820:08talgiatI just noticed it when testing and didnâ€™t understand why#2018-03-2820:08talgiatbut thanks so much for the clarification#2018-03-2820:09mikerodyeah, I find the â€œaggregatingâ€ to one idea common#2018-03-2820:09mikerodI think the main takeaway is that the rules donâ€™t short-circuit or control â€œduplcatesâ€ for you#2018-03-2820:09mikerodit lets you decide what makes sense there#2018-03-2820:10mikerodIâ€™d say though, donâ€™t be afraid to introduce â€œintermediate factsâ€#2018-03-2820:10mikerodto tie multiple rules together#2018-03-2820:10talgiatYeah that makes sense#2018-03-2820:11mikerodSo rule-with-multiple-duplicate-inserts-possible and aggregate-the-duplicates rules with an intermediate/ephemeral fact between the two#2018-03-2820:11mikerodthen most other â€œdownstreamâ€ rules just take the aggregated selection fact#2018-03-2820:11mikerodLater on, there may be more complex reasoning in the aggregate-the-duplicates than just â€œtake oneâ€#2018-03-2820:12talgiatyeah in our case it really doesnâ€™t matter#2018-03-2820:12mikerodif for example, they are no longer complete duplicates, or perhaps you want to count how many times it was â€œtrueâ€ by counting the duplicates#2018-03-2820:12mikerodsure#2018-03-2820:12talgiatbut I see the point#2018-03-2820:12mikerodItâ€™s been discussed before to have a working-memory-as-a-set sort of Clara mode#2018-03-2820:12talgiatI just think itâ€™ll helpful to have a real or#2018-03-2820:12talgiatinstead of doing the heavy lifting yourself#2018-03-2820:13talgiatlike a purposeful or#2018-03-2820:13mikerodwhere there were never duplicates inserted, etc. Drools does that by default with logical insert (managed by truth maintenance). However, it does have a performance cost to manage a set for working memory (frequent hash code calculations etc) and also, it isnâ€™t always what people want#2018-03-2820:13mikerodsometimes â€œcardinalityâ€ of duplicate facts inserted can matter to the rule logic#2018-03-2820:13talgiattrue it can#2018-03-2820:14mikerodSomething like a â€œshort circuitâ€ or could be done#2018-03-2820:14talgiatbut canâ€™t I control which behavior I want#2018-03-2820:14mikerodEasiest would be to just have it generate several rules#2018-03-2820:14mikerodthat all do the â€œtieredâ€ blocking pattern one one another#2018-03-2820:14mikerodjust generically#2018-03-2820:15mikerodalso, there is nothing stopping you from making a higher-level macro that did the short-circuit rule generation pattern to normal Clara rules#2018-03-2820:16mikerodIf you were sufficiently motivated and had enough places you foudn it useful hah#2018-03-2820:28talgiatYeah, can do a macro#2018-03-2820:35wparkerAgreed on all @mikerodâ€™s comments - I just wanted to mention that you donâ€™t necessarily have to use a macro generating â€œdefruleâ€ calls, Clara can take rules as data structures if you prefer to go that way (easier in clj than cljs though)#2018-03-2820:37wparkerIt seems the infinite looping behavior has tripped a lot of people up - we should probably add a page to the http://clara-rules.org site on that somewhere. Iâ€™ve also logged an issue before to fail in that scenario analogously to StackOverflowException, just havenâ€™t ever gotten around to it#2018-04-0303:26alex-dixonMay have seen this. Was the proposal for a max number of iterations per rule?#2018-03-2820:39wparkerMy personal mental model of rules is (I think similar to his) that when using truth maintenance they are like statements that â€œfor each join of things in these sets, these other things must existâ€. Declarative logic, like SQL or even Excel#2018-04-0221:51ggaillardI have some business processes that end up reading/saving data from and to a relational database. Some of my logic is pure, and some of it need this shared mutable state. Is there an idiomatic or clean way to handle side effects in clara ? It would be great if I could, for example, rollback a transaction in my database when the fact that caused the corresponding side effect is retracted â€¦ don't know if it's a sane way to tackle the problem thoughtâ€¦#2018-04-0302:38mikerod@ggaillard when you perform the side-effect, you can insert a fact that indicates that the side effect was performed#2018-04-0302:38mikerodyou can then have a rule that uses that to â€œretractâ€ the side effects#2018-04-0302:39mikerodyou likely need to make these effects â€œidempotentâ€ so they can be replaced multiple times without causing issues#2018-04-0302:42mikerodmaybe something like 
(r/defrule do-thing
  [A (= v :something) (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (do-side-effect ?a)
  (r/insert! (->DidSideEffectFor ?id)))

(r/defrule undo-thing
  [?effect-data <- DidSideEffectFor (= ?id id)]
  [:not [A (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (retract-side-effect ?effect-data))
Assumes you have a way to link facts up, like an ID. This doesnâ€™t attempt to remove the DidSideEffectFor facts. So if this is a long running process, this may start to add up as too much data in memory#2018-04-0302:42mikerodIf thatâ€™s the case, you may just want to handle the side-effects externally and clean up the DidSideEffectFor as well#2018-04-0302:47mikerodMy post on ways to update facts may be somewhat related to, if you are interested http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html#2018-04-0309:26ggaillardAwesome answer! Thank you!#2018-04-0419:19wparkerClara-rules 0.18.0 is released. The release includes performance optimizations, a bugfix in error handling code, and new APIs targeted at ClojureScript library/platform developers consuming Clara. The release adds a new listening method that anyone creating a custom listener will need to implement, but the implementation can just be an empty body so it is an easy uplift. Additionally, the :rule-matches key in session inspection will now only have rules that led to logical insertions, with a new :unfiltered-rule-matches key now optionally available with a superset of the data previously in the :rule-matches. For a discussion of the rationale behind this change see https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/386#2018-04-0520:54sparkofreasonFellow clarians (?): linked is a draft of an article of describing some of the fun I've been having using clara for UX. Any feedback greatly appreciated. https://sparkofreason.gitbooks.io/maali/content/#2018-04-0522:24sparkofreasonPlease DM or comment in the git book unless the topic is of broader relevance to clara.#2018-04-0920:19whilohi#2018-04-0920:20whiloi have just stumbled over factui and finally realized that clara is like reactive dataflow base programming#2018-04-0920:20whilohttps://github.com/frankmcsherry/differential-dataflow#2018-04-0920:20whiloi am working on datahike: https://github.com/replikativ/datahike and am wondering how i would stream datoms properly into clients with factui#2018-04-0922:27whiloone idea would be to make clara's memory durable and do a joint database#2018-04-0922:41whiloso a simple approach would realize the web after tomorrow scenario of @tonsky http://tonsky.me/blog/the-web-after-tomorrow/#2018-04-0922:43whiloon a next step one can introduce CRDTs for intermediary result sets. this would allow local and offline edits in p2p fashion, which can occur with a parallel addition of the fact to the main central database that will acknowledge the intermediary result set#2018-04-0922:47whilothe latter is necessary for the facts to be joinable in a synchronized fashion with other parts of the system. that would yield a very good tradeoff for data driven application development in my opinion#2018-04-0922:49whiloi can provide a durable sorted-map with the hitchhiker tree as a fast and transparent building blog: https://github.com/datacrypt-project/hitchhiker-tree#2018-04-0922:49whilooperations can be done in memory and flushed at distinct points in time#2018-04-0922:51whilojust to be clear the hitchhiker-tree is not from me, but david greenberg, but i have ported it to clojurescript with core.async and have used it to make datascript durable in datahike#2018-04-0922:54whiloi guess i would have to implement IPersistentMemory, IMemoryReader and ITransientMemory for durability, right?#2018-04-0922:54whiloi am not sure whether this makes sense in your opinion, would be nice to chat a bit about how do it right#2018-04-1018:57mikerod@whilo Iâ€™m not completely up-to-speed on all of the various references you posted here. I can at least (for now) add a bit of light on the â€œdurabilityâ€ side of things. Clara does currently have some (fairly raw) support for session and working memory durability. More on that can be read about first @ http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/durability/#2018-04-1018:57mikerodMuch of the working memory side of the durability implementation is up to your particular use-case#2018-04-1018:58mikerodClara does provide a Fressian backed impl of durability for the Clara infrastructure part of the rule sessions themselves#2018-04-1018:58mikerodit offloads all facts in working memory to a separate protocol, that the consumer would implement to effectively serialize their facts.#2018-04-1018:59mikerodSince Iâ€™m not familiar with each of the points you mention above though, this may or may not suit the goals you have#2018-04-1018:59mikerodI need to read a bit deeper into some of your links to have anything else to say on the subject I think#2018-04-1019:01mikerodIt seems to me that you may be interested in a way to store facts in a way that are out-of-memory, perhaps because the set of facts will grow to potentially too many to fit all in memory at once.#2018-04-1019:02mikerodIn that case, the durability alone wonâ€™t be enough. I think youâ€™d then have to do a custom implementation of the memory layer of Clara, as youâ€™ve mentioned. In Claraâ€™s early days, Ryan Brush (the creator of Clara) had a demo project that prototyped how Claraâ€™s working memory could be realized over a distribution cluster using Apache Storm#2018-04-1019:03mikerodhttps://github.com/rbrush/clara-storm This isnâ€™t maintained and very likely doesnâ€™t work now. However, perhaps it is inspiration or at least related to some of your ideas youâ€™ve mentioned above.#2018-04-1221:05whilo@mikerod ok thanks ðŸ™‚#2018-04-1221:07whiloactually i would like to have a datahike database somewhere central, stream data out of it in some places that pre-computes datalog queries for clients and writes them to CRDTs which are then replicated. the client can then use these replicated CRDTs to render its views and write to them offline in many cases while sending to the server as well. anyway, i will think it through a bit more and get more familiar with clara.#2018-05-0715:53jimbobHas anyone explored the area of exploration for why rules left-hand-side did not meet the rules prerequisites for firing of the RHS?#2018-05-0716:05mikerod@ben.borders In a way yes. That is, if I understand your question.#2018-05-0716:06mikerodNot directly that though, instead you could consider a pattern to create complementary rules to the primary rules. These complementary rules were meant to catch the opposite case of the assertions.#2018-05-0716:09jimbobyes, thats exactly it.#2018-05-0716:11jimbobInteresting.. im assuming then there are multiple complements to each core â€œruleâ€. maybe the # of complements = the number of left hand constrints or something similar? unless your compllement rule that is generated has more complex logic#2018-05-0716:11mikerodI think the structure of generated rules may depend on which sorts of things you need to capture#2018-05-0716:12mikerodYou could end up writing rules in an alternative fixed format that can generated several â€œtiersâ€ of rules from it. so there was the typically rule where you tried to match, but then there were tiers of unsatisfied matches where different parts of the rule were successively removed#2018-05-0716:15jimbobah interesting, so you made the rules very granular so that the complements might be easier to generate?#2018-05-0716:15jimbobwell.. the main rule you cared about at least.#2018-05-0716:17mikerodIn that example, you can see itâ€™d get carried away if you tried to capture everything perhaps#2018-05-0716:18mikerodbut maybe you could split the â€œconstraintsâ€ you want to test for into logical â€œchunksâ€#2018-05-0716:18mikerodAnd when it comes to joining to other facts, you can do somewhat similar things#2018-05-0716:19mikerodbut you have to capture the case that facts you are joining to may not be satisfied themselves#2018-05-0716:22mikerodSo you have to basically just come up with a way to structure these aspects you care about, then probably write something to generate the rules via some extra metadata markup on what is hand-written#2018-05-0716:23mikerodI donâ€™t think it is a trivial problem to solve and is going to end up being domain dependent. I think that this may also bring up another interesting question though regarding perhaps comparing the forward-chaining (as used in Clara) vs a backwards chaining approach to the problem#2018-05-0716:27jimbobdefinitely! Thanks Mike this helps a lot!#2018-05-0716:27jimbob@alex.furmanov#2018-05-0716:28mikerodNo problem#2018-05-0916:26wparker@ben.borders the :condition-matches in session inspection might be of interest as well: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.18.0/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/inspect.cljc#L183#2018-05-0916:28jimbobgreat point!#2018-05-0916:31wparkerSo that should be the matches on constraints that donâ€™t depend on joins - if you do [Fact (and (= field 1) (< field2 ?binding-from-ancestor))] youâ€™re forcing those constraints together in Claraâ€™s view, where [Fact (= field 1) (< field2 ?binding-from-ancestor)] keeps them separate#2018-05-0916:31wparkerThe latter is also better for perf reasons, Clara can optimize it more#2018-05-0916:32wparkerAlso note that :condition-matches doesnâ€™t work for accumulator conditions yet: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/293#2018-05-1223:03devnAnyone here familiar with any work or have ideas on taking a medium to large rulebase, and then teasing out the underlying order?#2018-05-1223:04devnBy, for instance, running a bunch of examples through, and capturing logical "groupings" of rule firings? By namespace, for instance.#2018-05-1322:22wparker@devn Would the fact-graph functionality help? https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/fact_graph.cljc I know I never got around to building graphical tools on top of it and frankly probably wonâ€™t at this point, but even in a REPL or with text-based visualization maybe it could be useful. The main ways youâ€™d get at that sort of info would be session inspection (which the fact graph functionality uses internally) or listeners such as tracing - since the resulting data is just Clojure data you could process it as appropriate to make it more easily understood in your use case. To be honest though, my first thought is that if you need to go from the actual rule firing patterns backwards to the logical order, something is probably suboptimal about the organization of the codebase in question. Code organization is a tricky thing to get right and IMO highly domain-dependent but FWIW the rulebases Iâ€™ve worked with tended to either be DAGs or have broad groupings of rules that could be sketched out with their relationships to each other on a single piece of paper (with each of those groupings potentially containing other groupings and so forth)#2018-05-1322:25alex-dixonMaybe attach a listener and accumulate rule names#2018-05-1406:18devn@wparker for large-ish rule sets, visualization is an extremely tricky problem in my experience#2018-05-1406:19devnOnce it gets past 25-30 fact types and 100+ rules itâ€™s a mess#2018-05-1406:22devnThe graph Iâ€™ve produced, even with distinct edges is huge and mostly incomprehensible. #2018-05-1406:25devnImagine this scenario: you walk up to a system like this, and you know nothing about the â€œstepsâ€ that exist within the maze of fact types and rules that operate over them. Assume that 99% of rules produce a fact on the RHS.#2018-05-1406:26devnWhat you want, is to try and tease out the clusters of logic.#2018-05-1406:32devnThere are so many variables that make this problem difficult to generalize.#2018-05-1406:45devnFor instance, whether people write fat or skinny rules, whether they have a few types with a lot of fields or a number of facts with variants, etc#2018-05-1423:04devn@wparker to your point though about code organization. yeah, that's really important.#2018-05-1423:07devnwe have ~28 files containing rules#2018-05-1423:08alex-dixonIâ€™ve made some devtools for Precept. (defrule app-asg-min-size
  [:box/type [[e a v]] (= v :server) (= ?app e)]
  [?tup <- :min-size [[e a v]] (= e ?app)]
  =>
  (let [[e a v] ?tup]
    (insert!
      [(str e "-asg") :min-size v])))

(rule todo-is-visible
  [[_ :visibility-filter :active]]
  [[?e :todo/done false]]
  =>
  (println "The todo with this entity id is visible: " ?e)

I agree that that sounds cool#2018-05-1714:33mikerodProbably would be applicable to people in the clj-ecosystem looking into Clara too if that was the sort of data models they were already using. Interesting if Precept already has that layer implemented#2018-05-1714:35alex-dixonThe devtools were conceived in isolation, so before Iâ€™d work on porting some of it to Clara Iâ€™d really want to know what would be useful for people. As it stands, you can view the history of a rule, history of a fact, â€œevent logâ€ (all inserts and retractions in order), see explanations for all of those (the rule conditions that were defined, the facts they matched on, the bindings of the variables, what was inserted or retracted), whether something was inserted or removed unconditionally, logically, or the result of schema enforcement, if it was schema enforcement which existing fact triggered the schema enforcement and the relevant schema rule, added and removed facts for a particular rule firing (i.e. diff), and the total set of facts that exist in the session at the end of any rule firing#2018-05-1714:36alex-dixonItâ€™s implemented as a client and serverâ€¦the client for visualization, the server for receiving messages from the inspected session/app over socket#2018-05-1714:46mikerod@alex-dixon sounds really useful. You should make it public in a github repo or something for people to try out ðŸ™‚#2018-05-1714:58alex-dixonYeah hahaâ€¦I definitely will, Iâ€™ve been dragging my feet because Iâ€™m not completely happy with it#2018-05-1715:34mikerodcall it alpha ðŸ˜›#2018-05-1716:07dominicmI have been using the fact graph for fact history, it's been a pretty cool demo. I wired it up to rhizome pretty easily, and was able to see that X created asg Y, and asg Y has property Z because of Rule A#2018-05-1716:20zyloxim certainly interested as well. i agree with @mikerod, just mark it alpha. works for spec right ðŸ˜›#2018-05-1716:22dominicmthe alpha stuff works very well, as long as your namespaces are .alpha too#2018-05-1716:35alex-dixonIâ€™ll try to publish it this weekend, maybe just mentioning it here will make that easier ðŸ™‚#2018-05-1716:35alex-dixonThanks for the encouragement and feedback#2018-05-1807:47dominicmhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/ Is it possible to set a fact type in such a way that this isn't needed?#2018-05-1810:13wparker@dominicm Could you give a minimal failing example? Well I put them in maps for key access by name. #2018-05-1813:16mikerodYou canâ€™t refer to bare symbols that â€œrepresentâ€ lookup keys in a rule condition if you are asking that though with regard to â€œreferring to e. Clara currently only offers special syntactic access directly to record or â€œJava beanâ€ field/accessors. If you are using generic types it doesnâ€™t attempt to resolve like the symbol e to (:e this) This may be what youâ€™re asking#2018-05-1813:17mikerodItâ€™d actually be interesting to explore making Clara offer that sort of syntax though on more generic data. #2018-05-1814:02dominicmSorry. There are many modern day rete extensions that Clara uses too. The paper is really good at explaining the foundations of rete though. #2018-05-1815:01zyloxalso just about any info you can get on rete will be intersting#2018-05-1815:02mikerodThe Drools/Jboss people also had some good blogs out there regarding rete. #2018-05-1815:03mikerodThen there is also this great blog about Clara/rete here http://www.metasimple.org/2017/02/28/clarifying-rules-engines.html (I wrote it ðŸ˜› ) #2018-05-1815:05sveri@mikerod thank to you too#2018-05-1815:07dominicm
(ns roll-alt
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]
    [clara.tools.fact-graph :as fg]
    [clara.rules.accumulators :as accum]
    [rhizome.viz :as rhizome]))

(defrecord D [e a v])

(defrule todos-done-invisible
  ;; [:todo/title (= ?e e)]
  [:todo/done (= (:v this) false) (= ?e (:e this))]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->D ?e :todo/visible true)))

(comment
  (-> (mk-session
        :fact-type-fn :a
        :ancestors-fn (constantly [:all]))
      (insert
        (->D "foo" :todo/title "FOO!")
        (->D "foo" :todo/title "FOOBAR!")
        (->D "foo" :todo/done true)
        (->D "blah" :todo/done false))
      (fire-rules)
      (query visible-datoms)))
@mikerod the first line in the defrule doesn't work.#2018-05-1815:16mikerod@dominicm that seems related to the explanation I at least attempted to give above about when you can refer to â€œfield nameâ€ symbols directly in a rule#2018-05-1815:16mikerodClara compiler cannot statically/compile time know what those symbols mean since the rule condition has a custom type that canâ€™t be introspected#2018-05-1815:17mikerodItâ€™d be interesting if Clara added support for you to explicitly state â€œfieldsâ€ that go with custom fact types. But nothing like that right now. Youâ€™d have to do (:e this) instead of e or use destructuring as you have in the past#2018-05-1815:20mikerodWhen rules have records or other types of classes directly in the rule condition Clara compiler will reflect on the class to determine its available field names. When it can do that, you can refer to field names directly as their name symbol. #2018-05-1815:29dominicm> Clara compiler cannot statically/compile time know what those symbols mean since the rule condition has a custom type that canâ€™t be introspected That explains it to me, that's entirely what I was missing. It obviously worked when I wrote the form this way: 
(defrule todos-done-invisible
  [?d <- D (= a :todo/title)]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->D (:e ?d) :todo/visible true)))
Which has a trade-off.#2018-05-1815:30dominicmI was a bit confused because it was still a record, ergo it should work (in my head).#2018-05-1815:30dominicmI looked for something to provide a custom keys function, and when I didn't find it, I presumed I was missing something.#2018-05-1815:45mikerod@dominicm Itâ€™d be interesting to have a fn that takes your custom â€œtypeâ€ and returns a set of â€œfield keysâ€#2018-05-1815:45mikerodand thatâ€™d be caleld when the compiler was compiling rules and then itâ€™d allow for the shorter accessors#2018-05-1815:45mikerodYeah, Clara just has built-in special casing to class types since they have reflection utilities available to find out how to resolve those symbols#2018-05-1815:46mikerodIâ€™ll add that you probably donâ€™t want to write all your rules against a single type like D, so that isnâ€™t a pattern Iâ€™d advocate#2018-05-1815:46mikerodItâ€™d lead to a lot of thrash in the rules since every insert/retract would potentially affect every rule#2018-05-1815:46mikerodThe fact type serves as, what Iâ€™d call, the first level of discrimination/partitioning in the network.#2018-05-1816:14dominicmMy data set isn't particularly large I think. I'm struggling to come up with good fact types for my domain. But that's likely a thing on my side.#2018-05-1816:35dominicmThe problem I have is that I'm operating in a large domain, and I'm asserting facts on a per-key level, instead of whole entities.#2018-05-1816:36dominicmI suppose I could generate something like S3BucketFact which takes an id, key and value. Iâ€™m not sure#2018-05-1817:59dominicmI guess I can invent static generation of that somehow later. It feels less "open".#2018-05-1818:43mikerod@dominicm I think itâ€™d come down to the sort of rules you were needing to write#2018-05-1818:44mikerodthe fact type is just a useful way to group facts across the network that are coming from an external and also to categorize derived data#2018-05-1818:45mikerodI donâ€™t see the fact types as being a closed off concept. They are just what the rules refer to to match things, join things, and check other constraints. All of this is probably too vague though. I donâ€™t have a good enough understand of what your data might be looking like and the sorts of things you want to do with it.#2018-05-1818:45mikerodThis now does make me wonder what sort of â€œfact typeâ€s are used in #precept#2018-05-1823:01alex-dixonWe use fact type fn :a https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/blob/712868374f7339910e1c90596ec41c26283693d7/src/clj/precept/macros.clj#L48#2018-05-1818:52dominicmI've been thinking the same, and also how certain problems of querying are solved, particularly around duplicate entities, potentially. I'm moving rather fast. (defquery created-by
  [:?for]
  [?fact <- ::Fact
   (= ?by (:e this))
   (= (:a this) :roll/created-for)
   (= (:v this) ?for)])

I think I've got a grip on this generally though.#2018-05-1920:48dominicm
(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?dbi <- AWSDBInstance]
  [?dbox <- DatabaseBox]
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->AWSDBInstanceEngine ?dbi ?v)))
This inserts 2 AWSDBInstanceEngine rules, I think I understand why, it's due to how the dataset is being queried. Do rule engines / Does clara provide anything around stopping the insertion of facts twice here? I'm quite happy to "defend" on the LHS, rather than attempt to deduplicate on the RHS. I'm somewhat trying to avoid having to figure out conflict resolution in my final state.#2018-05-1921:17mikerod@dominicm I havenâ€™t been able to look at anything today. I can quickly answe your last question though: Clara doesnâ€™t try to prevent duplicates. Thatâ€™s up to your logical structuring. You can often do something like an accumulate all sort of rule to â€œde dupe â€œ or aggregate your duplicate facts and choose how to merge it. So youâ€™d let some â€œintermediate typeâ€ be duplicated but have some downstream aggregate/merged type result from them and then be used in subsequent rules#2018-05-1921:18mikerodItâ€™d be interesting to have a mode for Clara to prevent duplicates. However there are practical use cases for actually wanting duplicates too. So the default I feel is sane. Think something about logic that cares about cardinality of matches etc. Also removing duplicates tends to be performance overhead. #2018-05-1921:21dominicm@mikerod yeah, I actually want the many cardinality in some cases. I was hoping there might be a way to structure the rule such that there was no duplicates in the query.#2018-05-1921:24mikerodI could give good example if not on phone. Hah#2018-05-1921:24alex-dixon
(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?dbi <- AWSDBInstance]
  [?dbox <- DatabaseBox]
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
[:not AWSDBInstanceEngine ?dbi ?v]
Maybe something like this? Sry on phone also #2018-05-1921:24mikerodI tend to just let the rules insert duplicates. But make it a intermediate fact type. Then have a single rule that aggregates it. #2018-05-1921:25mikerodThere are negation patterns too. Like @alex-dixon just said. You just have to watch out for making a logical infinite loop#2018-05-1921:28mikerod
Defrule example

Lhs Logic

=>

Insert IntermediateThing data from rule

Defrule aggregate-dups 

?all <- acc/all :from IntermediateThing (= ?id is)

=>

Insert RealThing (merge-somehow ?all)
#2018-05-1921:29mikerodPseudo code#2018-05-1921:36dominicmAppreciate the help here. I'll take a shot at this tomorrow#2018-05-1921:38alex-dixonNb I think my example above would loop with insert logical, not if you were to use insert unconditional #2018-05-1922:09dominicmI'm worried about unconditional insert, because I don't want ordering to become a problem. The intermediate facts also feel "icky", I think because they expose a part of the LHS which isn't able to match the user's view of the world. It feels more incidental, and less domain.#2018-05-1922:41mikerodI like to be able to avoid unconditional inserts. But there are reasons where it canâ€™t be easily avoided currently. Those are mostly around expressing removing old facts etc. I typically donâ€™t use it though. #2018-05-1922:41mikerodI donâ€™t see intermediate facts as a bad thing. I think it is really common. #2018-05-1922:41mikerodOften have to express intermediate concepts to connect rules for more complex logical conditions. At least in my experience with the rules Iâ€™ve needed to write. #2018-05-2008:40dominicmI seem to have identified a big misunderstanding on my part: 
(ns bugB
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]))

(defrecord DatabaseBox [id])
(defrecord AWSDBInstance [id])

(defrecord DatabaseBoxEngine [e v])
(defrecord AWSDBInstanceEngine [e v])
(defrecord RollCreatedFor [e v])

(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi) (= v ?dbox)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (println ?dbi ?dbox ?v))

(comment
  (clear-ns-productions!)
  (let [foo (->DatabaseBox "foo")
        foo-db (->AWSDBInstance "foo")
        foo-db-backup (->AWSDBInstance "foo-backup")]
    (-> (mk-session)
        (insert
          foo
          (->DatabaseBoxEngine foo :postgres)
          foo-db
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db foo)
          foo-db-backup
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db-backup foo-db)
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db-backup foo))
        (fire-rules))))
I cannot understand why this prints #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} :postgres (among the 2 other results, I expect of AWSDBInstace with a DatabaseBox). I particularly don't understand how it finds a DatabaseBoxEngine where e is an AWSDBInstance?#2018-05-2008:41dominicmThe total output: 
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id foo} :postgres
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id foo} :postgres
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} :postgres
#2018-05-2017:32alex-dixonLooks like the only a database box engine has an e of foo record and if thatâ€™s your only rule thereâ€™s no way it should match on two different fact types when the fact type function is type#2018-05-2017:54dominicm@alex-dixon sorry, I'm struggling to understand. Can you try in different terms.#2018-05-2017:54alex-dixonWhatâ€™s happening seems completely wrong#2018-05-2017:55alex-dixonYour rule expresses a join your input data can satisfy at most once#2018-05-2017:57alex-dixonAnd your rule specifies a join on two different fact types. So a match for it that contains only one fact type should be impossible #2018-05-2017:58alex-dixonHave you tried restarting the repl?#2018-05-2017:59alex-dixonSomething just seems wildly off. Do you think it could be caused by old repl state?#2018-05-2018:04dominicmI'll try a restart of the repl. I had presumed a fresh namespace was enough.#2018-05-2018:08alex-dixonI would too. Iâ€™m not sure how records refresh or whether they are repl friendly in general (think they need imported?). I see you were using clear ns productions but itâ€™s not clear to me how rules are being loaded using mk session without passing in the productions?#2018-05-2018:10dominicmI'm still getting this behaviour: 
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id foo} :postgres
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id foo} :postgres
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} :postgres
I experimented with (clear-ns-productions!), but I'm not actually running it anymore.#2018-05-2018:11alex-dixonI see in the source mk session with no args uses /ns/#2018-05-2018:11dominicmyes ðŸ™‚#2018-05-2018:12dominicm*ns*#2018-05-2018:12alex-dixonWith earmuffs #2018-05-2018:12alex-dixonThx lol#2018-05-2018:12dominicm` is what you're after#2018-05-2018:12alex-dixonYeah...Apple doesnâ€™t have that on their phones #2018-05-2018:13dominicmoh ðŸ˜ž silly fruit#2018-05-2018:13alex-dixonThe last result is the most glaring#2018-05-2018:15alex-dixonTry binding the whole fact and printing that out. I may be confused#2018-05-2018:15dominicmwhich fact, first, second or both?#2018-05-2018:16alex-dixon?fact1 <- condition 1 ?fact2 <- condition 2#2018-05-2018:16dominicm
(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?a <- RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi) (= v ?dbox)]
  [?b <- DatabaseBoxEngine (= ?dbox e) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (prn ?a ?b))

=>

; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}, :v #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo-backup"}, :v #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo-backup"}, :v #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
#2018-05-2018:21alex-dixonOk so the fact types are right I was mistaken on that#2018-05-2018:52dominicmI suppose that in [?b <- DatabaseBoxEngine (= ?dbox e) (= ?v v)] The (= ?dbox e) is being ignored.#2018-05-2022:11thegeez
(= (->DatabaseBox "foo")
     (->AWSDBInstance "foo")) ;; => false
  (.equals (->DatabaseBox "foo")
           (->AWSDBInstance "foo")) ;; => true
So there is probably some confusion in some of the java collections used within clara#2018-05-2023:06thegeez@dominicm the problem is here: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/platform.cljc#L11 Replace the group-by-seq with 
(seq (group-by f coll))
and it works properly again#2018-05-2023:07thegeez
(platform/group-by-seq vector
                         [(->DatabaseBox "foo")
                          (->AWSDBInstance "foo")])
  ;; =>   [[[#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"} #clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}]]]

  (defn group-by-seq [f coll]
    (seq (group-by f coll)))
  (group-by-seq vector
                [(->DatabaseBox "foo")
                 (->AWSDBInstance "foo")])
  ;; => ([[#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}]] [[#clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}]])
#2018-05-2105:29dominicmThat equality is crazy! Thanks!#2018-05-2105:39dominicmhttps://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-867#2018-05-2105:59dominicmhttp://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/defrecord > and will defined Java .hashCode and .equals consistent with the contract for java.util.Map. Looks like this is intentional#2018-05-2107:56dominicm
(definterface Foo
  (getB []))

(deftype C [a]
  Foo
  (getB [this] a))

(deftype B [a]
  Foo
  (getB [this] a))
Onto java beans I go!#2018-05-2110:52mikerodClara just uses clojure =. Not sure the issue above? Clojure = takes type into consideration with records. #2018-05-2110:54dominicm@mikerod The code that @thegeez referred to uses a java.util.HashMap, which uses java's notion of equality.#2018-05-2110:58dominicmFortunately for me, I am in an intersection of 2 points: 1) My data is all the same keys 2) I use macros for generating my types So I've been able to switch to beans with deftype rather trivially, and that's resolved everything.#2018-05-2111:52mikerod@dominicm thatâ€™s interesting. I donâ€™t know how you were encountering the use of platform/group-by-seq though. It does sound to me like there could be potential edge cases around platform/group-by-seq though on the jvm-impl since it does make use of Java collections to (a) preserve consistent order (b) do the grouping and order preservation efficiently.#2018-05-2112:02thegeez@mikerod if the promise is that clojure = is used, than @dominicmâ€™s example shows a bug#2018-05-2112:05thegeez
(defrecord ClauseOne [b])
(defrecord ClauseTwo [b])

(defrule rule-one
  [ClauseOne (= ?b b)]
  [ClauseTwo (= ?b b)]
 =>
  (println "Match found:" ?b )
  )

(defrecord WrapAlice [num])
(defrecord WrapBob [num])

(comment
  (clear-ns-productions!)
  (let [alice (->WrapAlice 1)
        bob (->WrapBob 1)]
    (println "(= alice bob)" (= alice bob))
    (println "(.equals alice bob)" (.equals alice bob))
    (-> (mk-session)
        (insert
         (->ClauseOne alice)
         ;; Line below is important, without it the wrong behavior does not surface
         (->ClauseTwo alice)
         (->ClauseTwo bob)
         )
        (fire-rules)
        ))
  ;;(= alice bob) false
  ;;(.equals alice bob) true
  ;; Match found: #clara_bug.core.WrapAlice{:num 1}
  ;; Match found: #clara_bug.core.WrapBob{:num 1} ;; <- should not happen
  )
#2018-05-2112:47mikerod@thegeez I think this actually is a bug#2018-05-2112:47mikerodI had suspicion of it being one as soon as I saw this discussion above regarding platform/group-by-seq#2018-05-2112:49mikerodplatform/group-by-seq was added on the JVM-Clara to make the operation of grouping more efficient, as well as to have deterministic ordering of the seq it returns on each run to avoid variance in rule performance. The use of Java collections for this can cause subtle problems when the bindings of fact fields are record types that are Object.equals() from Java, but not clojure.core/=. This is the case with Clj record since their Java-interop form uses Java map equality instead of incorporating the type.#2018-05-2112:55thegeez@mikerod this might be of use: https://github.com/ztellman/bizarro-collections to get a speedy group-by-seq with the semantics of clojure =#2018-05-2112:55mikerodI believe the issue is fairly isolated to the platform/group-by-seq. I think the solution would be to stop using a Java-based equality hashmap impl. A clj based one would be needed instead. It may be slightly tricky to do to keep similar performance characteristics. (itâ€™s a hot spot in the rule engine).#2018-05-2112:56mikerod@thegeez maybe, but we need a â€œlinked hash mapâ€#2018-05-2112:56mikerodthe deterministic â€œorder preservationâ€ is an important characteristic#2018-05-2112:57mikerodI believe the bizarro only has hash map (unordered)#2018-05-2112:58mikeroda java.util.LinkedHashMap is used to do the grouping by operations, then it is seqâ€™ed in platform/group-by-seq. The order the seq comes out, we want to be the same given the same input, independently from one process/machine to another (really, the Java runtime execution)#2018-05-2112:59mikerodIf we didnâ€™t need the order preservation part, we could just use a clj transient map and likely not have a problem with performance#2018-05-2113:00mikerodOne solution would just be to write some sort of collection in Clara to fit this goal. That maybe the smoothest path forward.#2018-05-2113:03dominicmhttps://github.com/amalloy/ordered supports transients.#2018-05-2113:03thegeezI don't know of one of the shelve#2018-05-2113:04thegeezBut when does the case occur that the order is different between process? And when do these two different orderings meet?#2018-05-2113:19mikerod@dominicm @thegeez I logged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/393 - fixed link#2018-05-2113:19mikerodit has quite a bit of detail on this#2018-05-2113:20mikeroddeterminism from one JVM instance to another is pretty important in some production scenarios#2018-05-2113:20mikerodplatform/group-by-seq is hit in a hot spot in the engine - it has a fairly large effect on performance#2018-05-2113:21mikerodthe order of its results can play a large role in the activity that takes place within the engines evaluation of the network facts#2018-05-2113:21mikerodIf the order changes from run to run, then the performance characteristics change too. This can make it hard to track down a bottleneck that comes up only on occasion#2018-05-2113:22mikerodAlso, different orders of evaluation could potentially even lead to things like exceptions thrown in defects in written rules. However, may only sometimes these defects would manifest themselves - aka hard to reproduce problems#2018-05-2113:22mikerodA while back, all known places within Claraâ€™s engine evaluation and compiler were made deterministic run-over-run to alleviate these issues#2018-05-2113:27thegeezThis is quickly going beyond what I know of rules systems, which is very little. I'm only surprised to see the "order changes from run to run", I would expect the ordering to be arbitrary, but the same from run to run with the same input data#2018-05-2113:44mikerod@thegeez the ordering guarantees are arbitrary from a user-level semantics#2018-05-2113:44mikerodand the outputs are produced in a deterministic way from that level#2018-05-2113:44mikerodIâ€™m talking on more of a low-level evaluation within the engine#2018-05-2113:44mikerodIt is basically opaque to the user-level semantics#2018-05-2113:45mikerodhowever, it has real world implications, (a) deterministic performance characteristics (b) deterministic order things actually are evaluated (mostly useful to reproduce error cases)#2018-05-2113:46mikerodThings get more involved if you consider using the truth maintenance system within Clara, ie performing a typical clara.rules/insert! on a rule right-hand side (RHS).#2018-05-2113:46mikerodThe engine works to put the system into a consistent logical state#2018-05-2113:46mikerodThe â€œworksâ€ part, is where time is spent#2018-05-2113:47mikerodThere are different orders/paths to take to reach the same consistent logical state, depending on how rules are chosen for evaluation, how facts are propagated from node to node in the internal network etc#2018-05-2113:47mikerodThe determinism Iâ€™m talking about is in being deterministic in those inner choices taken#2018-05-2113:55thegeezIf "defsomething A, defsomething B, execute" should do the same as "defsomething B, defsomething A, execute" I would expect the usage of a HashMap instead of a LinkedHashMap, with its insertion-order preserving. That part is still fuzzy in my thinking#2018-05-2114:09mikerod@thegeez I guess Iâ€™m not able to explain it correctly#2018-05-2114:09mikerodYes, they can do the same thing, however, the way they accomplish it may be different depending on the order#2018-05-2114:10mikerodhash map can arbitrarily change the order#2018-05-2114:10mikerodand it does#2018-05-2114:10mikerodFor example, we had correct rules running in a production case before. However, about 1 in 10 times, it performed about 100x worse#2018-05-2114:10mikerodthat 1 in 10 time, was when the hash map ordered 2 groups in a flipped way#2018-05-2114:11mikerodthe engine then went on to do extra work, it hit a performance bottleneck case#2018-05-2114:11mikerodit still was functionally correct, it just went down a â€œbad pathâ€ performance-wise#2018-05-2114:11mikerodfixing the determinism allowed the case to be pinpointed and recreated in a consistent way, the bottleneck was then fixed#2018-05-2114:12mikerodThere are many places within the engine evaluation where the â€œorder things are doneâ€ can make measurable performance differences. Even if the outcome is always the same no matter the order.#2018-05-2114:13mikerodIt is hard to explain most of these, since they are detailed things about the engine/network/fact propagation#2018-05-2114:14mikerodAlso, truth maintenance can evaluate a rule, evaluated its RHS actions, like insert!, but then later, realize that that rule isnâ€™t satisfied anymore due to some other rule that evaluated. The engine can â€œretractâ€ the work done by the rule in that case.#2018-05-2114:14mikerodThere are cases (many) where itâ€™d be better to never have evaluated that rule at all, it wasted time#2018-05-2114:15mikerodThe situation is really that the engine can at times â€œspeculativelyâ€ evaluate a rule that is later found to be invalidated by other rules. There are ways for user-level directed rule orderings, and also there are engine-level â€œheuristicsâ€ or similar that attempt to avoid premature evaluation#2018-05-2114:15mikerodSo a rule could have a RHS that says (throw (Exception.))#2018-05-2114:16mikerodThis rule may never be true after fire-rules, however, during the truth maintenance cycle, it could actually be evaluated#2018-05-2114:16mikerodSo if you have non-determinism in that cycle, you may only sometimes hit the exception side-effect#2018-05-2114:17mikerodIt doesnâ€™t (and likely wouldnâ€™t) be something trivial like that. It could be something less obvious like (insert! (call-my-fn-that-has-a-defect-for-some-args ?x))#2018-05-2114:17mikerodIf that rule sometimes evaluated, but needs to retract later by the truth maintenance, and this only happens 1 in 10 times, you may have a 1 in 10 times sort of scenario you are trying to recreate to debug your defect in your rules#2018-05-2114:18mikerodThis will manifest itself in cases like, our tests fail arbitrarily at times when run on our build servers, but when we rerun the build/retest the error is gone#2018-05-2114:19mikerodThe determinism of ordering used within these areas of Clara help both of these scenarios, the performance situations, and the finding failures scenarios situation#2018-05-2116:06thegeez@mikerod Thanks for the explanation#2018-05-2116:12alex-dixon@mikerod ditto that was great#2018-05-2116:12zyloxwe should probably codify that mentality somwhere because we do think of it as first class here when considering changes#2018-05-2116:12zylox(here being cerner)#2018-05-2116:13zyloxnot sure where though. When writing rules it shouldnt be a consideration or a concern to the user#2018-05-2120:00curtis.shafferengine behavior? or guiding principles perhaps?#2018-05-2120:03wparkerI think https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md is intended for that purpose in the GitHub templates, perhaps something there?#2018-05-2120:22zyloxthat makes a degree of sense to me#2018-05-2315:51jdtHello all, I've been trying a bit of clara-rules to assess it for a project. I'm having some trouble with with-tracing though.#2018-05-2315:52jdtIf I omit the with-tracing call fire-rules does its work. If I add with-tracing before it, fire-rules no longer works (none of my rules are fired).#2018-05-2315:53jdtIf I move with-tracing before (insert ...) I get lots of traces.#2018-05-2315:53jdtWhat am I doing wrong?#2018-05-2315:54jdtI'm using [com.cerner/clara-rules "0.18.0"]#2018-05-2315:54jdtand clojure 1.9#2018-05-2315:55jdtI don't want to trace the rete activity on the initial insert, just the activities of fire-rules and the working memory alterations there.#2018-05-2317:11mikerod@dave.tenny itâ€™s an interesting point you bring up, but I donâ€™t think it really makes sense to only â€œpartiallyâ€ have with-tracing enabled#2018-05-2317:12mikerodAll session interactions prior to fire-rules are susceptible to lazy evaluation and batching.#2018-05-2317:12mikerodIn general, Iâ€™d stress to not rely on any stateful information of a session that has had inserts/retracts performed on it, but no fire-rules#2018-05-2317:13jdtHeh, not sure I was trying to make a point. I didn't understand why fire-rules didn't work based on the placement of with-tracing. Since my rules weren't firing.#2018-05-2317:13mikerodIâ€™d actually rather it be the case that the API threw an exception if you tried to query or do something like with-tracing when it was in an inconsistent/lazy/batched state prior to fire-rules#2018-05-2317:13jdtNaively (since I am naive here), I just figured my session would be upgraded to do tracing.#2018-05-2317:13mikerodItâ€™s an interesting point regarding the limitations of with-tracing and lazy/batched insert/retract behavior I meant#2018-05-2317:14mikerodI certainly havenâ€™t dug into details to diagnose your specific issue, but Iâ€™d imaging the with-tracing added late, after the insert missed some listener information it needed#2018-05-2317:14jdtSo how should I be using with-tracing here?#2018-05-2317:14mikerodOnly add it when you have a session that doesnâ€™t have insert, insert-all, or retract calls possibly still pending on it#2018-05-2317:15mikerodso either (a) right after your mk-session, or (b) right after a fire-rules#2018-05-2317:15jdtI'm doing insert! and retract! in my rule RHS's, but but the only insert was as shown, before the with-tracing call.#2018-05-2317:15mikerodbut you wonâ€™t get tracing â€œonly for the fire-rules actions that took place, youâ€™ll get a complete picture, you can looking into tracing details to find out specific things, like facts inserted due to rules firing etc (at least to some degree)#2018-05-2317:18mikerod@dave.tenny you did this? 
(-> (mk-session)
	(with-tracing)
	(insert ...)
	(fire-rules))
#2018-05-2317:19jdtYes, that way I get tracing, and fire-rules works as expected.#2018-05-2317:19mikerodthatâ€™s the way to use it#2018-05-2317:20jdtok, thanks#2018-05-2317:20mikerodSo I donâ€™t know what your question is beyond that and beyond what I said about it being misleading in the API to let you add it at arbitrary points#2018-05-2317:20jdtI'm trying to get the network activity after the initial bulk load of facts.#2018-05-2317:20mikerodI think itâ€™d be better to reject an attempt to add it at the â€œwrong timesâ€, enhancement#2018-05-2317:20jdtAnd when I do that, by moving the trace after the facts are loaded, my fire-rules don't work.#2018-05-2317:21mikerodyeah, it doesnâ€™t work on that principle#2018-05-2317:21jdtok, good to know, still learning#2018-05-2317:22jdtThat begs the question of when it is safe to use it. Say I make a session, load data, run rules, query results. Then I want to change the data in the session and run it again with tracing. Will it work then? Or is it always safe to use with-tracing after fire-rules calls?#2018-05-2317:22mikerodIâ€™m not actually sure there is a way to look at the listener information and know the different between a fact inserted externally, via insert and a fact inserted from a RHS, via insert!. I donâ€™t know of one off hand.#2018-05-2317:23mikerod> Or is it always safe to use with-tracing after fire-rules calls? I think so and expect so. If it has issues, itâ€™d be interesting to discuss them. Also, I donâ€™t have any reason to think that it should ever change the semantics of the rules, you may just get bad/invalid tracing results#2018-05-2317:24mikerodEarlier you said it caused your rules to not fire correctly, Iâ€™m skeptical on that#2018-05-2317:24mikerodthe tracing may not have accurately reported the rule firings, but they probably still fired#2018-05-2317:24mikerodyou can test that assumption, by adding a defquery to your session#2018-05-2317:24jdtre: firing, my rules had printlnin them, which didn't print when the with-tracing was done after the insert.#2018-05-2317:24mikerodand then using a query on the RHS insert! facts that you think didnâ€™t get inserted#2018-05-2317:25mikerodYeah, if you can reproduce that case at all, thatâ€™d be valuable#2018-05-2317:25jdtOkay, well it's pretty simple, I'll see what I can do.#2018-05-2317:25mikerodI donâ€™t expect with-tracing to be able to interfere with evaluation in that way#2018-05-2317:26mikerod@dave.tenny found it#2018-05-2317:26mikerodyeah, so with-tracing does appear to wipe out pending work#2018-05-2317:27mikerodso youâ€™re right, itâ€™d cause trouble like you saw#2018-05-2317:27mikerodafter fire-rules should be safe - there is no pending work#2018-05-2317:28mikerodit may be a â€œgood thingâ€ that with-tracing wipes out pending work since it makes a session that it can actually trace#2018-05-2317:29mikerodwell, idk about that, itâ€™s just a weird situation hah - either needs docs or to throw an exception or something I think ðŸ™‚#2018-05-2317:29jdtSounds like the documentation should be a bit clearer about restrictions though to avoid noob run-ins like mine.#2018-05-2317:29mikerodYes, it is too mysterious#2018-05-2317:33jdtI'm just trying to wrap my head around other things, like the Truth Maintenance capabilities that may or may not have been present in the OPS5 systems I was using 30 years ago. I'm pretty rusty at this. Retracting the preconditions that led to the state of the RHS doing the retraction seems to mean I need to fire rules, query my reults on the session afterward, make changes, then rinse-lather-repeat, where it used to be I'd do more stuff in the RHS clauses. Thus my attempts at ... modular ... tracing.#2018-05-2317:35jdtSo a bit of catching up for me. I'm investigating clara for the job dispatch logic of a new scheduler I'm writing.#2018-05-2317:35jdtMeanwhile thanks for the help.#2018-05-2317:37mikerodsure#2018-05-2317:38mikerod@alex-dixon has done a lot with Claraâ€™s tracing by extending it for his own purposes in the #precept library. Perhaps you can find some inspiration there.#2018-05-2317:38mikerodhttps://github.com/CoNarrative/precept#2018-05-2317:43alex-dixonI think I ended up using the listeners namespace only. I forget at the moment how it relates to claraâ€™s tracing#2018-05-2317:44mikerod@alex-dixon oh, tracing just organizes the data coming from listeners I believe#2018-05-2317:45mikerodwait no, tracing is a default impl over listeners#2018-05-2317:45alex-dixonAh ok. That what I seem to remember but thought I may have been confusing it with explanations #2018-05-2317:45mikerod(sort of the same as I said)#2018-05-2317:45mikerodyeah, explanations/inspect are above all that#2018-05-2317:46alex-dixonYet listeners is very user friendly imho. Though I may have ran into some private things I wanted public #2018-05-2317:48alex-dixonIt is nice to have it boxed up and ready to use just at the same time the listeners ns is highly usable in and of itself I mean#2018-05-2318:08alex-dixon@dave.tenny If you end up poking around Precept at all Iâ€™d recommend the issue 19 branch#2018-05-2318:09jdtWill keep that in mind, so far have only looked at Clara-rules.#2018-05-2319:18jdt(defquery my-query ...) followed by a what is typically another function wrapping the query with a call to (query session my-query) gets old. Is there w away to do a lexical defquery equivalent at the point I'd call query?#2018-05-2319:24zyloxdefquery more or less sets up an endpoint in your rules network, it needs to be known before hand#2018-05-2319:25zyloxquery goes and grabs the list it generates at when things are fired, it doesnt go calculate it then (to my knowlege)#2018-05-2319:37zyloxyou can, and i would not reccomend this outside of development, create a defquery for Object that just grabs everything in the session and then filter that as you see fit.#2018-05-2320:35mikerod@dave.tenny Iâ€™ve only partially read your example so far, but one immediate piece of feedback, donâ€™t query until after fire-rules#2018-05-2320:35mikerodthink of query the same as with-tracing earlier, you have to only do it on â€œconsistentâ€ states of a session#2018-05-2320:36mikerodClara does some delayed evaluation for performance reasons. Any inserts/retracts that occur prior to a fire-rule cannot be relied upon and Iâ€™d consider the session to be in an â€œundefinedâ€ state#2018-05-2320:37mikerodIâ€™d actually prefer Clara to change for query to either (a) throw exception if called prior to a fire-rules or return something that indicates it is not ready yet.#2018-05-2320:38mikerodClara takes advantaged of batched insertion and also potentially a few other things, so it does not eagerly perform things like insert or retract. The evaluation is typically pushed to batch up the facts propagating through the network. This can play a major role in performance.#2018-05-2320:39mikerodYou mentioned OPS5, which you likely wouldnâ€™t have seen behavior like this long ago. It is more common now. Drools is a popular JVM-based rules engine and it similarly has delayed evaluation of things prior to rule firing due to similar concerns.#2018-05-2320:40mikerodThis issue seems to somewhat often trip people up though. So I donâ€™t think it is clear enough.#2018-05-2320:41mikerodFor your second question > ;why are my counters still there, I retracted them? I think it is because (query % counters) doesnâ€™t return what you are thinking it does#2018-05-2320:41mikerodIt doesnâ€™t return the bare counter fact, instead it returns a bindings map from the query, so it returns something like: 
{:?counter <the counter fact>}
#2018-05-2320:42mikerodso youâ€™d probably have to do something like 
(#(apply retract % (map :?counter (query % counters))))
#2018-05-2320:42jdtOh sorry, forgot to include the output#2018-05-2320:42jdtIt works, just not as expected#2018-05-2320:42jdtHere comes the output#2018-05-2320:43mikerodthat output looks consistent with the explanation I just gave#2018-05-2320:44mikerodso try to apply the things I mentioned#2018-05-2320:45jdtAh, that fixes it#2018-05-2320:45jdt(map :?counter ...)#2018-05-2320:45mikerodðŸŽ‰#2018-05-2516:57jdtI'm guessing the second [Derived 1] is retracted after insertion, though that isn't what I want, in fact in my POC rule set I'm doing an insert-unconditional! because the fact must survive, subsequent retraction, but I still only one exactly one instance to be inserted, i.e. one-time initialization.#2018-05-2517:04mikerod@dave.tenny you know youâ€™re inserting a vector there right?#2018-05-2517:04mikerodJust noticed that this seems odd (insert! [Derived ?x])#2018-05-2517:04jdtLol, I looked at it thinking "something isn't right here" too#2018-05-2517:04jdtJust too Friday-minded to see it, thanks for looking#2018-05-2517:04mikerodhowever, with insert! I think you may get in an infinite loop#2018-05-2517:05mikerodbecause your rule becomes a logical contradiction#2018-05-2517:05mikerodSo I think there are just several different topics with this example, ðŸ˜›#2018-05-2517:05jdtyes indeed, infinite loop#2018-05-2517:06mikerodyou can do an insert-unconditional! of course#2018-05-2517:06jdtAmending the snippet#2018-05-2517:06mikerodIâ€™m not a huge fan of those, because they cause rules to become more order dependentâ€™#2018-05-2517:06mikerodHowever, there are times where they are difficult to avoid I know#2018-05-2517:07jdtIn my case, I need to add a fact to the system, once to "initialize" the absense of a missing fact. E.g. only dispatch at most two at a time on a worker in one fire-rules loop.#2018-05-3015:58jdtMy approach now is to generate very minimal sets of candidates in a fire-rules session, then query the results, dispatch jobs, update relevant counters-as-facts, then run fire-rules again in a loop.#2018-05-3015:59jdtThe counters I need to maintain are mainly worker resource availability and active user job counts partitioned by type of job.#2018-05-3015:59jdtOkay, well, hopefully I'm nearing some kind of first load test, we'll see what happens.#2018-05-3016:00jdtAdvice always appreciated.#2018-05-3017:11wparker@jdt The Clara count accumulator should fire with an initial value of 0. Do you have an example where it does not? Also keep in mind that you can create your own accumulators with arbitrary domain-specific logic. So say "choose the top two at most" could be done. My instinct here is that it sounds like the problems you describe might be addressable with accumulators without any insert-unconditional logic, although as always hard to say without knowing the problem space. It sounds like @mikerod was suggesting that as well.#2018-05-3017:13wparkerSee the writing accumulators section at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/#2018-05-3017:14wparkerAlso regarding the cost of joins, that varies depending on the type of join, I'd suggest reading http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/hash_joins/ if you're working with millions of facts#2018-05-3017:59jdtI thought the behavior I observed with the acc/count condition not firing seemed consistent with the documented behavior on this page: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/, however I suspect I read it wrong and they were talking about other accumulators not firing when there weren't facts matching the condition, instead of acc/count. I don't have the example in code any more so will have to revisit it later if necessary. Meanwhile I'll checkout those other links you posted.#2018-05-3018:38mikerod@dave.tenny if an accumulator has a â€œtruthyâ€ :initial-value, itâ€™s condition in a rule will be considered satisfied even if no facts exists to match the accumulators fact match criteria#2018-05-3018:39mikeroddefault :initial-value is nil, so the default would not be true, however acc/count initializes to 0, so a condition that uses it will be satisfied when no facts match the condition.#2018-05-3018:40mikerode.g. [?count <- (acc/count) :from [NoMatchEver]] would bind ?count to 0 and the condition would be satisfied.#2018-05-3018:40jdtI definitely had a [?x <- (acc/count ...)] that was not being successful, or at least a [:test (do (prn ...) true) ] following that accum condition was not printed, but perhaps they're not evaluated sequentially. My rule definitely wasn't firing, but again I no longer have the code to reason about it.#2018-05-3018:41mikerodweird, Iâ€™d have to see it#2018-05-3113:06wparker@dave.tenny perhaps your example created new bindings, in that case Claraâ€™s accumulators wonâ€™t fire without facts even given an initial value. i.e. for [?result <- (acc/all) :from [Fact (= ?a a)]] if ?a isnâ€™t created elsewhere you need facts to give ?a a meaning so the accumulator wonâ€™t fire without them. This is in the accumulator docs pages I posted before IIRC, I think there are some examples in the clara-examples project too#2018-05-3113:09mikerod@wparker I forgot that that was ever changed. I thought they still fire always even without a binding#2018-05-3113:09mikerodI see what you are saying in the docs though#2018-05-3113:16wparkerI can find it in the history later#2018-05-3113:18wparkernote that only applies if the binding in question is new though - if a previous condition creates it the accumulator will still fire with the initial value#2018-05-3113:18wparkerIt is a bit confusing.. but otherwise IMO you end up with bindings that donâ€™t make much logical sense#2018-05-3113:25mikerodYep, thanks for clarifying#2018-05-3117:24wparkerLooks like the work was done under https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/102 unfortunately the discussion there is less than simple to understand.
