It's really like I want each rule firing to be sensitive to the prior rule firings in a single call to (fire-rules), but that isn't what happens.#2018-06-0116:12zyloxyou absoultely are fighting the engine if you do an insert-unconditional based on an inference, but still want logical retractions. Why are you using unconditional again? i havent followed all the conversations.#2018-06-0116:13jdtthat's just one way to do it, but it wouldn't work because that rule is going to fire twice and both firings will NOT see the Derived asserted by the first firing#2018-06-0116:13jdtSo it's not even about truth maintenance so much as WHEN the LHS is evaluated#2018-06-0116:14zyloxoh..hmm#2018-06-0116:15jdtI'm open to any reasonable way to do it, but given LHS matching those two facts I inserted, the result needs to be ONE derived.#2018-06-0116:15zyloxI guess i dont understand why you need it only inserted once and not that the final state is one in the session.#2018-06-0116:15zyloxbecause you are going to absolutely end up with two if you are using unconditional#2018-06-0116:16jdtMaybe all I need to do is replace the [Fact (= ?ftype ftype)] with use of an accumulator and predicate to express the "if there is some", and fire the rule once, haven't tried that#2018-06-0116:16jdtCan you give a sample of the merge logic?#2018-06-0116:17jdtOops, I see you did, I think#2018-06-0116:17mikerodthe rules donâ€™t assume what a â€œduplicateâ€ means to you or what you want to do with them. You need an extra rule to configure that yourself.#2018-06-0116:17mikerodExample, Maybe you wanted to know how many duplicates you had#2018-06-0116:17mikerodyou could then have (defrecord Derived [ftype matches-count])#2018-06-0116:18mikerodThen 
(defrule merge-derived
  [?all <- (acc/all) :from [::derived-intermediate (= ?ftype (-> this :derived :ftype))]]
  =>
;; Merging to one, but include the count of the "duplicates" for whatever reason
  (insert! (-> ?all first :derived (assoc :matches-count (count ?all))))
#2018-06-0116:18jdtok, digesting this, back to drawing board#2018-06-0117:02mikerod@dave.tenny Yep, I donâ€™t see a reason for it there#2018-06-0117:02mikerodI didnâ€™t use it in the merge-derived rule either#2018-06-0118:14jdtThat use of with-meta and :type is interesting to know about when doing type based dispatches.#2018-06-0118:14jdtInteresting tip#2018-06-0118:29jdtAnbody got an emacs cider clojure mode switch to adjust LHS condition indentation? My clauses don't seem to want to indent to the level of the prior clause.#2018-06-0118:29jdtRather, bindings/predicates, not the clauses.#2018-06-0119:33mikerodI donâ€™t have special indentation rules#2018-06-0119:33mikerodit indents less than ideal for vectors Iâ€™d say#2018-06-0119:33mikerodIâ€™ve mostly just let it happen#2018-06-0121:50mikerod@dave.tenny I agree it isnâ€™t ideal#2018-06-0121:50mikerodfor multiline, I typically go with: 
[WorkerViableJob 
    (= ?user-id user-id)
    (= ?job-type job-type)]
#2018-06-0122:05alex-dixonClojure in general I find it helps to just give up on making lines short#2018-06-0122:08alex-dixonMost rules Iâ€™ve written have positional syntax so everything on one line works wellâ€¦joins typically line up nicely. In Clara Iâ€™d probably do the same for the same reasonâ€¦try to group things vertically by joins#2018-06-0214:05alex-dixon@mikerod Regarding datalog syntax for Clara: Would you want it to be schema based? The implementation I have only enforces a datomic schemaâ€™s cardinality and uniqueness â€¦ nothing related to types. It enables upsert behavior, which may or may not be desirable for Clara users. Cardinality and uniqueness indices are checked and updated before inserting or retracting facts (within the insert/retract functions), and if anything should be upserted then the appropriate retracts and inserts are made. Only one to one facts are indexed at this time, since thereâ€™s no uniqueness or cardinality enforcement that applies to one to many. Overall I tried to follow Datomicâ€™s semantics on this: https://docs.datomic.com/on-prem/schema.html#operational-schema-attributes, https://docs.datomic.com/on-prem/schema.html#required-schema-attributes. If a fact is not mentioned in a schema it defaults to one to one cardinality. I think that could be changed easily if you wantedâ€¦the idea there was facts are typically one to one for UI and we didnâ€™t want to force users type out cardinality for every fact.#2018-06-0214:13alex-dixonThis would affect the implementation at the session-ish level. None of this has to be part of a LocalSession and I donâ€™t think it should be, but Iâ€™m toying with a LocalDatalogSession that takes a LocalSession and â€œindexesâ€ argument so the indexes can travel with a session. It should be possible to use with insert/retract per the normal api (`(-> session (insert facts) (fire-rules))`) though the insert/retract functions would need be datalog specific (`(clara.rules.datalog/insert)`) if enforcing a schema the way I described#2018-06-0413:10mikerod@alex-dixon thatâ€™s interesting. When Iâ€™ve mentioned support for the datalog syntax before, I was only thinking of it at a syntactic level - like an alternative DSL. The one thing I wasnâ€™t sure of in that was how the fact-type-fn would work (what would it be?). It sounds like youâ€™re considering an approach that is a bit more integrated with the semantics of these structures. That may be a reasonable thing to do. I havenâ€™t worked with this sort of thing enough to have any big insight. What you describe above seems like something that may be useful and reasonable to me.#2018-06-0414:45alex-dixon@mikerod > The one thing I wasnâ€™t sure of in that was how the fact-type-fn would work (what would it be?) Precept uses :a with a Tuple record [e a v t] (t is an incremented fact id). We use the clojureâ€™s (derive) to associate cardinality and uniqueness with :a keywords. Clara receives the hierarchy via the :ancestors-fn option in order to be able to match on :all attributes. Every :a descends from :all so you can write conditions that will obtain across attributes (e.g. [?e :all 42]). The ancestry is also used outside Clara for maintaining e-a-v and a-v-e indexes. When facts are inserted or retracted it lets us determine their cardinality and uniqueness constraints. Based on that and the current indexes we determine whether inserts and retracts should be performed so that the schema can be adhered to, or whether an error should be thrown. Over the weekend I worked on a design that doesnâ€™t use global vars for the indexes and ancestors hierarchy. I havenâ€™t figured it out yet. insert! seems like the real challenge. Itâ€™s not part of the ISession protocol and only takes facts as arguments. My best guess is that we should bind a sessionâ€™s indexes and ancestry to a dynamic var (like session-context) when fire rules is called on it. Then we could read from it from within an insert! implementation and update the indexes there. I think thatâ€™d require something like a LocalDatalogSession that could take these extra arguments in its constructor.#2018-06-0415:11mikerod@alex-dixon this makes sense to me.#2018-06-0415:11mikerodI was thinking that the :a may be the best fact type too, wasnâ€™t sure. And good point on deriving from :all#2018-06-0512:57jdtAny tips on analyzing where I'm spending time in rules? (for example, which rules).#2018-06-0513:10mikerod@dave.tenny should be possible to use Clara tracing to take a look at something like that. Although itâ€™s exploratory to find what you want given the data structures it returns. You could get something like count of times things were evaluated that way. #2018-06-0513:10mikerodItâ€™d be nice if Clara had more supporting functions for this purpose though. #2018-06-0513:13jdtThere are some minimum number of queries in addition to the above rules.#2018-06-0513:16jdtBetween each fire-rules the dispatcher will select one job per job type (so 15 in this numbers case), dispatch it, update the ActiveUserJobCount, WorkerResource, facts, and retract the dispatched JobRequest facts.#2018-06-0513:17jdtSo I'm averaging about 1-3 seconds per job dispatch, and whacking the hell out of my CPU. (Memory footprint is good however... surprise!)#2018-06-0513:23jdtI had originally hoped to do the fact maintenance for active user job counts (used for round robin eligibility consideration), and worker resource stats (to track remaining worker capacity), in the RHS of rules. But I gave that up early in the process because it was a side-effect oriented process with a bunch of [:not A] => A scenarios, which might have been doable, but it was really the timing of the rule LHS evaluations that killed it, since LHS evaluations are perceptually "in parallel" and not sequential with respect to cause and effect for a given rule.#2018-06-0513:24jdtSo I compute some eligible things, then do the dispatching and accounting between calls to fire-rules, then do it all over again (always saving and continuing from the updated session).#2018-06-0513:44mikerod> but it was really the timing of the rule LHS evaluations that killed it, since LHS evaluations are perceptually â€œin parallelâ€ and not sequential with respect to cause and effect for a given rule. Only the case for insert-unconditional! (and possibly even a defect), but yeah. if you have to extract these facts after they are â€œdoneâ€ it may make most sense to be an external thing anyways.#2018-06-0513:44mikerod@dave.tenny I can look at your rules from above some, sounds too slow#2018-06-0513:45jdtHappy to share the whole module, nothing but some pretty rules and ugly code to do the bookkeeping and setup mock data and such#2018-06-0513:46mikerodwhen something takes long in that range of seconds (like 10+) I tend to do a cpu sampling#2018-06-0513:46jdtJob dispatch and completion is all about accounting then trying again with updated rules.#2018-06-0513:46mikerodWith a profiler, I tend to use visualVM because it is good enough for this situation#2018-06-0513:46mikerodsometimes it gives quicker leads to what is causing issues. Sometimes it is too opaque unless you know the rule engine internals, but not necessarily always#2018-06-0513:46jdtYeah, I'm having problems with VisualVM on my Linux system becuase of some JNI/Jar problem I can't figure out, and HPROF sampling is usually useless#2018-06-0513:47mikerodbut also, doing some just blunt counting of times that certain conditions in rules and/or rule RHS were fired sometimes can give you the outliers as well#2018-06-0513:47mikerodHmm#2018-06-0513:47mikerodYeah, VisualVM with â€œcpu samplerâ€ is what I have used. if things are whacky there, not sure hah#2018-06-0513:47jdtYeah, I'm looking at instrumenting, is it possible to capture the time spent, via instrumentation, in each LHS condition?#2018-06-0513:47mikerodwell, time will obviously go to the instrumentation/tracing you do#2018-06-0513:48mikerodbut if you do something like just gather counts#2018-06-0513:48mikerodthat is not time-sensitive anyways#2018-06-0513:48jdtRe the rules, any obvious stupid hash-join failures or things that might be better done in predicates or with accumulators?#2018-06-0513:48mikerodwhen Iâ€™ve tried â€œcounting condition/rhsâ€ firings before in bad performance cases, there are often outliers#2018-06-0513:48mikerodLike most things evaluation perhaps no more than 1k times for example#2018-06-0513:48mikerodbut then you find something that evaluates like 1 mil times#2018-06-0513:49mikerodtypically its something like that#2018-06-0513:49jdtIn my case I'm worried it's the tests in the conditions that are firing a lot, but I'll get more data.#2018-06-0513:49mikerodSo even your rule like worker-viable-jobs may be pretty heavy#2018-06-0513:50mikerodIâ€™m just looking over what you had and your sort of fact counts#2018-06-0513:50jdtFor example, if I'm doing N^2 firings on the worker-viable-jobs conditions for the 100k job requests and 45 worker-resource facts.#2018-06-0513:50mikerodyou have 100K job requests facts and 45 workers, and you also have a :not in that rule#2018-06-0513:50mikerodso you are something like 100K x 100K x 45 territory#2018-06-0513:51jdtRight, is there a way to achieve the semantics there without the combinatorics?#2018-06-0513:51mikerodprobably just doing millions of comparisons with clj = and < etc and it adds up#2018-06-0513:51mikerodyes, I think there is a way out of it#2018-06-0513:52jdtThis is where, if I could update the worker resources in the RHS and immediately prune the possibilities for the next firing of worker-viable-job it would have been a win, but that doesn't work because all the worker-viable-jobs are going to fire regardless of whether I update the worker resources because of that seemingly parallel LHS evaluation protocol.#2018-06-0513:52mikerodExtract a rule, find the oldest jobs first, then only bring those into the join with WorkerResource rule here#2018-06-0513:53mikerodin general, you have a lot of JobRequest facts to deal with. You want to avoid any rule that may do a join across that set of facts with itself#2018-06-0513:53mikerodIâ€™m not sure how memory and thread factor into an â€œoldest jobâ€ situation#2018-06-0513:53mikerodso hard to give you an example#2018-06-0513:53jdtExcept we'll still need to potentially consider the next oldest, and so on, until we find one that fits the avaialble worker resources, so does an extra rule really help?#2018-06-0513:54mikerod
[:not [JobRequest (< job-id ?job-id) 
                    (= ?job-type job-type)
                    (= ?user-id user-id)
                    (<= threads ?threads)
                    (<= memory ?memory)]]
#2018-06-0513:54jdtThe memory and thread tests are to test only for jobs that can actually execute on the worker resources, i.e. for which enough resources exist.#2018-06-0513:54jdtThat's the "viable" part of the semantics#2018-06-0513:55mikerodthe rule can help, just have to figure out what the correct rule is#2018-06-0513:55mikerodthinking about it#2018-06-0513:55jdtAny advice for a beginner on how to effectively use the tracing API here? The one time I tried it there was too much data to process, and that was on the simplest most minimal amount of facts.#2018-06-0513:57jdtre: the "oldest job" stuff, I was wondering if accumulators would in any way help, I have no idea how they're implemented w.r..t incremental fact maintenance.#2018-06-0514:11mikerod> Any advice for a beginner on how to effectively use the tracing API here? The one time I tried it there was too much data to process, and that was on the simplest most minimal amount of facts. I havenâ€™t used it as much as Iâ€™d expect. I was used to rolling my own stuff prior to when tracing stuff was introduced. However, for counting, I believe you can do something like: 
(let [traced (-> (clara.rules/mk-session <your rules>)
                 (clara.tools.tracing/with-tracing)
                 (insert <your facts>)
                 fire-rules
                 clara.tools.tracing/get-trace)]
  (frequencies (map :node-id traced)))
#2018-06-0514:12mikerodor perhaps better sorted: 
(let [tr (-> (clara.rules/mk-session [temp-rule])
                                       (t/with-tracing)
                                       (insert (->Temperature 10 "MCI")
                                               (->Temperature 20 "MCI"))
                                       (fire-rules)
                                       (t/get-trace )
                                       )]
                            (->>  (map :node-id tr)
                                  frequencies
                                  (sort-by val)
                                  reverse))
#2018-06-0514:13mikerodonce you know the highest count :node-ids you can look those up in the rulebase associated with the session#2018-06-0514:13jdtexcellent, thanks#2018-06-0514:16mikerod
(let [session (-> (clara.rules/mk-session <your rules>)
                  (t/with-tracing)
                  (insert <your facts>)
                  (fire-rules))

      trace (t/get-trace session)
      node-id <whatever node id in question from `trace`>


      {:keys [rulebase]} (clara.rules.engine/components session)
      {:keys [id-to-node]} rulebase]
  (get id-to-node node-id) )
This is how you could look up the node-id to try to find what node in the engine it is#2018-06-0514:16mikeroda node will be a defrecord of stuff, not all that readable to you, but you should be able to recognize aspects of it and align it back to your rules typically#2018-06-0515:09jdtThanks Mike, I'll have a look#2018-06-0516:38jdt@mikerod as I am still new at accumulators, I'm trying to discern the purpose of the ?user-id binding on line 30 in the above snippet. Is it used so that the rule will fire once for each distinct user id? Does it work given that ?user-id is not otherwise bound?#2018-06-0516:43mikerod@dave.tenny > Is it used so that the rule will fire once for each distinct user id? yes, in thatâ€™s its purpose in that example#2018-06-0516:44mikerodwhich makes me realize I had a typo there, it should have been (= ?user-id (-> this :worker-viable-job :user-id)) since it was nested one level lower, will update. Sorry if that caused confusion.#2018-06-0516:46mikerodAccumulators behavior with field-level bindings like that is explained more in http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/#2018-06-0516:53jdtI'm getting null pointer exceptions on calls to < that I think are the accumulator, but are maybe something else, unfortunately the stack trace doesn't not clue me in other than it's in (fire-rules), pretty much. However the acc/min isn't documented to accept a :initial-value argument, so it's probably something else. Just in case something obvious is missing above.#2018-06-0516:58jdtAh wait, maybe it's because I removed an explicit binding of :user-id in the candidate rule.#2018-06-0516:59mikerod@dave.tenny more typoâ€™s because I forgot the thing was neste#2018-06-0517:00mikerod(acc/min (comp :job-id :worker-viable-job) :returns-fact true), I updated the snippet above to reflect that#2018-06-0517:00mikerodif :job-id may be nil though, would have to defend against it#2018-06-1502:25hiredmanI've just started exploring with Clara, and don't have a ton of experience with rules systems, and I've run into a surprise. When I have a rule something like [Foo (= x 1)] (not [Foo (= x 2)]) => (insert! (->Foo 2)) it goes in to an infinite loop#2018-06-1503:21mikerod@hiredman insert! Is a conditional insert. These inserts are monitored by a â€œtruth maintenance systemâ€ (aka TMS). The goal of the TMS is to keep all of the rules and their consequences in a logically consistent state#2018-06-1503:21mikerodSo the rule you put above is a logical contradiction. #2018-06-1503:21mikerodThere are workarounds. Depending on what it is you are trying to achieve. #2018-06-1503:23mikerodAlso the TMS is useful to be able to express large numbers of rules in a declarative/non order dependent way. You donâ€™t have to worry about â€œwhen something was insertedâ€ to be careful to not check for it â€œbefore it was insertedâ€ and that sort of thing. It leads to a less brittle system. #2018-06-1503:23mikerodThe concept of a TMS has been around in many of the more modern rule systems. #2018-06-1518:15hiredman@mikerod thanks, makes sense, I hadn't connected those dots#2018-06-1518:24mikerod@hiredman I will say that the engine going into an infinite loop without trying to help isnâ€™t really user-friendly. The action a rule does on the right-hand side (aka RHS) of the => is arbitrary from the rules engine perspective, so it cannot â€œknow it is in an infinite loopâ€. However, something could reasonably be added to allow a configurable upper limit on the times youâ€™d allow what may â€œlook like a loopâ€ to be allowed until the engine halted and reported a possible error. For now though, it could be documented as a FAQ or something as well.#2018-06-1518:24mikerodeg â€œIf the engine seems to be in an infinite loop, this is commonly the causeâ€¦â€#2018-06-1518:29mikerodThere are cases that you may think it is hard to see how to not need a rule like you have above. Some of those can actually be tricky to express, but in many cases that Iâ€™ve seen, accumulators can be used to achieve the semantics desired, or a new fact type that is used for the derived fact that is different from what is deriving it eg instead of 
[:not [Foo (= x 2)]] => (insert! (->Foo 2))
Something like 
[:not [Foo (= x 2)]] => (insert! (->DerivedFoo 2))
#2018-06-1615:58sparkofreasonJust a quick brain-bubble on this topic: I wonder if there could be a sort of "debug mode" where during fire-rules a graph is built for the causal relationships, e.g. Fact A -> Rule B -> Fact C -> Rule D... That graph could be analyzed for cycles. Haven't thought this through at all, and would guess it isn't perfect, but perhaps better than nothing?#2018-06-1616:36alex-dixonI think for Clojure :no-loop true can be provided in the properties map. Iâ€™ve heard it mentioned a couple times#2018-06-1616:37alex-dixonhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/8c4898498b5bff7a231f5c5ce74d56ab84453a53/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L1108#2018-06-1617:47mikerod@dave.dixon the thing is that it isnâ€™t clear it is actually looping just because it goes through the same rule path a few times. RHS can do arbitrary logic. Including have different paths they may take via conditionals. #2018-06-1617:47mikerodSome sort of general warnings could be nice perhaps that suggest that â€œmaybeâ€ there is a loop though#2018-06-1617:50mikerod@alex-dixon yep. It exists. Donâ€™t generally recommend it unless the use case really makes sense to use it. #2018-06-1617:50mikerodTypically itâ€™s best to solve the problems just purely via the logical TMS if practical. #2018-06-1617:52sparkofreasonYeah, it's another version of the halting problem. But it might be a nice way to get some visibility on the causal structure, and highlight loops that are unexpected.#2018-06-1618:03mikerodYes indeed#2018-06-2517:58tony.kayHi, is it ok to use *current-session*? it isnâ€™t documented, but it would be handy to run queries during rule executionâ€¦or is that just a bad idea?#2018-06-2518:30mikerod@tony.kay sounds like a bad idea ðŸ˜›#2018-06-2518:30mikerodAre you wanting to use it for debugging or for more than that?#2018-06-2518:31tony.kaySo, we have facts that are stored in a datomic-fashionâ€¦so â€œinsertâ€ needs to know if the fact (as an E/A pair) is already present so we can retract the old value before inserting the new one#2018-06-2518:31mikerodThe thing is (a) it isnâ€™t documented/impl detail, so would be subject to breaking changes (b) but even more worrisome is that there isnâ€™t any strong guarantees about rules firing order or if a rule will be fired/retracted/re-fired etc So arbitrarily looking into the *current-session* could cause problems#2018-06-2518:31tony.kayso, we need to know what is in the current session#2018-06-2518:32tony.kayyeah, I understand that, but rule firing order doesnâ€™t matter in that caseâ€¦I need to know if a fact is in there right as that rule fires#2018-06-2518:32mikerodI think that http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html relates to this concept of safely â€œupdatingâ€ facts#2018-06-2518:32mikerodalthough it doesnâ€™t provide an ideal solution#2018-06-2518:33mikerodYou can use things like insert-unconditional! and also :no-loop properties on a defrule to attempt to do things like you are describing. However, I try to avoid those since they become more imperative/order-dependent etc in nature. Also, they can have interactions at odds with the rest of the truth maintenance system.#2018-06-2518:33mikerodIn the post linked above, I mention â€œApproach 1: Append only updatesâ€#2018-06-2518:34mikerodthatâ€™s the easiest, but can run up against memory limits depending on how you are using things#2018-06-2518:35mikerodI didnâ€™t explain in that post, but I think the â€œApproach 1: Append only updatesâ€ could be extended to have an external process/fn that cleans up old UpdatingFactSnapshot later (using a query to access them externally).#2018-06-2518:37tony.kaycool, thanks. Iâ€™ll read the article. Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™m missing somehting about the TMS that Iâ€™m not clear on ðŸ™‚ Hopefully thatâ€™ll get me squared up#2018-06-2519:01tony.kay@mikerod so, in the project Iâ€™m helping with, they are not using the logic tracking facilityâ€¦so invalidating a truth does not auto-retract anything. Perhaps this is a problem that should be addressed as well, but does that affect your answer at all?#2018-06-2519:01tony.kay(e.g. they are using unconditional inserts)#2018-06-2519:02tony.kayoh, I guess you mentioned thatâ€¦unconditional#2018-06-2519:02mikerodIf you use unconditional inserts, those rules will rely on order of firing#2018-06-2519:02tony.kayI lost track while reading the article ðŸ˜œ#2018-06-2519:02mikerodsince the rules wonâ€™t try to â€œcorrectâ€ for inconsistencies if a rule fires in the â€œwrong orderâ€#2018-06-2519:03mikerodbut if you are opting out of truth maintenance, then yeah, you can do unconditional things#2018-06-2519:03tony.kayok, Iâ€™ll try to get to the bottom of why they want to opt-out as well#2018-06-2519:03tony.kayI agree it would be nice to reason about things in isolation#2018-06-2519:04mikerod
(defrule udpate-it
  [?old-one <- A (= ?e e) (= ?a a)]
  [?new-one <- NewA (= ?e e) (= ?a a)]
  =>
  (retract! ?old-one)
  (insert-unconditional! (map->A ?new-one)))
#2018-06-2519:05mikerodIâ€™d worry a bit about pervasive use of unconditional inserts#2018-06-2519:05mikerodit misses out on one fairly large advantage of the rules engine - which is a declarative logical truth maintenance system.#2018-06-2519:05mikerodIf unconditional is used, itâ€™d be best to a least to try to isolate it to some fringe â€œlayerâ€ of the logic#2018-06-2519:16tony.kayyeah, these are more derived new factsâ€¦but I see your point about invalidating the condition of the rule youâ€™re running#2018-06-2613:43baptiste-from-parishello friends, is there a way to save the entire LocalSession in a db#2018-06-2614:20dominicmIs this related to #portkey in some way? ðŸ˜„#2018-06-2613:44baptiste-from-parisI mean serialize/deserialise for later analyse#2018-06-2613:45mikerod@baptiste-from-paris there is some support for this. Itâ€™s referred to as durability in the Clara codebase. You do have to implement a protocol though to serialize the working memory facts that are specific to your domain of use#2018-06-2613:46baptiste-from-parisnice ðŸ™‚#2018-06-2613:46mikerodAlso, the durability is currently targeted at being fast for serialization, but especially for deserialization. It doesnâ€™t attempt to be able to deal with evolution to the stored data structures. If you have a change of rules, or a change of Clara version, sometime you may have to rerun rules and re-serialize. #2018-06-2613:47baptiste-from-parisok, got it#2018-06-2613:47mikerodWell to clarify, any change in rules requires a new run. A change in Clara version may or may not. It just depends on what changes. #2018-06-2613:47baptiste-from-parisyes offcourse#2018-06-2613:48baptiste-from-paristhanks for your time ðŸ™‚#2018-06-2613:48mikerodhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/durability/#2018-06-2613:48baptiste-from-pariswas on it, but I had to ask the communuty ðŸ˜‰#2018-06-2615:22jeremyHow might I accumulate facts of the same type to test if they are: all contain the same value and any contain a certain value?#2018-06-2615:34mikerod@jeremy642 Sounds like 2 separate things, if so#2018-06-2615:34mikerod
;; ?all contain the same value for :val
[?all <- (acc/all) :from [A (= ?val val)]]


;; ?all has at least one containing :some-val for :val
[?all <- (acc/all) :from [A]]
[:test (some #(= :some-val (:val %))
             ?all)]
#2018-06-2615:34jeremyYes ðŸ˜›#2018-06-2615:34mikerodHowever, the 2nd accumulator is weird, not sure why you want to accumulate like that#2018-06-2615:34mikerodbut perhaps#2018-06-2615:35mikerodâ€œany contain a certain valueâ€ sounds like a typical rule match#2018-06-2615:35mikerod[?all <- (acc/all) :from [A (= ?val val)]] and this will group each A where they have the same value for val#2018-06-2615:35jeremyYes it is.#2018-06-2615:36mikeroditâ€™ll match and propagate for each grouping possible#2018-06-2615:36jeremyYeah, I think any would be a typical rule match.#2018-06-2615:36jeremyI think my mind was just farting on it.#2018-06-2615:37jeremyBut on the all, does that work if there is a fact of the same type with a diff value?#2018-06-2615:37jeremyA : 1, A : 1, A : 2, it shouldn't match since all As don't have the same value.#2018-06-2615:39jeremyMaybe it'd be more like the 2nd one#2018-06-2615:39jeremyWhere you accumulate them all together, then apply a test to them.#2018-06-2616:34jeremyGot it ðŸ‘ Feel so accomplished when a rule works.#2018-06-2619:23jeremyDid any of the visualization stuff that Ryan talks about in his videos get released?#2018-06-2623:34tony.kayIâ€™m not seeing anything in the docs that would allow you to separate rule sets, and defrule seems globalâ€¦is there support (planned) for having â€œrule setsâ€ for different things, or is the idea that you just keep your domains separate by having facts that donâ€™t cross over and trust that the optimizations in the engine will make it mostly â€œnot matterâ€ when your rule set gets big because it covers 10 different domains?#2018-06-2700:00mikerod@jeremy642 I believe what you are referring to was a bit of an experimental project and not actively maintained. #2018-06-2700:01mikerodIt maybe this https://github.com/rbrush/clara-tools#2018-06-2700:03mikerod@tony.kay you can provided collections of rule structures to mk-session. It doesnâ€™t only accept namespaces. You can also define a var that holds a collection of rules and give it metadata :production-seq. So that single var name can be passed. #2018-06-2700:03mikerodDifferent ways to do things. Depending on your goals. #2018-06-2700:04mikerodHowever sometimes it can be fine to combine into larger rule sets. Rules that donâ€™t match facts wonâ€™t contribute much to runtime. #2018-06-2700:13tony.kayAh, I misunderstood how mk-session workedâ€¦my bad#2018-06-2700:54mikerod No problem!#2018-06-2702:22jeremy@mikerod Thanks#2018-06-2717:20jeremyI have a bunch of rules that derive some final state fact. What I run into is that multiple rules might match and in the end I get multiple results. So in the standard decision tree, there is order to the final state precedence. Would it be appropriate to add a priority property to these final state results and then query on that priority to narrow it down to a single result?#2018-06-2717:58mikerod@jeremy642 that is one approach#2018-06-2717:58mikerodI think Iâ€™ve answered variations of this question a lot of times, but donâ€™t think itâ€™s saved anywhere#2018-06-2717:58jeremyðŸ™‚#2018-06-2717:58mikerodyou can prioritize rules by building a tiered structure to them#2018-06-2717:58mikerodor you can let them all fire#2018-06-2717:58mikerodinsert some â€œintermediate factâ€#2018-06-2717:59mikerodthen have 1 more rule to accumulate all â€œintermediate factsâ€ and insert your final fact based on the aggregate of them#2018-06-2717:59mikerodI can give examlpes in a bit if needed#2018-06-2717:59mikerodI guess I have one example of one approach here https://gist.github.com/mrrodriguez/6a6f8373b25d69826b3efe154c928fac#file-clara_tiered_fact_update_rules-clj#2018-06-2718:11jeremyThanks. I'll check it out and play with it.#2018-06-2919:27Daniel HinesHello all. What is the current status of dynamically generated rules in CLJS with Clara? The compiler uses eval#2018-06-2920:35mikerodWhat are you wanting to explore in this regard?#2018-06-2920:38Daniel HinesI know a major goal of Clara is to "take back rules for the developer", but a major goal of a project I'm working on is to be able to update rules on the fly based on changing business logic. You can build rules in more dynamic ways when useful. #2018-06-3002:27mikerodhttp://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/ A bit older post but related shows interesting things that can be done. I think that Daniel mentioned in an earlier comment today. #2018-06-3002:43jeremyI read through it. Instaparse is a bit of gibberish to me right now. Iâ€™ll have to look into it more. ðŸ™‚#2018-06-3006:05alex-dixon@d4hines itâ€™s not a path anyoneâ€™s cleared that I know of. Iâ€™d expect it to be challenging no matter the approach you take. Another one depending on what kind of setup you ultimately want could involve figwheel I think. Iâ€™ve had some success getting live reload to work by redefining the session var in cljs and manipulating the keys in the cljs compiler env that Clara stores productions in. I only had it working for changes to source code though#2018-07-1602:03alex-dixonStupid question time: Is it possible to use Rete with disk storage only for working sets that canâ€™t fit into memory? Would there be any advantage to using it as part of a database implementation?#2018-07-1608:34wparker@alex-dixon There isn't any reason in principle why you can't use disk storage in a Clara memory implementation. It would obviously be less performant than in memory storage; if every Rete operation resulted in a random disk seek it could be pretty poor at a guess. I've toyed with the idea of a memory implementation dumping overflow to disk before though with some kind of heuristics for what to keep in memory. There could be complications to work through if you're trying to basically serialize random objects too.#2018-07-1618:17alex-dixon> Iâ€™ve toyed with the idea of a memory implementation dumping overflow to disk before though with some kind of heuristics for what to keep in memory Heh, I was thinking about the same thing yesterday ðŸ™‚ I havenâ€™t been able to find any papers or mention of Rete being used with a persistence layer. Do you know of any?#2018-07-1619:09wparker@alex-dixon No, I donâ€™t know of any offhand. My (completely untested ðŸ™‚ ) guess would be that avoiding internal retractions from truth maintenance would be a big part of it. Maybe if the data were appropriately structured you could use a local database to back the memory - is that what you were getting at with â€œWould there be any advantage to using it as part of a database implementation?â€#2018-07-1620:40hiredmanthere is presentation from, uh, maybe it was at a clojurewest, the presenter discusses implementing a rules system on top of a database, it does away with, maybe just alpha nodes, in rete because it expects database indices to do basically the same thing#2018-07-1620:42hiredmanhttps://github.com/threatgrid/naga#2018-07-1817:15alex-dixon@hiredman thanks! The readme says in memory only but plans for persistence with an rdf triple store or graph database. Iâ€™ll look into it more#2018-07-1817:22alex-dixon@wparker That was poorly phrased but basically yeah. More specifically Iâ€™m trying to figure out whether Clara or rete in general could be implemented as a hybrid in memory and persistent db like Datomic that uses rete for in memory processing as well as for querying persistent data that can never fit into memory. #2018-07-1817:24alex-dixonHaving rules writing to persistent storage would be key too#2018-07-1822:34mikerod@alex-dixon seems doable#2018-07-1822:35mikerodbut not without a bunch of effort if you were going to try to implement a memory that works well/performant doing that#2018-07-1822:35mikerodLong ago, Ryan did an example storm cluster-based Clara impl of memory. it was experimental but did show how memory could be extended potentially#2018-07-1822:38alex-dixonThanks. Yeah Iâ€™ve been looking at that. Itâ€™s not clear to me whatâ€™s going on there. Best I could figure out is storm is doing a lot of the work#2018-07-1822:39mikerodyeah, itâ€™d require storm understanding Iâ€™m sure#2018-07-1822:39mikerodand it isnâ€™t really the same thing#2018-07-1822:40mikerodYou could certainly try to hook a memory impl up to have facts potentially in slower storage, youâ€™d just have to deal with that serialization stuff and also the concern of how to make it not super slow#2018-07-1822:40mikerodalso, accumulators are an issue#2018-07-1822:41mikerodif you are dealing in numbers of facts too large for memory, but then you try to do an accumulator that needs to see them all at once#2018-07-1822:42mikerodI watched the naga talk before too. It was interesting. It seemed a bit more special-purposed than Clara, but still cool to think about#2018-07-1822:46alex-dixonIâ€™m thinking of using RocksDB specifically https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/wiki/Performance-Benchmarks#2018-07-1823:26mikerodnever saw that one#2018-07-1823:26mikerodlooks like it could be interesting to experiment with the idea though#2018-08-0103:34jumblemuddleDoes it make sense to have singleton facts in my network? Whenver I update one of these I retract the previous fact and insert the updated fact.#2018-08-0113:40mikerod@jumblemuddle maybe something I wrote a while back can go through some of those situations http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html#2018-08-0113:41mikerodif you are just wanting to skim, perhaps see â€œApproach 1: Append only updatesâ€ and â€œApproach 2: Externally managed updatesâ€ sections#2018-08-0114:19jumblemuddleThanks, @mikerod!#2018-08-0821:22jeremy@mikerod Do you know if there is a way to go from Java -> Clojure when rules are keywords and not records/java beans?#2018-08-0821:28ennI have a Clara rulebase that, for comprehensibility reasons, Iâ€™d like to split into â€œphases.â€ So, phase 1 gets a bunch of facts, the rules fire, and new facts are generated. Somehow, this becomes the input to phase 2, which fires a new set of rules, generating new facts. Etc. Iâ€™m not sure what the best way is to pass the output of one phase into the next. Originally I was thinking Iâ€™d just take the session from phase 1 and use that as the starting point for phase 2. But unless Iâ€™m missing something, itâ€™s not possible to load new rules into an extant session. So I guess what I need to do is to just grab all the â€œoutputâ€ facts out of phase 1 and insert them into a new session for phase 2. Is there a simpler way to do this than by writing (and then executing) a query for each and every fact type?#2018-08-0821:30mikerod@enn > So I guess what I need to do is to just grab all the â€œoutputâ€ facts out of phase 1 and insert them into a new session for phase 2. Is there a simpler way to do this than by writing (and then executing) a query for each and every fact type? I think this is likely a smoother approach (there is an alternative I can mention in a min) As far as worrying about querying for too many types, maybe you can make a â€œparentâ€ type for the output types you care about and just have a query on that parent type.#2018-08-0821:32mikerodAnother possibility is to just use one session with all the rules. Iâ€™m not sure what about your logic makes it where youâ€™d want some rules to be separate from others. Are you worried about them running too early or something, performance?, etc#2018-08-0821:34mikerodI donâ€™t understand your situation enough, but there is something called â€œactivation groupsâ€ that can also be considered in some cases that may relate to yours https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.18.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L328-L331#2018-08-0821:35ennNo, theyâ€™re all in one session now and it works fine performance-wise. Itâ€™s more about making it easier for the programmer to understand the universe of rules and fact types in play at a given point in the code.#2018-08-0821:39ennAnd making it easy to ensure that an intermediate fact type (used to derive some other final result) does not get inadvertently referenced outside of its intended scope#2018-08-0821:40ennMaybe my whole idea is antithetical to the idea that a rules engine hides some of the order-of-execution concerns of regular code? Iâ€™m not sure.#2018-08-0821:49mikerodYeah, I understand your reasoning then#2018-08-0821:49mikerodYou can separate them to independent rulesets if that helps reasoning#2018-08-0821:49mikerodthere would be a slight cost of taking facts from queries of one session and inserting again into another session, but that may not really be a concern#2018-08-0821:50mikerodbut yeah, order independence is a key idea#2018-08-0821:50mikerodand Iâ€™d also sort of argue that rules should be able to somewhat function in aggregation with one another#2018-08-0821:50mikerodwhere they can all share related information when relevant, but they are also fine when the information they need isnâ€™t present etc#2018-08-0821:51mikerod> And making it easy to ensure that an intermediate fact type (used to derive some other final result) does not get inadvertently referenced outside of its intended scope I think this is the most interesting concern though.#2018-08-0821:52mikerodIf everything gets lumped together, I can see how it could become problematic if you were wanting to have a better control on scope#2018-08-0821:30mikerod@jeremy642 I donâ€™t think I understand the question. You want to use rules with â€œkeywordâ€ sort of type dispatch, but on underlying Java objects? Maybe show a dummy example or something.#2018-08-0821:31jeremyI have rules built on a keyword type dispatch. I wasn't sure if there might be a way to create them from Java.#2018-08-0821:32jeremyMore a question on Java -> Clojure interop I guess than clara-rules. How I might go about creating the necessary type map for clara-rules from Java.#2018-08-0821:33jeremy#2018-08-0821:35mikerod@jeremy642 you can provide a custom fact-type-fn (and ancestors-fn if relevant) http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2018-08-0821:36mikerodThis may be what you are looking for. e.g. the fact-type-fn could take an arbitrary (Java) object and map it to some keyword/alternative typing system you have within the rules#2018-08-0821:38mikerodA likely incomplete example, but perhaps inspiration to think about.#2018-08-0821:39mikerodIâ€™m not sure if you already have a custom fact-type-fn or not though. You might since I see you have a map with :weather-fact-type#2018-08-0821:39mikerodClaraâ€™s default is clojure.core/type, which is implemented as (or (get (meta x) :type) (class x))#2018-08-0821:40jeremyYeah I was just thinking of a way to take Java Maps and Convert it to Keyword Key Map in the fact-type-fn?#2018-08-0821:40mikeroddepending on what is priority, you may flip the if above and do alternative things. I was just showing the idea of what could be done at least.#2018-08-0821:40jeremyCurrently the custom fact-type-fn looks for :type or something like that. I'll have to grab the work laptop. This just came to me off the top of my head.#2018-08-0821:41mikerodso for the fact-type-fn you just need to return the type (a keyword in your case I think)#2018-08-0821:41jeremyYep#2018-08-0821:41mikerodbut if you want to also work with the Java data as clj maps, like this: (< (:temperature this) 0), youâ€™d have to convert the facts themselves coming into the session#2018-08-0821:41mikerodwhich is different than the fact-type-fn#2018-08-0821:42jeremyYeah that's how the rules work with them currently.#2018-08-0821:42mikerodthe fact-type-fn doesnâ€™t transform the facts that are used during constraint matching. It just gives a value that is used as the â€œfact typeâ€ partitioning of the network#2018-08-0821:42jeremyHmm ok#2018-08-0821:42mikerodIâ€™ve wrote Clara rules a bunch with external Java type data#2018-08-0821:43mikerodWhat Iâ€™ve done typically is to have some fairly basic rules to match those types and apply any sort of useful filtering if performance was a conern#2018-08-0821:43mikerodbut then just had the RHS insert a clj type to use in all the rest of the rules#2018-08-0821:43mikerodso the rule was sort of a transformation/mapping from Java to CLJ data structures#2018-08-0821:44jeremyAhh, might be a decent idea.#2018-08-0821:45mikerod
(defrule find-java-things
  [JavaThing (= x ?x)]
  =>
  (insert! {:fact-type :thing
            :x ?x}))
#2018-08-0821:45mikerodbut if you need the JavaThing in the end, for the query consumer#2018-08-0821:45mikerodyou can attach it to the facts#2018-08-0821:45mikerodeither as a first-class field, or metadata#2018-08-0821:45jeremyI was thinking about keeping the rules in a seperate jar. And allowing Java applications and Clojure applications import and use the rules in that jar. The question was just how to define the facts when the rules were all in Clojure and no beans were provided that allowed Java to create them.#2018-08-0821:45mikerod
(defrule find-java-things
  [?j <- JavaThing (= x ?x)]
  =>
  (insert! (with-meta {:fact-type :thing
                       :x ?x}
             {:source ?j})))
#2018-08-0821:46mikerodIf itâ€™s a classpath issue, where you wonâ€™t know the types ahead of time youâ€™ll have to be more tricky#2018-08-0821:46mikerodand also, you are going to hit reflection stuff Iâ€™d think that way#2018-08-0821:47mikerodor you write your core set of rules in a type-independent rule set/session#2018-08-0821:48mikerodand you have to write a separate ruleset that does know about specific type mapping parts - or maybe you donâ€™t need rules for that transformation layer at all.#2018-08-0821:49jeremyI thought about just writing a interface for Java to call and create facts, insert into engine. But the rule engine itself would most likely need to be run in clojure and not instantiated from Java so it's pretty self contained. It'd save me the hassle of dealing with java vs clojure types.#2018-08-0821:51jeremyJava doesn't really need much control over the engine. Just to insert facts and get response from the queries.#2018-08-0822:09mikerodyeah, hard to say without fully understanding the setup you have#2018-08-0916:47wparker@jeremy642 @mikerod this might be useful in combination with Mikeâ€™s suggestion of using Java objects as facts that you could translate into Clojure objects if desired: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/java/ Basically Clara has a wrapper that you can use instead of needing to do the interop glue work yourself. In case you werenâ€™t already aware.#2018-08-0916:49wparkerAlso FYI Clara will use the bean properties on Java objects to allow field use by name in the DSL, that isnâ€™t just for records#2018-08-0916:50wparkeri.e. Object A has a â€œgetBâ€ method, you can just refer to â€œbâ€ in a condition like [A (= b some-value)]#2018-08-0916:51jeremyMy rules implementation does not use Java types for fact types. So the question was how to handle the interop.#2018-08-0916:51jeremy
(defrule new-return
  "The service is a new return."
  [:approval-status (= (:value this) :new-return)]
  =>
  (insert! {:type :rule/result
            :id :new-return
            :priority 2}))
#2018-08-0916:52jeremy
(r/insert {:type :approval-status :value :new-return})
is how I would insert using clojure.#2018-08-0916:53jeremyWithout changing the rules to beans or defining the facts with defrecords. The big ?? was how to allow Java to create maps with the keyword format that matched the rules properly.#2018-08-0916:54wparkerPerhaps write a rule that matches on Java maps and translates them, then inserts the result? That way you could just insert the Java map into the session#2018-08-0916:55wparkerThat rule could then just not do anything if only Clojure maps were in the session#2018-08-0916:56jeremySo that's one thought. I could write new rules that's sole job was to convert say a Java map if matches to a clojure map.#2018-08-0916:57jeremyI haven't progressed on any implementation yet. Been busy but I have some ideas to play with.#2018-08-0916:57jeremyðŸ‘#2018-08-0917:02wparkerNote that Clojure maps also implement Javaâ€™s map, so youâ€™d need to guard against an infinite loop there (i.e. require that it a Java Map but not a Clojure map)#2018-08-0917:14jeremyThanks#2018-08-0917:15jeremyI noticed that clara-rules is on the tech radar by thoughtworks. https://www.thoughtworks.com/radar/languages-and-frameworks#2018-08-0922:57mikerodSaw this one back when it was new on there. Pretty cool though! #2018-08-1006:30henrikIâ€™m working on an ingestion pipeline for scholarly material. It takes XML files and adds them to a (Datomic) database. Thereâ€™s a ton of little decisions to be made along the way. Depending on the publisher, the type of material, the presence of related material already in the database, the subject matter, the presence or absence of a myriad of little attributes in the file itself, and so on, the ingestion process behaves differently. This means tons and tons of conditionals all over the place, and it quickly gets hard to get an overview. Iâ€™ve been contemplating ways to extract this decision making process into its own place. Would Clara be a suitable tool for this?#2018-08-1010:21wparker@U06B8J0AJ that sounds like a plausible use-case. Much depends on how much involved the logic is - IMO a rules engine has some upfront cost to bring in especially if the team hasnâ€™t used one before, but at a certain complexity of business logic it helps a lot. Clara does what it can to help by â€œplaying nicelyâ€ with the rest of the Clojure ecosystem e.g. by being simple Clojure code rather than an entirely separate framework with its own IDEs etc., but it still is a different way of thinking and is a nontrivial component to introduce to a system. FWIW the analysis in the ThoughtWorks radar linked above seems on-target to me. My guess would be that something like you describe would work best with a rules engine if large chunks of logic can be computed before needing to return to the stateful pipeline, but as always it is hard to say since so often it is the details that are most important.#2018-08-1017:50devnhowdy folks#2018-08-1017:50devnim interested in partial condition matches#2018-08-1017:50devni want to answer the question: what conditions didn't match for a given rule#2018-08-1017:51devni'm not sure this is possible at the moment#2018-08-1019:30wparkerCould you give a concrete example @devn?
