(defrule simple-rule
 [A (= ?f f)]
 [?bs <- (acc/all) :from [B (= f ?f)]] 
 =>
(insert! (->C)))
This does cause an retract on the production node, but thats due to new facts being add. So not as i remembered.#2019-01-1016:52eraserhd#2019-01-1016:55mikerod@U0ECYL0ET Itâ€™s a bit cutoff and always a challenge to really know. From this, it seems to suggest that you have a rule with a negation - :not that is initially true due to no matches at some point in fire-rules. Later, it gets matches so becomes false. Due to order of rule firing, when it is becomes false, there was already staged activations of the rule from when it was true that need to be discarded now that that is no longer the case - via the truth maintenance#2019-01-1016:55mikerodThe activations being discarded may have large tokens as one possibility - perhaps there is a large data gathered via an accumulator in this rule?#2019-01-1016:56mikerodAlternatively, I may have to see more stack to know (or canâ€™t really know), the rule had a lot of combinations of matches resulting in many activations that now all have to be discarded#2019-01-1016:57eraserhdOK, my reading also. We're going to try to isolate which rule(s) cause it.#2019-01-1016:58mikerodMaybe you can find one of that structure. The negation May be your actual last condition of the role, although that isnâ€™t strictly true in all cases I believe. #2019-01-1016:59mikerodMay be able to do some listener tracing to find more details too. Iâ€™d have to play around to come up with a useful example of how to use it in this sort of case. #2019-01-1017:39wparkerRegarding tracing - I wrote some helpers at one point for this that I really need to clean up some and push to master - but basically you get an entry in a list for every interaction in the rules engine, most of which have a node ID attached. You can then use that ID to look up the node in the session and see what rules/queries it corresponds to. So if you see an ID come up a lot those rules are doing a lot of work. Since it is ordered, you can investigate in more complex ways, but often a â€œlots of stuff is happening in this ruleâ€ can be enough to narrow things down enough#2019-01-1017:45mikerodwould be good to get some doc examples of this sort of thing#2019-01-1313:19frickeHi all, (in the google-group the title is Infinite Loop when using :not-guard in a rule) I tried to do something that is really easy to do in e.g. Datalog, like having given a node->parent relationship, I try to get hold of all the parents that are around (no duplicates). This snippet show the data-model with the rule: 
(defrecord Node2Parent [node parent])
(defrecord Node [node])
(r/defrule insert-all-parents
  [Node2Parent (= ?parent parent)]
  [:not [Node (= node ?parent)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Node ?parent))
  )
The way I read this is that we add a new Node-fact for each occurring parent, that has not been added already. And here's how I call it: 
(defn s [] (-> (r/mk-session 'engine.core) (r/insert (->Node2Parent :inner1 :root)
                                                     (->Node2Parent :leaf1 :root)
                                                 (->Node2Parent :leaf2 :inner1)
                                                 (->Node2Parent :leaf3 :inner1))
           (r/fire-rules)))

(r/defquery all-nodes "all nodes"
  []
  [Node (= ?node node)])
(r/query (s) all-nodes)
It goes into a infinite loop and never comes back. Adding a print-statement to the rule tell you that it keeps adding :root nodes to the fact-base. I guess that I miss something the way the unification in the LHS-conditions play out. thanks and regards markus#2019-01-1316:04eraserhd@markus.frick the issue here is that Clara performs "truth maintenance". The better way to interpret the Node2Parent rule is, "Every Node which does not have a parent, should have a parent."#2019-01-1316:05eraserhdIn this case, it confuses Clara. Clara sees a node with no parent and decides it should have one. Then it sees that the node has a parent, and therefore shouldn't have one, and therefore retracts it.#2019-01-1316:06eraserhdIf there's no other way for Node to be created, just remove the :not. If there is, you'll likely have to restructure it.#2019-01-1316:17ethancYou could also use an unconditional insert, as this would remove the fact from truth maintenance.#2019-01-1319:37frickeoh thanks a lot; I totally missed the "truth maintenance" aspect (coming from a Datalog world where rule-evaluation is monotonous). I guess it's just easier to understand and implement, if I add the Node-facts by hand and add them to the session before I execute the rules. More so, since I won't get rid of the duplicate facts anyway. With unconditional inserts I get 
({:?node :root} {:?node :inner1} {:?node :inner1} {:?node :root})
I guess set semantics are just really difficult to have in a world where you just see the fixed number of facts from the LHS. thanks, markus#2019-01-1521:29mikerod@markus.frick late to this answer, but you can eliminate duplicates via â€œintermediary factsâ€ and accumulators#2019-01-1521:32mikerod#2019-01-2200:14eraserhdI feel like I need a CLI program like awk but using Rete / Datalog. It would be a souped-up join.#2019-01-2200:15eraserhdIt would take a rule description and an input file of facts, and the RHS can be only "print" or "insert fact".#2019-01-2400:08kahunamooreDid you ever get a response here or elsewhere?#2019-01-2400:25jvtriguerosI would use that. Trying to figure out a rule system isnâ€™t straightforward if youâ€™re not used to it #2019-01-2416:19eraserhd@kahunamoore no discussion elsewhere#2019-01-2416:19eraserhdI suspect I'll eventually do it, but it's behind another personal project that's probably months away.#2019-01-2416:28mikerod@eraserhd sorry for delay, wasnâ€™t completely clear on what you were saying there#2019-01-2416:29mikerodis a â€œrule descriptionâ€ a set of rules/queries? so a ruleset?#2019-01-2416:31mikerodAnd this would be convenient because you could tie it in with scripts?#2019-01-2418:38wparkerI'm also not clear on what's being discussed - is this a proposed tool for rule generation?#2019-01-2419:53eraserhdAhhh.... OK. So I'm thinking of a tool like awk that can take a ruleset with -e the way awk takes a program, and reads facts from input, like an FS separated file.#2019-01-2419:54eraserhdThe example I came up with was a script to iterate through my tmux panes and use their positions to find the upper-rightmost pane (because I need to configure the editor in that one).#2019-01-2419:55eraserhdSo essentially I had two tables: <top> <left> <pane-id> and <pane-id> <editor-id>.#2019-01-2419:56eraserhdAnd this is in shell, because my editor likes to be extended that way.#2019-01-2419:57eraserhdBut it seemed natural to have a tool that can do datalog-like queries on files like this.#2019-01-3119:39wparkerOk I think I see @eraserhd. I've only used Clara personally as a component of larger JVM systems so I haven't needed a CLI tool but I can see the utility and it doesn't sound unduly difficult. I haven't heard of any existing such CLI tools though.#2019-02-0211:31david_clojurianHello everyone, I have a problem with clara rules and I hope you can help me. To resolve components that are productive I create facts of dependencies and mark components that are used by productive components as productive as well. Right when I have a loop in the dependency chain, clara rules ends up in a endless loop while firing rules. Here is the code: 
(ns clara.error
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all]))

(defrecord DependsOn [element dep])
(defrecord Productive [element])

(defrule productive
  ""
  [DependsOn (= ?element1 element) (= ?element2 dep)]
  [Productive (= ?element1 element)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Productive ?element2)))

; Works
(as-> (mk-session 'clara.error) $
      (apply insert $ [(->Productive "A")])
      (apply insert $ [(->DependsOn "A" "B")
                       (->DependsOn "B" "C")
                       (->DependsOn "C" "D")])
      (fire-rules $))

; ends in a loop
(as-> (mk-session 'clara.error) $
      (apply insert $ [(->Productive "A")])
      (apply insert $ [(->DependsOn "A" "B")
                       (->DependsOn "B" "C")
                       (->DependsOn "C" "A")])
      (fire-rules $))
The approach of clara rules is awesome. That's why I hope we can find the problem so I can continue using clara rules. Thanks in advance.#2019-02-0309:40ggaillardHey David! I've been using for some time so I hope I'll be able to help. Based on the graph you are building, if I understand correctly, it seems normal that Clara ends up looping. You have Productive -[DependsOn]-> Productive. And you insert A -> B -> C -> A, but A DependsOn B, so clara run again A -> B -> C -> A -> B -> C -> A -> B â€¦. You have a loop in your graph. It might be a problem with identity. You create a new Productive instance every time, but do clara knows that (->Productive "A") is identical by value to (->Productive "A") (new instance) ?#2019-02-0309:43david_clojurianHello @ggaillard. I filed an issue on github and I get 2 answers. I'm evaluating these answers now, but as far as I can see, it seems to resolve my issue. Here is the link: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/418#2019-02-0309:43ggaillardAh nice, will look into it!#2019-02-1922:04eraserhdOver the next week or so, we're going to be working on a library to translate pull expressions into Clara rules productions. Any thoughts on that now could shape how this works.#2019-02-1922:33dominicmWhy do you need this? I'm missing something I think #2019-02-1923:00eraserhdThe primary system I work on models tasks and data dependencies. Inputs and output for a task are described as pull expressions, and this allows us to compute task dependencies. We couldn't do this with raw Clara queries, since they model general computation so halting problem yada yada.#2019-02-1923:01eraserhdPull expressions are a really nice, natural way to describe the shape of data wanted, IMHO.#2019-02-1923:03eraserhdWe are moving to Clara handling more of the computation, because its truth maintenance property solves a lot of problem for us, and one of the new things we want to know is when a tasks inputs have changed, in order to retrigger our task.#2019-02-1923:04eraserhdSo we're building this library to have Clara compute the inputs for a task in real time and update them as new data arrives.#2019-02-2003:48adamfeldman@U0ECYL0ET sounds like an interesting project. Do the task inputs and outputs change frequently, preventing the use of a simple dependency graph? Can you say more about the business domain? If you havenâ€™t seen this, you may find it useful for working with pull expressions: https://github.com/edn-query-language/eql#2019-02-2006:34dominicmThis sounds quite similar to something I've been working on in my spare time! #2019-02-2013:55eraserhd@UCHV4JZ7A the problem with a hand-coded dependency graph is that the tasks are sort of "locally owned" by different teams. This project coordinates tasks across the org.#2019-02-2013:57eraserhdeql looks really neat, definitely something to investigate#2019-02-2014:00dominicm@U0ECYL0ET are you familiar with terraform at all? would you say your tool is similar?#2019-02-2014:04eraserhdI am familiar, we use it. I have big rants on terraform. Our thing is much higher level.#2019-02-2014:07eraserhdOur thing's tasks are like, "we need a marketing site". That integration might use terraform.#2019-02-2014:08eraserhdThere's some similarities, except that we really lean on forward-chaining rules. We need to have things built as early as possible, and we incrementally discover the information we need to do things.#2019-02-2014:09eraserhdA terraform-like thing using Clara would be nice!#2019-02-2014:29dominicmI want to write a terraform like thing in clojure. So I may look closer at what you're saying here.#2019-02-2014:33adamfeldman@U09LZR36F Pulumi uses Terraform under the hood (and therefore takes advantage of the existing Terraform ecosystem), perhaps adapting Pulumi to Clojure would be a reasonable route to take https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi, https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi-terraform#2019-02-2014:34dominicmInteresting, will take a look#2019-02-2014:37dominicm@U0ECYL0ET we probably share complaints about terraform, and also the level at which you are describing things sounds similar to a project I tried to tackle things.#2019-02-2014:40eraserhdMy main complaint is that it is trying to be declarative. I think that's a mistake in that domain. We frequently need one object per thing in some database, for example, and that leads to terrible duplication and weird text ETL procedures.#2019-02-2014:41eraserhdThose ETL procedures defeat the idea of what terraform is for. So they've added things like loops and getting external data, but it is kind of terrible and they don't want you to use it.#2019-02-2014:41dominicmOh I know. And the modules don't even help! Count doesn't even work for the "loop construct" in a number of cases, so you have to take explicit counts for everything#2019-02-2014:41eraserhdIn reality, it should be pure functional.#2019-02-2014:41eraserhdright?!#2019-02-2014:41dominicmThe terraform language sucks, generally. I'd love it if they had a minimal extensible core. #2019-02-2014:42dominicmI quite like the idea of figuring out some primitives for building your own tf :)#2019-02-2014:44eraserhdIn Clojure, terraform really just becomes a data structure and a plan/apply procedure. The data structure can be generated by a function.#2019-02-2014:44eraserhdI mean, Clara is probably good here :D But not necessary.#2019-02-2014:46eraserhdThe data structure needs some kind of ?var to bind results of some operations to inputs of others. Unlike the go people, we know about proper unification :D#2019-02-2014:47dominicmSo, I'm looking at clara to do the dependency graph of work semi-automatically. For example, when do you go fetch the list of GitHub users? Well, if something wants to query them (and then you cache it). If you've diffed the list of users, and something inserts a new user, then you need to change your actions based on that. This is a pretty half-baked idea though ðŸ™‚#2019-02-2014:50eraserhdSo, are you using it ahead-of-time to build a plan? Or are you using it during execution?#2019-02-2015:00dominicmexecution#2019-02-2015:01dominicmthinking about trade-offs, I decided that a plan is possible to do as an auxiliary based on a secondary set of rules which inform you of the "optimistic write output" of a task.#2019-02-1922:05eraserhdWe're thinking about depending on clara_eav, since this will need a triplet type, and I'm considering the EAV record in clara_eav the "canonical triplet type" for Clara.#2019-02-1922:06eraserhdIt'll likely use nothing else from it, though.#2019-02-2012:26dominicmhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/ mentions "props", but I can't see documentation for them on that page. Does anyone know what they are?#2019-02-2014:11ethanc@dominicm it is a simple map, currently the only thing supported would be salience, i think. http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/conflictsalience/#2019-02-2014:19mikerod@dominicm @ethanc there is also :no-loop#2019-02-2014:21mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/23#2019-02-2014:21mikerodHowever, itâ€™s typically not recommended to write rules in a way where you have to use that#2019-02-2014:21mikerodit can have confusing semantics I believe#2019-02-2014:21mikerod(probably why it hasnâ€™t been documented much ðŸ˜› )#2019-02-2014:33dominicmIs it possible to create rules with parameters? And be explicit about passing them in?#2019-02-2014:42mikerod@dominicm It isnâ€™t clear to me how that would work in general#2019-02-2014:42mikerodHowever, queries take parameters if thatâ€™s more what youâ€™re looking for#2019-02-2014:42mikerodFor rules, instead of taking a parameter, model the param as a fact inserted by a rule perhaps#2019-02-2014:44mikerodInstead of 
(defrule param-rule
  [A (= <my-param-here> x)]
  =>
  <do things>)
Do 
(defrule find-param
  [?i <- InputFact]
  =>
  (insert! (map->Param (extract-data ?i))))

(defrule param-rule
  [?p <- Param]
  [A (= (:x ?p) x)]
  =>
  <do things>)
#2019-02-2014:45dominicm@mikerod hmm, maybe I haven't thought it through. But I want to write rules like "for every X insert 5", where I might have multiple of these inserted.#2019-02-2014:45dominicmAh, right, of course.#2019-02-2014:45dominicmMy rule just needs to find "Candidate X", and then insertions can be made about X candidate. ðŸ™‚#2019-02-2014:46mikerodI think so#2019-02-2615:45bmaddyDoes anyone know if Clara supports recursion in queries? I couldn't find a mention of it on the website.#2019-02-2616:01ethanc@bmaddy could you elaborate on "recursion in queries"#2019-02-2616:07bmaddySure, be advised that I'm really new to Clara and rules engines in general. Basically, I have a tree of data (nested associatives). I want to convert that into facts to query over it. If you're familiar with Datomic, it would be like asserting an entity {:a 1 :b {:c {:d 5}}} into datoms. I then want to do a query that finds a result if :d is 5 and any ancestor has an :a with the value 1. And because I said ancestor there, I think I'll need a recursive query.#2019-02-2617:28ethancSorry for the delay You could probably brute force it in a query(iterate over the nested maps), but i would think that the idiomatic way would be to deconstruct the parent and insert the children with reference to there parent or root. for example: 
(ns some.namespace
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]))

(r/defrule expansion-rule
  [?e <- :entity (some map? (vals this))]
  =>
  (doseq [v (vals ?e)
          :when (map? v)
          [k v] v]
    (r/insert! (with-meta
                 ;; wrapping ?e in a vector to prevent
                 ;; v from having a child with that is a map
                 ;; (infinite loop)
                {:key k :val v :root (or (:root ?e) [?e])}
                {:type :entity}))))

(r/defquery get-root
  [:?val :?key]
  [:entity
   (= ?key (:key this))
   (= ?val (:val this))
   (= ?root (or (first (:root this)) this))])


(-> (r/mk-session)
     (r/insert (with-meta {:a 1 :b {:c {:d 5}}} {:type :entity}))
     r/fire-rules
     (r/query get-root :?val 5 :?key :d))
#2019-02-2617:31ethancUsing clara's fact-type here as i was being lazy and didn't want to construct a wrapper fact. By default clara uses clojure.core/type to determine rules to activate, thus i made the maps of type :entity#2019-02-2617:44ethancThe when in the doseq would be wrong and could be removed#2019-02-2617:46ethancand would be replaced with logic to expand all the keys rather than just maps#2019-02-2618:12ethancThe ancestors questions would then have to be post query, either that or you could insert some sort of fact representing what you are trying to join logically. Queries are aimed more at field equivalence#2019-02-2619:11ethancAs an example of what i mean by inserting a fact to represent what you logically want to join, 
(ns some.namespace
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]))

(r/defrule expansion-rule
  [?e <- :entity (some map? (vals this))]
  =>
  (doseq [v (vals ?e)
          :when (map? v)]
    (r/insert! (with-meta
                 (assoc v :ancestors (conj (or (:ancestors ?e) []) (dissoc ?e :ancestors)))
                 {:type :entity}))))

(r/defrule query-rule
  [:query
   (= ?aq (:ancestor-question this))
   (= ?eq (:entity-question this))
   (= ?t (:query-id this))]
  [?e <- :entity]
  [:test (and (?eq ?e)
              (some ?aq (:ancestors ?e)))]
  =>
  (r/insert!
    (with-meta
      {:res ?e :query-id ?t}
      {:type :result})))

(r/defquery result-query
  [:?query-id]
  [:result
   (= ?query-id (:query-id this))
   (= ?result (:res this))])

(-> (r/mk-session)
    (r/insert (with-meta {:a 1 :b {:c {:d 5}}} {:type :entity}))
    (r/insert (with-meta {:query-id :d-5_a-1
                          :entity-question #(= (:d %) 5)
                          :ancestor-question #(= (:a %) 1)}
                         {:type :query}))
    r/fire-rules
    (r/query result-query :?query-id :d-5_a-1))
=>
({:?query-id :d-5_a-1, :?result {:d 5, :ancestors [{:a 1, :b {:c {:d 5}}} {:c {:d 5}}]}})
#2019-02-2620:21bmaddyWow, thanks for all the explanation. I must admit, I'm rather stunned. I thought rules engines would let you do datalog-like queries across data to get notified as it changes, but now it seems like you need to build data up every step of the way in order to answer your question. I was thinking about using that to help with a ton of validations on nested data I have, but that sounds like I might be better off with something like datascript. So what's the killer app for rules engines? Right now my understanding of it makes me basically think it's like calling iterate on a set of data until it doesn't change anymore (applying rules) and then filtering it (the queries). (If you don't have the time to explain, I totally understand--you're generously volunteering your time after all! Thank you!)#2019-02-2620:45mikerod@bmaddy I believe the distinction may be more around the forward-chaining vs backward-chaining strengths and weaknesses#2019-02-2620:46mikerodClara being oriented around the forward-chaining style rules#2019-02-2620:47mikerodand logic programming systems like prolog (core.logic too?; datascript too?) more around a backward-chaining design#2019-02-2621:01bmaddyYeah, I've heard that. I could certainly stand to do some research to get a better grasp on that.#2019-02-2621:49mikerod@bmaddy I think itâ€™s difficult to explain well and there are probably good write-ups out there on the differences#2019-02-2621:50mikerodClaraâ€™s forward-chaining approach is good for a type of problem where you have a set of known facts and you have a complex chain of logical inference that can be done based on those facts to arrive at some - typically pre-enumerated set of outcomes#2019-02-2621:51mikerodYou can parameterize the queries in Clara to an extent that does allow you to look for different sorts of matches, but I donâ€™t think the concept extends well to asking arbitrary questions about the state of the system#2019-02-2621:51mikerodLike, I can say â€œGive me the outcomes that have an x value between 30-50â€#2019-02-2621:52mikerodbut it is harder to say, â€œTell me what facts Iâ€™d need to get an outcome with x value between 30-50â€#2019-02-2621:53mikerodSo Ethan had good examples above of how you can use forward-chaining to explicitly model relationships - so that you can query on those relationships-as-facts later#2019-02-2621:53mikerodI think backwards-chaining may have more built-in approaches when thatâ€™s teh type of problem you are solving#2019-02-2621:54mikerodForward-chaining is nice when you are doing waht I said above, and it comes with a good mechanism of chaining along a â€œpathâ€ that supports arriving at your various outcomes. I donâ€™t think anyone tends to say which is better, forward/backwards, I think itâ€™s just that each is better at a certain class of problem.#2019-02-2621:54mikerodBut not sure why I typed all that. Probably much better explanations available online. ðŸ˜›#2019-02-2622:44bmaddyYeah, I'm a little familiar with what you're describing. I certainly have an entity (nested associative structure) that regularly changes slightly (in one case this is part of a state for a UI) and I want to run the same set of validations on it after every little change. That's what makes me think a rules engine is the way to go (i.e. my queries don't change, my data does). I just thought the querying would have something like datalog rules. I think I'll just need to study Ethan's examples a little more. I think I get the general idea it's describing, but haven't fully wrapped my head around it yet. Thanks again everyone for your help!#2019-02-2816:13wparkerI donâ€™t have much to add to the above - as the examples shows, Clara doesnâ€™t try to query further into facts, it just treats them as top level entities to be joined, inserted, etc. 
Right now my understanding of it makes me basically think it's like calling `iterate` on a set of data until it doesn't change anymore (applying rules) and then filtering it (the queries).
That sounds on target. One thing a rules engine such as Clara is good at is efficiently applying small changes onto a complex ruleset - the intermediate states of the rule engine internals are kept to facilitate this. The â€œtruth maintenanceâ€ page on the webpage is a good one to read if you havenâ€™t yet. @bmaddy#2019-02-2819:21bmaddyThanks, it's nice to know my mental model is in the right ballpark. ðŸ™‚ Yeah, I've read that page before--it's very clear and well written. I haven't been able to find much on joins though. I actually didn't even realize that was possible until I was looking at Precept.#2019-04-0318:34eraserhdcan we cut a release? See the changelog for details: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0191#2019-04-1017:52eraserhdOh, I missed this. \o/#2019-04-1017:54eraserhdOn another note, we've been troubleshooting some serious performance issues loading our database, and I've just figured out it is memory. If I fire-rules with the facts of the worst kind in batches of 5 (that chain the most), it completes in about 25 minutes; otherwise, it takes about 4h10m.#2019-04-1017:54eraserhdI mean, that's what tells me it is memory. Tell me if I'm wrong.#2019-04-1017:58ethancDo you have profiles of the heap when this occurs?#2019-04-1018:02eraserhdNo, but I'll happily make some.#2019-04-1019:06mikerod@eraserhd both heap profile and CPU sampling snapshot info would be good - not sure what you use. visualvm is good#2019-04-1019:06mikerodAnother shot in the dark suggestion - if you are making rules with long LHS sequence of conditions, perhaps youâ€™d be better off breaking it into multiple rules that arenâ€™t as â€œdeepâ€#2019-04-1019:07mikerodusing â€œintermediate factsâ€ to represent the parts#2019-04-1019:08mikerodthis can often give better perf characteristics and I generally think itâ€™s better modularization anyways. This may not be relevant to you at all though. I just noticed the â€œchainâ€ part and wasnâ€™t sure what it referred to.#2019-04-1019:08mikerodThe clara inspection tracing/tools recently had an update by Will I believe where it can try to report â€œcountsâ€ of operations happening at points in the network. if your chaining is resulting in large â€œcartesian productâ€ of facts joining together, these helpers may be useful to diagnose too#2019-04-1019:09mikerodThis is the relevant commit https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/commit/dde409c446a731e364096440d02ea0f7e8442c04#2019-04-1019:09mikerodwhich gives you a fn clara.tools.tracing/ranked-productions#2019-04-1020:03eraserhdby chain, I mean deep - rule A inserts a fact, then rule B fires and inserts a fact, etc...#2019-04-1020:03eraserhdThat counts things seems really relevant. I'll try it.#2019-04-1020:27eraserhdoh wow. clojure.lang.Atom memory usage is climbing by 20M per second.#2019-04-1020:41mikerodAre you making a lot of atoms? Clara shouldnâ€™t be hah#2019-04-1021:13wparker@eraserhd Clara uses atoms in engine.cljc in some places to store pending operations, conceivably you could get there from data being put in those atoms. It would be fairly hard though. But then the performant version of your rules sessions taking 25 minutes is striking. ðŸ˜± Obviously it could be unavoidable if youâ€™re just processing massive amounts of data, but Iâ€™d be curious to see any kind of reproducing example of inordinate resource use, smaller examples obviously being easier to diagnose. I suspect youâ€™ve uncovered some kind of bad pattern in the way the rule network fires rather than this (poor) level of performance being inevitable. Most of Claraâ€™s optimization to date has been done against Cernerâ€™s use cases; having a broader sample of benchmarks would be useful.#2019-04-1022:04ethancAlphaNodes are also generated with an atom for the bindings that the node will propagate in the event that its satisfied, however they would be scoped to the function that determined the satisfaction of the node. The atom is probably unnecessary and could be probably be replaced with shadowing within the functionâ€¦ I doubt that this is the growth that you are seeing though. Might be a performance gain by not having to swap! that atom thoughâ€¦.#2019-04-1022:29mikerod@U3KC48GHW interesting on the use of an atom there. Iâ€™ll have to check that out again. However, overall, I wouldnâ€™t expect to see an â€œAtomâ€ itself taking memory up. Itâ€™s a pointer to something that may be large, but it itself shouldnâ€™t show up as taking that memory (thatâ€™s not what I expect in heap dumps at least I think?)#2019-04-1022:30mikerodSo a lot of memory taken by actual clojure.lang.Atom makes me think thereâ€™d be a lot of instances of the Atom class#2019-04-1902:20Joelsomebody have a starter project for spring boot, but with clara support?#2019-04-1903:10Joelalso, what is attracting me to Clara is that I'm expecting i could "introspect" the rules relatively easily, possibly even modify dynamically --- is that a reasonable assumption?#2019-04-1906:26wparkerWhat sorts of introspection did you have in mind? If you mean introspection on what the rules engine did and why, there's a good amount of that, you can take a look at the inspect namespace and if you wanted something lower level the tracing namespace. If you mean introspection on the rules network, possibly yes if you write things yourself, but since the rules can contain arbitrary code (that the user writes) you have the usual problems with inspecting arbitrary code.#2019-04-1906:28wparkerRegarding dynamic modification, if you want to change the rules you have to build a new session and rerun the rules.#2019-04-1913:49Joelno, not in that respect. I'm interested in reading the rules to see what data they are looking for, fetched, and put into working member before running. For DB/REST calls.#2019-04-1913:51JoelBasically, its an optimization so multiple calls aren't made while rules run, can do them all up front with single calls.#2019-04-1913:59JoelThe second part, probably thinking about the wrong way, but for parts of the rules that have variables, I'd kind of like to see the rules served up with the variables replaced with actual values, so that it's easier to understand for user (developer). Basically I'll be serving up the rules from a server, and the server will also know what some of the vars should be in the rules, if server could basically inject that info, my thinking it's easier than having to reason about than having to look-up the values by hand. These variables change infrequently. Maybe server could inject them not necessarily inline so at least easy to see in one place. Hope that makes sense.#2019-04-2214:58mikerod@UH13Y2FSA The way to model what you are saying in the â€œsecond partâ€ above, would be to make your variables expressed as facts instead.#2019-04-2214:59mikerodThatâ€™s the typical way itâ€™d be done and the most straightforward with the way the forward-chaining data flow of the rules engine works.#2019-04-2214:59mikerod> if server could basically inject that info The â€œinjectionâ€ would be to just insert these facts.#2019-04-2215:00mikerodYou base logic on them. If you need to derive things from them for other rules - derive â€œintermediate factsâ€, ie facts meant to just build up higher-level concepts to relay to other rules.#2019-04-2215:01mikerodRemember, the working memory â€œsessionâ€ state is immutable. So if you donâ€™t want to continually put in these infrequently changed facts, you could potentially create a session, insert these facts only, then use that as your base session for other later independent memory states with the more frequently changing facts.#2019-04-2408:52wparkerThis will work and is probably easiest, but if you really want to have the values be determined statically note that Clara can build sessions from rule data structures that you pass it; rules/queries don't have to be created with the defrule/defquery macros. So you can have arbitrary generation logic. You can look at the schemas namespace and the data under rule/query vars for examples. It might be best to become familiar with code generation e.g. macros in Clojure if you go down this route though.#2019-04-2203:43Joel(dir clararules.core) will give me a list of the rules in that ns, but how can i tell rules from other items in the namespace?#2019-04-2205:15Joelhow do i see which rules are/were fired? I don't see an example.#2019-04-2212:46ethanc@joel380, Im not sure if this is an implementation detail or not, but clara uses a protocol and metadata to determine productions in a given namespace. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.19.1/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L270-L305 To your second question, i believe the way you would determine if rules have or have not fired would be to use the tracing listener. http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/listeners/ Either that or the end state of the session could be used via queries and facts returned from those queries.#2019-04-2304:45Joelthanks... that second question. I was able to look at the session and see a fired rule, so that seems workable. The link you sent looks good, it looks like it uses something called "meta" to determine (query or rule), but doesn't seem to work for me.#2019-04-2304:50Joelactually no, this works: (meta (resolve 'has-email))#2019-04-2305:32Joel@ethanc --- is there any examples around activation-group-fn. Maybe the documentation is good enough, but being a clojure newbie, I'm really not understanding what that function should be receiving (a map that always represents rules only? or the metadata?) Also the it's sort sibling is fuzzy to me.#2019-04-2312:50ethanc@joel380, This is a test demonstrating the usage of the activation-group-fn: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.19.1/src/test/clojurescript/clara/test_salience.cljs#L76-L99 Please note that the manipulation of salience is typically reserved for tuning poor preforming rules. By poor performing, I mean rule scenarios where a pattern can be established where the execution order of rules will drastically impact the time that subsequent rules will take to execute and maintain truth.#2019-04-2402:05Joelanother good link, that makes it understandable.#2019-04-2402:09Joelit looks like a "one-to-one" port of existing drools rules is problematic. Drools has a way for you to veto a rule firing, it also can allow us to skip rule groups. It looks like the equivalent involves just ensuring proper behavior by writing appropriate when clauses. I do like how using a defrecord to predicate on is simple.#2019-04-2402:41Joeli suppose the "clara way" to control groups would be to modify the productions --- add predicate(s)#2019-04-2404:36Joeli'm getting infinite loops: (defrule has-email "allow rule" [User (= "<mailto:/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection|/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection>" email)] [:not [Decision (contains? #{:allow} type)]] => (insert! (->Decision :allow)) (println "allowed")) (defrule has-email-deny "deny if not allowed" [:not [Decision (contains? #{:allow :deny} type)]] => (insert! (->Decision :deny)) (println "denied")) trying to make "allow" take precedence over "deny" decisions, but either my "contains" or universal non-existence seems to not be working.#2019-04-2408:33wparker@UH13Y2FSA Does your Decision record have a "type" field? Perhaps you're running into https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/259#2019-04-2408:34wparkerIf that is the problem you can fix it by using an explicit field lookup e.g. (:type this)#2019-04-2501:51Joel(defrecord Decision [type])#2019-04-2501:58JoelI tried this format, didn't help: [:not [Decision (contains? #{:allow} (:type this))]]#2019-04-2501:59Joelkind of feel like i can't do "non-existance"#2019-04-2504:01Joeli see examples of the same ... i don't get what I'm doing wrong.#2019-04-2504:09JoelIt actually works as expected if I add the fact when making the session.#2019-04-2504:45Joelchanging salience fixes this!?#2019-04-2408:44wparkerRegarding looking at fired rules, the idiomatic way to get output from the session would usually be to have facts that represent that output and query on those facts. The tracing listener will tell you what rules fired, but it will also include rules that were later retracted. The API guarantees are generally around the final state of the session, not what rules are fired on the way there. It's possible to design rules in a way that constrains this, but this has to be done carefully and wouldn't be my first approach to solving a given problem. The tracing listener is primarily intended for debugging and performance problem diagnosis.#2019-04-2517:48Joelthanks @wparker. I opened clara ticket and that has been insightful as well.#2019-04-2604:21Joelis it possible to refer to the doc string on the RHS?#2019-04-2612:54mikerodThat seems odd. Maybe with a defrule style macro you could refer to its own self var and find the doc string on there somehow. #2019-04-2612:55mikerodWould have to test that theory out though. Canâ€™t at the moment. #2019-04-2613:02ethancSince clara allows arbitrary clojure in the rhs, most things are possible. It just seems a bit weird to do them: 
(defrule a-rule
  "hello"
  [A (> x 3)]
  =>
  (println (:doc (meta #'a-rule))))

(-> (mk-session)
    (insert (->A 4))
    fire-rules)
hello
#2019-04-2623:02Joelsweet.#2019-04-2623:04Joelwell, i dunno like you say a bit weird, but at least possible.#2019-04-2623:15Joel@ethanc --- commented on ticket #428 - curious if retract rules from :rule-matches reasonably possible.#2019-04-2704:04JoelI want to have multiple rule systems, each would have it's own namespace, but I'd like to share not only records, but defquerys as well. However, I'm not figuring out how to add the defquery from another namespace.#2019-04-2717:08mikerod@joel380 you can pass ns names, or a collection of rule/query structures to mk -session#2019-04-2717:08mikerodSo if you did defquery, youâ€™d just do: 
(mk-session [my-query])
#2019-04-2717:08mikerodThere is more you can do too if you mark a var metadata with :production-seq that allows you to store sequences of rule/query structures under a single var when a ns is searched for rules/queries. #2019-04-2723:14Joelthanks, i had tried (mk-session '(my-query)) ... still getting up to speed on clojure#2019-04-2723:18Joelhopefully that let's me use another ns as well. ill give it a go.#2019-04-2809:53wparkerYes, you can use an arbitrary mix of namespaces and sequences of explicitly included rules/queries when defining your session.#2019-04-2800:10mikerodUse a vector and no quoting needed#2019-04-2803:57JoelHow is anyone going about getting the reasons for the rule decisions? Or, as often done in other systems, use the rule name, in Clara case the :doc tag. The problem I see is when I do (inspect session) the :rule-matches matches rules that never fired.#2019-04-2804:19JoelActually it looks like the rules have a () "matches" section, that I need to check... Unclear how I should be parsing that. Is there any convenience fn's?#2019-04-2809:54wparkerI'm not sure what you're trying to do, could you elaborate?#2019-04-2817:31JoelI was trying to strip out the rule :docs that had matches. It wasn't clear to me that there were rules listed that weren't fired. This did the trick: (defn matched-rule-docs [session] (let [rule-match-map (:rule-matches (inspect session)) matched-rules (filter #(seq (get rule-match-map %)) (keys rule-match-map))] (map :doc matched-rules)))#2019-04-2818:57JoelCan this be done w/o using :test?: ''' [?registry <- ListRegistry] [:test (.isMember ?registry "userguidwl" "whitelist" "userguid")] '''#2019-04-2818:58Joel(java class)#2019-04-2818:59ethancUse the this symbol in place of ?registry, If I read your question correctly#2019-04-2819:05Joelyou probably do read it correctly, ill try that.#2019-04-2901:27mikerod
[?registry <- ListRegistry (.isMember this <..etc..>)]
#2019-04-3000:22JoelHow can I apply the working memory from one session to another? Or fire one group of rules, and then apply it's WM to another set of rules?#2019-04-3001:33mikerod@joel380 if needing to go from one group or rules to another, you could just make query for the facts you want out of the first group, then insert those query results into the next group. #2019-04-3001:43Joeli'd want all of them, would rather avoid queries for each type.#2019-04-3001:44JoelI didn't see them listed as part of the session.#2019-04-3013:27mikerodYeah a query for all types is typically rough on performance. #2019-04-3013:28mikerodFor all facts in working memory I donâ€™t think there is a direct hook. I think maybe @ethanc would remember how we did â€œall factsâ€ before. #2019-04-3013:29mikerodAlso, keep in mind that the engine wonâ€™t hold onto facts that it knows will never match. So for example, if you insert a fact A but no rule will ever be able to match it, it doesnâ€™t stay in working memory. So you wouldnâ€™t get it back with some â€œall factsâ€ request. #2019-04-3014:00ethanc@joel380, Perhaps creating a marker protocol for the types of facts that you are interested in, and then leveraging a single query on that protocol. Something like: 
(require '[clara.rules :refer :all])
(require '[clara.rules.accumulators :as acc])

(defprotocol ImportantFacts)

(defrecord A [x])
(defrecord B [y])

(defrecord C [z]
  ImportantFacts)

(defrecord D [a]
  ImportantFacts)

(defrecord E [b]
  ImportantFacts)


(defrule a-rule 
  [A (= ?x x)]
  =>
  (insert! (->C (+ ?x 10))))


(defrule b-rule
  [B (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (insert! (->D (+ ?y 50))))

(defrule ab-rule
  [A (= ?x x)]
  [B (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (insert! (->E (+ ?y ?x))))

(defquery important-query
  []
  [?all-important <- (acc/all) :from [user.ImportantFacts]])


(-> (mk-session)
    (insert (->A 12))
    (insert (->B 1))
    fire-rules
    (query important-query))
There is something goofy about the clara.rules.dsl namespace, with respect to how it resolves â€œtypesâ€, specifically protocols so i had to fully qualify the ImportantFacts symbol.#2019-04-3014:09ethanc
=> ({:?all-important [#user.C{:z 22} #user.D{:a 51} #user.E{:b 13}]})
#2019-04-3015:03mikerod@joel380 @ethanc discussed on the side w/Ethan, but the defprotocol pattern for type hierarchies is sort of pedantically â€œwrongâ€ Iâ€™d say. I think the host-type associated w/a defprotocol is meant to be more of an â€œimpl detailsâ€ (although it isnâ€™t going to change), that is concerned with performance optimizations. So Iâ€™d probably go w/ definterface when all you want is the type marker. That said, Clara has supported defprotocol types being used in rules when the symbol is in reference to the the class type, not the protocol metadata var. Ethan is likely going to log a Clara issues concerning the 2nd case and how this can get weird.#2019-05-0101:13JoelI appreciate all the help here so far! FWIW, I'm looking into something that might work better than Drools for us. On that side we currently leverage rule-groups, and the order of groups is controlled. I think we can probably break away from that pattern, but just in case, the reason for my question is to see if that behavior could be had as a "fallback" in Clara. I think though if facts get "kicked out" of WM, then managing that could be kind of ugly. It sounds like the "one true way" in Clara is to put guards in as appropriate, and that's the approach I'll take for now rather than trying skip rule-groups or some such by segregating the rules.#2019-05-0101:14JoelI'm curious if anyone changes their rules dynamically in a production environment, and any issues that may come up as a result.#2019-05-0114:36mikerod@joel380 Clara does have support for activation group like behavior. But it doesnâ€™t completely disable rules. It prioritizes a firing order. Itâ€™s much like salience, but on a group of rule level. And salience works within a group. #2019-05-0114:36mikerodI just tend to think you can write more robust rules when you donâ€™t write them in order dependent ways. Clara defaults to logical inserts that self-maintain the logical consistency to eliminate a large need for ordering. #2019-05-0114:37mikerodDrools provides a truth maintenance system too, but it isnâ€™t the default in drools to insert â€œlogicalâ€, you have to call a separate fn for that in Drools. #2019-05-0114:37mikerodIn Clara the reverse is true. #2019-05-0114:37mikerodPart 2: what do you mean changing rules dynamically in production? #2019-05-0114:38mikerodYouâ€™d have to create a new session+rulebase for new rules. Clara doesnâ€™t support dynamic addition and removal of rules in an already constructed network. #2019-05-0114:39mikerodDrools does. And the semantics are to distribute working memory state to the new rules as they are added I believe. Clara has some mice optimization properties due to it not allowing this. #2019-05-0114:40mikerodItâ€™s possible it could be a future â€œmodeâ€ supported, but thatâ€™s require someone quite motivated to do it. I tend to think you can often just make a new session and re-run from scratch, or only put new rules in separate session and propagate facts from one to the next as needed. Cases vary though. #2019-05-0203:06Joeldynamic loading --- i mean doing load-string on a clojure file containing the rules/defsession, at runtime as rules are occasionally dynamically updated.#2019-05-0203:10Joelin drools we short-circuit to the last group if a previous group makes a decision basically. I think for Clara we just put guards in all the following rules.#2019-05-0314:21JoelCouple of questions 1) I see there is no "update!" --- is retract! followed by insert! considered non-idiomatic?#2019-05-0314:37eraserhdIn general, updating a fact would make truth maintenance really hard, if not impossible. If you find yourself retracting and inserting a fact on a right-hand-side, you are probably also going to run afoul of truth maintenance, likely by creating an infinite loop.#2019-05-0314:38eraserhdLogically, if a fact is no longer true because of a new piece of data, you should have an additional condition on the left-hand-side of the original rule.#2019-05-0314:38eraserhdWhich allows truth maintenance to clear it up.#2019-05-0314:39Joel2) I have a case where I take measurements of events something like {"eventX" [ (:limit 5 :prior (5 hrs)) (:limit 10 :prior (1 day)) ]} also I need to +1 those measures if they just now happened based on rule. (I don't have a list of events over that time, just the prior totals) I'm guessing the short answer is I need to "normalize the list" into individual facts and leverage insert-all! as well as use an accumulator (prior total + 1?), but then I need to accumulate and match against the limit, and how to do this with a flexible list is the part I'm not currently seeing. Particularly totaling over each period to compare against limit.#2019-05-0314:43eraserhdI would absolutely break down the measurements into independent facts.#2019-05-0314:44eraserhdI'm not sure how you are saying :prior works. Do you want a rule to fire a rule if you get an event more than :limit in the last :prior?#2019-05-0314:45Joelso there's the existing count (from DB) if that count + (just now happened) > limit fire rule.#2019-05-0314:47eraserhdYou've inserted multiple facts that has the database count of events of a particular type?#2019-05-0314:48Joeli can do that... currently the logic is the LHS side fetches the info (uses cache)#2019-05-0314:48Joel(java call)#2019-05-0314:49Joelthe final piece is maybe something like [ EventCount (?name name)(?limit limit)(?period period) (>= ?limit ( accumulate total for ?period ?name)) ; pseudocode#2019-05-0314:50Joelbut then accumulating will be redundant.#2019-05-0314:50eraserhdAssuming you aren't using an immutable, global database, you will likely have trouble with consistency if you put database calls on the left-hand-side.#2019-05-0314:51Joel(the cache fixes that part, only refetches for another session)#2019-05-0314:52Joelbut that doesn't give me a flexible list of periods#2019-05-0314:52eraserhdYou have access to the session on the left-hand-side?#2019-05-0314:52eraserhd(in a rule at all, in fact?)#2019-05-0314:52Joelno... its a java bean inserted into WM#2019-05-0314:53eraserhdwhat's a WM?#2019-05-0314:53Joelbut a new one for each ... sorry firing. (working memory : clara currently drools ðŸ™‚ )#2019-05-0314:54Joelbasically the bean is inserted before fire rules.#2019-05-0314:54eraserhdah, right. But this will have the consistency issue I'm talking about. If the count changes in the database, it will not refire a rule.#2019-05-0314:54Joelnot an issue.#2019-05-0314:54Joelit caches the call and keeps it for rest of that firing.#2019-05-0314:54Joeland that's acceptable.#2019-05-0314:54eraserhdAhhh, I see.#2019-05-0314:55eraserhdIt presents an immutable snapshot to the session. That's kind of neat.#2019-05-0314:55Joelbut currently we write rules and add to them if we add more periods, that sort of thing... rather have the list of periods flexible and rules take care of.#2019-05-0314:56JoelI think I need two defrecords one for name/period combo and another for keeping the count?#2019-05-0314:57Joelso match on all periods records and accumulate on the counting records (i think).#2019-05-0314:58Joeli think i was trying to keep this all kind of in one structure, and that's not do-able.#2019-05-0314:58eraserhdI think doing arbitrary, data-driven periods will be hard without generating rules from data.#2019-05-0314:59eraserhdWell, maybe not the way you are doing it.#2019-05-0315:00Joelyeah, i'm going to see what that looks like if I can get it working refine from there... Thanks!#2019-05-0610:17wparker@joel380 not sure if this will impact you, but note that facts should be immutable, including as regards their equals and hash methods. If, say, a hashcode changed while rules were firing you could get strange (undefined) behavior.#2019-05-0903:25JoelI'm thinking I may like to express a part of my system as a list (of maps) that gets turned into rules dynamically. However, I'd still need to express part of the LHS conditions in this list. The examples I saw suggested that I should produce the data structure as if the macros had been run. Is this a bad use case for rule generation, as I'd somehow need to transform these partial conditions and inject into final form?#2019-05-1013:05wparkerThe API constraint is that mk-session needs to receive unevaluated code in the same format that the defrule and defmacro macros construct. Iâ€™ve worked on cases where the rules were generated from a DSL that had quite a bit of processing into Clara rule forms, so what youâ€™re suggesting sounds plausible.#2019-05-1516:34drewverleeApologies for asking wide sweeping and possible horrible inaccurate questions: 1. clara (and rules engines in general) has no story for how to persist data correct? 2. datatomic and clara would seem to overlap in that they both use declarative joins to query data. 3. clara has reactive in memory updates to rules, while nothing in the dataomic ecosystem offers this (that i know of, which isn't saying much). It seems like reactive datalog, would bridge many of these gaps (but at what costs!). However, i also assume maybe trying to bridge these differences at the library/database level has large implications for how your system has to be setup (databases, etc...). especially in order to be fast enough to be interesting.#2019-05-1520:43mikerod@drewverlee > 1. clara (and rules engines in general) has no story for how to persist data correct? Yeah, for the most part it doesnâ€™t do that. There is some foundations for â€œdurabilityâ€ supported, but subject to change, but itâ€™s nothing like datomic or something to that extent. > 2. datatomic and clara would seem to overlap in that they both use declarative joins to query data. There is some overlap in how you query data out perhaps. However, itâ€™s done much differently. Datomic assumes much more of an ecosystem around it. Clara is a lightweight lib you can drop in the middle of your app and it just is a way to express conditional logic that is perhaps hard to express well with your own if-then logic. It also gives you the ability to be more declarative in describing your logic by using a truth maintenance system and a modern variant of the classic rete algorithm for perf benefits. > 3. clara has reactive in memory updates to rules, while nothing in the dataomic ecosystem offers this (that i know of, which isnâ€™t saying much). I canâ€™t say exactly that datomic is lacking this. I think youâ€™d have to put a system over it indeed. You allude then to datalog, which is probably similar to Clara in nature, but I believe it is based on backwards-chaining logic, so then you have to consider forward vs backwards chaining for your application area. Hopefully this sheds some insight for you.#2019-05-1520:47drewverleeThis is hugely helpful, thank you. I was only recent aware of forwards chaining logic and to find out there is a (potentially) a relationship with datalog through a similar model, backwards chaining logic, is very interesting.#2019-05-1520:49mikerodNo problem. Yeah, exploring forwards vs backwards chaining and when one may be better suited or not is always a topic of interest to me.#2019-05-1520:50mikerodI think more or less, you can do similar things in both, but one may be more optimal for certain usages than the other#2019-05-1520:53mikerodAnd in Claraâ€™s case specifically, queries are expressed in a pre-defined way that is built directly into the rules network - via something such as defquery. So they are â€œpre-cannedâ€ and actually participate in the forward-chaining logic just like any other rule does. Something like datalog, I believe you just specify arbitrary queries on demand. These then form backwards chaining execution paths. More like a relational db query or something to that extent.#2019-05-1521:30drewverleeI think your right mike, that very much gels with what i understand in principle about both. I think my next step is some papers and hammock time. Thanks a ton!#2019-05-1614:32eraserhdJust so you know, we use Datomic with Clara, and bolting them together has hit a sweet spot where we solved several problems at once.#2019-05-1614:33eraserhdBefore, we had custom data validation code, and custom code to create "synthetics" - computed values that appear in our GraphQL queries that don't exist in the database.#2019-05-1614:34eraserhdWe are using less and less of datomic though, as it's now merely a data store, and we never query it directly except for debugging.#2019-05-1700:48drewverleeHow are you using datomic if your not querying it?#2019-05-1615:09mikerod@eraserhd nice, hybrid situation of above#2019-05-1615:11mikerodforgot to mention this project that came out a bit back and was discussed some here https://github.com/clyfe/clara-eav#2019-05-1615:12mikerodI think the idea was to smoothly use EAV style tuples as facts. I havenâ€™t used it or anything though. I just think it relates to datomic datoms.#2019-05-1902:08drewverleeWhats the difference from a query and a rule in rules engines in general. As i understand it. a rule is propositional logic "if X then Y" / X :- Y. But is query something else or is it just a rule where X is some direct match lookup?#2019-05-1902:08drewverleeIt seems in clara that rules can have arguments, is that right?#2019-05-1902:36mikerod@drewverlee queries gives you an external hook to pull data from the session. It has no RHS. When you â€œcallâ€ the query you get the matches as a result. The matchâ€™s have all the variable bindings of the rule bound by those keys for you to access. #2019-05-1902:36mikerodYou can parameterize a query. When you call it, you bind those parameters. #2019-05-1902:37mikerodNormal rules canâ€™t be parameterized like this because you donâ€™t â€œcallâ€ into rules directly. #2019-06-2619:00mishawhy do rules have to have fact-type? e.g. Person here: 
[?person <- Person (= first-name "Alice") (= ?last-name last-name)]
;; or here
[Person (= ?name1 name) (= ?age1 age)]
#2019-06-2619:05mishahow does engine implementation leverages that? it seems like having datomic-like datalog api would be somewhat more uniform or convenient, or ...?#2019-06-2620:07wparker@misha in essence Clara, given facts, finds the types that match that fact and looks up the rules with conditions on that type. Note that â€œmatching the typeâ€ includes conditions matching on an ancestor of the factâ€™s type.#2019-06-2620:09wparkerThis improves performance when there are lots of rules - a fact doesnâ€™t have to be evaluated against rules that itsâ€™ type wonâ€™t allow it to match#2019-06-2620:10wparkerThereâ€™s some tangentially related discussion of this at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_fn_perf/#2019-06-2620:36mikerod@misha also, there are alternatives to how you could structure a DSL over this - Clara just has this one as the default. It isnâ€™t necessarily trivial to extend things, but there are examples of at least datom-like datom support with https://github.com/clyfe/clara-eav#2019-06-2711:50mishaThanks, Mike and W. Reading into both clara and eav sources now. However I still have strong feeling, something clever can be figured out on top of â€œvanillaâ€ datalog (or very tightly coupled with). Eav seems to wrap clara, and only pretend to be datomic-like, in dsl layer. Iâ€™ll dig deeper into how attribute in conjunction with :aevt index can be used to pre-narrow down query space, as clara does with records-as-ruletypes#2019-06-2714:33mikerod@misha Clara implements a forward-chaining, Rete based, engine. Datalog I believe is backward-chaining and maybe based on something like miniKanren or something? Either way, they arenâ€™t the same. So thatâ€™s a correct observation. #2019-06-2714:33mikerodAnd typically on this path, youâ€™ll have to consider the trade offs of the different styles of engine. #2019-06-2714:34mikerodI wasnâ€™t suggesting changing a DSL will change the fundamentals of the underlying engine for you there. It was just if you had EAV style data to represent as facts, and wanted to use them with a forward chaining engine. #2019-06-2714:47mishadoes forward-chaining give any speed, or other guarantees/properties, which clara relies on explicitly (comparing to backward-chaining)?#2019-06-2715:56mikerod@misha I think thatâ€™s a more difficult question to answer succinctly. There are some papers out there that do discuss this exact topic (which I think we should work to link to in some Clara reference docs sometime soon). It looks like this paper https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/54af/b81b814acea73450430b4dabd0fc5c13732a.pdf and (a paper the above references) http://iips.icci.edu.iq/images/exam/artificial-intelligence-structures-and-strategies-for--complex-problem-solving.pdf section on â€œ3.2.1 Data-Driven and Goal-Driven Searchâ€ have some guidelines and more overview on the topic. I think there is a lot more out there than this though. The key concept being, â€¢ forward-chaining emphasizes the â€œdata-drivenâ€ approach - use available facts to see what all possible â€œend statesâ€/â€œgoalsâ€ can be reached â€¢ backward-chaining emphasizes the â€œgoal-drivenâ€ approach - see if there are available facts to support some desired â€œend stateâ€/â€œgoalâ€#2019-06-2715:57mikerodSince they emphasize a different desired solution finding paradigm, they tend to optimize better for that purpose#2019-06-2715:58mikerodMeaning, * forward-chaining is likely more performant, and also more natural, when you want the â€œdata-drivenâ€ approach. * backward-chaining is more performant, and also more natural, when you want the â€œgoal-drivenâ€ approach.#2019-06-2716:00mikerodThere are engines that do a blend of each at times too. Clara doesnâ€™t currently. An example of how where this could apply, is that a Clara style query (typically defined via defquery) could be utilized in a way where you perhaps could say (query session :?x 5) and the engine could potentially use a backward-chaining approach to arrive at that goal. Perhaps to reduce the search space/work done. Nothing like this exists right now. I think that in the later version of Drools (popular, Java-centric (currently)) Rete-style, forward-chaining rules engine, there was actually limited support of a somewhat backward-chaining approach to deriving query results.#2019-06-2716:01mikerodhowever, if your main target is â€œgoal-driveâ€, itâ€™d likely still be best to use something centered around a full backward-chaining engine.#2019-06-2807:47mishafirst paper link is $$$, thank you, Mike#2019-06-2807:54misha(2nd link is probably golden too, but, man, 800pages kappa)#2019-06-2809:23wparkerAnother point to consider is that since forward-chaining computes results upfront, applying diffs e.g. new facts can be quite fast once an initial "batch" has been completed.#2019-06-2809:50mishaI wonder if datomic's datalog is still implemented with backward chaining, given team recommends to put the most specific query clause first#2019-06-2809:52mishahttps://docs.datomic.com/on-prem/best-practices.html#most-selective-clauses-first#2019-06-2810:09mishaso what I am actually trying to achieve/figure out, â€“ is how to sneak rule-based parasite system onto datomic/datascript, without any changes to user api, e.g.: there are d/q, d/transact, d/transact!, and I'd like the defrule to be just a composition of those from user point of view (with some cleverness under the hood, like extra working memory or knowledge base). For example, clara-eav seems to have lots of internals leaking out into user api, making it less and less looking like datomic/datascript, which people already are used to "dev-flow"-wise. One seemingly minor, but I think very important from usability/adoption point ov view â€“ is it is still dsl with custom tokens, which will be highlighted all over the ns as undefined in Cursive and probably some other IDE, on top of being yet another DSL you need to remember semantics of.#2019-06-2810:11mishare dsl, from https://github.com/clyfe/clara-eav#fact-dsl 
;; Clara fact syntax
[?eav <- :todo/text (= (:e this) :new)]
[?eav <- (a/all) :from [:eav/all (= (:e this) :new)]]

;; ClaraEAV fact syntax
[?eav <- [:new :todo/text]]
[?eav <- (a/all) :from [[:new]]]
#2019-06-2810:15mishawhy this, if everyone is familiar with let-style bindings, and many libraries manage to represent domain-specific bindings with their custom let forms, eg: let for monads: https://github.com/funcool/cats/blob/master/src/cats/core.cljc#L233-L255 let for generators: https://github.com/clojure/test.check/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clojure/test/check/generators.cljc#L1590-L1630#2019-07-0116:13mikerodhttps://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C08TC9JCS/p1561715419047500 I donâ€™t know the specifics here at all. But probably could still be backwards chaining and have something like this apply. #2019-07-0116:16mikerodhttps://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C08TC9JCS/p1561716926057800 The syntax can be altered if you want an alternative dsl. The rules have a well defined data model. Itâ€™s not â€œjust letâ€ syntax since that would be awkward to make semantically work for more complex rules. Rules are about unification bindings etc. datalog isnâ€™t let-binding syntax either. Also Clara is aligning its default DSL syntax closer to the world of forward chaining rules engines that have existed for a long time. #2019-07-0116:17mikerodBut your problem seems interesting @misha I donâ€™t have necessarily any easy answers there. First I would make sure the rules can express your problems that you try to solve. Then maybe worry more about blending it with a datalog syntax if thatâ€™s youâ€™re goal. #2019-07-1322:48drewverleeso rules engines model if then relationships and in the "then" part its easy to insert new facts or take abitrary actions on those facts. What i'm not clear about, is how this model relates/overlaps with building a hierarchy of data, or if its orthogonal. Like, a common rules example is that my fathers brother is my uncle. But what about answering questions like, what are the names of all my friends, something that would be easy with datomic pull.#2019-07-1415:25mikerod@drewverlee similar to recent posts in this channel, I think you may be running up against the pros/cons of forward chaining rules (clara) and backwards chaining â€œparadigmâ€ in terms of what is best for what sort of situation. #2019-07-1415:25mikerodYou could model that question as an explicit query in clara though. #2019-07-1415:26mikerodThe query could be parameterized to some extent as well to give some flexibility. #2019-07-1415:26mikerodhttps://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C08TC9JCS/p1561651104030900#2019-07-1418:02drewverleeThanks @mikerod, are their any resources that you recommend that compare these two different approaches? Or talk about using them together? Well feel free to ask if you have more questions. #2019-08-0720:29sparkofreasonIf the only thing that changes in the LHS of a rule is an accumulator value, is it correct that the rule won't fire if the collection of facts matching the accumulator condition change?#2019-08-0720:35ethancI would think that if an accumulator saw a new value, and the previously accumulated objects changed that there would be work that the rhs would have to do. Though I might be misunderstanding your question#2019-08-0720:36sparkofreasonThat's how I want it to behave, but I have a distant recollection that it doesn't actually work that way. Been awhile since I've played with clara.#2019-08-0720:42ProbablyJody@dave.dixon, are you thinking of the retract-fnâ€™s behavior?#2019-08-0720:42sparkofreasonCould be. Possible I'm just writing my accumulation clause wrong or something, because sometimes it does seem to behave as you described.#2019-08-0720:53ProbablyJodyAh, I think this might help: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/ce65c5071a271905786449db1190687ee40e4624/src/test/common/clara/test_accumulation.cljc#L1121#2019-08-0721:22mikerod@dave.dixon in current version of Clara (and several before) the rule will not continue to propagate if the accumulated value hasnâ€™t changed according to = See lines like https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1200#2019-08-0721:24mikerodSo specifically if the accumulators result from the :convert-return-fn is = to what it was in the previous round of accumulating fact matches, propagation stops - which would imply no RHS action being triggered/activated#2019-08-0721:25mikerodThe tests near what Jody pointed too could be enlightening on some more semantics though. I agree#2019-08-0721:26mikerodThere are quite detailed github issues out there that also discuss these semantics when we added the related changes. #2019-08-0721:48sparkofreason@mikerod Thanks. Not exactly sure what I was thinking of. My actual problem was that I was hacking at something trying to make it update in place rather than letting truth maintenance do the lifting. Need to get back to "thinking TMS" ðŸ˜‰#2019-08-0721:52mikerodYes. No mutate in place. Thatâ€™ll indeed cause issues. #2019-08-0800:26sparkofreasonThink I hit another issue trying to update in place. I thought I could get away with it for unconditional facts, but it appears that when I have multiple LHS bindings on a rule that does a retract! followed by an insert-unconditional!, the RHS fires for all bindings, so the retracts all occur before other rules fire that would potentially invalidate the LHS on the first rule after a subset of firings, based on those retractions.#2019-08-0801:50mikerod@dave.dixon if you get into the business of doing unconditional things, youâ€™ll have to control rule order more. This can be done with salience and possibly â€œblockerâ€ fact patterns. #2019-08-0815:19sparkofreasonIt seems like avoiding this sort of thing can be a guiding principle for data modeling. For example, the existence of an entity might be unconditional, but the facts describing that entity may have more detailed logical relationships. Trying to group those facts as attributes under a single entity fact map or record leads to the headaches I'm encountering. But maybe if I separate them so that they can be separately inserted/retracted, things will be cleaner. Giving clara-eav a try for this purpose.#2019-08-2813:10griersonShould I run side effectful things (database/email) in the RHS of a rule. Or should I insert a new fact, query the session, and do side effectfs based on the query result?#2019-08-2813:45ethancThe latter is recommended, Clara makes no promises on the number of times that the RHS will be executed before reaching steady state.#2019-08-2813:57griersonThank you @ethanc, I thought that might be the case but just wanted to clara-fy :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:.#2019-09-1014:12mbraggHi. Im having a play around with Clara and seeing if itâ€™ll fit our use case. One of which is to know which Rule(s) failed. I can see the inspect function gives loads of nice info for all the activations; what could I do if i wanted to know which Rules were not triggered and why?#2019-09-1014:18mikerod@mbragg I think that will be a bit of a challenge with a forward-chaining approach to rules#2019-09-1014:19mikerodif you have more specific questions - you can model that as rules and queries#2019-09-1014:19mikerodbut just to find out something like â€œwhat was missing that you would have needed to reach certain goals/conclusionsâ€ is more of a backwards chaining strength (ie goal-driven) Iâ€™d say#2019-09-1014:19mikerodâ€¢ clara is based around the rete algo which is a forward-chaining (ie data-driven) approach Good references for further reading: 1) https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/54af/b81b814acea73450430b4dabd0fc5c13732a.pdf 2) http://iips.icci.edu.iq/images/exam/artificial-intelligence-structures-and-strategies-for--complex-problem-solving.pdf (section 8.2 Rule-Based Expert Systems)#2019-09-1014:20mikerodyou can make some progress of course with inspection - you can see what did happen, and subtract that from all the rules you know exists to find which were left out#2019-09-1014:21mikerodyou can also make more rules in some cases, perhaps even systematically (and programmatically) that try to capture the â€œnegativeâ€ cases#2019-09-1014:21mikerodeg. if I have a rule rule a => insert b, then also make a rule rule not(a) => insert z#2019-09-1014:22mikerodof course it can be more difficult than that with mult-condition joins, negation, and accumulators involved#2019-09-1014:33mbraggMany thanks @mikerod That all makes sense. diffing the activated vs non-activated rules & using inspection does feel a little hacky, It seems like I should either re-think the problem and model it in a forward-chaining manner, or maybe not use clara and implement some sort of backward-chaining model. Thanks again!#2019-09-1018:33devn@mbragg at my previous gig, we found that doing what @mikerod mentioned was sufficient for our observability purposes. (Namely, we generated negative cases for certain types of rules, and created targeted queries to aid in observability.)#2019-09-1018:42mbraggThanks @devn yeah Iâ€™m having a think about that too#2019-10-0420:19jjttjjIs the support for map types documented anywhere? In isolation#2019-10-0616:40mikerodIf old state doesnâ€™t need to influence â€œnewâ€ you donâ€™t need to try retracting the last cycle of facts etc. just start from scratch again from the base session#2019-10-0616:40mikerodThis will be cheap. #2019-10-0616:43jjttjjgreat, thanks!#2019-10-0816:24Eduardo MataI have a multi-threaded parallel synchronous processor using Clara rules.
